HEADLINE: DEPOSED HAITIAN MEETS WITH FOES

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARTAGENA, Colombia, Nov. 22

 BODY:
The Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Haiti's deposed President, arrived here tonight and met with opposition leaders from his country for the first time since he was overthrown in a military coup on Sept. 30.
Father Aristide's 45-minute session with 11 Haitian legislators opened a weekend of talks in which the possibility of his reinstatement will be discussed. The meeting was also attended by delegates from the Organization of American States, who are to mediate. 
 Haitian delegates and members of the O.A.S. delegation said it was urgent that some compromise be reached soon to rescue the Caribbean nation from a "critical and dramatic" situation. The country's already desperate economy was dealt a near-mortal blow on Oct. 8, when the O.A.S. announced a trade embargo to protest the coup. A month later, the United States suspended about $85 million in aid and froze Haiti's assets.
"Life in Haiti is paralyzed right now," said Josue LaFrance, a member of Parliament and delegate here, who opposes a return by Father Aristide to Haiti. "We have virtually no transportation, people are dying, and there is danger of epidemic."
 
Desperate Journeys
 So drastic have conditions become that about 3,000 Haitians have undertaken the perilous 600-mile journey to southern Florida by small boats. Many of those are believed to be lost at sea.
The United States officially resumed a policy this week of returning the Haitians, but a temporary restraining order issued by a Federal judge bars any forcible returns pending a hearing on Wednesday.
The broad agenda of the meetings here is to find a constitutional solution to the crisis. Father Aristide said earlier in the week that he would be willing to name a new prime minister and open the Government to opposition leaders. He also said he would agree to a pardon for the military as long as those directly responsible for the coup were removed from power.
Augusto Ramirez Ocampo, Colombia's O.A.S. delegate, said that one of the goals of the talks would be to reinstate the former President. Mr. Ramirez, who spent three days last week in meetings with leaders in Haiti, said the military had pledged to honor whatever measures are agreed to. But whether that promise extends to Father Aristide's return is unclear.

HEADLINE: Mining Solid Gold on the Radio

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR

 BODY:
Just after 9 A.M. a man in a yellow sweatshirt spins his chair around in a Manhattan studio, pulls his headphones on and shoves a tape into a cassette player. "Hello, Luv," he booms into a microphone. "Good morning, everybody, this is Ron Lundy at CBS-FM, and I got a song for ya. Oh, 'Baby, I Love Ya.' "
As that 60's tune fills the studio on West 52d Street, the more subdued co-anchors one floor below at WCBS-AM preach the commuter gospel -- news reports from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut peppered with traffic and weather updates. 
 A flip of the dial to the right finds a Spanish-language station and Gospel music. To the left is WXRK's Howard Stern, the nation's foremost "shock jock," who recently asked Wilt Chamberlain, a guest, to explain his claim that he'd had sex with 20,000 women.
This is New York radio.
No question it is big. With more than 18 million listeners, New York-area stations have the largest reach in the nation; they took nine of the top 10 slots in a recent poll of America's most-listened-to stations by the Arbitron Company, which measures radio audiences.
New York radio can also be quite profitable.
 
A Money-Making Proposition
 Though its gross revenues are only a third of newspaper and television revenues, even the smallest stations can be profitable, says Elliot B. Evers, a partner in Media Venture Partners, a radio and television brokerage firm.
"In a market the size of New York, there are a lot of people making a hell of a lot of money," he said, adding that the region's top 10 stations will take in $18 million to $30 million this year.
The secret of radio's success, industry experts say, is that in the heat of the cable television revolution and recent recession that have scalded network television and newspapers, radio has been able to make the most of its biggest assets: low production costs and the ability to appeal to specialized audiences.
Like the region itself, New York-area frequencies are a smorgasbord of languages and subcultures -- from sermons at Harlem's Abyssinian Baptist Church on WRKS-FM to "Memories of Lithuania" on WSOU-FM to "Ruby, the Intergalactic Gumshoe," a weekly science-fiction serial on WBAI-FM.
"There are so many choices that it is a very competitive market for both listeners and advertisers," says Chris J. Witting Jr., general manager of WCBS Newsradio 88, the all-news AM station.
Though New York radio has always been eclectic, much has changed since the days when a handful of large stations dominated the region's AM airwaves, broadcasting live shows cross-country from Radio City Music Hall in Manhattan. The arrival of television brought an identity crisis for the medium that once monopolized in-home electronic entertainment. The industry then underwent a further transformation with the advent of the technologically superior FM band, where high fidelity music would sparkle.
Now regional listeners can choose from as many as 100 stations -- urban and suburban -- based in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and beyond.
They have turned from "broadcasting" to "narrowcasting." No more Madonna bumping up against Metallica on dozens of stations. Today, even playing "rock" isn't specialized enough. Now there is "lite rock" (WLTW-FM), "classic rock" (WXRK-FM), "adult contemporary rock" (WNSR-FM), "heavy metal rock" (WZRC-AM) and "rock-and-roll" (WNEW-FM) -- just to name a few.
"There is so much out there -- some of it is almost subterranean," said Jo Maeder, a disk jockey for WXRK who is known as the "Rock-and-Roll Madam."
In suburban areas, narrowcasting has allowed local stations to be even more local. "We're not New York, not Philadelphia. Proud to be New Jersey 101.5 FM," is a refrain repeated regularly on WKXW-FM in Trenton.
Many listeners say they prefer narrowcasting because they can tune in to specific stations for specific things. Jeffrey Nichols of Hackensack, N.J., for example, listens to New York City's WXRK classic rock as he drives to and from his job as a delivery man with United Parcel Service in Secaucus, N.J. At other times, he says, he listens to New Jersey talk shows, which he likens to "the regional section of your local newspaper."
Advertisers say that narrowcasting offers an efficient and accurate way to target consumers. A case in point is WCBS-FM. Having grown steadily in popularity since the early 1970's, WCBS-FM last spring did what radio experts thought impossible. Playing a "golden oldies" format with a cast of disk jockeys who had appeared on WABC-AM in the 1960's, the FM station struck a chord with baby boomers and became New York's top-ranked station in the spring and summer Arbitron ratings.
Advertisers, who covet 25-to-54-year-old listeners and who funneled more than $325 million into New York radio last year, were ecstatic.
James Duncan Jr., editor and publisher of a trade publication, Duncan's Radio Market Guide, predicts that WCBS-FM will be the third-biggest money-maker in the nation this year, with total advertising revenues of about $29 million, right after top-ranked WGN-AM in Chicago, which plays adult contemporary music, and KABC-AM in Los Angeles, a talk-radio station.
"This has been a soft year for radio revenue," said Mr. Duncan, adding that revenues were off by 3 percent from last year. "But radio has done better than television and newspapers because of its low costs and because it efficiently targets audiences."
This has also been a bad year for the Top-40 stations -- not only because there are fewer teen-agers listening, but also because of heightened competition in an increasingly fragmented market.
For example, Top-40 playing WHTZ-FM, known as Z100, was No. 1 in its market from 1987 through the summer of 1989, three times earning a 6.2 share, or percentage of the listening audience, based on Arbitron data. By last summer, Z100 was hovering at 3.8 percent, having been surpassed by stations specializing in oldies (WCBS-FM, with a 5.1 share), rhythm and blues (WRKS-FM and WBLS-FM, with 4.8 and 4.2, respectively), "lite" music (WLTW-FM, with 4.9) and six others.
"The Top-40 format has just gotten so narrow," said Rick Sklar, a radio consultant, former vice president of programming for ABC's radio division and now a vice president of Interep Radio Store in New York, which sells radio advertising. "It appeals to young people, particularly young women, and it's no longer the mass appeal format that it once was," said Mr. Sklar, the author of a book about New York radio entitled "Rocking America," (St. Martins Press, 1984).
 
Old Loyalties Persist
 Other Top-40 stations have struggled as well, in the region and elsewhere, buttressing two themes voiced frequently these days by radio experts: narrowcasting works, and New York radio, though multifaceted, is more conservative these days than one might think. According to Arbitron, for example, the top two stations in Nassau and Suffolk Counties play adult contemporary rock (Phil Collins, say, or Billy Joel) and golden oldies, respectively.
Though most listeners and radio professionals say that the predictability of narrowcasting is an important radio quality these days, there are exceptions.
The most notable among them are the "shock jocks," Don Imus of WFAN-AM and Howard Stern, whose irreverent often controversial talk show on WXRK (which also calls itself K-Rock) is beamed to radio stations in three other cities.
But for listeners, finding a station that suits them is, after all, what matters.
"I have to admit, I love Howard Stern," said Robin Brooks, a 32-year-old housewife in Toms River, N.J. "I don't know why. I guess I just can't believe what he gets away with."
Ali Breland, 19, a student at Nassau Community College, prefers WBLS-FM and WRKS-FM (known as KISS-FM), which play rhythm and blues and some Jamaican music. "Rap and Jamaican is hot," he says.
And for Rick Sandri, 39, a business executive who lives in Glen Rock, N.J., in Bergen County, it is the golden oldies that have his loyalty.
"When I'm at home with the kids I tend to turn on 'oldies but goodies,' " he said. "I've got a 3-year-old and a 9-year-old, and I dance with them. I want them to hear the music I grew up with."

HEADLINE: House G.O.P. Makes Late Sally on Taxes

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
With the blessing of the White House, Republicans in the House of Representatives tried today to embarrass Democrats by offering a broad package of popular tax cuts that stand no chance of enactment just days before Congress plans to adjourn for the year.
The initiative by the House Republicans underscores their frustration with the lack of forceful policy proposals by the Bush Administration. But even more, it demonstrates an attempt to regain political momentum that has been lost in recent weeks because of the shaky economy, a drumbeat of attacks from Democrats and a series of misfires at the White House. 
 Announcing the package, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip, delivered one political sally after another in the hope that at least one would make the television news. A typical line about the Democrats was this: "In the next four days they get to show the people of America whether they are truly interested in creating jobs."
The measures would go far beyond what President Bush has proposed. But before he had seen the initiatives, Richard G. Darman, the budget director, said the White House would support them so long as they did not cost the Treasury a net loss of revenue.
 
Differences in Accounting
 Because under the Administration's accounting system some tax cuts actually raise revenue, at least in the short term, the Republicans were able to say that their plan would not lose money. But it would cost billions of dollars over the next five years according to the way the Congressional Budget Office does the accounting.
The Republicans worked hard to choreograph their strategy for maximum political impact. Here are the steps:
1. The Republicans will offer their tax proposals next week as an amendment to legislation providing money for the savings and loan bailout, which must be passed before Congress adjourns.
2. The House Rules Committee, an arm of the Democratic leadership that establishes the procedures under which legislation is debated and voted on, will declare that the amendment is not "germane" to the savings and loan legislation and thus, under House rules, cannot be presented.
3. The Republicans will demand a vote on this ruling and will lose on a nearly party-line vote. Then they will offer to back down if the Democrats will agree to a specific date next year on which their package can be brought up for a vote. The Democrats, who hold a better than 3-to-2 majority in the House, will reject this idea, too.
 
Delay Would Be Costly
 The final step is not clear. Whether, without their amendment, enough Republicans will refuse to vote for the savings and loan legislation to defeat the bill is not clear. The Administration has asked for $80 billion more to finish the bailout. Albert V. Casey, president of the Resolution Trust Corporation, which is in charge of the bailout, has estimated that a delay in financing the bailout until Congress returns in January would cost taxpayers an additional $300 million to $400 million.
But whatever happens in the end, the days before Thanksgiving are sure to be filled with barbs and jibes about growth and jobs and fairness and all the other words that Republicans and Democrats throw out when they are bickering over the economy.
Representative Thomas S. Foley of Washington, the Speaker of the House, left no doubt today that he and other Democrats would vigorously oppose adding tax cuts or any other amendments to the savings and loan measure.
"There's no chance in my judgment, none, that the R.T.C. can bear burdens other than its own," Mr. Foley told reporters. "What are the chances of this having some forced leverage for other issues? Zero, absolutely zero."
 
Significant Tax Code Change
 Among the Republican proposals are a lower capital gains tax rate, new tax breaks for small businesses and real estate investments, new and more generous rules for individual retirement accounts, a tax-free savings plan for households with incomes of less than $50,000 a year and a repeal of the excise tax on expensive boats, cars and aircraft.
This would amount to a signficant revision of the income tax code, the kind that normally takes Congress a year or two to act on. The measures, many of which would enjoy broad popular support because they would save taxpayers money, are sure to arise again next year, when some kind of tax legislation may be considered.
This year, however, the White House has not even pushed for a capital gains break, the centerpiece of its tax strategy. That is because senior officials like Mr. Darman and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady feared that if they opened the issue of taxes, the Democratic-controlled Congress would produce legislation the Administration could not abide.
Senate Republicans did not participate in this latest sortie. In large part that is because they are a potent force in their own right and can get their way better by striking deals with Democrats rather than attacking them.
In the House, however, the Republicans are such a small minority that their only real strength is making noise and causing trouble.

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
Folks, Take My Unemployment Check (Please)

BYLINE: By Douglas Martin

 BODY:
At a comedy club on Manhattan's West Side, a favorite fixture for years has been the nights when people from a given walk of life gather to tell jokes about their jobs. Doctors, gravediggers, cabbies, ad executives, plumbers, whatever.
Nights to remember. A bus driver once reported being asked how long will the next bus be -- a common enough, though grammatically murky expression. He replied, "About 19 feet." A dentist said he almost flunked out of dental school because he didn't have enough hair on his arms. Lawyers have flagellated themselves unmercifully, though not nearly enough. 
 But with so many people losing jobs in every walk of life, such vocational fun has worn thin -- not least because the ranks of possible contestants keep thinning. So it was that Cary Hoffman, owner of Stand Up New York at 236 West 78th Street near Broadway, saw the need to confront these bleak economic times. He began a contest to find New York's funniest unemployed person.
Mr. Hoffman characterizes himself as an old-time liberal furious at how little is being done for the jobless. "I became outraged about the lack of outrage," he said.
His plans are to hold monthly contests until the Presidential election or until the unemployment rate dips. The first installment, a preliminary one, was Wednesday night, when an even dozen brand-new comics eagerly debased themselves in front of strangers.
The winner got a T-shirt, said to be brand-new, and a chance to move on to the next level of competition where the prize will be a chance to perform for money. A measly $50, but who's counting?
The emcee got things rolling with some definitions. He said the phrase hardcore unemployed is used to refer to people who watch daytime TV. Entrepreneur was defined as a French word meaning, "My check's no good." He said to call oneself self-employed is "like saying I have an imaginary friend."
Last, he warned the audience to be nice. "The unemployed have a self-esteem problem," he explained. That was a line that nobody laughed at. Jobs are teetering all over this edgy town.
And, indeed, the first contestant, Ed Hagar, began with a request. "Please be gentle," he begged, before lapsing into something of a reverie about his days employed in a shipping room. "I was the Picasso of cardboard," he said to scattered applause.
Christine Petrillo, who used to work in advertising sales, kept the momentum going. She said she lives in a high-rise apartment directly across from an office building, and pulls the shades up each morning. Then she said she dances nude. "If I can't work, why should they?" she asked.
Next up was Dave Weinberg, an erstwhile art director, who announced, "I'm a Street News success story."
Lauri Kay, an unemployed writer, said she has taken to answering the remotest leads, a recent one of which was to be a technical writer for a pharmaceutical company. "Hey, I used to do drugs," she reasoned.
Next came a former usher who couldn't remember his jokes; an unemployed real-estate agent who said her father had sent her picture to Save the Children Foundation in lieu of urgently requested money, and a journalist who knew more about Geraldo than seemed altogether seemly.
Kevin Calloway, a security guard who has been relieved of his badge and gun, said he thought he had developed the perfect line for a job interview: "I know where your children go to school."
Even that hasn't worked.
Sometimes, there seemed to be tears just beneath the laughter. Barry Hauptman, an unemployed sportswriter, began ordinarily enough by saying one of his goals was to dispel the myth that the jobless are lazy. "So I took my pajamas off and came over here," was the punch line.
Things continued to progress pleasantly, with Mr. Hauptman meticulously recounting a claimed former job stamping the expiration date on edible underwear.
But his final remark chilled. "I get to the point where crying is the only alternative," he said.
Similarly, a cabdriver whose career has run out of gas, Jay London, also left poignancy hanging in the blue air. "If you have a nightmare tonight, could you include me?" he asked.
The emcee bounced back to thank the audience for building performers' self-esteem. But he jerked them right back to ground-zero when someone wondered if the losers also got T-shirts. "No, they're losers," was the reply.
The winner was Lauri Kay, the writer. She is well past the point of looking any gift horse in the mouth. "I have something to wear to my next job interview," she said appreciatively.

HEADLINE: O'Casey of 1923: Not Dated Yet

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
Last summer in Belfast, Northern Ireland, a 13-year-old girl sorrowfully approached one of the actors of the O'Casey Theater Company after a performance of "The Shadow of a Gunman," Sean O'Casey's 1923 play, which uses exuberant humor and soaring language to evoke the human tragedy of the 1919-1921 bloodletting between the British and the Irish.
"The girl said to me, 'Isn't it terrible that nothing has changed,' " recalled the actor, Niall Buggy, who portrays Seumas Shields, a sharp-tongued Dubliner and onetime revolutionary. The play opens on Monday at the Symphony Space, at Broadway and 95th Street in Manhattan, for a two-week run. It is the first production of the newly formed O'Casey company, which has arrived in New York on its inaugural American tour. 
 "The Shadow of a Gunman" is the story of a struggling writer, Donal Davoren, the roommate of Seumas Shields, whom the neighbors believe to be a gunman. He encourages their interest, especially when he wins the admiration of a pretty neighbor, Minnie Powell, but this fantasy puts him, and Minnie, on a collision course with the British Black and Tan forces.
Most plays of this age are creaking theatrical antiques, "but we quickly realized that this play wasn't a bit dated," said Richard Holmes, one of the American actors in the troupe. Others come from the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland.
 
Combatants in the Audience
 Shivaun O'Casey, who is directing her father's play, said after a performance in Boston: "There are so many similarities between the situation in the play and in Northern Ireland -- the intolerance and strife. On opening night in Belfast, where the sound of the stage-effect explosions always startle audiences, there was the sound of a real explosion outside."
"Shadow" began its American tour in Boston, was in Pittsburgh last week, and is traveling to Philadelphia and Washington after its New York run.
In Newry, the Northern Ireland town where the O'Casey company is based, the police were advised that rifle shots and bombs would be going off during the play. "When the explosion went off in the second act, the people flinched -- they thought it was a real bomb," said Ian Fitzgibbon, who plays Donal Davoren.
The play may have even been attended by a fair number of combatants on both sides in the struggle. "One day we were invited to a reception," Mr. Fitzgibbon recalled, "and I said, 'So, where are all these gunmen that are supposed to be everywhere?' And the man with me said: 'Oh, didn't you know? You've already met three of them.' "
Pauline Flanagan, who plays Mrs. Grigson, a neighbor of Donal Davoren, said, "Doing this play was very daring in the north."
Although O'Casey himself was a Protestant, and the play's message is one of peace, Ms. Flanagan said that the subject matter of "Shadow" was risky in the atmosphere of tension between the Irish Republican Army and British soldiers in Newry.
The actors and their director were not sure how audiences would react to a play that came so close to portraying the crisis of their own lives, but the company received an enthusiastic response from audiences. These included republicans, unionists and people from all walks of life. Often they applauded after every scene.
"I think the play was a catharsis," said Stephen Gabis, who plays an auxiliary policeman in the play.
One purpose of the company is to transcend Ireland's boundaries, said the 52-year-old Ms. O'Casey, who founded it last year and established it in Newry, an old manufacturing city at the foot of the Mourne mountains in County Down near the border with the Irish Republic. Her partner is Sally de Sousa, an international festival producer. "
 
Widespread Support
 The O'Casey company has been supported by a consortium of government agencies, local and international businesses, foundations and hundreds of individuals on both sides of the Irish border, as well as contributors from the United States. The townfolk in Newry hope the troupe will serve as a catalyst for tourism and economic growth by training and employing young people from both sides of the border in theater arts. Local youths serve as trainees in set construction, scene painting, carpentry, lighting and sound.
The company's first performance was in a 500-seat space in Newry Town Hall on Sept. 18, the 27th anniversary of Sean O'Casey's death. The company then toured five northern and southern Irish cities with "The Shadow of a Gunman" and "The Shadow of O'Casey," a documentary theater piece celebrating the playwright's life and work that will be performed in two New York matinees, Dec. 5 and 7.
Working with O'Casey's daughter "was like being taken into the family," said Mr. Buggy, whose last name is pronounced as might be expected and whose first name, Niall, sounds like "nile." He is best known to New York audiences for his much-praised performance in the Manhattan Theater Club production of the Brian Friel play "Aristocrats" in 1989.
"I do have a knowledge of what Sean wanted his plays to be like, because we shared an awful lot of thoughts about the theater together," said Ms. O'Casey, who studied acting at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art, toured England and America at the age of 18 with the Dublin Players and worked at the Bristol Old Vic.
She said she strongly believes that the spareness and economy of the play, which scholars have said influenced the work of Samuel Beckett, is best served by keeping it in a single room. "Sometimes directors open the play up and take it outside, but the sense of place is very important to the play. It's a small masterpiece, not an enormous canvas."
She also objects to productions in which the characters are made to look like coarse, cruel brutes, wearing dirty costumes on a delapidated set. "That's a very middle-class attitude about the poor," she said. "But most of the people in the situation my father described had their dignity about them. They wore the cleanest clothes they could and kept their flat as tidy as possible."
 
A Force for Peace
 What would O'Casey have thought of the production? "I think he would have loved it," said Doreen Keogh, another member of the company. She toured with O'Casey in England during the first production of his play "The Purple Dust" in 1953. "He would have felt so happy about the community participation in Newry, and the fact that Shivaun is directing it. But most of all he would have liked the fact that his play could be a force for peace."

HEADLINE: Sonny Werblin, an Impresario of New York's Sports Extravaganza, Is Dead at 81

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr.

 BODY:
David A. (Sonny) Werblin, the sports and entertainment impresario who upstaged his entire stunning career by luring Joe Namath to the struggling New York Jets in 1965, died Thursday at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 81 years old.
Mr. Werblin, who had homes in New York, Miami and Rumson, N.J., died of a heart attack, his wife said yesterday. 
 In a career that spanned more than 50 years and included almost as many professional successes, Mr. Werblin became an agent with the Music Corporation of America in the 1930's and later built its television division into such a dominating behemoth that it ran afoul of the nation's antitrust laws. The company represented clients like Elizabeth Taylor, Johnny Carson and Ronald Reagan and put together television hits like the Ed Sullivan and Jackie Gleason shows.
 
Other Arenas
 In his later career in sports, Mr. Werblin at one time or another owned a share of the Monmouth Park race track, ran Madison Square Garden and rejuvenated moribund Knicks and Rangers teams. In his crowning achievement, he created the $340 million Meadowlands Sports Complex in New Jersey, which has become one of the nation's premier sports venues.
But for a generation of sports fans in New York and for football fans across the nation, nothing Mr. Werblin ever accomplished could compare with what he did in January 1965, when as president and part-owner of an American Football League franchise renamed the New York Jets, he put the Broadway in Broadway Joe.
The $427,000 Mr. Werblin spent to induce Namath, the acclaimed quarterback from the University of Alabama, to pass up the established National Football League in favor of the much-maligned American Football League transformed professional football.
Or, as Mr. Werblin's longtime friend Howard Cosell put it yesterday, "He single-handedly changed the face of sports in America."
 
Lift for the A.F.L.
 The three-year deal was not all in cash and included money for two of Mr. Namath's brothers, who were hired as scouts. But the sum, by far the biggest ever paid to a collegian to turn pro up to that time, captured the imagination of the nation's fans, helped make the flamboyant Mr. Namath into a national celebrity and represented the emergence of the A.F.L. as a force to be reckoned with.
Although the contract seemed stunning in 1965, Mr. Namath was not the Jet with the highest annual salary. And after adjusting for inflation, the $427,000 would translate today to $1.86 million, well below what elite sports stars are making.
"He knew the value of the fan and the star system," Mr. Namath said yesterday, recalling Mr. Werblin as an employer who became a close friend. "Over the years, he adopted me. He made sure I was getting along well. He told me to get to know New York, that it was the greatest city."
Mr. Werblin, who together with several partners had paid $1 million for the languishing New York Titans franchise, drew on his theatrical experience to explain the significance of the Namath contract: "A million-dollar set is worthless if you put a $2,000 actor in the main role."
Eighteen months later, after Namath proved in his first season both on and off the field that he was worthy of his pay, the N.F.L. agreed to a merger and the Super Bowl was created as an annual championship game, initially between the leagues and since 1970 between the top teams in the American Football Conference and National Football Conference.
In one of the crueler twists of Mr. Werblin's career, by the time Namath led the Jets to their famous upset victory over the Baltimore Colts in the third Super Bowl, in Miami in 1969, the man who built the championship team was no longer an owner of the team.
His partners, including Leon Hess, the chairman of the Amerada Hess Corporation, had become so miffed at all the attention paid to Mr. Werblin that they bought him out before the start of the 1968 season, paying him $1.2 million for a share that had cost him $250,000.
 
Grew Up in Flatbush
 Mr. Werblin, whose father was a founder of a successful paper-bag company, was fond of talking about his early years in Flatbush, where his mother, to honor the oldest of her three sons, called him Sonny, thereby planting the seed for what Mr. Cosell acknowledged yesterday was one of the most memorable sobriquets the broadcaster ever lifted from Variety: "David A. 'Sonny' (as in Money) Werblin."
David Abraham Werblin was born in Flatbush on March 17, 1910. As a Jew he relished the fact of having been born on St. Patrick's Day. The Jets' colors, green and white, were bestowed on the team "because they're my colors," he once explained.
He played high school football at Erasmus Hall and James Madison and went to college at Rutgers University. But he injured his shoulder as a freshman and never played college football.
In 1932, a year after his college graduation, and following a stint as a copy boy at The New York Times, he joined M.C.A., the huge talent agency, and was soon pioneering the practice of packaging talent, invariably his clients, into single productions.
A movie producer, for example, might need a singer and Mr. Werblin would agree to provide one -- if a band, which he also represented, also was hired. He sometimes provided the bulk of the cast of movies.
 
Married in 1938
 While he moved toward the top as a show-business agent, he met the singer for Phil Harris's band, Leah Ray Hubbard, who performed under the name Leah Ray. They were married on March 27, 1938.
In 1951, Mr. Werblin became president of M.C.A.-TV, and it became so successful that it began producing its own shows and providing the talent for them as well as others, including "Wagon Train, "My Three Sons," "Bachelor Father" and "The Virginian." The enterprise was so successful in establishing a virtual monopoly that the Justice Department eventually forced it to break up into several divisions.
As an agent, Mr. Werblin, whose own M.C.A. stock was once valued at $11 million, was something of a visionary. In addition to negotiating one of Johnny Carson's early lucrative contracts, for example, he also helped establish a line of Johnny Carson clothing that made millions for both men.
Despite his own accomplishments and his famous, often flamboyant, clients and friends, Mr. Werblin remained straightforward and direct, even self-effacing, not to mention understated. When someone, inquiring about a client, asked, "What's Elizabeth Taylor really like?" Mr. Werblin got to the point. "Short," he replied. "Very short."
 
Stranger to 'Retire'
 When he finally left M.C.A. in 1965, the headline in Variety read, "Mr. Show Business Retires."
"Retired" was hardly the word. By then, Mr. Werblin was well on his way to becoming Mr. Sports.
Two years earlier, he and his other partners in the Monmouth race track, including Mr. Hess, bought the Titans for a nominal $1 million, nominal because almost no money changed hands. The new owners merely assumed the team's debt.
When Mr. Werblin sold his share in the remamed Jets in 1968, it was also not a retirement.
 
'Greatest Thrill'
 By 1970, he was back near the top of a sport once again when he had a highly touted colt, Silent Screen, in the Kentucky Derby. The 3-year-old had the lead in the stretch, but faltered and finished fifth. Still, Mr. Werblin described that brief moment as "my greatest thrill in sports."
Within a year he became head of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, luring his old football rival, the Giants, across the river. Yet, no sooner was the Meadowlands complex built than he left in 1977 to take over Madison Square Garden, whose Knicks and Rangers had started a downward spiral after great success in the late 1960's and early 1970's.
Although the formula was less successful this time, Mr. Werblin again spent money freely to acquire big names. Despite some success, neither club was able to sustain winning campaigns and after a degree of upheaval and several coaching changtes, Mr. Werblin relinquished active control of the Garden in 1984 but remained as chairman of the MSG Corporation.
He remained active with one of his early loves, Rutgers, and not only was a major fund-raiser for the school but also worked diligently in upgrading its athletic teams. A new, $18.5 million recreation complex on the university's Busch campus in Piscataway was named after him last month.
In addition to his wife, Mr. Werblin is survived by two sons, Thomas and Robert. According to friends, a third son, Hubbard, died earlier this week, but Mr. Werblin was not told.

HEADLINE: Tougher Rules On Fuel Are Set For California

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The California Air Resources Board voted yesterday to adopt new standards on gasoline that will require the most significant changes in fuel since the Federal Government ordered the removal of lead from gasoline nearly 20 years ago.
The board said the new fuel would be "the world's cleanest," reducing the emissions of smog-forming chemicals by 30 percent to 40 percent compared with current blends. 
 By most estimates, the cleaner fuel will add 15 to 20 cents to the cost of a gallon of gasoline, which is likely to be passed on to the consumer eventually.
 
Eastern States Are Watching
 Oil companies say yesterday's 6-to-1 vote by the Air Resources Board, which regulates activities that pollute the air in California, is being closely watched by Eastern states. Those states have already said they will adopt California's new auto emissions standards.
The rules adopted yesterday are to take effect in California in 1996. Small refiners get an extra two years to meet the requirements.
The rules, which do not require further government approval, build on less stringent standards that take effect in January.
Most oil companies oppose the standards because they fear they will bear a large portion of the cost.
But George H. Babikian, president of the ARCO Products Company, California's largest gasoline marketer, said he favored the change. "I'm proud of the Air Resources Board," he said in a telephone interview shortly after the vote. "They took some heat, but they did the right thing."
Mr. Babikian said that the new fuel would meet the Federal standards into the next century and that while the expense would be substantial, it would damage the economy of the state far less than trying to remove an equivalent amount of pollutants from other sources. The investment will "jump start this economy," he said.
He said the ARCO refinery in Los Angeles, which produces more than 10 million gallons a day, would spend $700 million to $800 million on the refinery to meet the requirement.
California regulators have tried to minimize that cost by describing it as being about half a cent for each mile a motorist drives, compared with an average motorist's overall cost of driving of 38 cents per mile, including fuel, aintenance and the purchase price of the vehicle.
But oil companies have argued that the collective cost is in the tens of billions. The cost of pollution control measures is typically measured in the dollars required to remove a ton of pollutants from the air. Texaco, arguing against the changes that the board made, put the cost at $500,000 per ton. Previous pollution control measures like smokestack controls on factories cost $5,000 to $10,000 a ton.
"I think the American people lost," said the chairman of Texaco, James Kinnear. "What they've done is very bad for the economy of California and bad for the economy of the United States. This country is in a recession. What we need is some productive investments."
Cleaning up "stationary sources" of pollution, from factories and other areas, would be cheaper, he said.
Mr. Kinnear complained that the delay in the standards for small refineries would destroy the refining industry. If small refineries can sell gasoline that cost 15 to 20 cents less to produce, he said, big refiners will have to meet the small refiners' price, and will be unable to recoup the cost of their investments.
The motor vehicle standards could easily have an effect far beyond California. The District of Columbia and all the East Coast states from Virginia to Maine with the exception of Connecticut, have agreed in recent weeks to adopt them.
Those states have not yet said what they will do about fuel, and they do not have to act together. But the oil industry is persuaded that those states will eventually conclude that to get the full benefit from cleaner cars, they should also require the cleaner fuel.
As a result, the oil companies that market nationally vigorously fought the proposal the Air Resources Board accepted. The exceptions were ARCO, a regional oil company that does most of its business in California, and Ultramar, which is also centered in California.
But the California standards could have an influence in another way, said Michael J. Bradley, the executive director of the Northeast States for Coordinated Air Use Management, an organization of state air pollution control officials from the New England states, New York and New Jersey. California's action may convince the Federal Government to adopt a similar fuel for polluted areas nationwide. In that case, the Eastern states would not have to take any action, he said.
Alternatively, Mr. Bradley said, the Eastern states might tinker with the California fuel to suit their own needs. For example, the California specifications call for a gasoline that is highly resistant to evaporation, but weather conditions in the Northeast are less severe, making such a strict limit on evaporation less necessary. The eight states in Mr. Bradley's organization moved jointly in 1988 to require more evaporation-resistant gasoline, thus becoming the largest state coalition thus far to take action on fuel.
Independent of California, the Clean Air Act amendments passed by Congress last year require the Federal Environmental Protection Agency to issue new standards to take effect in 1995 for gasoline used in polluted areas. The California requirements are far more stringent, however.

HEADLINE: For New York's Businesses, Time of Wrenching Changes

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
Businesses in the New York City region that are waiting for a national recovery to lift them out of their doldrums are looking in the wrong direction, several economists say. The downturn here, they say, has less to do with the nationwide slump than with the wrenching changes being forced on many of the industries for which the city is a center.
The large New York banks have watched new competitors from both their own and other industries, often based elsewhere, come into fields they have traditionally dominated. Television broadcasters have been hurt by deregulation, which forces them to compete against cable and other media companies for audiences and advertising dollars. 
 And New York's plethora of firms that specialize in accounting, law, public relations and advertising have all suffered from the shrinkage of publicly owned companies during the merger-ridden 1980's, companies that were once their clients.
 
Reinventing Themselves
 Although these industries have already shed thousands of jobs, they may have still further to go.
"They are having to reinvent their industries," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics for New York and New Jersey. "So many industries key to New York are in that stage, and we don't have experience as a city with that phenomenon."
Mr. Ehrenhalt calculates that one-quarter of all jobs in the city are in financial, business and professional services. But in the 1980's, those industries generated 56 percent of all job growth. Since their peak in 1988, they have lost 79,600 jobs.
Of course, not every industry in the region is hurting. The health-care and pharmaceutical industries in particular are still growing.
But with so many companies in so many vital industries experiencing a fundamental challenge to their existence, the effect on the local economy has been dramatic. Most recessions since World War II in the New York region have been more moderate than those nationwide, and have generally run for about the same length of time.
This time around, however, the New York region went into its tailspin a full 17 months before the national economy. "That's unprecedented in the post-World War era, and signals that there is something different going on," Mr. Ehrenhalt concludes.
In part, companies in New York are being hurt by an upheaval that reshaped the corporate world in the 80's. Salomon Brothers has estimated that 500 publicly owned companies disappeared from the business horizon from 1985 to 1988 alone, as the result of mergers and the trend of companies to go private. And many of the companies that remain took on large debts to do so.
 
A Muted Recovery?
 The ripple effect is clear. Until they disappeared or became hobbled with debt, those companies were among those that accounting firms audited for, advertising firms wrote snappy jingles for and law firms defended.
The structural changes afflicting some of New York's most important industries suggest that even when the national economy starts to rebound, the salutary effect on the metropolitan region will be muted.
"It's not that New York is impervious to the national economy," said Matthew Drennan, a professor of economics at Cornell University. "But it won't bounce back because of the structural problems."
He predicts that the local economy will not hit bottom until early 1992.
How quickly New York rebounds depends on how far these industries have come in their transformations.
 
Halfway Through?
 In the case of banks, those based in New York City have already shed 12.5 percent of their workforce since 1987, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Despite that, most analysts think there is still a long way to go, and indeed, Citicorp, and Chemical Bank, which recently merged with the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, have already announced another round of layoffs.
Even with their cuts, most of the largest banks still have expenses that are much larger in proportion to their revenues, compared with smaller but fast-growing "super-regional" banks, according to analysts at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods. "They're only about half to three-quarters of the way through their adjustment," said Robert Litan, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.
Advertising firms are also still in the throes of restructuring. The industry has been suffering from a steep decline in corporate advertising, which has hurt television networks, publishing companies and public relations agencies as well. According to Robert J. Coen, director of research at McCann-Erickson, the growth rate in ad spending has declined from the low teens in the early 1980's to zero this year.
 
Slow to Cut
 Few new consumer products are being introduced, and companies' debt is discouraging research and development efforts, trends that suggest that advertising spending will not rebound any time soon.
That leaves many of the large publicly held advertising firms that gobbled up many of their smaller competitors during the 1980's with heavy overhead expenses and declining revenues. Just this week, Oglivy & Mather, a division of the WPP Group, announced that it was laying off 7 percent of its New York staff, after layoffs earlier this year.
New York's big accounting firms are privately held, but that has not helped them escape the pressures of change. The industry has been hurt by the shrinking number of public companies that need full audits, and by tax reforms that have reduced the number of shelters and made it harder for many accounting firms to bill as much for tax consulting.
 
The Big 5?
 The growth in the largest firms' revenue has declined from a healthy 16.6 percent in 1988, to an estimated 4.5 percent this year, according to the Atlanta-based Bowman's Accounting Report, which tracks the industry. On top of those problems, of course, is the decline in business from the recession.
Employment has already shrunk in the industry by 5.7 percent since 1988. But Mr. Bowman thinks that when the process is over, there will no longer be the Big Six firms -- already down from the Big Eight -- but simply the Big Five.
Department stores in New York have also been part of the disappearing act. Although New York's famous department stores have long been a treat for locals and tourists alike, over the last few years the industry has suffered severe setbacks unrelated to the national recession.
The final blow for some stores was the heavy debt load they took on during the late 80's wave of mergers and buyouts. The result is plain in the loss of names like B. Altman's, Gimbels and Bonwit Teller.
Employment in the industry has already shrunk an astonishing 40 percent since 1979, and most of the weakest participants have been weeded out, analysts say. "I think the worst is over," said Steven B. Greenberg, president of the Greenberg Group, a Hewlitt, L.I., real-estate adviser to several national retailers.
The one industry that most analysts think has gone through the worst of its adjustment and is emerging intact is the securities business. Wall Street firms have been cutting jobs as quickly as they added them in the boom years. Employment in the industry is down by 18 percent, or 30,000, since it peaked in 1987.
The size of the workforce, however, has finally started to stabilize, and some firms, like Shearson Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch have actually started hiring.

HEADLINE: Letter: On New York City;
Showing Private Business How to Help

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As chairman of the Mayor's Committee for Public-Private Partnerships, I read with great interest "The Business of Business" (editorial, Nov. 2). You correctly state that "individual corporations already provide much direct financial and volunteer aid" to New York City. However, you conclude by saying that many business people "feel they are talking to deaf ears," and that business partners can only help if there is a mutual willingness to hear and act. 
 That willingness is more than exemplified by our pro bono committee. In April 1990, Mayor David N. Dinkins created the Committee for Public-Private Partnerships and the Office of Partnership Programs to match the resources and abilities of the private sector with the right public-sector partner to address some of the city's most pressing needs.
Since that time our committee has helped with more than 100 different partnership projects -- from refurbishing basketball courts with the support of Reebok and the Parks Department to getting the advertising firm of Korey Kay & Partners to assist the city, pro bono, in alerting the public to the current water shortage. The study you cite by Booz, Allen & Hamilton for the Board of Education was a marriage made possible by our staff's bringing the right people together as partners.
Other notable projects our committee helped coordinate include the donation of $10,000 to the New York City Housing Authority's urban gardening program by the Swatch watch company; the renovation of playgrounds at 10 city schools made possible by a donation from J. P. Morgan; the production by the Department of General Services of a free film series called "Street Cinema," in which donated films were projected on building walls in vacant city-owned properties, and an ongoing partnership to increase the level of communication between city government and the foundation community.
Our job also includes bringing greater public attention to successful partnerships. To that end we have participated in more than 50 press events that have announced joint initiatives between the public and private sectors.
Our small operation has established itself as a point of access for the private sector. We know the private sector wants to contribute, but sometimes they just don't know to whom to talk and consequently they get frustrated. That is exactly why the committee was established. Any company or private individual who would like to contribute toward addressing the city's ills should call 212-240-4300. Our ears are open; we want to listen.
 
CARL SPIELVOGEL
Chairman, Mayor's Committee for Public-Private Partnerships
New York, Nov. 13, 1991

HEADLINE: American-Made Cars on Comeback Road;
Still Disenchanted

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re: "Big Losses for Top 2 in Detroit" (Business Day, Oct. 23): 
 It is easy for American auto makers to blame rebates and the recession for the worst losses in history. The answer is more painful than that. American cars are not as good as Japanese imports.
My husband's family and mine were loyal General Motors car drivers for decades (with an occasional lapse when Studebakers caught everyone's fancy). We remained loyal longer than most of our friends, all of whom are, like us, dedicated Americans. In 1986, when our Buick Century wagon needed a new transmission before it was a year old, and that was just one major nuisance that year, my husband wrote the president of General Motors to warn we were being forced to switch to Japanese cars.
He received some half-hearted response from a regional lackey. No satisfaction was offered. In June 1990 we bought an Acura Legend, which has required no service from the dealer. Our children have also bought Japanese cars and have nothing but pleasure from them. The one child who bought a Ford wagon has had the vehicle back to the dealer several times, which is a nuisance and usually unsatisfactory.
Protective tariffs are not the answer. Quality products are needed. How to recover lost customers is the problem poor quality and service caused.
 
CORINNE K. KLAFTER
Great Neck, L.I., Nov. 4, 1991

HEADLINE: 9,900 Jobs To Be Cut By Nynex

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The Nynex Corporation, the provider of local telephone service in New York State and New England, said yesterday that it planned to reduce its work force over the next two years by more than 10 percent, or about 9,900 employees.
The cost of severance pay and early-retirement benefits, plus costs for getting out of the separate businesses of writing computer software in Britain and developing real estate in the Northeast United States, is expected to total more than $500 million. As a result, the company will report a substantial loss for its fourth quarter, instead of the modest profit that had been expected. 
 The layoffs and early retirements are expected to begin in January and end in December 1993, and will further chill the recessionary climate of the New York City metropolitan area, which is home for many of the employees who will lose their jobs.
There are no detailed estimates of how many white-collar employees, known as management workers, will be laid off, or of how many blue-collar employees, known as craft workers, will take advantage of an early-retirement offer.
 
Replacements May Be Hired
 But the Communications Workers of America, Nynex's union, estimates that in New York State 4,000 craft workers and more than 500 management workers may be off the payroll by April. Most of those employees will be in the New York City area. To help replace these experienced workers, at least temporarily, several thousand new permanent and temporary workers may be hired, presumably at lower salaries.
Analysts estimate that the savings from the work-force reduction -- without taking other factors, like inflation, into account -- will amount to roughly $50,000 a year per worker, or $495 million for 9,900 employees.
Like other regional Bell operating companies, Nynex has been struggling to reduce its operating costs as the installation of more advanced equipment, like digital fiber-optic transmission gear, means that fewer employees, both white-collar and blue-collar, are needed. Nynex has also been hurt by competition from smaller, more efficient telecommunications companies that specialize in serving large corporate customers.
Moreover, Nynex has been hurt even more than the other "Baby Bell" companies by the lingering recession, which has been particularly damaging in the Northeast. The downturn has dampened revenue from professionals, who are responsible for the greatest proportion of business phone traffic, both for conversations and for the transmission of text, numbers and images over telephone lines.
Growth in the number of telephone lines and in the minutes of telephone use has slowed considerably in the Northeast.
In the third quarter, the number of Nynex telephone lines rose 1.1 percent, to 15.3 million access lines, half of the average growth rate of 2.2 percent for all of the Baby Bells. The minutes of use by Nynex customers rose 2.9 percent, to 11.8 billion minutes, compared with 4.7 percent growth for all of the Baby Bells.
Nynex, based in White Plains, is the parent of New York Telephone and New England Telephone. As of Oct. 31, it had 91,200 employees, including 59,500 craft employees and 31,700 management employees.
The charge announced yesterday, of $550 million, or $2.73 a share, means the company will have a large loss for the current quarter. Frank J. Governali, a telecommunications analyst with the First Boston Corporation, had estimated before yesterday's announcement that the company would report a fourth-quarter profit of $1.47 a share, or $297 million. The new charge will mean a loss of $253 million instead.
In reaction to news of the fourth-quarter charge, Nynex's stock price fell 87.5 cents a share yesterday, to $75.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Under the Nynex plan, about $395 million of the quarterly charge relates to work-force reductions. And half of that figure stems from early-retirement provisions for craft workers who will leave the payroll by January.
About 6,500 craft workers have announced that they intend to take advantage of an early-retirement offer. Although some 20,000 workers qualify for some form of early retirement, Nynex has set aside enough money for only 10,000, which is considered the likely upper limit for retirements.
As part of an unusual early negotiation of a union contract, announced in September, Nynex agreed to expand retirement pay by changing certain assumptions in the pension plan, like years of service.
Most of the reductions of white-collar employees will come from layoffs. Nynex plans to reduce the number of management employees by 1,900 by April, and by up to 1,500 more over the next 24 months.
Nynex also plans to take a $155 million charge against earnings for restructuring costs.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 25, 1991, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Saturday about layoffs at the Nynex Corporation misstated the company's plans for its software-writing subsidiary in Britain. Nynex is consolidating several offices of its BIS Group in London. It does not plan to terminate its operations.

HEADLINE: Credit Cards: Variable Rates Don't Always Help

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
Congressional efforts to cap interest rates on credit cards have ground to a halt amid fears that banks might revoke millions of credit cards and drive the economy deeper into recession. Consumers who want good deals -- low interest rates and low annual fees (or none at all) -- will have to continue shopping around.
Some will no doubt be attracted to variable-rate credit cards, which account for about 10 percent of all cards issued, according to Bankcard Holders of America, a consumer advocacy group in Herndon, Va. 
 Such cards are often made to seem like adjustable-rate mortgages, an attractive concept. Rather than being saddled with a fixed interest rate, for instance, the borrower can play the financial market, finding a card that ties its interest rate to a benchmark like the prime rate. When the prime rate goes down, as it has in recent years, the borrower should be the winner. The prime rate is the interest that banks charge their most credit-worthy customers.
 
Borrowers Don't Always Win
 But as some consumers who signed up for variable-rate credit cards are finding out, the borrower does not always win when the prime rate falls. In some instances, the rates on such cards have actually gone up despite the decline in the prime rate over the last year. In other cases, companies offered consumers variable-rate cards to get them signed up and then dropped those plans for fixed rates, which were set higher.
Consumers should not assume that the interest rates on their cards won't decrease as the prime drops. Robert McKinley, the publisher of Ram Research's Cardtrak, a newsletter, in Frederick, Md., warned, "There are a lot of gimmicks and games that companies play with variable rates."
Elgie Holstein, president of the Bankcard Holders group, said, "The concept of a variable rate for a credit card doesn't work anything like an adjustable-rate mortgage."
Consider the case of the Bank of New York, which offers a variable rate on its standard Visa and Mastercard. Early this year, the rate the bank charged on both cards was 16.98 percent. The variable-rate formula used by the bank was based on fluctuations in the interest rate paid on certificates of deposit plus an additional 8 percentage points, said Michael Pascale, a bank spokesman. Rates are adjusted monthly.
Under the plan's terms, the lowest the rate could go was 16.98 percent, even if rates for certificates of deposit dropped further. But on March 1, the interest rate charged by the bank on both cards rose to 18.4 percent. C.D. rates hadn't risen, so how did it happen?
Easily enough. The Bank of New York changed its variable-rate formula to one based on fluctuations in the prime rate plus 8.9 points.
"The effect of the change was to increase the pricing somewhat," Mr. Pascale said. As required, the bank notified all customers in advance of the change, he said. The bank also let those who wished to close their accounts pay balances at the old rate. The rate on both cards recently dropped back to 16.98 percent.
The Bank of New York is by no means the only lender to reshuffle its formula as interest rates drop. American Express, for example, has changed the ground rules on its Optima card twice in recent months.
 
Rising Surcharge on Optima Rate
 In December, interest on an Optima card was 15.75 percent. The formula used by American Express was the prime rate plus a surcharge of 5.75 points.
Since January, the prime rate has fallen by 2.5 percentage points, to 7.5 percent from 10 percent. But interest charged by American Express on its Optima card rose to 16.75 percent in January and is now 16.25 percent. The changes occurred because American Express raised its surcharge to 6.75 points in January and then to 7.75 points in October; it adjusts its Optima rate twice a year.
Maureen Bailey, a spokeswoman for American Express, said customers were alerted to the changes, and added hat the rate currently charged is still below that charged by many companies that use fixed rates. The current national average on fixed-rate cards is 18.98 percent.
But Mr. McKinley of the Cardtrak newsletter said that if American Express had not changed the formula, Optima holders would now be paying about 13.75 percent interest. Based on an average $2,400 monthly balance, the typical Optima holder will pay an added $60 in interest this year as a result of the changes, he said.
The rate on another popular card, the A.T.&T Universal card, has fallen to 16.4 percent from 18.4 percent for most customers, said Bruce Reid, a company spokesman, and to 17.4 percent from 19.4 for others, Mr. Reid said, adding, "If the prime keeps going down, our rates will keep going down." The Universal card has no interest-rate floor.
Mr. McKinley said he is concerned that as interest rates continue to fall, lenders will begin to change variable-rate formulas more often.
"When card rates start dropping issuers start to get nervous," he said.

HEADLINE: Sununu Says Bush 'Ad-Libbed' Comment on Credit Card Rates

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
John H. Sununu, the beleaguered White House chief of staff, said today that President Bush was responsible for the remark about credit card interest rates that started a chain of events and sent the stock market skidding last Friday.
Mr. Sununu's comments in a television interview to be broadcast this weekend seemed aimed at heading off the mounting pressure for his removal. 
 This latest development in the public drama over Mr. Sununu's survival at the White House came as many Republicans speculated that Mr. Bush had privately decided to replace his chief of staff and was waiting for the right moment. There was also a general sense that Mr. Sununu had been caught up in one of those capital controversies that have proved fatal to other Washington figures.
Mr. Sununu said Mr. Bush "ad-libbed" the remark about credit cards. The remark added to the impression that Mr. Bush is confused about how to handle the economy.
 
Sununu's Account Rebutted
 Late today, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, rebutted a crucial part of Mr. Sununu's account. He said the credit card proposal, included in a political speech in New York on Nov. 12, was "the President's idea." But he said the remarks were in the President's text, not ad-libbed as Mr. Sununu said.
This public back and forth between a President and his top aide has few parallels in recent Washington history, and it came at a time when most major newspapers have been publishing articles about the torrent of advice from top Republicans urging Mr. Bush to dismiss the combative former Governor of New Hampshire.
Mr. Sununu's latest account, in an interview on "John McLaughlin's One on One" television program, to be broadcast on WRC-TV in Washington at noon on Sunday and on PBS stations elsewhere at varying times, conflicted with earlier accounts from the Administration.
Administration officials said the credit card notion came from Kenneth M. Duberstein, a White House chief of staff under President Ronald Reagan, and that Mr. Sununu had talked to Mr. Bush about it before he delivered the speech. They said Mr. Sununu wrote the lines about credit cards.
Even if Mr. Sununu did not write Mr. Bush's specific words, his comments today represented an extraordinary attempt by an aide under fire to shift the political heat to his boss.
Publicly, the White House and Mr. Sununu himself said today that his job was secure and that Mr. Bush had no plans to replace him.
But Administration officials and Republican Party strategists said Mr. Bush was under increasing pressure to move Mr. Sununu aside as he nears the time when he would have to announce the formation of his re-election campaign team.
 
Challenges From Far Right
 Although Mr. Bush had been widely expected to name his campaign team in January, there is increasing evidence that he will move the date up to December, when the process begins for choosing delegates that will be on the ballot in the New Hampshire primary.
Mr. Bush went to the Presidential retreat at Camp David, Md., for the weekend, and Mr. Fitzwater said the President would discuss by telephone with his advisers the campaign and administrative concerns.
Mr. Bush, who thought just a few weeks ago that he would be unopposed in New Hampshire, now faces the possibility of two challenges from the far right, from Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator, and State Representative David Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan leader and neo-Nazi who lost last Saturday's race for governor in Louisiana.
The problem Mr. Bush is facing, Republican strategists said today, is that it is becoming increasingly difficult to build a campaign structure around Mr. Sununu, especially when the President's political ground seems so shaky.
"If Sununu's the problem, the solution cannot be a new campaign structure or other bright people doing things outside the White House," said one Republican. "The solution has to be to make a change inside the White House.
At the White House, aides said Mr. Sununu's political difficulties had cast a pall over Mr. Bush's efforts to deal with criticism that he was not paying enough attention to domestic issues. One official described the attention to Mr. Sununu as "very frustrating."
At a campaign fund-raiser in New York last week, Mr. Bush said in a speech that he had been talking to business people recently and thought that it would spur the economy if banks lowered the interest they charge on credit cards.
That remark prompted Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, to introduce legislation, which was passed by the Senate, to put a legal limit on those rates. Last Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average, which tracks 30 of the nation's leading companies, fell 120.31 points, the largest plunge in more than two years. The credit card issue was blamed by many analysts for the plunge.
In his interview with Mr. McLaughlin, Mr. Sununu said the idea was "never in" any text of Mr. Bush's speech. "The President ad-libbed," Mr. Sununu said.
 
'Dead Wrong'
 In the interview, Mr. Sununu also said his relationship with the Bush family was warm and that after The New York Times reported that Barbara Bush was souring on him, the President's wife made a point of seeking him out and made him "very, very comfortable." The Wall Street Journal said in a front-page article today that "even Barbara Bush is said to be convinced that the former New Hampshire Governor's 'flaws are fatal.' "
Although Mr. Bush has a record of resisting outside pressure of this kind, in the high-stakes world of White House politics, it is an article of faith that a senior official like Mr. Sununu can stand only so many political body blows before his downfall becomes inevitable.
In his interview, Mr. Sununu also denied that he had called Ann Devroy, the White House correspondent for The Washington Post, a "liar" in a widely reported confrontation on the lawn of the Rose Garden after Mr. Bush signed the 1991 Civil Rights Act on Thursday.
Ms. Devroy said on Thursday and again today after hearing of Mr. Sununu's comments that he shouted at her: "You're a liar! Your stories are all lies! Everything you write is a lie!"
Asked by Mr. McLaughlin about the exchange, Mr. Sununu said: "Well, I told her that everything she had written recently was dead wrong. There's a difference."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 1480 words

HEADLINE: As 'Steamtown' Grows, So Does Parks Debate

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SCRANTON, Pa., Nov. 22

 BODY:
A $73- million Federal project to build a theme park meant to recreate the age of steam locomotives in a decrepit railroad yard here has touched off an extraordinary debate over the changing mission of the National Park Service.
Members of Congress, which has become more and more involved in setting priorities for the Park Service over the past decade, say the park, called the Steamtown National Historic Site, could help revive the depressed economy of this northeastern Pennsylvania region by drawing hundreds of thousands of visitors every year. 
 "The bottom line," said Representative Joseph M. McDade, a Republican who has represented Scranton in Congress for almost 30 years, "is that we have the opportunity to create and display to the world a highly important era in the history of our nation."
But a number of historians and museum curators around the nation call Steamtown a second-rate collection of trains on a third-rate site. They say that while such historic recreations have a place, the Federal Government should not be financing them simply because influential members of Congress want them for their districts.
And officials of the National Park Service, in interviews over the past week, said Steamtown and other such Congressionally mandated projects were diverting the agency from its historic mission of preserving and maintaining great national parks like Yosemite and Yellowstone.
 "It is the most serious problem we face in the next 10 years," said James M. Ridenour, director of the Park Service. "We're spending lots of money creating new parks, which may or may not be of national significance."
Not all historians dismiss the Steamtown project. "The person who finds his way to Steamtown will have an excellent and enjoyable experience," said Walter P. Gray, director of the California State Railroad Museum in Sacramento, though he added that the money could have been better spent on rail preservation projects elsewhere.
And others point out that industrial restoration efforts have been successful elsewhere. Since 1978, the Park Service has spent $23 million restoring textile mills, canals and worker housing at the widely acclaimed Lowell National Historical Park in Lowell, Mass.
But Mr. Ridenour said that too many restoration efforts "were pork-barrel projects that the Park Service neither wanted nor needed," and he added: "Many of these proposals are great ideas, but they should not all be lodged in the National Park Service. Tourism is not our mission."
The director said the agency had been forced to administer an increasing number of such projects since 1981. In that year, the Reagan Administration sought to rein in the agency's spending and Congress responded by providing the agency with hundreds of millions of unrequested dollars every year for construction projects that the members earmarked for their own states and districts.
 
Hurting Established Parks?
 But the Park Service's operating budget has not been increasing at the same rate, and its officials complain that the proliferation of new sites like Steamtown are hurting the older parks, which have postponed maintenance projects worth over $2 billion.
Congress began spending money for Steamtown five years ago at the behest of Mr. McDade, a 15-term Republican from Scranton, who is the ranking minority member on the House Appropriations Committee and a member of the Appropriations subcommittee for the Park Service. Even the Reagan Administration, which had earlier tried to enforce a moratorium on new park development, enthusiastically supported Mr. McDade's proposal.
The provision for the park was inserted into a huge appropriations bill at a late-night meeting near the end of the legislative session in October 1986. Congressional authorizing committees, which are charged with setting policy and reviewing such proposals, were bypassed, and the Park Service did not conduct its customary two-year review of proposed new parks.
Indeed, the agency had earlier rejected a plan to acquire the same collection of trains, then assembled at a site in Vermont that was also called Steamtown, saying it lacked historic importance. The collection "didn't fit our basic mission, to preserve historic sites, actual places that are significant in American history," said Barry MacKintosh, an agency historian.
 
Panel to Vote on Project
 But in Scranton, which has never recovered from the decline of the region's coal mines, such concerns were dismissed as academic hair-splitting. At a subcommittee hearing on Steamtown last month, Representative McDade called one historian a "loser" for criticizing the park.
Congress has appropriated $56 million for the project since 1986. And next Tuesday, the House Interior Subcommittee on National Parks and Public Lands, is scheduled to vote on legislation that would formally establish Steamtown as a national park and set a $73 million ceiling on development costs, making it the second-most expensive park project in the past 20 years.
The goal is to build a functioning railway yard, almost from scratch, on a 42-acre downtown site that was abandoned by Conrail, the freight railroad, in 1983. By that time the yard had been razed, remodeled and pillaged so many times that there was little to recall the glory days of steam transportation -- 1851 to the late 1940's, when railroads like the Delaware, Lackawanna & Western hauled coal and passengers around this region.
In early 1995, when Steamtown is scheduled for completion, visitors will be able to take excursion rides in refurbished commuter cars and see steam locomotives puffing down rebuilt tracks, being spun around on a new concrete turntable and maintained in a reconstructed roundhouse.
Mayor James P. Connors of Scranton testified at a subcommittee hearing last month that "The Steamtown National Historic Site has already drawn thousands of people to our area and it's only in its infancy."
Markley E. Smith, publisher and editor of Locomotive and Railway Preservation Magazine, said that although he had concerns about the quality of the collection of trains, Steamtown had the potential "to be a leading contribution to railway preservation in North America. "
Because it takes a big labor force to run a railyard, Steamtown's projected annual operating cost is $6.5 million, more than twice the operating budget of 39,000-acre Acadia National Park in Maine. Steamtown's sponsors expect to attract 500,000 visitors a year; Acadia received five million visitors last year.
Along with officials of the Park Service, some members of Congress say such spending priorities distort the agency's mission. Representative Bruce F. Vento, the Minnesota Democrat who is chairman of the panel that is to vote on the Steamtown measure next Tuesday, calls the project "a runaway locomotive." But he added, "It's hard for members to oppose each other's projects."
Some junior members of Congress have sought in vain to halt spending on such projects. This year, Senator Robert C. Smith, a Republican from New Hampshire, introduced a measure to rescind $1 billion appropriated for 325 projects, including Steamtown, but the bill went nowhere.
 
Complaints Over Projects
 Agency officials also complain about many other projects that depart from the service's traditional mission. For example, Congress last year required the service to spend $500,000 on a new local museum in Tennessee and $4.5 million to convert a theater in West Virginia into a four-screen movie house.
The Park Service also had to make the Charles Pinckney Home in Charleston, S.C., into a national park. Then it completed a historical survey concluding that Pinckney, a signer of the Declaration of Independence, died long before the "generic early 19th Century" house was built. The property's annual operating budget is $315,000.
 
Trying to Block Proposals
 Mr. Ridenour, the Park Service director, said the agency planned to make a concerted effort to deflect such proposals. He said the agency might create a separate program that would provide start-up grants and technical assistance in historic preservation to the state and local governments that would run such projects, reducing the burden on the Park Service.
What angers many historians about Steamtown is that there are many railroad collections of far greater historical value rusting away.
"I can't find words strong enough to express my contempt for this whole thing," said Robert M. Vogel, who was curator of mechanical and civil engineering at the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American History for 30 years before retiring a few years ago.
"There are only a few remnants of structures on the Scranton site," he added, "so they are spending millions of dollars building a Walt Disney movie set that will be absolutely phony from the word go."
