HEADLINE: The Whole Untruth

BYLINE: By Clifford Krauss; Clifford Krauss, a correspondent in the Washington bureau of The New York Times, is the author of "Inside Central America."

 BODY:

LIVES, LIES AND THE IRAN-CONTRA AFFAIR
By Ann Wroe.
Illustrated. 341 pp. New York:
I.B. Tauris & Company/
St. Martin's Press. $24.95. 
 THE Iran-contra scandal was so Byzantine, the Congressional investigation of it was so inadequate and the public performances of President Ronald Reagan and Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North were so dissembling that most of the American public was left either hopelessly confused or apathetic. Senator William S. Cohen aptly quoted T. S. Eliot to describe his feelings about the affair: "We had the experience but missed the meaning."
The meaning, according to Ann Wroe, the literary editor of The Economist, is that deceit and illegality permeated two of the Reagan Administration's major foreign policy initiatives -- its proxy war on the Sandinista regime in Nicaragua and its haphazard effort to free the Western hostages in Lebanon. In "Lives, Lies and the Iran-Contra Affair" she reproaches not only the Reagan Administration but also the American political culture that produced it. Ms. Wroe writes that the players in the scandal -- from some of the President's closest foreign policy advisers to the private profiteers who moved the weapons and the money between Iran and Nicaragua -- "did not seem to see much correlation between right action and observance of the law."
For this, Ms. Wroe believes President Reagan should have been impeached, and probably would have been, had lying to Congress not become as common in the 1980's as the lobbyist's lunch, had patriotism not become indistinguishable from conservative politics and had the general public not fallen into the same know-nothing lotus-sleep as President Reagan himself.
MS. WROE would be more effective driving home her moral points if her book were not flawed in several fundamental ways. It reveals little about the scandal that is not already in the public record, and it jumps around so much that a reader not previously well versed in the chronology of the scandal can easily become confused. Ms. Wroe, like too many writers who have tackled the mountain of documents that came out of the Tower Commission, the Congressional investigation, the North trial and the special prosecutor's probings, gets lost in the trees. The Iran-contra forest has as many canopies as a dense tropical jungle, but the basic outline comes down to this: The Reagan White House disobeyed an explicit Congressional ban on supplying a guerrilla army in order to make war on the Government of Nicaragua. That the aid was financed by the secret sale of arms to Iran in a vain attempt to buy American hostages out of Lebanon compounded the illegality with foolishness.
Ms. Wroe is especially weak at explaining the Middle Eastern and Central American contexts. Her point that few of the senior American policy makers deciding Nicaragua's future spoke Spanish or understood the country they were attacking has merit. But there is no evidence that she herself has studied Nicaragua. Her description of the contras as purely a creature of the United States, the Frankenstein of the Iran-contra affair, is a simplistic distortion. Many of the contra leaders were corrupt and inept, especially those, perhaps not surprisingly, who depended most on American financial support. But the Nicaraguan counterrevolutionary movement began before the Reagan Administration started financing it, and took root in at least half the country.
In her indefatigable search to root out immoral politics and cynicism, Ms. Wroe ascribes the religious aspects of the contra effort to Washington's manipulations. She states offhandedly that the large numbers of Protestant evangelicals found in the contra camps were "presumably converted by American missionaries while the Catholic priests were away," as if Nicaraguans can't make their own religious choices. As evidence for this claim, she ingenuously quotes from a poem by Ernesto Cardenal, a renegade Roman Catholic priest who, as the Sandinista culture minister, was hardly an objective observer. In fact, the contras attracted widespread support among the conservative peasants of Nicaragua's central highlands, evangelicals and Catholics alike.
Fortunately, for all her moralism, Ms. Wroe does succeed in bringing wit to her subject, and her best writing, describing the plain wackiness of the Reagan White House's shenanigans, has a P. J. O'Rourke flavor. She complains that the American public, if it thinks about the Iran-contra affair at all, remembers it only in terms of Mr. North's testimony, "that piece of film everyone had seen and talked about, like the shooting of JR in Dallas or the opening on Geraldo of Al Capone's secret vault." Perhaps Ms. Wroe's good humor can help perk up interest in this scandal. When the White House breaks the law and conducts war in secret, those actions should attract more lasting attention than J.R.'s shooting.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 52; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4576 words

HEADLINE: Lamar Alexander's Self-Help Course

BYLINE: By Susan Chira; Susan Chira is national education correspondent for The New York Times.

 BODY:
ONE DAY LAST SPRING, WHEN THE SUNLIGHT SPARKLED ON broken glass and Manhattan streets had already begun to smell of summer, Andrew Lamar Alexander Jr., at the age of 51, went to school.
At the Holy Cross School in Hell's Kitchen, children in magenta plaid uniforms sang for the new Secretary of Education, stood up when he entered their classrooms, and greeted him in singsong unison. Later, the tall, soft-spoken Alexander sat with the principal and superintendent and pulled out a green spiral notebook. "Is there anything I ought to know?" he asked, and took notes as the Catholic educators described how much the school's largely working-class parents would benefit from his proposal to let taxes pay for Catholic school tuition. 
 The approach was vintage Lamar Alexander -- understated, unaffected, purposeful and quietly subversive. It may have seemed like a routine visit for a Secretary of Education, but Alexander was pushing the most controversial idea in the President's plan to transform American schools -- "choice," or vouchers that would let parents apply tax dollars toward the cost of whatever public or private school they chose. The hope is that market competition will force schools to improve.
Presiding over dozens of school visits, press events and community rallies, Lamar Alexander has swept into office like a whirlwind after the lassitude of his predecessor, Lauro F. Cavazos. In his first eight months, Alexander has drawn up a new education plan, jetted around the country promoting it and recruited a highly respected team at the Education Department, including his deputy, David T. Kearns, the former chairman and chief executive officer of Xerox, and Diane Ravitch, an Assistant Secretary who is an outspoken advocate of academic rigor.
Alexander is embarking on the most important sales pitch of his career: convincing Americans that their schools are in trouble, and that they alone can fix them. President Bush, under attack for ignoring domestic issues in general and his pledge to be the "education president" in particular, is counting on his Education Secretary for results he can trumpet during his re-election bid. Success in this risky undertaking could boost Alexander's political profile -- many of his friends believe he wants to be President. But he is betting his national prospects on improving education, a goal that has defeated generations of reformers before him. Now Alexander must persuade the country that his education strategy is more than an empty public relations exercise.
America's education crisis is really two crises: the mediocre performance of most students and the complete failure of others in many inner-city schools. Alexander's plan addresses the first far better than the second.
By training and temperament, Alexander is well suited to attack the first problem: shaking up a complacent public and spurring parents to take responsibility for improving their children's schools. He comes armed with a strong resume as an education reformer acquired as a Republican governor of Tennessee and president of its state university system. Friends and enemies alike call him a brilliant salesman and politician with a sure populist touch.
Alexander wants to lead what he calls a "populist crusade," one that subverts the education establishment and incites people to get so angry about school failure that they will force through real changes. "Too many people say the nation's at risk but I'm O.K.," he tells his audiences around the nation.
In the speech he gives as he barnstorms the country he asks American communities to consider these questions: "If you weren't already doing it, would you let children out of school in the afternoon to go home to empty houses? Would you let teachers off in the summer to bring in the crops? Would you have the playground locked in a city when boys and girls need somewhere to play at night? Would you have classrooms that had teachers without a telephone? Would you continue to have buildings that are almost untouched by the technological revolution of the last 20 years?"
The plan he endorses, however, ignores the poverty at the heart of many inner-city school problems. It does not provide much money for innovative programs, although Alexander pushed through the biggest tax increase in Tennessee history to pay for education when he was governor. In the end, Alexander draws his vision of what American education can be from his own roots in a small, cohesive town, a world apart from the ravaged neighborhoods of the inner city.
Faced with such criticisms, Alexander remains, as ever, affable. He does not betray anger, and he does not betray himself. He resists detailed debate on issues, offering instead a series of well-crafted political set pieces. This composure can be infuriating to the questioner who tries to pin him down, or to find the cracks in his smooth persona. He approaches fans and critics alike with a grave, earnest, butter-wouldn't-melt-in-my-mouth demeanor. He has an air of determined reasonableness, as if he is leaning over the back fence chatting with his neighbor and can't understand why anyone would ever disagree. His is a consistent, carefully cultivated, folksy image that he insists is the truest reflection of himself and his East Tennessee roots.
While his admirers praise his ability to reach and persaude the public, his detractors call him a politician of the sound-bite era, better at symbol than substance. Either way, the success of the education reform will be Lamar Alexander's crucible in public life. And the question remains: Is his vision enough to save all American schools?
THE TENNESSEE CITY of Maryville is dotted with churches and ringed by the Great Smoky Mountains. When Lamar Alexander was growing up in the 1940's and 50's, the town had fewer than 7,000 people, and most of them made it their business to know his.
When he was in first grade and crossed the street on an errand for his mother, a neighbor called her to say she thought it wasn't safe. When the young Lamar was paddled in school for leading fellow ninth graders in a chorus of whooshing noises every time the teacher opened the window, he got in trouble all over again at home. This vision of small-town America, of communities, families and schools working together to celebrate achievement and enforce discipline, shapes the education plan Alexander is selling.
Accompanied occasionally by President Bush, he began criscrossing the country this fall to enlist "America 2000" communities that pledge to act to force radical change in schools. The President is proposing voluntary national tests to enforce high standards and shatter illusions by showing how students and schools really rank nationwide. To create models of excellence and get communities involved in thinking about education, the President charged business leaders to raise $150 million to help found at least 535 "break the mold" schools, designed by local groups with help from a team of experts. To force schools to change through competition with each other, even between private and parochial schools, the plan endorses choice and calls on Congress to allow Federal money for disadvantaged children to follow them to any school. The total price tag: $690 million.
There are few definite deadlines for action, which depends largely on local communities. Dozens of towns have already begun "America 2000" efforts. Design teams for the 535 "break the mold" schools are to be selected by next spring, and the first of the voluntary national tests are supposed to be given to fourth graders in the fall of 1993.
The plan raises several provocative ideas, like national standards and national testing. This strategy puts the focus squarely on public attitudes, which must change before schools can. The proposal issues a long-overdue challenge to families, who have too long blamed teachers for problems that are rooted in the home. In the American tradition of local control of education, the plan leaves many important decisions to individual communities.
But the plan shirks what have traditionally been Federal responsibilities -- like poverty, equity or desegregation. There are no specific ideas to combat the social ills that have destroyed in many areas the safe, disciplined world that Alexander knew. The grinding poverty that blights many children's lives and prospects of school success is not addressed. There is not enough money for health care or preschool classes like Head Start (a documented winner) that would help children be ready for school, one of the national education goals. The proposal does not talk about extensive teacher training or recruitment or the gap between rich and poor schools. Many educators fear that the plan's endorsement of choice essentially gives up on the idea of public education. Nor is it clear how the plan would transform entire school systems, rather than individual schools.
These omissions have drawn passionate criticism. "Is war over a desert sheikdom more important than the destruction of a million children?" says Jonathan Kozol, author of "Savage Inequalities: Children in America's Schools," a book about the gap between rich and poor schools. "No goal calls for equal education for rich and poor children. No goal breathes a whisper of the abiding American embarrassment of racial segregation. I feel bewildered, heartsick, that it is politically possible to omit what ought to be the two most pressing ethical goals of a just society."
Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, a Democrat who has led the governors' efforts to reform education and who has worked closely with Alexander, says that he applauds parts of the plan, but that it is not enough. "It's dangerous to answer the concerns of the nation with glib generalities," he says. "There are 110,000 schools out there right now that cannot wait. There are 30 states in a deficit position, cutting back, and we're dancing around the tent."
BY FAR THE MOST vociferous opposition has come on the voucher issue, the idea Alexander was plugging when he visited the Holy Cross School in New York. The presidents of the two national teachers' unions have bitterly attacked the plan, primarily because they fear parents will take their vouchers from public to private schools, leaving public schools short of money to teach those students who are either too handicapped or too disruptive to be accepted at private schools. Many educators who applaud the idea of choice still worry that children in the most desperate shape, those whose parents are indifferent or unable to choose the best schools, will end up stranded in the worst schools.
Alexander's friends say they believe that, if he could, he would spend more money on education, as he did when he was governor. In the tradition of most Tennessee Republicans, Alexander has consistently displayed a moderate, pragmatic bent, but now he is part of an administration that must satisfy a vocal and powerful right wing. That is the reason, some of his friends believe, Alexander pushes choice so hard.
Alexander offers a spirited defense of his plan, exhibiting his sometimes exasperating calmness and ability to skirt the details for the big picture. With an air of bland surprise, he says over and over again that he cannot understand why choice is an issue at all, because this is America and people can choose anything they like, so why not schools? Or, without raising his voice, he attacks doubters as elitist. To those who charge that the plan ignores the poor, he paints himself as their champion.
"What I really think people are saying is that we don't trust poor people to make decisions for themselves," he says. "The truth is, they don't and I do." Most of the criticism has come from educators and politicians, but Alexander is confident he can sell the plan to the voting public.
He sounds Republican themes of small government and faith in local enterprise. The proposal may sound vague, he says, but that is because each community must investigate the problem and come up with its own answers.
"Very few people understand what we're doing with America 2000," he says. "Over time they will. Everybody wants a how-to-do-it book today in American society. Everybody wants to be saved by a TV preacher. But you've got to, in the end, save yourself.
"We don't want to tell people how to have an America 2000 community. It would be silly for me to try to tell a professional educator how to teach a child, but I can help put that professional educator in a different sort of classroom or school where he or she can think about how to reach a much higher standard than we're now reaching. I can help a community introduce itself to reality by reminding them to watch MTV six hours a day like a lot of kids do and see what they think about that. They can go down to the neonatal care center or police station and find out how kids are growing up, sit in the back of a classroom for three hours and come to their own conclusions. It's frustrating to lots of people because after a while it hands them the ball. Leadership does point the way, but it doesn't walk for you."
ALEXANDER'S LEADERSHIP style, forged in his eight years as governor of Tennessee from 1979 to 1987, is reminiscent in many ways of Ronald Reagan's -- a skillful use of symbols, an approachable yet unflappable manner, and an understanding that the public resonates to broad themes simply stated, not to the details that interest Washington insiders or policy makers.
He formed that style with the help of his wife, Honey, and Doug Bailey, a consultant, after they told him he had lost his first race for governor in 1974 because he was too stiff and formal to reach voters. Bailey came up with the idea of walking across the state, and Alexander did, wearing a favorite red plaid shirt and spending each night in the home of a voter.
"Playing the trombone and walking across the state without a tie on and meeting people, that was the way I grew up," Alexander says. "So I guess I was more in my element."
Besides the governorship, Alexander gained from his walk an abiding conviction that he understands what people really care about and how to reach them -- a knowledge he used to rally Tennesseans for better schools and a host of other issues.
One of the first actions of his term set the pattern not only for his school reforms in Tennessee, but also for his strategy as Education Secretary.
He convened a jobs conference in Memphis to talk about the city's goals and strengths. In 1979, Alexander says, Memphis was a city battered both economically and psychologically. Out of the conference grew a successful promotion of Memphis as a major distribution center, an agricultural research center, a new hotel, a renovated performing arts center and a new emphasis on tourism and the city's blues heritage, according to Bill Gibbons, a Memphis lawyer and former assistant to Alexander.
From that experience, Alexander decided that communities did best when leaders helped them define their task, but stepped back to let them figure out how to achieve it.
In the first years of his term, Alexander sought jobs, and succeeded in landing two coveted automobile plants: the Nissan factory in Smyrna and General Motors' Saturn project in Spring Hill, near Nashville. But he concluded that Tennesseans would not get better jobs unless they got better educations.
As a result, Alexander became one of the first governors to start statewide education reforms. He presided over a series of changes, including merit pay for teachers, requirements that all students demonstrate mastery of specified basic skills before high-school graduation, tougher math and science requirements and computer literacy. He also called for mandatory public kindergarten. The teachers' union fiercely opposed his merit pay proposals, but after a tough fight, Alexander won the Democratic Legislature's approval of his plan, which was paid for by what he said was the biggest tax increase in Tennessee's history -- an interesting fact, given the lack of money in the "America 2000" proposal.
Tennessee's efforts won national acclaim. How lasting and important the changes were is still being debated. What no one disputes is that he roused a state that had been indifferent to education.
"Rather than trying to put your finger on any one program that made a significant difference in education, I think what happened in Tennessee under Lamar's leadership was we got down to the serious business of talking about education and got away from talking about the football games on Friday night," says John Jones, the Superintendent of Schools in Murfreesboro, who was Deputy Commissioner of Education during the last year of Alexander's tenure as governor.
Other indicators are less conclusive. Scores rose in most subjects in most grades on a series of tests that measured students' progress in basic skills, but S.A.T. scores stayed about the same. Teachers' salaries have risen, teachers are getting better training and tougher state university entrance requirements mean that more students are taking advanced math and science courses in high school.
Despite his unquestionable intelligence and his reputation as a knowledgeable education reformer, however, several educators who have worked with Alexander say they found him disappointingly superficial on the issues. One politician who works with Alexander and insisted on anonymity said, "There has been a lot of opportunity for me to hear, deeply, and I have not."
IF A SMALL-TOWN childhood provides security, it also often breeds a drive born of a determination to escape. Lamar Alexander's was a boyhood fueled by both emotions.
Maryville is hardly the poky mountain town or its children the arrant hillbillies that Alexander sometimes describes, with what he might call typical mountain hyperbole. It is a solidly middle-class bedroom suburb of Knoxville, and despite what were tight finances at home, Alexander grew up guided by middle-class aspirations.
Unlike those of Presidents Reagan or Bush, Lamar Alexander's background does in fact evoke the old-time American ideals on which a once-divorced actor and a New England patrician based their campaigns.
His mother ran a private nursery school and kindergarten, and his father was an elementary-school principal who took a job with Alcoa to earn more money for his family. His was a childhood of Boy Scout hikes in the Smokies, 4 A.M. wakings for paper-delivery routes and church on Sunday plus choir practice on Tuesday and prayer meeting on Wednesday. Piano lessons began at 3, and between schoolwork, church, Boy Scouts and chores, his mother made sure her son had plenty to occupy his considerable energies and decided mischievous streak.
"I knew from the beginning I had a little boy who was going to be into everything," recalls Floreine Alexander, a lively and opinionated woman who says herself that she is not known for her flexibility. "Our interests were church and school and music and books, and that's the atmosphere he grew up with."
It is clear that much of Alexander's politely masked but unmistakable drive was cultivated by his mother. When President Bush announced he was nominating Alexander as Secretary of Education, the new nominee made a minor grammatical error. Friends who met Mrs. Alexander around Maryville the next day recount that she told them, "He didn't learn to speak that way at home."
After high school, Alexander chose not to apply to Maryville College, the local college where his parents met. "It was the only time I ever saw his daddy get angry with him," his mother says. "I could tell when his ears turned purple that he was angry."
It was one of several choices that reveal contradictions beneath Alexander's smooth surface. At Vanderbilt University, he campaigned actively to allow blacks to become undergraduates -- an unpopular stand in 1962 that brought him and a classmate, the humorist Roy Blount Jr., threats of violence. He accepted a scholarship to New York University Law School, an unconventional choice for a would-be Southern politician.
At the same time he began grooming for a political future. He helped manage Howard H. Baker Jr.'s campaign for Senate in 1966, worked as his legislative assistant, and did a stint as an aide at the Nixon White House, acquiring the knowledge of Washington that serves him well now as secretary. He also amassed an ideologically diverse and influential circle of friends, including the author Alex Haley, Paul Tagliabue, the National Football League commissioner, who was his law-school roommate, Tom Johnson, president of Cable News Network and former publisher of The Los Angeles Times, and Judge John Minor Wisdom, the Louisiana judge known for his progressive civil rights decisions who hired Alexander as a clerk after law school.
Baker, whom Alexander includes as one of the people with the greatest influence on his life, recalls that his protege needed little training.
"He has a natural instinct for politics and public relations," Baker says. "He is a very even person. He can also be a very tough person. When he is very tough, even ruthless sometimes, he maintains that level of equanimity, calmness. I've never seen him blow up."
HIS POLITICAL opponents have felt his sting. Bill Nolan, a former Democratic state representative from Knoxville who supported Alexanderin his first run for governor, grew disenchanted when the new Governor impounded budget money set aside for higher education. Nolan and others sued the Governor, successfully, charging that Alexander tried to impound spending for Medicaid and declined to enforce a state law on hazardous wastes. Nolan says Alexander helped his opponent raise $50,000 and brought in several Congressmen to campaign against him, and he lost his next run for office.
"When Lamar has adversaries, he goes after them ruthlessly," Nolan says. "It was nothing for Lamar to say, if you do this, it's going to cost you."
By contrast, his friends tell of quiet acts of generosity. While a law clerk in New Orleans, he became friendly with Judge Wisdom's maid, whose husband was killed. Judge Wisdom recalled that when Alexander started practicing law, he sent her a check for $300, a large amount in 1966.
At the same time, his friends sense a certain remoteness. "He's a little bit mysterious in that he doesn't open up enormously," Roy Blount says. And Alexander's daughter Leslee, in an essay she showed him when she was 14, described him this way: "I characterize my father as an egret, standing on one leg and viewing the world. Although powerful in government, he is withdrawn in family life."
The description stung enough that he decided to take time off when he left office and flee with his family to Australia, a move that many warned would take him off the political fast track. In a charming, literate and self-deprecating memoir, "Six Months Off: An American Family's Australian Adventure," published in 1988 by William Morrow, Alexander wrote of learning the value of spending time with his wife, two sons and two daughters. Now, he acknowledges, he is back to being the busy politician and sees his children, now aged 12 to 22, less than he would like.
While Alexander's friends talk about him as a man of integrity, others have raised questions about his finances. In an August political storm, Tennessee newspapers were filled with headlines about Alexander's failure to disclose when he was president of the University of Tennessee that his wife, through a blind trust, retained a one-third interest in an East Tennessee resort where the university spent $65,000 for entertainment. University officials told Tennessee newspapers that they had not entertained very much at the resort before or after his tenure. They also said Alexander had assured them he had no interest in the resort, but did not tell them of his wife's interest.
Alexander says he acted on legal advice to avoid conflicts of interest by creating a blind trust to manage that investment and making his wife the beneficiary. Furthermore, he says, he and his wife had actually lost money on that investment, when the trustee sold their share in January for $2,000 less than they paid for it.
In addition, during Alexander's confirmation hearings for Education Secretary, investigators turned up what some Democratic Senators saw as questionable transactions, although no one said they were illegal or unethical. Democratic Senators charged, and a series of articles in The Wall Street Journal implied, that Alexander had used the high-level political contacts he had as governor to expedite lucrative business transactions once he left office.
Alexander says he was always careful to avoid any conflicts of interest, and any large profits have been due to his willingness to invest in risky start-up ventures.
"None of those ventures did business with the state of Tennessee, nor do they now, or with the Federal Government," he says. "I wondered why anybody would raise all this stuff. I think what surprises some people is that a governor would have enough sense to write a book or found a company, and I think that's just selling governors short. I could have gone to a law firm, done a lot of lobbying, peddled a lot of influence and made a lot of money. I thought that would be the most boring thing. I was helping to create something."
IN BETWEEN TRIPS around the country, Lamar Alexander sits in his new office in Washington. He favors a rocking chair with a cushion in his trademark red plaid, and on a rough-hewn desk is a carving of a plaid-shirted Lamar Alexander, striding across Tennessee.
The education plan is coming under increasingly strident criticism, but Alexander resists entreaties to endorse specific programs or provide more details. Asked to give examples of changes he likes, he mentions Murfreesboro, where his former Deputy State Secretary of Education charges parents a modest fee for child care before and after school hours; Vermont, where parents can use voice mail to hear their children's homework assignments, or a public school housed in Honeywell's headquarters in Minneapolis for teen-agers who have children or are pregnant. But he declines to endorse any particular educational approaches.
"We know plenty about learning," he says. "There are hundreds, maybe thousands of different ideas that would work. I think the problem is we haven't taken advantage of this last 20 years of technology to create systems that might help the school fit better into needs of families."
At least one prominent education analyst, who will continue to work with Alexander and spoke on condition of anonymity, says he believes that Alexander understands that his plan is in political trouble, and that he deliberately shies away from details in order to do what he has always done well in the past -- build coalitions and make compromises. "To get elected President, he's got to have a program that wins and the program he's got is not a winner," he says. "He'll be willing to modify it till he's put a coalition together."
If that is so, Alexander is not letting on. He talks about getting everyone on the train first, then arguing about what to do. But now Lamar Alexander, the train conductor, finds himself hectored by a sea of passengers wanting to know just where that train is heading.

HEADLINE: The Amish

 BODY:
To the Editor: In answering a question on whether there are any Amish communities in New York State (Q. & A., Oct. 20), you mention only the largest one, near Cherry Creek. Actually there are 14 Old Order Amish settlements in New York, scattered across 10 upstate counties. In most of these settlements a variety of crafts, baked goods and other products are sold by the Amish themselves. It is neither necessary nor advantageous to hire a guide or join a tour to meet and do business with the Amish. The "open" signs on Amish shops and homes attest that customers are welcome.
Cottage industry makes up an increasingly important part of the Amish economic base in New York, as in other states with an Amish population. For better or worse many Amish are far more accessible to the general public than in the past. From the visitor's point of view, being a customer goes a long way toward mitigating what might otherwise be an awkward and intrusive situation.
 
MARC A. OLSHAN
Associate Professor of Sociology, Alfred University
Alfred, N.Y.

LENGTH: 1760 words

HEADLINE: Buyers Insist a Bigger House Is Better

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
ARCHIE AND TERRI SIMONS of Newtown, Conn., are 40 years old. They have two incomes. They plan no children.
Edward and Kaye VanDyke of Fairfield, Conn., are in their 50's. They each have careers. Their three children have grown up and moved away. 
 Both families bought homes this year, but neither bought the condominium, town home or small house that might best fit their lives as "DINKS" (double-income couples with no kids) or empty-nesters.
Instead, they bought big houses (four and five bedrooms, respectively) with a wide range of modern amenities (both have Jacuzzis) and large lots (both have two acres).
"We wanted the biggest house we could afford," Ms. Simons said.
"I like a lot of space," said Ms. VanDyke.
The Simonses and the VanDykes are examples of American families, who, despite their shrinking size and the lingering economic recession, are buying bigger homes with more amenities on larger lots.
Home builders are well aware of the desires of buyers and are producing the bigger houses they want. The median size of new houses has been rising steadily year by year, according to National Association of Homebuilders, and hit 1,905 square feet in 1990. In 1970, the median size was only 1,350 square feet and in 1980 it was 1,595.
Moreover, the new homes increasingly have more expensive features. Of the houses built last year, 45 percent had two and a half or more bathrooms; 76 percent had central air-conditioning; 66 percent had one or more fireplaces and 72 percent had garages for two or more cars.
Lots, too, are getting bigger. Last year, the median lot size for a new house was 10,000 square feet, up from 8,875 in 1985.
What makes a larger home affordable during a recession?
For one thing, mortgage rates have plummeted. In April 1989, the national average for a fixed-rate, 30-year mortgage was 11.05 percent. Today, it is 8.5 percent. This, combined with the sharp decline in the price of many upper-end homes, have made some larger houses more financially accessible.
"I am building the same home today and pricing it for $100,000 less than I did last year," said Kevin Williams, president of Williams Contracting and Development Corporation, in Newtown. "A house that sold for about $450,000 a year ago, I'm selling for $350,000 -- and that is a pretty substantial drop."
"One thing is very loud and clear -- people want bigger homes," said Gopal Ahlunalia, an economist with the homebuilders association. "The size of homes has been on an upward track for 25 years." The pattern defies many projections made in the 70's and 80's that foresaw homeowners and home builders abandoning large houses for more compact and efficient, not to mention more affordable, models.
"Housing is a mystery," said George Sternlieb, a housing authority and the former director of the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University. "The only thing that seems sure is that Americans like lots of it."
SEVERAL reasons are cited for the continuing demand for big houses. A large part of the appeal appears to be flexibility. Maryanne DeGroote-Striano, 37 years old, and her husband, Peter, 40, intend to use the extra bedrooms in their new home as guest rooms and an office. They recently bought a 3,700-square-foot, four-bedroom house in Wycliff, N.J., for $414,000. They are planning, at the most, two children.
"If we have children, we don't think four bedrooms will be enough," said Ms. DeGroote-Striano, a lawyer who works in Manhattan. "We would probably need a fifth bedroom for live-in help."
Many economists and housing analysts also believe that because of exclusionary zoning laws in many suburban and rural areas, the only detached one-family housing that is built or bought consists of three-, four- and five-bedroom models.
"I find that you pick a location you like, and usually it is in a subdivision, and there are restrictions for certain size houses," said Rita VanHorn, who, with her husband, James, paid $350,000 for a 10-room, four-bedroom, 3,300 square-foot, colonial-style house in Newtown earlier this year.
Large homes appear to remain popular for their investment value, too. Rick Fernandes, a marketing executive, cited resale value as a prime factor for the purchase, with his wife, Lori, of a four-bedroom, five-bathroom, 3,700-square-foot home in the Greenfield Hill section of Fairfield, Conn.
The Fernandeses, both 33 years old, childless and planning no more than two children, paid $475,000 for the home. "Go for the biggest thing you can afford," Mr. Fernandes said. "If the market is at the bottom, the more you leverage, the more you will make."
"You buy them to sell them, even if you don't need the space," added Dr. Sternlieb.
Then there is the long-held American credo that bigger-is-better simply because it is bigger. "The United States middle class lives with more square footage than anyone else on Earth," said Leon T. Kendall, a professor of finance and real estate at the Kellogg Graduate School of Management at Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill. "We really are homebodies -- big homebodies."
Younger homeowners often seem to gauge their own comfort and affluence by what they had when they were growing up. "With a lot of people our age, baby boomers, even though they may have no children, I think there is sort of a trend back toward nostalgia, to the type of atmosphere you grew up in, a home, something warmer," Ms. DeGroote-Striano said. "Plus, I think people are spending a lot more time at home."
Older homeowners often want big homes as a way of holding on to their past. "I always had a big house when the kids lived at home, and now they will be coming to visit with my grandchildren," said Ms. VanDyke, who moved into a 3,000-square foot home. "Why should I get a smaller house? All of my friends, they move up from one big house to another. I don't have any friends that have moved from one big house to a smaller one."
The desire for more space appears to be a priority among prospective home buyers. Earlier this year, a National Association of Homebuilders survey of 1,776 families who bought homes in recent years found that they were living in a home with a median floor area of 1,826 square feet but would like to have a home almost 29 percent larger, 2,356 square feet. (The respondents, a third each of first-, second- or third-time buyers, had a median household income of $53,412.)
More than 70 percent of the respondents also would like to have two and a half bathrooms; one out of four would like more than three bathrooms.
"IN the past four years, we've done at least 60 houses at over 3,000 square feet," said Toni Curto, of Curto & Curto, a developer in St. James, L.I. "And a lot of the families buying those houses have only one or two children, and many have none."
When asked what trade-offs they would make if they could not afford the big house of their choice, 36 percent of the survey respondents said they would rather buy the home unfinished and 35 percent said they would rather live farther away from work in a less expensive neighborhood.
The survey also found that only 19 percent would want a smaller lot; 18 percent would want a smaller house and 11 percent would accept fewer amenities, such as a fireplace or a garage. "You have to think down the road, and you have to think about resale," Ms. VanHorn said. "A 3,000-square-foot house with two bedrooms would be an odd house and a hard resale."
Furthermore, the survey found that 60 percent of the respondents prefer four bedrooms or more and one-third of them prefer at least three bedrooms. Only 12 percent of the homeowners, however, would use four or more bedrooms for sleeping, and only 41 percent of them would use three bedrooms.
"If you plan to have family or friends over, you have to have a place to accommodate them," Ms. VanHorn said.
"I'm sort of an audiophile, and now I have a room for all my equipment," said Mr. Simons of Newtown, who recently moved into a new 3,200-square-foot home.
"WHAT you do with 3,000 square feet is the question, not what you do with four bedrooms," Mr. Kendall added. "They are using properties in a lot of ways these days. A four-bedroom house may not stay a four-bedroom house -- they are not going to use all four bedrooms, always. They may knock out a wall and make a suite."
The decline in prices apparently is not the major impetus for home buyers purchasing bigger homes. In fact, the median price of new and existing homes in the Northeast has fallen only moderately. In 1989, the median price for a new home was $159,600; for 1990, it was $159,000. The median price of existing homes fell from $145,200 in 1989 to $141,200 in 1990.
"Despite protestations by economists, marketwise, Americans want a house a little bit bigger than they can afford," Dr. Sternlieb said.
Ara K. Hovnanian, the president of Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank, N.J., the largest home builder in New Jersey, attributed the popularity of larger homes to demographics. He pointed out that, despite the declining overall size of the American family and a baby boomlet that is smaller than anticipated, a large bulge of baby boomers is still entering its prime child-raising years. (The size of the average American household has been falling steadily since the mid-1960's; the average was 2.62 persons in 1989 vs. 2.78 persons in 1979, according to the latest available Census Bureau figures.)
Mr. Hovnanian added that to meet the baby boomers' new familial requirements, his company is increasing the number of larger homes it plans to build. He also said there is an increased demand for larger homes on smaller lots and larger town houses.
"The average baby boomer is now between 35 and 45, and they are one of the major propellants to the housing market," he said. "They are maturing, nesting, having families -- having two or three children is not uncommon."
William C. Wheaton, former director of research at the Center for Real Estate Development at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, noted that the demand for larger homes is growing while the demand for starter homes is dwindling; the proportion of first-time buyers that make up new and existing home sales, according to the Chicago Title and Trust Company, has been fluctuating between 35 and 40 percent since 1981.
"The demand for entry-level housing will fall because of the baby bust," he said. "Those in the entry market now are those left over from the baby boom who are trying to get a piece of the dream while it is cheap."

LENGTH: 1096 words

HEADLINE: Talking: Refinancing;
Getting Around Hurdles

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
IT'S one thing to be told that interest rates are at their lowest levels in 17 years and now is the ideal time to refinance; it's another -- as many people are learning -- to actually get a bargain loan.
"I would read all those marvelous ads," said Thad McGar, who was eager to refinance his brownstone in the Chelsea secton of Manhattan, "but when I went to apply, the documentation was unbelievable." 
 About 10 percent of those who apply are being turned down, according to HSH, a mortgage monitoring service in Butler, N.J. But, says Thomas Hylinski, first vice president for residential lending at People's Bank of Connecticut, "there are things you can do to get around the problems."
Bankers say many people are rejected because of the erosion of values in the last five years, especially on the West and East Coasts. Many loans written in the mid-80's now exceed the customary 80 percent loan-to-value ratio limit and thus no longer qualify for refinancing.
Richard Rist, vice president of Shawmut Mortgage Company of Hartford, said this happens most often to people applying to refinance a luxury condominum, many of which have dropped over 30 percent in value.
In addition, lenders avoid properties considered high-risk for defaults as well as those that, if foreclosed, may be hard to sell. For instance, it is getting tougher to find a lender to refinance a vacation home unless the borrower can limit the refinancing to 70 percent of market value.
Vicki Papson, for example, was told that to refinance loans on her primary residence in Stamford, Conn., and her vacation home in Northport, L.I., she had to agree to cross-collateralize the properties -- let the lender seize one if she defaulted on the other.
Margaret Scott, president of Mortgage Advisory Services of Manhattan, a mortgage broker, warned that New York City lenders may also refuse to refinance a co-op in a converted building where the sponsor still owns a large number of shares. Also being shunned, she said, are studios, especially those under 450 square feet, apartments in walk-ups, co-ops or condominiums built on leased land and anything bought strictly for investment -- all deemed hard to sell now.
Qualifying the borrower has grown harder, too. The recession has left many people with lower income or even no income. Others may have taken on added debt or run up excessive amounts on their credit cards -- all of which adversely affect eligibility.
The lender may now also insist on certain repairs before approving a loan. Keith Gumbinger, an analyst at HSH, has found that the secondary market investors who buy most of these mortgage loans are adding more requirements. For instance, though the secondary buyers might have formerly sought only a market appraisal, they may now require a home inspection, too. Mr. Hylinski, the Connecticut banker, said that as a result, the borrower might be asked to repair the roof or certain leaks before being approved.
Lenders concede that rejections can be reversed or avoided with appropriate strategies. First, all borrowers should start by approaching the bank holding their current loan to see if it is offering special terms or rates to retain its mortgages. Staying with the original lender often can save on upfront origination costs for a new loan. Some lenders offer such deals.
Borrowers who suspect they may fall into a high-risk category should probably work through a mortgage broker instead of trying to go it alone. Mr. McGar did so because he had retired and his retirement income was 30 percent below what it had been.
Like an independent insurance agent, a mortgage broker has ties to many lenders as well as an awareness of which lenders have the most liberal policies.
USING a mortgage broker should not cost the borrower extra. Mortgage brokers normally are paid by the lender out of the "points" -- the amount the lender charges for writing the loan. The brokers, who can be found in the Yellow Pages or through real estate agents, are permitted, however, to charge the nonrefundable application, appraisal and credit-check fees normally charged by the lender.
Nancy Gordon, vice president of Globe Mortgage Company of Hackensack, N.J., said owners who suspect the value of their home may have dropped so steeply that refinancing is no longer feasible should begin by calling several local real estate brokers to get a realistic idea of current values. Most brokers will provide a free informal appraisal to build goodwill and the potential for a future listing.
If the appraisal indicates the 80 percent limit might be exceeded all is not lost. The borrower should offer to take out private mortgage insurance, which gives the lender more security by guaranteeing the loan. Premiums are based on the size of the loan. If the new loan represents 90 to 95 percent of value and if $100,000 is to be borrowed, the mortgage insurance is likely to cost $1,100 for the first year and $500 a year thereafter. If the same $100,000 represents 85 to 90 percent of value, the premium would drop to $450 for the first year and $350 thereafter. Premiums are normally divided into monthly amounts and added to regular payments.
The insurance can be lifted only if a reappraisal later shows that values have risen to the point where the loan now represents less than 80 percent of value. But it will be up to the borrower to ask the lender for an updated appraisal. Otherwise, the insurance will stay in place until the outstanding balance has been paid down to 80 percent based on the original appraisal -- normally 15 years on a 30-year schedule and 5 years on a 15-year schedule.
If household income has shrunk, the borrower should first find out if today's lower interest rates would let him qualify for the same amount anyway. Ivan Kaufman, president of Arbor National Mortgage of Westbury, L.I., noted that interest rates have tumbled so far that even borrowers with a 25 percent drop in income might still qualify.
Other bankers say an unblemished payment record for at least two years would encourage them to stretch conventional income limits to permit the refinancing. Mr. McGar squeaked through by noting there would be some freelance fees coming in.
Ms. Papson solved her problem by refinancing her primary residence only -- at least for the moment. She is now looking for a lender who will accept her vacation home as a separate deal. "Being right on the waterfront should make difference," she added, noting that a borrower should always bring such special attributes to a lender's attention.

HEADLINE: Tax-Credit Program on Borrowed Time

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
THE New York region stands to lose more than 3,000 units of low-income housing next year if the Federal Low-Income Housing Tax Credit -- scheduled to die on Jan. 1 -- is not extended by Congress before it adjourns later this month.
Since 1987, the tax-credit program has been the nation's primary source of Federal aid for producing low-income housing. In New York City alone it has been used to create more than 12,000 low-income apartments. This year, 1,157 more for families and 564 single-room occupancy accommodations are being developed, with about 1,000 more projected to be developed in 1992. 
 "For New York City and hundreds of communities all over America that benefit from the credit, an interruption of even a few months would be disastrous because it would undermine corporate confidence, stall projects now in the pipeline and slow the momentum that has been achieved," Mayor David N. Dinkins said in a statement released earlier this month.
The program also has made an impact outside the city. In the rest of New York State, 6,000 units have been built with the aid of the tax credit. An estimated 800 additional units are projected for 1992.
In New Jersey, the program has assisted in the development of about 5,000 low-income housing units. Should the program expire, it will halt about 800 to 900 units now in various stages of planning.
In Connecticut, the program has helped build 3,950 units, with 750 more projected for 1992. Many of the projects there are in suburban or rural areas. In Ridgefield, in Fairfield County, a 25-unit complex partly paid for with the tax credits opened last week.
"The program has proven itself as an effective program and one of the strongest incentives for the development of low-income rental housing," said Orest T. Dubano, president of the Connecticut Housing Finance Authority.
The program works by giving states Federal tax credits of $1.25 for each resident; in New York, for example, this is about $22.5 million. The state then gives the credits to not-for-profit or for-profit community development corporations interested in building low-income housing in their neighborhoods. The development corporations then trade the tax credits to businesses for investment capital, which is often leveraged to get additional funds from other sources. After 15 years, the project is sold to the developer for the remaining mortgage cost plus taxes.
Investors can deduct from their Federal taxes 9 percent of their investment each year for 10 years. Depending on the price paid for the tax credits, which is negotiated with the developer, annual returns of about 10 to 20 percent can be achieved.
"It benefits the bank with significant tax credits," said John Tamberlane, executive vice president with Republic National Bank, which has participated in the program. "And it benefits the community by providing affordable, rehabilitated apartments for individuals with low and very low incomes."
BORN out of the Tax Reform Act of 1986, the program was scheduled to expire at the end of 1989 but has been extended each year. Although the program remains popular with both parties in Congress and has been endorsed by President Bush, chances of another extension are marginal.
The executive director of the National Council of State Housing Agencies, John T. McEvoy, said that most of what little opposition exists to the tax credit has not been targeted on its cost -- for a permanent extension, about $5.3 billion over five years; for a one-year extension, $1.8 billion.
"It is a matter of timing more than anything," Mr. McEvoy said.
He said that the extension's best chances of passage would be as an attachment to the tax legislation now being considered by President Bush. That proposal, however, probably will not be debated by Congress until March. He added that if the tax credit extension were proposed by itself, it is likely it would become weighted with other, less desirable, tax initiatives.
"We're telling our folks that they have to expect a shutdown because we cannot give them a concrete assurance that Congress is going to pass a bill," Mr. McEvoy said.
Since its inception, the tax-credit program has helped build 94 percent of all the new low-income housing in the nation, some 440,000 units. This represents more than 35 percent of all housing starts in that period. Eighty-five percent of the units are occupied by tenants who pay $450 a month or less in rent.
Supporters of the tax credit said they will be satisfied with another one-year extension but would prefer to see it extended indefinitely.
"The annual lobbying to extend the credit has a detrimental effect on the production of affordable housing," Mr. Dinkins said, adding that budgetary constraints have already diminished state and local subsidies for low-income housing.
Paul S. Grogan, president of the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, added that even an abeyance of the program for a few months -- a scenario that he said was being considered by some in Congress -- could be catastrophic. The nonprofit corporation, through its New York Equity Fund subsidiary, links corporations looking for tax credits with nonprofit community-based developers looking for investment capital.
Mr. Grogan said that the uncertainty over future funding dwarfs other long-term problems the program faces in New York City, such as the dwindling number of city-owned buildings that can be renovated into low-income housing.
"No one could rely on assurances or raise any capital if the program isn't there at the end of the year," Mr. Grogan said. "We could rebuild the momentum, but there would be a real cost in investor relations and a serious reduction in the less tangible matter of confidence."
In suburban areas, the money generated by the tax credits is often used to build new housing. In urban areas, such as New York City, it is often used in conjunction with city loans to renovate city-owned vacant buildings.
Under Federal guidelines, apartments can be rented only to families earning no more than 60 percent of an area's median income. Tenants pay up to 30 percent of their annual income for rent. Maintenance on the project must be provided by the community development corporation.
"The program has been a success," said Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan. "Nearly all the credits allocated each year have been used by the states. Nearly every state has used up all of its allocated credits.
"When used at this rate," he added, "the program can develop over 120,000 units per year for low-income tenants."
GROUNDBREAKING for the city's newest project financed by the tax credit took place last Monday at the 71-unit Hattie Dodson Houses on West 131st Street in Harlem.
"The transformation of this neighborhood from an area known for having the highest concentration of city-owned abandoned buildings into a viable, economically integrated and socially healthy community is under way," said the Rev. Calvin O. Butts, a pastor at the Abyssinian Baptist Church and a board member of the Abyssinian Development Corporation, which is developing the project.
One of New York City's most successful projects has been a six-story brick structure at 1450 Bryant Avenue in the South Bronx that has been rebuilt by the Mid-Bronx Desperadoes, a not-for-profit community development corporation, into an 80-unit apartment complex. The building had been on a block of bombed-out brick, one of many that blight the area.
"It's so different, so much better," said Olfelina Sorian, a home attendant who used to live a few blocks away and moved last year into her new two-bedroom, $367-a-month rental in the building.
"The program works," added Ralph Porter, president of the Desperadoes. "And if it is not extended, then low-income housing is just going to stop around here and in a lot of places."

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Decontrolled Rent
 
Question: If a one-bedroom, rent-controlled unit with a maximum base rent of $600 a month is vacated, and another one-bedroom apartment in the same building is renting for $1,200, will the decontrolled one-bedroom apartment automatically rent for a minimum of $1,200 too? . . . Marjory Rice, Manhattan
 
Answer: No. The new rent would depend on several factors. The procedure for setting rents after a tenant moves out of a rent-controlled apartment in New York City is spelled out in Section 25-22.3 of the Rent Stabilization Code. This applies to apartments in buildings with six or more units constructed before Jan. 1, 1974.
The code says, in part, that the landlord of a decontrolled apartment has the right to set the first rent at a fair market level, which means what a similar apartment would rent for in the neighborhood. However, the first tenant after decontrol has the right to challenge that rent if he believes it exceeds what is fair for the market.
The landlord must file an initial rent registration form, which includes the new rent, with the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. The landlord must also give the tenant a copy of the form, via certified mail, within 90 days of the tenant's occupancy.
"The tenant then has 90 days to challenge the rent," said Joseph D'Agosta, an assistant commissioner for the agency. "If there is no protest, the rent is set and all future increases are calculated on the stabilized rent."
If the tenant objects to the rent and the housing agency agrees that it exceeds the fair market rate, the new stabilized rent can be calculated in one of two ways. In one formula, it is determined by adding 15 percent to the maximum base rent of the controlled apartment. In the other, that figure -- the M.B.R. plus 15 percent -- is added to rents on similar apartments in the same building, and then the average of those two figures provides the new stabilized rent.
The rent registration forms and forms for the Fair Market Rent Appeal are available at the central rent administration office, 92-31 Union Hall Street, Jamaica, Queens, and in the rent office in each borough office. In Manhattan they are at 156 Williams Street, ninth floor, and 163 West 125th Street, fifth floor.
More information is available by calling the Rent Administration Hotline at (718) 739-6400.
 
The Legal Fee on a Sale
 
Question: I recently inherited a co-op apartment, which I plan to sell. I understand that the board of directors requires that the seller pay not only his own legal fees, but also the fee of the lawyer handling the co-op's involvement in the sale. Is this legal? . . . Jo G. Trabucco, Woodside, Queens
 
Answer: Yes. Marc Luxemberg, a lawyer specializing in real estate matters, said it is common for co-op proprietary leases to require that legal fees be paid by the shareholder in cases involving the sale or transfer of shares. If the co-op uses the standard proprietary lease, he said, this provision will probably be in paragraph 16.
"If this owner refuses to pay the co-op's legal fees," said Mr. Luxemberg, "the board would be within its right to reject the sale."
 
New Rule for Tenants
 
Question: Recently I received a notice from the managing agent for my co-op concerning an extra payment for subletting. The board of directors has decided that after next January there will be another charge on subletting apartments.
As I recall, the bylaws mention an initial fee for approved sublets. Can the board pass new fees without amending the bylaws? . . . Rosalyn Levin, Brooklyn
 
Answer: They probably can. The bylaws of most co-ops give boards the authority to establish fees, among them sublet fees and flip taxes. Moreover, the right of boards to levy or increase fees without the specific approval of the shareholders has been upheld by the courts.
But to determine if the board has exceeded its authority, you should check the language of your co-op's documents.

HEADLINE: Bankruptcies Increase Sharply as the Stigma of Filing Fades

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
ACCELERATING a four-year trend of increasing numbers of bankruptcies in the state, residents and businesses have filed more than 18,000 bankruptcy petitions this year and are expected to file hundreds, perhaps thousands, more by the end of 1991, Federal Bankruptcy Court officials say.
With a record number of petitions already filed -- the vast majority for personal bankruptcy -- experts say the trend is reflective of more than just the fallout from the nation's vexing economic slump. 
 The bankruptcies, they say, though typically precipitated by unemployment or reductions in income, are often more deeply rooted in the frenetic consumer borrowing that was encouraged by banks and credit companies during the 1980's.
That, they say, along with a lessening of the stigma associated with bankruptcy and increasing anger at the anonymous forces that have unbalanced many borderline budgets, has led a record number of people to seek the fresh start afforded by the bankruptcy laws.
"It's almost uncontrollable," said Edward P. Bond, managing partner in the West Orange accounting firm of Bederson & Company, referring to the number of bankruptcies filed in recent years.
"Today, every major accounting firm and law office has established a bankruptcy department," Mr. Bond said, adding that in the past, bankruptcy work was often shunned by lawyers and accountants alike. "Now, my conception is that every attorney in the state has become a bankruptcy attorney," he said.
Mr. Bond said the effects of the current recession, coupled with tight credit, stretched budgets and diminished incomes, had created one of the most severe bankruptcy filing frenzies he had seen in 30 years in business.
By the end of August, New Jersey residents and businesses had already filed nearly as many bankruptcy petitions as the total number filed in all of 1990.
James J. Waldron, clerk of the United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of New Jersey, said that last year 15,394 bankruptcy petitions were filed by businesses and individuals in the state. By Aug. 31 of this year, Mr. Waldron said, 15,112 petitions had been filed. By Oct. 31, the number had risen to 18,783. By the end of the year, he said, the total filings are expected to exceed 20,000.
"It's impossible to react to that," Mr. Waldron said, alluding to efforts of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in New Jersey to deal with the rising number of filings. "You just kind of scrounge around as best you can and put Band-Aids on the problems by processing paper."
With only seven Federal Bankruptcy Court judges assigned to New Jersey, the state desperately needs another judge, he said. "Our judges are overwhelmed," he said.
The vast majority of filings, Mr. Waldron said, are for personal bankruptcies. Through Oct. 31, for example, 1,085 businesses had filed while 17,698 personal bankruptcy petitions had been logged.
In fact, while the number of business bankruptcies has remained fairly constant -- averaging about 1,000 each year since 1985 -- the number of personal bankruptcies has nearly tripled from a 1985 total of 5,977.
That does not come as a surprise to bankruptcy experts.
"It's like buying a new set of clothes," said Hugh M. Leonard, a lawyer with the Hackensack law firm of Cole, Schotz, Bernstein, Meisel & Forman. "It really should be a last resort, and for the most part it is, but there are some situations where it's used in a turnstile approach."
Mr. Leonard, who was the United States Trustee for bankruptcy courts in New Jersey, Delaware and Pennsylvania, said the "turnstile approach" had been made worse, at least in part, by law firms that advertise for bankruptcy clients.
"For the most part, I think they're factories," Mr. Leonard said. "You run into an office, you fill out the papers and you don't really understand the consequences."
A major consequence, Mr. Leonard said, is that after a bankruptcy "it takes people a while to rehabilitate their credit." Another, he said, is that those who file are effectively barred from filing another bankruptcy within six years.
Mr. Leonard said that when he was United States Trustee in 1979, there were about 250 bankruptcy filings each month in New Jersey. The current average for New Jersey is more than 1,800 filings a month.
Charles M. Forman, a Newark lawyer who specializes in bankruptcy law, said the only common denominator among people who filed for bankruptcy was that they had simply run out of options. "You have people from all walks of life now filing for bankruptcy," Mr. Forman said. "It runs the gamut from laborers who are dependent on overtime straight across the board to professionals like lawyers, doctors and chiropractors."
He said that among the reasons for many personal bankruptcies he had handled were the effects of balloon mortgages and home-equity loans that many property owners obtained in the early to mid-1980's.
A balloon mortgage, Mr. Forman said, is usually a short-term mortgage with monthly payments, often of interest only, calculated as if it were a long-term mortgage. After a specific number of years, the entire unpaid balance is due and payable.
"Years ago, people had conventional mortgages," he said. "But now, people have balloon payments coming due on these balloon mortgages and they can't get the refinancing they need."
Inability to pay off home-equity loans, he said, have also contributed to increased filings.
 
Trustees Are Busy
 "People underestimated the impact of home-equity loans on their household budgets," he said. "When you need two incomes to meet your budget, all it takes is for one of the partners to get sick or lose a job to put you right behind the eight ball."
Bunce D. Atkinson, a Red Bank lawyer who also acts as a trustee for the Bankruptcy Court, said he had seen "a tremendous increase in business over the last year and a half."
Mr. Atkinson said that in addition to lost employment and fewer work hours as the primary causes of bankruptcies, many people were also succumbing to financial pressures stemming from illness, overextended credit and divorce.
As businesses cut back on expenses, he said, many workers have lost their health insurance. Unexpected medical expenses not covered by insurance, Mr. Atkinson said, can place an insurmountable financial burden on a family with a fixed income.
 
Problems With Credit Cards
 And overextended credit, he said, which is at least partly a result of credit card companies' sending consumers unsolicited, preapproved credit cards, is also taking a toll on delicately balanced household budgets.
"People who use the cards always intend to pay them back," he said. "But when you're paying interest at 18 and 21 percent, it gets to the point where you can't even pay the interest back."
Even divorce, Mr. Atkinson said, contributes to the increase in bankruptcies. "Two households are more expensive to maintain than one," he said. "And in this economy, where both parties' incomes may be down, the divorce can push one or both of them over the edge."
Mr. Atkinson said that in his experience, filing a bankruptcy petition was "definitely not a move of convenience."
 
A Last Resort for Many
 Most people who file for bankruptcy, he said, do so "only after agonizing over whether or not they should do it." And most people, he said, do everything they can to avoid filing.
"They've utilized their savings, sold their autos to raise money to pay bills, and finally there's nothing left -- they don't have an alternative," he said.
Despite such reluctance on the part of individuals to file for bankruptcy, many experts say the stigma previously associated with insolvency is no longer as great as it once was.
"There's no question that the stigma as we usually know it has been removed from bankruptcy," said Dr. Stanley Fisher, a counseling psychologist speaking on behalf of the New Jersey Psychological Association in Livingston. "Bankruptcy by itself does not emotionally disturb all people," Dr. Fisher said.
He said an individual's reaction to being forced into bankruptcy depended upon a number of factors.
 
May Feel Anger or Depression
 "It depends upon the kind of people he's surrounded by and the kind of upbringing he's had," Dr. Fisher said. "He may be angry about it if he feels it has been forced upon him, or, if he believes that it's his own personal failure, he may feel depressed about it."
Not everyone perceives bankruptcy negatively. In fact, Dr. Fisher said, "there's a whole group of people who see it as a good business maneuver."
Albert Togut, senior partner of the Manhattan law firm of Togut, Segal & Segal, agreed that there was no longer a stigma associated with filing for bankruptcy. He said that with many large corporations filing for reorganization under the bankruptcy laws, the practice has now "gained respectability."
"Nowadays, the public's perception is that they don't care whether a company is in bankruptcy or not," Mr. Togut said.
 
Chance to Reorganize
 The reason, he said, is that the current bankruptcy code does not require a company to be actually insolvent to take advantage of the protections afforded under the law. A filing under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code, for example, allows a corporation in danger of insolvency to reorganize and restructure its debt in order to have a fighting chance at survival.
Not all companies that seek protection under Chapter 11, however, are ultimately successful in reorganizing. One of Mr. Togut's clients, Mr. Goodbuys, a Pennsylvania-based retail hardware chain with stores in New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania, is now liquidating after having filed for a Chapter 11 reorganization last May.
"At the time we filed, we expected to do a classic reorganization," Mr. Togut said. "We would adjust our debt through a Chapter 11 plan, and we would emerge as a smaller but healthy company."
 
Creditors Take Action
 As the economy continued to decline, however, the business that Mr. Goodbuys needed to continue in operation failed to materialize, Mr. Togut said. As a result, he said, the creditors of the company, in an effort to maximize the return on its remaining assets, requested a liquidation of the company.
"The goal was to do what was best for the creditors," Mr. Togut said.
Mr. Togut said the factors that frustrated the company's attempt at reorganization were essentially no different from those affecting individuals.
"People are often the victims of economic circumstances beyond their control," Mr. Togut said. "Thank God for the bankruptcy laws."
 
 
 
THREE TYPES OF FILINGS
 There are three common types of bankruptcy, said Brian T. Moore, the partner in charge of bankruptcy and reorganization for the accounting firm of Arthur Andersen & Company in Roseland.
Bankruptcies filed under Chapter 7 of the Federal bankruptcy code, he said, involve the liquidation of a business's or a person's assets to pay outstanding debts. Typically, creditors receive only a portion of the amount they are owed, if they receive anything at all.
For individuals, debts that are discharged are permanently forgiven. Debts owed for such things as alimony, child support, income taxes, student loans and certain other judgments and fines, however, are not dischargeable.
Chapter 11 bankruptcies, Mr. Moore said, allow for a restructuring of the debts of a corporation or a self-employed person. After the petition is filed, he said, the business continues to operate under the jurisdiction of the Bankruptcy Court.
A committee is created to represent creditors during the reorganization. A plan of reorganization is developed and the plan is submitted to the creditors for their approval and to the Bankruptcy Court for its confirmation.
Chapter 13 bankruptcies, Mr. Moore said, apply to people who have regular sources of income like salaries, wages or commissions. In a Chapter 13 bankruptcy, debts are adjusted or payments are made over an extended period of time. A Chapter 13 filing may allow a person to retain assets that would otherwise be lost in a Chapter 7 liquidation.
Both Chapter 11 and Chapter 13 bankruptcies can, under certain circumstances, be converted to a Chapter 7 liquidation by parties other than the debtor, Mr. Moore said.
Someone who has had debts discharged in bankruptcy, he said, may be barred from obtaining a subsequent discharge in bankruptcy for six years.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mr. Goodbuys in Lodi, a store owned by a Pennsylvania-based retail hardware chain that is now liquidating after having filed for a Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization. (Jack Manning for The New York Times)
