HEADLINE: Restitution Plan Aids Crime Victims

BYLINE: By TOM CALLAHAN

 BODY:
IN addition to their monthly bills for utilities and rent, 600 convicted offenders on probation in Westchester have a new bill each month under a year-and-a-half-old county program. As part of their sentence for committing a crime or misdemeanor, these offenders have been ordered to pay restitution to the people they victimized.
Since the beginning of this year, 853 crime victims in the county have received $1,147,397.71 in restitution for damages or losses sustained because of a crime. 
 A judge decides whether to impose restitution, but the collection and payment of the fines is the job of the economic sanctions unit of the County Probation Department. There are 7,656 probation cases in the county, and 600 of the offenders have been ordered to pay restitution.
While judges have issued these sentences for years, probation departments have had difficulty in the past collecting. "What happens in probation is that unless we treat something special, it can get lost in the shuffle," said Francis W. Maiolino, deputy director of the Probation Department.
"When dealing with sex offenders or drug cases, restitution often took low priority," she said. "It's nice to get money back, but we have to protect public safety, and that often means getting a guy into a clinic or rehab first."
Increasing restitution collections was one of the goals of Rocco Pozzi when he took over as Westchester Probation Director in July 1989. "When I arrived in Westchester, I made a commitment to the county executive to come up with a viable Economic Sanctions Unit," he said. "The amount of restitutions being collected were not as high as we would have liked."
 
Payment Process Speeded Up
 Mr. Pozzi established the sanctions unit in June last year. Before then restitution records were kept by hand by two full-time and four part-time accountants. Probation officers were responsible for collecting the money on a case-by-case basis.
"The process used to take three months from the time we received the check from the offender to the actual payment to the victim," said Nancy Lick, chief of planning, research and development for the Probation Department. "Now we have reduced that time frame down to one month."
Both Mr. Pozzi and Mr. Maiolino came to Westchester from Philadelphia, where Mr. Pozzi was deputy chief for probation and Mr. Maiolino served as director of that city's Economic Sanctions Unit. They decided to model Westchester's program on the one they developed in Philadelphia.
"What we did was consolidate the supervision and accounting function," Mr. Pozzi said. "We put four probation officers into the economic sanctions unit and computerized the accounting function, thus eliminating the part-time accountants. The computer is key because it does sophisticated accounting. It tells us instantly what's due and what's been paid."
 
Victims Are Often Surprised
 When a defendant is convicted, the Probation Department, as part of the presentencing report, determines the economic loss to the victims.
"People don't understand restitution," said Charles Brenner, supervisor of probation officers for economic sanctions. "They talk to the District Attorney, and then they are surprised to find out later that they can get money. We had people come to us after they received their first check and say, 'Am I really allowed to cash this check?' "
If a judge decides to impose restitution at sentencing, the offender's name and the amount owed is entered into the computer. The amount is generally pro-rated over the length of the probation sentence, which can be up to five years.
Victims then receive a letter stating how much they will receive each month, and offenders are given 12 numbered envelopes to mail into the Economic Sanctions Unit with the payments.
While many restitution cases involve medical expenses and loss of wages for victims of violent crimes, restitution can also cover crimes against property, such as vandalism, and white-collar, or business, crime. Indeed, one embezzlement case against three individuals yielded a restitution payment of $616,615 this year.
While conceding that this restitution award was largely responsible for the 192 percent jump in collection figures over the previous year, Mr. Maiolino said that even without that case, collections still increased by $135,000, or 26 percent over last year. Probation Department policy prevents divulging names.
 
Computer Keeps Eye on Payments
 "If Master Card can track millions of payments each month by computer, we can do the same thing for a more important system," Mr. Maiolino said. "We designed it to be just like paying your mortgage or phone bill each month. Like the banks and utilities, we expect payment by the first week of the month."
And as with common household bills, the computer knows exactly when the bill hasn't been paid. If that happens, the computer automatically sends the offender a delinquency notice. If that is ignored, a second and third notice are sent, with an arrest warrant issued after the third notice.
"The program is successful because most people on probation don't want trouble," Mr. Maiolino said. "The whole idea behind probation is staying out of jail." The sanctions unit has a success rate of 50 percent, taking in an average of 300 payments totaling $50,000 a month. Mr. Maiolino said he expected that success rate to increase by 10 to 20 percent each year.
"Who better to collect money than us?" he added. "We carry badges, allowing us to take people to court. We don't like to go that far. But some people don't think we will expend the energy on restitution, and they're dead wrong."
 
An Aid in Restoring Self-Esteem
 "We don't care if we are ordered to collect 5 cents or $5 million," Ms. Lick said. "If the victim loses because of a crime, they deserve to get it back. We work just as hard to get it back no matter what the cost."
In addition to aiding the victim, restitution helps probation officers keep track of an offender's education record and employment situation. "One of the things we are seeing because of this program is a younger element of kids getting jobs because they have to pay off the restitution," Mr. Brenner said. "And when a kid in trouble can get a job, it helps get their self-esteem off the ground."
Mr. Pozzi said he hoped judges would increase both the number and dollar amounts of restitution sentences. "Looking down the road, we want more cases," Mr. Pozzi said. "When we first arrived, people said wait and see. But we're now in a position to expand. Our computerized system can handle more."

HEADLINE: JUMP-STARTING NEW YORK

 BODY:
Peter D. Salins writes a very timely but somewhat idealistic article ("Jump-Starting New York," Nov. 3). He has the city's woes in a nice bundle, but some of his solutions lack a realistic view of the human condition. It seems to me that "social-assistance grants" will wind up being paychecks for drug dealers. Instead, why not pay some individuals an hourly wage to clean up the neglected parks, roadways and municipally held properties. This not only cuts some heavy spending but also instills a needed ethic.
Salins's views, I hope, will not go unseen by the next mayor in the next election.

HEADLINE: All About/Weight-Loss Programs;
Crash Is Out, Moderation Is In, And Diet Companies Feel the Pinch

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
After many years of wild growth, the $32 billion weight control industry is plunging into the valley of the 1990's with the recession to the right, regulators to the left, and the ever-expanding-and-contracting Oprah Winfrey looming in front.
Only the marginal companies are likely actually to go broke betting on the American avoirdupois roller coaster, but times are troubled. Ms. Winfrey's high-profile pas de deux with Optifast, which ended when she regained most of the the weight she had lost, devastated the very-low-calorie liquid diet market, which industry experts say is likely to contract. Reports of health problems after quick and drastic weight loss have depressed the diet-center segment. And even the venerable Weight Watchers International Inc., has been pressured by its competitors to retool. 
 The culture at large is changing as well. According to the Calorie Control Council, a light-foods trade group in Atlanta, the number of dieters has dropped to 48 million this year from 65 million in 1986 -- give or take 5 million "holiday" dieters in any given year. And research by Marketdata Enterprises, a market research firm in Valley Stream, L.I., indicates that only in the parts of the market that appeals to do-it-yourself dieters -- convenience foods and over-the-counter diet aids like pills, for example -- is growth either stable or rising.
"Consumers have begun to recognize because of proliferation of diet books and diet centers that the way to lose weight is through moderation and balance," said Phil Lempert, editor of the Lempert Report, a food industry marketing trends newsletter.
 
The Industry Doyen
Weight Watchers Holds Its Lead
 They call themselves the "lean, mean Lankenau team" -- a group at the Manhattan law firm of Lankenau, Kovner & Bickford that has been dieting together for nearly a year. The women are a virtual microcosm of the part of the dieting culture that industry loves to hear from: with 15 to 108 pounds to lose, they sought a regimen. Four are on supervised programs -- three on Jenny Craig, one on Weight Watchers -- and two have been chugging those libations to anhedonia, the over-the-counter protein shake, on their own.
Josephine Hauck, the firm's office manager, started the trendlet at Lankenau last January when she decided to lose weight for her son's wedding. Ms. Hauck chose Jenny Craig on the advice of an acquaintance. "I felt like a dumpy old lady. That was not how I wanted to be in life, and it was certainly not how I wanted to be remembered in the album," she said.
Jenny Craig International, the No. 3 company in the $2 billion commercial diet-center segment, combines a regimen of company-provided foods, called Jenny's Cuisine, with counseling and a gradual reintroduction of independent eating. The program's approach of providing prepackaged food is similar in many respects to that of Nutri/System Inc., the segment's No. 2 company. The core at Weight Watchers International Inc., the Jericho, L.I.-based leader, with about $300 million in sales, and some five million members, is still its trademark meeting: part testimony and revival, part nutrition education, part pep talk.
This year, Heinz, which owns Weight Watchers, made its convenience foods a separate company, in Pittsburgh. Heinz, analysts say, has been slow to respond to such fast-growing products as Conagra's Healthy Choice frozen entrees. Last week, Weight Watchers Food announced that its winter ad campaign -- "Total Indulgence. Zero Guilt." -- would proceed without its longtime spokeswoman, Lynn Redgrave.
 
Selling Convenience
Jenny Craig's No-Fuss Approach
 Weight Watchers International, which runs the meetings and sells franchises, has been nudged into innovating, particularly by Jenny Craig, which just completed a public offering to raise money for development. Jenny Craig's prepackaged meals have lured dieters who don't want to fuss with food preparation. "People are extraordinarily busy these days, especially women, who are 95 percent of our members. They say they'd like a more convenient, one-stop shopping approach," said Charles Berger, the president of Weight Watchers International. It is testing a Jenny Craig-like storefront system. At Lankenau everyone has made it to her goal weight or is dropping weight steadily and determined to stay in for the long haul. "I look at a cookie now and say, 'Do I really want to eat this?' When I cheat now, I cheat with a piece of fruit," said Fran Dissinger, another Lankenau dieter. The success of Lankenau's team sends one ominous message to the diet industry. "Anyone with the right motivation and right program for them at the moment can lose the weight," said Betsy Taylor, program director of Health Extenders, an independent weight-loss center in Norwalk, Conn., which offers a variety of approaches to losing weight.
But nobody in the business is worried that Americans will abandon their obsession with weight. "The desire for weight loss is very powerful. It's tied up with basic human desires like greed and sex," Mr. Berger said, adding: "The only thing that happens is that the solution people select to weight-loss problems shifts around."
 
A New Scrutiny
The F.T.C., F.D.A. And Congress, Too
 The forms of fraud in the weight-loss industry over the years pay homage to human imagination -- and gullibility. Since the first case in 1926, which involved a cream that supposedly melted fat, the Federal Trade Commission has taken action against a long list of improbable products including sunglasses that, the maker claimed, altered the color of food, making it unpalatable.
"Americans always want a quick fix," said Representative Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, who last year sponsored hearings on the diet industry in Congress. "It is almost in the chromosomes. We want results in 20 minutes."
Mr. Wyden's hearings targeted a considerably more respectable segment of the industry -- liquid diets, usually administered in medical settings -- than the fringy products the F.T.C. typically goes after.
Last month, the F.T.C. announced consent agreements with three liquid diet makers whose advertising practices it had investigated. Sandoz, which markets Optifast; Jason Pharmaceuticals, which makes Medifast, and the National Center for Nutrition Inc., which produces Ultrafast -- no relation to Ultra Slim-Fast, the over-the-counter powder -- have agreed to abide by an F.T.C. directive to disclose health risks and back up their long-term weight-loss claims.
Mr. Wyden wants the F.T.C. guidelines extended to the entire industry. "The F.T.C. is off to a solid start, but there's a tremendous amount to do," he said. "It's very unfortunate that industry has gone without scrutiny for so long."
The F.T.C. is still looking into liquid diet makers and commercial diet centers. The Food and Drug Administration, meanwhile, is scrutinizing the $1.3 billion appetite-suppressant market.
 
 
 
LURING MEN TO THE DIET TROUGH

At any given time, according to Marketdata Enterprises, which publishes a consumer guide to weight-loss programs, half of the women in the United States and a fourth of the men are on diets. Male dieters have proved elusive to the diet industry, although industry experts believe there are as many overweight men as women. They say men are less likely to acknowledge a weight problem and even when they do are more likely than women to be do-it-yourself dieters or to head for the gym.
Some 95 percent of Weight Watchers' members are female, a number the company concedes is unlikely to grow much. "When we get a man," said Charles Berger, president of Weight Watchers International, "he's one of 5 to 7 percent. He walks into a room of 40 people, mostly women. The discussion veers toward women's problems, and he gets bored."
Slim-Fast, a unit of the Thompson Medical Company, was pleasantly surprised when its "regular guy" spokesmen, Tommy Lasorda and Dan Dierdorf, both sports figures, seemed to attract business from men. Thirty-five percent of Slim-Fast's customers are male, unusual in the industry. And the football-baseball angle seems not to have turned off women: "They see Dan Dierdorf and say 'if he can do it, I can definitely do it,' " said Barri Rafferty, Slim-Fast spokeswoman.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
There's Still Some Flab In the Dow

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:
Even for Laszlo Birinyi's consulting firm, which watches historical trends as closely as anyone, it took a while to figure out that the Dow's 120-point drop Friday a week ago was only the 134th-largest percentage decline in the history of that index. But if the Nov. 15 squall presaged no hurricane, neither did fair weather return. With the economic outlook still dark, the market fell another 40 points to 2,902 by week's end.
In recent years, sharp drops like the Nov. 15 one have presented buying opportunities. But so far, the brave souls have held back. Some analysts think it's simple: even after the drop, stocks are still pricey. And, as the Birinyi Associates research implies, a 3.9 percent drop, although painful, is just not all that huge. Remember that the Dow dropped 22.6 percent in the 1987 crash, 6.9 percent in October 1989. 
 The worst days in recent years have brought price-earnings ratios down to at least moderate levels -- 16 after the crash of 1987, 14 after the 190-point drop in 1989. But last week, it seems, the bargain-hunters never went shopping because bargains were few. A Standard and Poor's 500 that many regarded as overpriced at 20 times earnings before the drop was still no bargain at more than 19 times earnings on Friday.
Short-term interest rates, a crutch for a market that would otherwise be immobilized by weak earnings, fell again last week. But James Grant's a newsletter on interest rates, emphasized two more ominous signs:
First, the dollar continued its decline, reflecting and possibly aggravating the withdrawal of foreign investors from American markets. Second, the flight to the safety of Treasury securities, expected after a sharp stock decline, was confined to shorter maturities; bond yields actually rose. Wall Street loves Republican Presidents, but Mr. Grant fears George Bush will embark on an inflationary course to revive the economy before the election -- corroding the value of stocks and bonds.
After months of placid gains, the suddenness of the decline a week ago was actually more remarkable than its size. For all the talk about program trading, the markets are only slightly more jumpy than in recent decades. "Volatility has gone up somewhat, but not as much as the public perception," said Burton G. Malkiel of Princeton University.
Panics do occur, he added, and stocks tend to fall more abruptly than they rise. The Dow has had one-day drops of more than 100 points seven times, but has risen that much only three times. The more-frequent plunges represent virtually the only sensible occasions for a buyer to try to time the market, Mr. Malkiel said. But not this time around. "I don't think this was much of a decline," he said.
The Nov. 15 drop was, perhaps, underdone, not overdone -- smaller in percentage than dozens of movements now forgotten. These days, the fifth-largest point decline in history turns out to be not so historic after all.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Equities March Their Separate Ways

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
When stock markets worldwide fall as they did early last week, it fosters the belief that they always dance to the same tune -- in this case the 4.3 percent swoon of the Dow Jones industrial average from Friday, Nov. 15, through last Tuesday.
Actually, markets around the world do not move in lockstep very often. And because of the weakness of the correlation among world markets, European stocks could offer an interesting opportunity for Americans in the next several months, especially if Wall Street declines slowly. 
 The key here is the speed of the American retreat. World markets are more likely to move down at the same rate as Wall Street if the American move is fast and large because that tends to spook investors everywhere. This is what happened in the 1987 crash, the mini-crash in 1989 and the one-day tailspin after the coup in the Soviet Union. Last week, the Dow was off again on Friday, falling 29.96 points, or 1 percent.
"In periods of high volatility, markets pay more attention to each other, and this happens even when there is no obvious common news event," like a war or oil price jump, that would affect everyone, said Sushil Wadhwani, director of European equity strategy for Goldman, Sachs & Company in London.
But if the decline in the United States is slow, markets in Europe are likely to move more to their own domestic beat than to Wall Street's. This could even mean some rallies abroad.
Underlying market forces look better in Europe than in the United States for the next several months because of Wall Street's growing unhappiness about the uncertainty and sluggishness of the American economic recovery. The Japanese stock market could also offer the same opportunity.
One reason for a divergent performance is that a slow United States recovery will have less impact on European companies than on American ones. The country with the largest exposure through exports or subsidiaries in the United States is the Netherlands, where 34 percent of earnings are American based, according to Goldman Sachs.
The dependence on the United States drops from there. In Switzerland, 25 percent of the earnings are tied to the United States; in Britain, the earnings factor is 20 percent American. In Germany and Italy the factor is down to 10 percent; in France it is only 5 percent and in Spain, 3 percent.
Interest rates, which can spark a stock market rally by falling, are now about twice as high in Europe as in the United States and thus have the potential to fall sharply.
In addition, European stocks in general tend to be a better value -- selling at lower multiples of earnings -- than American stocks. And in some markets, particularly Germany, stock market indexes are still far below their record highs.
"Europe will split off," predicted David Roche, international strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company in London. He expects the Dow to fall a few hundred points more. But as long as the decline is gradual, he said, the prospects for American investors are better abroad than on Wall Street.
The German and Italian markets mirror Wall Street's moves the least, based on the measurement of correlations between markets by Ennis, Knupp & Associates of Chicago, the percent of earnings exposed to the United States and the sensitivity of European markets to a fall in the dollar, which has dropped 7 percent against the mark in the last four weeks. France is also quite independent, but its correlation to the United States is higher for the last five years than for the last 20 years.
The European countries least able to resist Wall Street's call are the Netherlands, Switzerland and Britain, which all have closer -- but still not slavish -- correlations to the United States and higher exposures to a dollar decline and a slow American recovery.
The Ennis, Knupp correlations show that over time many leading markets are not particularly close followers of the United States. But, as the numbers also show, these correlations can change, depending on the period covered.
The reaction of European markets last week may also have signaled a break in the follow-the-leader flops of the past. Many stock markets in Europe declined less than the Dow Jones industrial average this time. And the markets that had the steepest falls, France and Britain, were responding to domestic problems as well as to Wall Street.
For example, the German stock market's DAX index of 30 shares dropped only 1.9 percent, compared with a 4.3 percent drop in the Dow through Tuesday. But in the three-day mini-crash in October 1989, the German market plunged 7.7 percent, twice the Wall Street slump of 3.8 percent.
Spain's stock market, which fell 3.4 percent in October of 1989, dropped only 1.1 percent in this episode. Italy's stock market was down just half a percent at the beginning of last week. But it dove 21.9 percent at the beginning of the Persian Gulf crisis, almost twice the 11.2 percent fall on Wall Street.
"Certainly our traders were glued to the screen," Mr. Wadhwani said. "But we did not have the same slavish dependence on the United States in Europe in respect to the size of the decline."
In France and Britain, the sharp stock market declines were mostly a response to problems at home. In France, the 5.4 percent fall of blue-chip stocks came after the Bank of France's surprising increase in official interest rates on Monday. The rise was made to support a weakening franc in the European Monetary System.
In Britain, the stock market fell more than in Germany but less than in the United States, with the FT-SE index of 100 shares off 2.9 percent through Wednesday. Much of the fall was because of a weakening pound, which eliminated a chance of another cut in interest rates soon. The pound and the FT-SE fell further on Friday.
"The real message is that the reason you get a very sudden kind of coordinated fall around the world's markets is a panic reaction," Mr. Roche said. "But the panic this time was quite limited. People looked and saw that the United States had a major problem but that those problems are not the same for the rest of the world."

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Setting the Pace On Discounts

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
With their industry awash in red ink, most airline executives say that only increased traffic and higher fares can restore profitability. But USAir has set its rivals' teeth on edge by periodically offering discount fares -- most recently, earlier this month -- and some analysts think the carrier may be on the right track.
The credit for the move -- or the blame -- must go to Seth E. Schofield, the 52-year-old president and chief executive of USAir Group and its principal subsidiary, USAir, based in Arlington, Va. 
 Since taking over last June in the depths of the worst slump in airline history -- 34 years after he joined the carrier, which used to be Allegheny Airlines -- Mr. Schofield has been busier than the proverbial one-armed paperhanger.
In addition to imposing the discount fares, he realigned USAir's hub system and eliminated flights within California to refocus on the carrier's traditional East Coast markets. The airline, which already has more daily departures from La Guardia Airport than any other carrier, recently moved to add even more by agreeing to buy 108 arrival and departure slots from Continental Airlines for $61 million.
USAir executives defend the fare cuts, saying they are for travel during off-peak periods and are aimed at passengers who might otherwise not fly. "Those are the only price cuts that make sense," said Daniel A. Hersh, a Denver-based airlines analyst with the Kemper Securities Group. "If you impose restrictions and control the seats available on each flight, as USAir is doing, you can generate more revenue when times are bad."
Mr. Hersh also said that Mr. Schofield, who was unavailable for an interview, appears to be "going in the right direction" in striving to reduce the airline's costs, which have long been among the highest in the industry -- in part because of its many short flights.
Another cornerstone of Mr. Schofield's strategy is USAir's acquisition of up to 40 Boeing 757-200 jets from the Boeing Company and the General Electric Capital Corporation. The new planes will add greater economy and flexibility to USAir's fleet. And as part of the deal, G.E. Capital will purchase 15 smaller 737-300's from USAir for $330 million and lease them back, bolstering the airline's cash position.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
The 9.5% Credit Card Bank

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
A week or so ago, big banks -- and Wall Street -- screamed in pain and panic when the Senate considered putting a 14 percent cap on credit card interest rates. How's a bank supposed to make a living, much less a profit, without charging the more typical 18, 19, 20 percent?
Simple, says Robert C. Dill, executive vice president and marketing director of Simmons First National Bank of Pine Bluff, Ark., one of the banks that regularly appears at the top of lists of low-interest cards. 
 "We are interested only in good credit risks -- people who have a habit of paying bills," said Mr. Dill, adding, "If you don't have excellent credit, it is unlikely you will get a card from Simmons." Those who do get one have to pay an annual fee ($25) and forgo the 24-hour access to account information that the big card issuers provide.
Mr. Dill and his bank are, contentedly, of the "when you've got a lemon, make lemonade" school: Arkansas has some of the nation's most stringent usury laws, mandated by the state Constitution. Banks may charge no more than five percentage points above the Federal discount rate; at the moment, interest on Simmons's Visa and Mastercard is 9.5 percent. 
Because of the rate limit, Simmons was never tempted into competing for the higher credit risks whose inability to pay during hard times is now giving the bigger issuers grief. As a result, Simmons's write-off rate for uncollectible accounts is less than one-third the national average. Simmons's 161,000 active credit card accounts constitute 39 percent of its loan portfolio, and an "important part of the profitability" of the $600 million bank, Mr. Dill said.
A 48-year-old native Arkansan, Mr. Dill has been with Simmons for 25 years, long enough to remember the last time people were so concerned about card rates, at the end of the Carter Administration. Simmons got so much attention then that it finally had to cut off out-of-state applicants.
Such a move may be necessary again. Simmons normally gets 2,500 to 3,000 requests a day for credit card applications. Since the rate-cap debate began, it has been getting four to five times that many.
"If you turn and look out your window toward Arkansas," Mr. Dill said, "you will probably see the smoke rising from our switchboard."

HEADLINE: Will the Recession Always Be With Us?

BYLINE: By JOEL KURTZMAN

 BODY:
A year ago, when the economy tipped into recession, most economists were quick to say the downturn would be atypically short and shallow. They forecast a couple of quarters of negative growth brought on by uncertainty in the Persian Gulf and the looming war with Iraq.
The recession was on the shortish side, as Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at CRT Government Securities and Donald Ratacjczak of Georgia State University predicted 10 months ago in this space. It lasted barely three quarters before the White House declared it over, though the National Bureau of Economic Research -- the official referee of recessions -- has yet to make the call. 
 But the recession was not shallow. With a 2.8 percent contraction in the first quarter of 1991, it was not much different than the average post-World War II recession.
But the real concern now is the weakness of the recovery -- predicted here last year by A. Gary Shilling, an economic consultant -- which is far from normal. According to the Commerce Department, growth returned in the third quarter of the year, but with a whimper, not a roar. Gross national product grew by a modest 2.4 percent, far below the average rate for most postwar recoveries.
"In eight of the last 10 recoveries, first-year real GNP growth averaged 6.7 percent," said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company. "Two recoveries had growth rates of just 2 or 3 percent -- in 1970 and 1980. They were short lived," he said.
Such a poor showing so far has caused some economists to worry that the economy may "double dip," -- a less-than-technical way of saying the country may topple back into its slump. "The odds of a double dip are 50-50," Mr. Sinai said.
Consumers are worried too. The monthly Consumer Confidence Survey by the Conference Board, a business group, shows consumers growing more jittery each month since the end of the war in the Persian Gulf.
But what concerns economists most about confidence is the category called "expectations." It rates how people feel about their business and employment prospects. It is directly related to the way they spend. When consumers feel chipper, as they did in 1985 when the overall index hit 100, they buy, fueling growth. The overall index fell to 60.4 in October, its lowest level since January. "The October reading is down quite a bit," said Fabian Linden, the survey director. "It says the economy is still in a bit of a mess."
Slacking consumer confidence prompted concern at the White House. Last week, President Bush called a group of reporters to his office to remind them of some of the economy's strengths. "Inflation is down. Interest rates are down. Personal debt is down. Inventories are down," Mr. Bush said. He reminded them of the growth in exports and attributed the current gloominess about the economy to bad press.
No economist disputes Mr. Bush on these numbers. The economy has recovered, but too slowly. "It may sound trite," said Mr. Levy, "But 2.4 percent is not enough growth to lift all boats."
Financial services, real estate and business related services are still stuck on the shoals and the automobile industry is stumbling through its worst year of losses ever. Though housing starts jumped 7.4 percent in September, the housing industry is likely to have its first year since World War II with fewer than 1 million housing starts.
Ordinarily, Congress and the Administration can spark growth in a recovery through increased spending or by cutting taxes. This time, however, the government is constrained. A year ago in September, the White House hammered out a budget agreement with Congress that included spending cuts and a tax increase aimed at reducing the Federal deficit. Rather than provide the economy with a fiscal kick, those measures, some economists now say, helped nudge the economy into its slump.
The budget agreement "was a drag on growth," said Mr. Ratajczak. Nevertheless, it remains in place. "You probably need fiscal stimulus to really get growth going," he said. Mr. Ratajczak and many of his colleagues, are now less worried about the deficit than they are about sluggishness in the economy. "When you have a $300 billion deficit, what's another $20 billion?" he said.
One effect of the budget agreement has been to shift the entire responsibility for an economic rebound onto the shoulders of the Federal Reserve Board. Since the beginning of the year, the Fed has pushed down the interest rates it controls. The discount rate -- the rate the Fed charges banks for overnight borrowing -- dropped from 7 percent in January to the current 4.5 percent.
The prime rate has followed, down to 7.5 percent from 10 percent last year. With so many outstanding loans at variable rates, the rate drops have put money into the pockets of the consumer, as much as $50 billion, by some estimates. But with nervous consumers unwilling to spend, those dollars remain idle.
So what's ahead for the economy?
Mr. Shilling's model, which operates under the assumption that there is too much debt in the economy, thinks the economy will flail for another year before it recovers, providing a double-dip recession. Mr. Levy, who sees the economy drained of its vitality by three years of weak corporate profits, foresees lackluster growth with low inflation. Mr. Ratajczak's numbers show the recovery picking up slowly through the fourth quarter of 1993, with interests rates holding steady. Mr. Ratacjczak foresees a recovery, but without much oomph.
 
 
NO ,SAY THREE EXPERTS, BUT THE FIX WON'T BE QUICK

 
 
MICKEY D. LEVY
 
Chief economist, CRT Government Securities in New York.
The good news is there will be no "double dip," according to Mr. Levy. The recession really is over. But the bad news is that the recovery will be anemic and growth will be slow. "We're in an elongated trough," said Mr. Levy. That means any recovery will be uneven. Services, in Mr. Levy's view, will miss much of the recovery -- especially financial services, real estate and business services like accounting. Retail trade will rebound -- modestly. Exports should continue with some strength, so the Midwest will continue to outperform the East. "The economy will now start moving sideways," Mr. Levy said. The economy's problems began even before the recession. In mid-1989, "profit margins were being squeezed and employment growth was slowing," he said. That burden makes it likely the economy will remain virtually flat through the first quarter of 1992, then expand slowly.
 
 
DONALD RATAJCZAK
 
Director of the Economic Forecasting Center at Georgia State University, Atlanta.
Mr. Ratajczak thinks growth in the gross national product will be sluggish -- a slim 1.0 percent in the first quarter -- accompanied by a gradual increase in inflation. "We've stopped building apartments for so long now, rental rates will pick up, fueling some inflation," he said. Energy prices are also expected to rise moderately. Later in the year, growth inches up to 1.2 percent in the second quarter and gradually makes its way to a lackluster 2.3 in the third quarter of the year. "Nothing's moving in the economy," Mr. Ratajczak said. In his view, a change in the habits of the consumer is part of the problem. "The consumer is downsizing his expectations," he said. Part of the reason for reluctance among consumers to shop the malls, is that they are uncomfortable with their current level of debt. "Consumers are scared about the future," Mr. Ratajczak said.
 
 
A. GARY SHILLING
 
President of an economic consulting firm in Springfield N.J., that bears his name.
Mr. Shilling has been gloomy about the economy for quite some time, and his economic model is forecasting a double-dip recession with unemployment climbing to almost 10 percent. The nation will slip back into a slump, Mr. Shilling says, by the first quarter. "The principal reason for the double dip is the debt overload. It's a balance-sheet recession. The first one since the 1930's," he said. Mr. Shilling says the economy will not make it to higher ground until at least the end of 1992. What might help push things along is "an across the board tax cut of 5 percent or 10 percent like there was in 1975," he said. "Congress shouldn't take time to rejigger the rates, just cut taxes and link the cuts to some offsetting cuts in defense." Though that might throw some sand in the bottom of the trough, so the decline would be more shallow, the nation's overall level of indebtedness would prevent growth from being robust.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1757 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/November 17-22

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
Battle Shapes Up Over One of America's Last Areas of Dominance 

Jacques Attali, the French economist and philosopher, said America really only leads the world in computers and commercial aviation. In aviation, he said, it has a near monopoly. That's what keeps America competitive. But last week McDonnell Douglas decided to sell off 40 percent of its commercial airplane business for about $2 billion to a Taiwanese investor group that includes that country's government. A lot of people began wondering. Would McDonnell Douglas be forced to use Taiwanese suppliers? Would Taiwan's government subsidize it to the detriment of rival Boeing? "Without this alliance and international risk-sharing partners, we will be unable to grow as a commercial aircraft company," said John F. McDonnell, the company's chairman. That may be so, but Senator Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico, fired off a letter to President Bush questioning the deal. Twenty eight Senators co-signed. Hearings are planned; the deal could still unravel.
 
 
A Very Sober Look at Salomon
 
Marred by a summer's worth of scandals, Salomon Brothers Inc. is seeking to redefine its image. Last week, the word on the Street was that Solly would dismiss as many as 135 professionals. "People are just stunned," one Wall Street executive said. As many as 15 managing directors are also expected to go by the end of the year. That could change Solly's direction, since managing directors are the executives who set the firm's policy. The employees who remain are to refocus the firm on its core bond trading business, observers say. Scheduled for paring down: Solly's global equities, investment banking and real estate businesses.
 
 
Big Deal in Desktops
 
One of the largest contracts for small computers went to two little-known companies last week. The Compuadd Corporation of Austin, Tex., and Sysorex Information Systems Inc., of Falls Church, Va., will share a $1 billion contract from the Defense Department to build desktop computers based on Intel's i286, i386 and i486 chips. Compuadd -- which did not turn in the lowest bid -- has had experience with the Pentagon before. During the Persian Gulf buildup, it shipped $30 million worth of computers to the gulf from Texas in just six weeks. That impressed military leaders. Zenith Data Systems and Apple Computer Inc. were among the losers.


Cadillac's Recharged Pizzazz
 
Cadillac once touted itself as as the "standard of the world." Then came a host of competitors from across the seas, Europeans and Japanese nibbling away at Caddy's market and its image. Enter the new Seville and Eldorado models -- in the $32,500 to $38,500 range. They received rave reviews from the auto press for styling and (yes) technology. Drivers praised their nimbleness -- no land yachts, these. Best of all, the buyers are a baby-faced average of 44 years old -- 20 years younger than Caddy's typical customer. Now Cadillac has a problem it hasn't had in years: Too many orders, too few cars. The company said it would rather sell fewer cars than risk quality. "When you succeed in drawing people into the showroom," said Susan Jacobs of Jacobs Automotive, a consulting firm in Little Falls, N.J., "you have to capitalize and start building word of mouth and the car's visibility on the road." But that's a problem Cadillac can live with -- at least for now.
 
 
Orion After Allen
 
Orion -- the constellation, that is -- still has three bright stars in its belt. The Orion Pictures Corporation, the cash-starved studio owned largely by John W. Kluge, has lost at least one: Woody Allen moved to the Sony Corporation's TriStar Pictures last summer. Orion lost $48.1 million last quarter. Last week, Orion said it would delay the release of 12 films until next year. One of those is "Shadows and Fog," Orion's last film by Mr. Allen.

 
Door Closes on Clifford
 
Aside from the money that was lost, one of the greatest tragedies of the Bank of Commerce and Credit International scandal was the damage done to the reputation of Clark M. Clifford, a former Defense Secretary and Presidential adviser. Not only did the scandals sully Mr. Clifford's name, they caused his law firm, Clifford & Warnke, to shut down. Last week, Clifford & Warnke's wood panelled-offices, with their view of the White House, were put up for lease.


A Potential Winner for Merck
 
If a new drug does what two years of tests show it can do, it may prove to be a boon not only for heart patients but for Merck & Company. Merck's drug, called Mevacor, appears to halt and even reverse the buildup of fatty blockages in the arteries that can cause heart disease. Mevacor is already used to lower cholesterol levels. Last week Merck said it would seek approval of Mevacor as a plaque remover.


MCA Shifts Image a Bit
 
When Japanese companies bought studios in Hollywood, some wondered if it would change the way films portray Japan. Now they may be finding out. MCA Inc., now owned by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan, had a film in the works called "Mr. Baseball" before Matsushita bought it. The movie was about an American ballplayer in Japan. But last year the film was rewritten.That's common enough. But the emphasis was changed to incorporate Japanese values.Some jokes about World War II were dropped. Tom Pollack, chairman of Universal Pictures, said, "There was absolutely no involvement by Matsushita." The changes were made to lure Japanese viewers -- not to please Hollywood's new bosses.
 
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Stripped-Down Banking Bills
 
The banking bills passed last week in the Senate and House were as stripped down as they come. For nearly a year, Congress has whittled away at the Administration's plans. Out went the proposal to let banks write insurance policies and underwrite securities. Out went the plan to let industrial companies own banks. The Senate version lets banks open branches nationally; the House version does not. Together, the measures do little more than give the battered bank insurance fund, now down to its last $5 billion, access to as much as $70 billion for bailing out ailing banks. The Administration is not pleased.

 
Forget the Credit Card Cap
 
Even before the threat of a Presidential veto was raised, Congress lost its nerve about setting a cap on credit card interest rates. Its reasoning went as follows: Sure, banks have spreads that are wider than ever -- they pay 7 percent or less for the money they borrow but lend it at 18 percent or more to credit card holders. But those spreads contribute about the only profits the badly battered banking system now has. And even those profits are shrinking. Adherents of the proposal slunk away. Not to lose face, Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, said the House would undertake a "study," of the plan to cap rates.
 
 
Bush: What Problems?
 
President Bush told a group of reporters last week that he believes the economy is sound. The problem, Mr. Bush said, was bad public relations about a good economy. "You see, there's some fairly good fundamentals getting out there," he said. Mr. Bush referred to the low inflation rate, falling interest rates and the strength of America's exports. But he did not refer to growth, which has been paltry. Mr. Bush met with several economists last week. Critics of Mr. Bush, including Senator Lloyd Bensten, Democrat of Texas, say more must be done than simply letting interest rates slide. Try tax cuts, they say.Many economists agree. "Monetary policy alone won't do it," said Alan Sinai of the Boston Company. "Bad as the deficit is, the economy is worse."


An Upward Blip in Housing
 
To the economic mavens who peruse the statistics looking for signs of life, housing seems to be a bright spot. According to the Commerce Department, housing starts in October jumped 7.3 percent, the biggest gain in eight months. That comes after a decline of 3.3 percent in September. "The primary factor behind the increase is lower mortgage interest rates," said Richard Peach, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association. "We do have a recovery, the problem is its not as strong as the ones we've seen in the past."
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL


Hungry for Imports Again
 
The Commerce Department said last week that the trade deficit grew to $6.79 billion in September. Imports rose 3.2 percent while exports were up just 3 percent. The disparity between the two numbers suggests that America -- climbing ever so slowly out of its slump -- is starting to hanker for imported goods while the rest of the world, which is beginning to slow down, is not as hungry for the gadgets Americans produce. The sore spot continues to be Japan. The deficit with Japan grew 11 percent, to $4.18 billion.
 

The Parts Make Up Soviet Debt
 
Alexander Hamilton correctly grasped that the creditworthiness of the fledgling United States depended on the new government shouldering the foreign debts of the original 13 colonies. The fragmenting Soviet Union is trying to do the same thing, with a twist. Eight of the 12 republics, including Russia but not the Ukraine, have decided to make good on the entire $80 billion in foreign debt owed by the union. The republics told this to a Moscow gathering of finance ministers from the world's seven wealthiest nations. They were hoping that such an agreement would get the G-7 to extend more credit to Moscow. Maybe it will, but the offer presupposes that the republics can pay back those loans. That is still a big unknown.

Last week, the Soviet Union's major foreign creditors, agreed to defer repayment of that country's loans for up to a year.

 
Pressures on Maxwell's World
 
For Robert Maxwell's heirs -- and the businesses he left behind -- the pressure is mounting. The Swiss Bank Corporation said last week it was demanding repayment of a loan of 55 million (about $98.8 million at current rates) to a private company controlled by the Maxwell family. The big Swiss bank wants a repayment plan within 10 days. Other creditors are also demanding action on millions of dollars of outstanding loans. Last week, another group of creditors asked leaders of the Maxwell family's businesses to attend a meeting, bringing statements disclosing the condition of their finances. This is something new. It used to be that all initiatives came from Mr. Maxwell.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Barking Back Again for Big Oil

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
These are tough times to be a lobbyist for big oil. Oil and gas supply most of America's energy, but the public and Congress, far from grateful, want the job done with less pollution. The industry's image was so hurt by the Exxon Valdez spill and last year's sharp run-up in the price of gasoline -- even if that was Saddam Hussein's fault -- that oil companies have offered little resistance at times to their critics.
As the deadlines set by last year's Clean Air Act loom closer, however, the industry is complaining louder, and near the head of the pack is Charles J. DiBona, the president of the American Petroleum Institute since 1979. 
 Mr. DiBona has been saying more and more bluntly lately that some of the new requirements for cleaner-burning fuels will produce very little benefit for the environment, and at very great cost. He uses the recession as a cue.
"How many more inefficiencies can be imposed on the U.S. economy," he said in a speech at the institute's annual meeting here last week, "before the ultimate costs, in a more competitive world, are recognized? When will common sense be applied in evaluating the costs and benefits of proposed regulation? And more specifically, how much more damage will be done to this great industry before policy makers recognize the heavy price being paid for outlandish proposals?"
Mr. DiBona, whose organization is based in Washington, is also trying to capitalize on a general political alienation. "People are clearly angered with the way politics has been played in Washington and in state capitals across the country," he said.
The politics are strong within his organization, too. The petroleum institute represents companies in two different kinds of work -- drilling for oil, and then refining and selling it -- whose interests often differ.
But last week the audience, 1,700 oil executives, loved every word of Mr. DiBona's speech. His message will not play as well in the hearing rooms of Washington and the state capitals, though. The Senate just voted against considering opening up the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge for oil drilling, and the states are rushing to adopt stricter and stricter emission standards on cars and trucks, which consume most of the nation's oil.
Mr. DiBona, 59 years old, is a graduate of the U.S. Naval Academy and was a Rhodes scholar at Oxford. He served as deputy director of the White House Energy Policy Office under President Nixon and joined the A.P.I. in 1974 as executive vice president and chief operating officer. He is now in charge of a big shop, with a staff of nearly 500, divided between Washington and 33 state councils, and a budget of $65.5 million.

HEADLINE: Polaroid's Russian Success Story

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: OBNINSK, U.S.S.R.

 BODY:
To Soviet factory managers, whose lives are made miserable by ramshackle machinery and a lack of raw materials, the Polaroid Corporation's circuit-board operation here must seem like a mirage.
Tucked into one corner of a glum, fortress-like factory building, Polaroid's five brightly lit, freshly painted rooms hum with gleaming American machinery, an abundant supply of precision parts and 70 workers hunched intently over their workstations. 
 Located 60 miles south of Moscow, the Polaroid factory, which produces 70,000 circuit boards a month for the company's instant cameras, is one of the few American manufacturing operations in the Soviet Union. And despite the myriad hassles of doing business here -- the bureaucratic nightmares, the growing political disarray, the archaic phone system, the nearly worthless currency -- Polaroid boasts that the factory is as efficient as its other plants around the world.
"Many of my friends say it's impossible to get quality production in the Soviet Union," said Edward Doyle, technical director of Polaroid's Soviet operations. "I just invite them to this place."
The factory, the centerpiece of Polaroid's Soviet venture, shows that doing business in the land of Lenin need not be the no-win nightmare that many American companies fear, but can lead to modest success and, perhaps someday, even more than that. Polaroid's joint venture also includes a small plant in Moscow that assembles Polaroid cameras and a shop there that sells 24,000 instant cameras and 250,000 packs of film a year.
The Obninsk factory is a model of what many Soviet and Western officials say is needed to pull the rickety, obsolete Soviet economy into the 21st century. Demonstrating how vital foreign investment is, the factory has created jobs, introduced high-technology equipment and served as a showplace for Western production techniques, like quality control. A proud example: less than one-half of 1 percent of the circuit boards made here have defects while, by many estimates, other Soviet boards have a 10 percent defect rate -- and are notorious for catching fire.
 
'Oasis in the Desert'
 "You might say this is an oasis in the desert," said Gennadi Lisitsin, a technical director for Polaroid's principal joint venture partner, the Soviet Ministry of Atomic Energy. "Everyone knows the level of technology in the West is higher, and this enables us to learn a lot more about making circuit boards."
While it is nice to build an oasis, Polaroid executives would prefer to see the whole Soviet economic desert bloom so they could conduct business without all the trials and tribulations. They are frustrated about accumulating mountains of rubles that cannot be converted into hard currency to repatriate to their headquarters in Cambridge, Mass. They have all but given up trying to obtain raw materials domestically because Soviet enterprises cannot guarantee a steady supply of anything, except grief. They complain that the Government is in such a muddle that they cannot find any officials willing to stick their necks out to grant Polaroid much-needed additional office space.
What is more, Polaroid's joint venture has had to hire a person just to make deals with collective farms for eggs, meat and other essentials for its workers. Otherwise, many employees would have to skip work to forage for such things.
Recognizing the difficulties of doing business here, Polaroid is pursuing what management consultants say is the wise course of action for Western companies: start small, test the waters, get to know the territory and be ready to expand when the Soviet economy turns around, which could be a long time coming. In this immense country, where it usually takes at least a month to get a roll of film developed, Polaroid sees unlimited opportunities for its cameras.
"We're dedicated to spreading our technology among the people," said George Marquart, managing director of Polaroid's Soviet operation. To pursue that goal, Polaroid set up the joint venture in July 1989, investing $3 million in cash and equipment, while the Atomic Energy ministry and two other Soviet partners contributed a total of $3 million worth of office, retail, factory and living space. The venture grew out of a friendship between a former Polaroid chairman and a leading Soviet atomic scientist.
Mr. Marquart, an American citizen whose stepfather was a Russian nobleman, is one of the rare foreigners who could not be happier working here. He was born in Estonia 55 years ago, fled with his family in 1941, and spent his teen-age years in Nyack, N.Y., speaking Russian at home. A tall, white-haired man with gentle eyes, he is thrilled to be in the Soviet Union to witness -- and participate in -- its metamorphosis from Marxism to a market economy.
 
In the Vanguard
 Mr. Marquart, who has a touch of the missionary in him, is proud that Polaroid is in the vanguard of American manufacturers here and often tries to persuade other Western companies to lend a hand rebuilding a nation held back by decades of Communism. A few other American consumer products companies, including Tambrands and Johnson Wax, also have plants here, and the number could rise as the 12 remaining Soviet republics move to market economies.
Still, the line to visit Lenin's tomb remains far longer than the line of Western companies waiting to set up shop here. "By and large, few foreign businessmen like working here," said Mr. Marquart. "There are all kinds of difficulties. The place is filthy. It's falling apart. The roads are bad."
But for Polaroid, a land of 290 million people starved of consumer goods makes eminent sense. With Polaroid's instant camera sales falling to 4.5 million last year worldwide from a peak of 13 million in 1978, the company sees this as a potential pasture of plenty.
Mr. Marquart said Polaroid, which has annual worldwide sales of $2 billion, could easily sell 2.4 million cameras a year here rather than 24,000. The company is strictly limiting the amount of cameras and film it sells until it figures out how to generate more hard currency.
Rather than open its doors to all comers, Polaroid sells its cameras only to workers at enterprises that first write to request cameras for their employees. Even with this method, there is a two-year waiting list to buy the 635 CL cameras. They sell for 500 rubles, about the average monthly wage for a Moscow factory worker. This represents about $10 at the official commercial exchange rate, while these cameras typically sell for $35 in the United States.
 
Paving the Way
 "The demand for our product is so high that we cannot simply open our doors and sell our cameras or we would be trampled to death," said Mr. Marquart. Polaroid hopes to populate the Soviet Union with its cameras to create a huge demand for its highly profitable film.
Each morning several dozen eager Muscovites whose numbers have been called line up in front of Polaroid's shop on Leninskii Prospekt shortly before it opens. The store is far different from the typical drab, humdrum Soviet shop: it is immaculate, the salespeople are courteous and handsome blown-up photos of Soviet beach scenes adorn the walls.
"These cameras have so many good qualities," said one buyer, Dimitri Yemulianov. "They make pictures immediately, which is something we haven't had before. A lot of people develop pictures themselves, which is hard because of all the equipment and chemicals you need."
Polaroid assembles the cameras in a factory a mile south of the Moscow shop, using 44 parts and 5 subassemblies sent from its plants around the world. The Moscow factory, located in a technical school, has eight engineers who do the manual assembly.
At first glance, this seems like a crazy proposition: importing components for hard currency from Western countries, assembling them here and then selling them for worthless rubles. Polaroid executives admit that selling cameras here is a drain on hard currency, but that at least for now, there is no other way to distribute their cameras.
The Obninsk factory helps offset the hard currency drain by exporting its circuit boards for dollars to a huge Polaroid assembly plant near Glasgow. Each board, which controls a camera's electronic flash, brings in $1.50 in hard-currency profit.
"Every dollar we make will be reinvested in new camera parts and film to help us expand," said Mr. Marquart. When Polaroid set up the joint venture, it agreed to reinvest all its profits for five years. Nonetheless, it is straining to build up export projects to create a steady stream of hard-currency profits to repatriate after five years.
Although Polaroid is not in the plastics business, it is setting up a 110-worker factory in Estonia that aims to export each year 10 million plastic cases that hold videocassettes. In addition, Polaroid plans to almost double Obninsk's circuit-board production to more than 120,000 a month.
While production at most Soviet factories is plummeting, Polaroid is bullish about its Obninsk expansion plans because the operation is already going so smoothly. Every six weeks, Polaroid trucks leave Amsterdam to bring all the parts needed to build circuit boards. It is a far cry from the Soviet system, where suppliers rarely have what other factories need, and when they do, often demand five times the usual price.
"In the Soviet Union, the supply situation is very complicated," said Vladimir Ponomarev, production manager of the circuit-board operation. "With Polaroid, this is all taken care of."
Polaroid executives selected this soft-spoken 37-year-old engineer to head production because of his ability to think independently and work with people. Like the other 81 workers and managers in the circuit-board unit, he used to work elsewhere in the drab factory building making control instruments for nuclear power plants.
 
'This Is Good Work'
 The Polaroid operation is laid out neatly. In one room, a shiny American machine inserts 31 tiny parts onto the 3-inch-by-1.5-inch circuit boards. In another, 20 women sit around two U-shaped tables adding larger parts by hand. The rooms look out on a sea of white birches on the outskirts of Obninsk, a city of 150,000 known for having the world's first commercial nuclear reactor.
"This is good work," said Tamara Belibezeba, who helps prepare the circuit boards for soldering. "I have a guaranteed job. It's interesting. And the work is well organized."
In the room behind her is Polaroid's technological piece de resistance: a $300,000 machine that forms a precisely measured wave of solder that is splashed onto the back of the circuit boards. Workers continuously monitor the machine to make sure it is applying neither too much nor too little solder. Nonetheless, because of uneven soldering, about 5 percent of the circuit boards must be retouched.
"The problem with this work is that it's monotonous," said Alec Dimitric, who monitors some of the equipment. "It's the same thing all day long. On our old jobs, we at least did different things each day."
These workers are for the first time seeing up close the pros and cons of Western mass production. On the pro side, they earn about 15 percent more than workers employed elsewhere in the factory building.
"The more they produce, the more they earn," said Mr. Ponomarev. "It's a good system because people see the results of their labor right away. It's reflected in their check at the end of the month."
Polaroid is delighted with the workers' dedication and the quality of production. "I have never had to reject a single lot of circuit boards," said Mr. Doyle, the technical director.
Polaroid originally hoped to vastly increase the profits of its circuit-board operation by obtaining most components from lower-cost Soviet sources, rather than from the hard-currency West. "But we haven't had any success," said Mr. Doyle, "because we can't buy plastics or obtain precision tools."
Mr. Marquart said that despite such problems the joint venture is making a small profit on annual revenues of about $3 million, when rubles and dollars are combined. He hopes, once hard currency profits can be repatriated, to increase earnings by selling other Polaroid products here, including machines that do medical imaging and take passport photos.
 
Dual Missions
 All this is helping Mr. Marquart fulfill his two missions: make money for Polaroid and help rebuild this crumbling nation. Having begun but never finished studies to become a minister, Mr. Marquart sometimes sounds as if he is giving a sermon when he talks about the importance of Western investment here.
"It seems that all the Western aid plans ignore the fundamental situation that exists today, and that is the total and absolute bankruptcy of this country," he said. "Its currency is worthless. It has no significant technologies and no significant pool of financial or managerial people."
He said that since deficit-strapped Western governments were likely to grant only limited aid, it was crucial for companies to invest here.
"Pulling yourself up by your bootstraps," he said, "can take a long time, and involve instability in this part of the world for a very long time. If foreign companies could bring jobs, new products and technology over here on a large scale, that would be a big help."
Fortunately for Mr. Marquart, Polaroid's Soviet joint venture seems to be doing good and doing well at the same time.
 
 
THE NEW SOVIET WORKER
 Are Soviet workers the loafers and louts they are reputed to be? Judging from Polaroid's experience, the answer is mostly no.
Polaroid executives have taken pains to arrange their factories and offices so they are vastly different from Soviet ones. The Polaroid workplaces are bright and cheerful, the equipment doesn't break down, supplies are available and there are financial incentives to be productive. By contrast, many Soviet workers take a "who cares?" attitude because their machines often don't work and raw materials are lacking.
"The word is the Russians don't know how to work and can't make quality products," said George Marquart, head of Polaroid's Soviet operations. "The reason is they haven't been in a position to work for something meaningful."
For years, the Soviets have worked for hollow rubles that bought them only the barest and drabbest necessities.
Polaroid pays high wages and helps its workers obtain food and clothing. "Productivity and quality are not a question for us," Mr. Marquart said.
For training, Polaroid has flown a dozen employees to the United States and Scotland to learn about teamwork, quality control and other production techniques.
"When I was with Soviet enterprises, I never received any training," said Yuri Bezotosny, an engineer in Polaroid's Moscow camera assembly plant. This gregarious 36-year-old hopes to become a marketing manager when Polaroid expands here, but for now he is a bit frustrated, assembling cameras by hand.
Polaroid pays him 1,000 rubles a month, twice the average for Moscow factory workers, but still just $20 at current exchange rates. Expressing sympathy for his workers, Edward Doyle, Polaroid's technical director here, said, "One problem in this country is everyone seems to be overqualified but underpaid."
 
 
 
ADVISING OTHER COMPANIES TO GO IT ALONE
 Hoping to attract many other American companies to the Soviet Union, George Marquart, the head of Polaroid's operations here, is eager to give advice to all who will listen.
Mr. Marquart, one of the first Americans to set up a factory in the Soviet Union, said foreign investors must be ready to tolerate some rough going. The Soviet Union, he said, is in such bad shape that investors have to provide all the equipment and technology and can rely on the Soviets for only the people and the buildings.
When Polaroid began manufacturing cameras and circuit boards here two years ago, it could only do so by forming a joint venture with Soviet partners. Investment laws have since been liberalized, allowing Westerners to acquire 100 percent of a Soviet enterprise or to set up shop without a partner.
Mr. Marquart recommends that foreigners eschew the joint venture route. Today the important thing is to have full control, he said. Some Western companies -- but not Polaroid, company executives say -- have been hampered by Soviet partners who do not understand market thinking or have been immobilized by the nation's political and economic chaos.
Still, Mr. Marquart said, foreign companies coming here will probably need to find some Soviets to guide them. A Westerner coming in without any ties will have a hard time getting space, phones and raw materials, he said.
In his view, it is important for American executives here to be able to speak Russian.
"Companies will tell you that their greatest asset is their people," Mr. Marquart said. "I say it's not just people, but people with the ability to communicate. If they can't communicate in the country where they are working, you have a real problem."

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: Southwestern;
An Open Forum Sets Off Debate On Racial Issues

DATELINE: GEORGETOWN, Tex.

 BODY:
Angry exchanges between the dean of students at Southwestern University and the College Republicans, a student group, have generated campuswide discussions over racism and affirmative action. The talks flared into heated disputes during a recent debate of the issues.
About 350 students, faculty members and administrators attended the open forum at which Dinesh d'Souza, author of "Illiberal Education," argued that scholarships should be based on socio-economic need, not on race, and that multicultural curriculums are so politicized that they shut off discussion. His opponent, Evan Carton, an English professor at the University of Texas at Austin, insisted that Mr. d'Souza was the spokesman for a predominantly white, male and monied crowd. 
 University administrators said it was one of the largest such gatherings in their memory. Students welcomed classmates' emotional response. "Things like this debate are the signs of a healthy, thinking campus emerging from a comatose state," said James DeWitt, a sophomore in international studies from Houston.
Angela Sparks, a senior majoring in psychology from Mesa, Ariz., agreed. "There is something changing at Southwestern. People's feelings have gotten hurt from whatever remarks and whatever rumors that sprang from the College Republicans-Dean Ballou issue. That's what made this debate so important. To have a group that large and that vocal at Southwestern is unusual."
The catalyst for the dispute was a poster supplied by the Young Americans Foundation, a national nonprofit organization based in Herndon, Va., which was displayed by College Republicans at a campus recruitment session in late September. The poster said: "Smash apartheid on campus. Resist special privileges based on race," in what the foundation described as an effort to compare special privileges for black students on campus with the special protections afforded whites in South Africa.
In a letter to student groups on campus, the dean of students, Roger Ballou, dean of students, criticized the poster as "elitist," saying it "smacks of white supremacy and does nothing to help push America forward toward a more inclusive and multicultural society."
The displaying of the poster prompted weeks of written criticisms of the College Republicans by Mr. Ballou; verbal ripostes by the College Republicans; angry letters to the editor in the campus newspaper; an apology by Mr. Ballou for a "misconception" about whom he had been criticizing, and a rebuff of the apology. And recently all this led to an article published in The University Review, the conservative student newspaper at the University of Texas in Austin, which has incensed most at Southwestern as an outside incursion into its private affairs.
The article has been criticized by Dean Ballou and Jennifer Imle, the chairwoman of Southwestern's College Republicans, as well as by students on campus as unwarranted and inaccurate.
 
'Its Own Agenda'
 Angelyque Campbell, a senior from Houston majoring in political science and communications, who is chairwoman of the student government, said the article was misleading and would heighten tension on campus. "It seems The Review came to our campus with its own agenda," Ms. Campbell said. "I don't think they actually portrayed the true account of the issue."
Ms. Imle, a sophomore from Houston majoring in political science, said that the Review article "exaggerated a few points" but that "I think that many people who hadn't thought about the issue before have realized its importance."
"We think he should apologize and retract the letter," she said. "The College Republicans think that what he did was an attempt at political correctness."
Southwestern currently has a student population of 1,231, according to the admissions office, with less than 15 percent of them from minority groups.
"We do not have dual-admissions standards," Mr. Gaita said in an interview. "There is no policy written down somewhere saying we practice affirmative action in our admissions standards. We have goals, but we do not have quotas. Some years we meet the goals, some years we don't."

HEADLINE: On the Street;
Patches: In, Not Down And Out

 BODY:
All the patched clothes seen around town recently were not a result of the present recession, nor yet of nostalgia for the Great Depression of the 1930's, when patching clothes was a necessity. Today's patches are all about status and style.
Christian Francis Roth's clothes (at right and far right) have intricate patch inserts that are part of Mr. Roth's designs. 
 Patched jeans have been around since the 1960's. The newer ones are imitating Mr. Roth's more expensive designs with appliqued patches that don't cost as much (center).
And not to be confused with those styles are the rap-style patches with fringed -- or frayed -- edges on denim clothes (below).

HEADLINE: Lori G. Stern, A Lawyer, Wed

 BODY:
Lori Gwen Stern, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome L. Stern of Brooklyn, was married last night to Bradley Mark Feldman, a son of Jaclyn E. Feldman of East Rockaway, L.I., and Henry A. Feldman of New York. Rabbi Marc Dissick officiated at Temple Judea in Massapequa, L.I.
Mrs. Stern, 25 years old, is an associate in the New York law firm of Seward & Kissel. She graduated magna cum laude from the State University of New York at Albany, and received a law degree from Albany Law School. Mr. Feldman, 26, is a junior technical market analyst for Prudential Securities in New York. He graduated summa cum laude from SUNY at Albany, and was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. His mother is a giftware manufacturers' representative. His father is a C.P.A. in New York.

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
For Collectors, a Decade to Treasure

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
I HAVE known a lot of neat cars. I have driven Ferraris. I have been at the wheel of the Thomas Flyer that once, back in July 1908, won the New York-to-Paris race. I have ridden down Fifth Avenue in a Hispano-Suisa. But for all that, my pocketbook has never let me be a real player in the world of fancy iron.
Pshaw. There was the '37 Cord convertible, for instance, flamingo pink and strutting around with a price tag of only $2,500. I could have bought the dark green Packard at the farm auction in Quakertown, Pa. My buddy Jim Case traded his '40 Cadillac on a new '54 Ford, and I could have had that lovely Fleetwood sedan real cheap. I should have kept my '36 Ford. 
 Coulda, shoulda, woulda. It is the stuff of life and dreams, and my failings come to mind because of the October issue of a slick classic-car magazine called the du Pont Registry. I could have done without it.
Bill Gillette is actually the guy responsible. He is a former stockbroker, a former New Yorker now transplanted to Tampa, Fla. He is an editor of the Registry, with collateral duty as what the magazine likes to call its "collector-car market analyst." And he set out to compile the rise and fall of neat-car prices over the past decade.
He did it, I think, just to make me feel bad, although he denies that. "I picked the cars at random," he said. "They're just cars that I like, although I threw in some old stuff, some newer stuff. Some snappy, some basic. I wanted something for everybody."
What that something amounts to is a list of 61 automobiles, the eldest being a 1930 Packard roadster and the youngest being a Jag and a Ferrari, both vintage 1974. According to the study, the whole lot could have been purchased for $1.6 million in 1980, while today's price would be close to $22 million.
Over all, it shows an increase in value from 1980 to 1991 of 1,285 percent -- if you include the 1962 Ferrari 250 GTO. Without that conspicuously outrageous automobile, the listed increase is a mere 703 percent, but it still makes title to a collector car a gilt-edged security.
A sampling from the magazine's list appears at right, and it indicates that the Ferrari would have cost $65,000 in 1980 while today's price would be $10 million. Gillette cautions, though, that some of the figures, including the GTO's, are high. "You could probably pay the top price," he said, "but it would have to be for a car that Marilyn Monroe made love in and that originally belonged to the Queen of England, who sold it to Elvis Presley."
Whatever the true figures, this seems to be one of the better times to buy. "With the recession, the heavily hyped stuff took it on the nose," Gillette said. "Those cars had been going up by about 200 percent a year, and this is really the first time they've been checked. But prices are off 15 to 40 percent across the board."
The way to start, he said, boils down to one word: research. But it's important, too, to know precisely what you want. "For starters," he said, "you ought to buy something that's fun and that's relatively easy to fix. And remember what they say: When the top goes down, the price goes up."
