HEADLINE: Why We Must Help Russia at Brink of Abyss

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Zbigniew Brzezinski may be right in criticizing the Bush Administration for its pro-Gorbachev bias (Op-Ed, Nov. 10). However, his own anti-Gorbachev bias is dangerously misleading. He advocates a "league of sovereign states to replace the fading Soviet center." Otherwise, he thinks, the United States might be opting for "a showdown between Mikhail Gorbachev and Boris Yeltsin." He recommends the United States must deal directly with the republics, thus undercutting the Soviet Government, whose "international responsibilities and nuclear weapons will be inherited by the Russian state." 
 One could hardly imagine any advice more misguided. It is not the "fading center" the republics fear after the failed August coup and the disintegration of the empire, but precisely the giant Russia, which may try to appropriate the place -- and the power -- of the former imperial center. It is against Mr. Yeltsin's Russia, not Mr. Gorbachev's center, that the Ukraine intends to build one of the biggest armies in Europe, complete with nuclear weapons. Why should Russia control the Soviet nuclear arsenals, asks Kazakhstan. And don't forget Byelorussia, riddled with nuclear bases. Is the United States really interested in confronting four nuclear powers instead of one? What about nuclear nonproliferation?
Unfortunately for Mr. Brzezinski, the embarrassing questions do not end there. Somebody has to be responsible for dividing the Soviet debt among the former republics. For coordinating their economic reforms. For serving as a troubleshooter in their conflicts. For keeping those conflicts from turning into waves of Russian refugees, which would undermine reform in Russia and supply Mr. Yeltsin's opponents with a ready-made army of counterreform.
Is there anyone in the former Soviet Union capable of performing any, let alone all of these necessary functions, except Mr. Gorbachev and his "fading center"? As long as the humbled and reduced center devotes itself to these limited but vital functions, there could be no showdown between it and Russia. If only because Mr. Yeltsin needs Mr. Gorbachev as a troubleshooter -- to dispel the fears of the republics, as well as dangerous anti-Russian sentiment, which tends to grow into bloody pogroms.
I found this out firsthand last month when I was included in the governmental delegation of Mayor Anatoly A. Sobchak of St. Petersburg to the Republic of Tadzhikistan and participated in difficult negotiations to prevent another bloody riot in Dushanbe. This time we succeeded. But it would be unfair not to point out the major role Mr. Gorbachev's personal authority played in our mission. Paradoxical as it may seem, he is still a powerful force in Soviet Central Asia.
Mr. Brzezinski's recommendations and biases seem irrelevant to the post-August Soviet reality. There is no more Boris Yeltsin or Mikhail Gorbachev in this new reality. The nation is in a veritable revolution. And the stakes are high enough for the former adversaries to join forces against a threat of a complete reversal of everything both stand for. Establishing a credible division of labor between them seems a purpose worth pursuing for United States policy.
Mr. Yeltsin is finally starting Russia on the path of an economic breakthrough many times delayed by Mr. Gorbachev and much feared by the population. The breakthrough is starting amid economic chaos, ethnic strife and consumer panic. If the breakthrough fails, Russia may find itself in the situation of Weimar Germany in the early 1930's.
How to prevent such fateful developments? How to make sure that Russia's rendezvous with destiny does not end in worldwide disaster, and that fascism is not an option? This is the new post-August political agenda we should be discussing, not obsolete recommendations of how to undercut Mr. Gorbachev's "fading center."
 
ALEXANDER YANOV
New York, Nov. 12, 1991
 
The writer, professor of political science, CUNY Graduate Center, is author of "The Russian Challenge and the Year 2000."

HEADLINE: On Not Teaching Children the Wrong Economics Lessons

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a parent of twin 8-year-old sons, I enjoyed "With Allowances, Every Parent Differs" (Consumer's World page, Nov. 2). However, as a lawyer, I have to note that following the suggestions about interest and taxes would send inaccurate, misleading and confusing messages. 
 Since the maximum legal interest rate for personal loans in New York State is 16 percent -- General Obligations Law, Section 5-501, and Banking Law, Section 14(a)(1) -- the interest on a $1 advance on an allowance would be no more than 16 cents a year. As a matter of fact, charging more than 25 percent would be a class E felony (Penal Law, Section 190.40).
Requiring a child to give back $1.10 or $1.20 to impose a small interest rate on a short-term allowance advance would violate the law and teach the child the concept of loan sharking, instead of lending.
As for taxes, the suggestion to put aside allowance money for taxes suffers from several flaws:
(1) To the extent an allowance is a gift, it is nontaxable as to both donor (parent) and recipient (child) at the levels suggested.
(2) If the allowance is income for chores performed or other services rendered, the $3,250 standard deduction would typically cover the entire year's allowance.
Moreover, assessing a "tax" on the first money received at such low levels would be harshly regressive, and inconsistent with the principle of progressive taxation (one pays a higher percentage of one's income as one's income increases) that underlies our income tax structure.
If a parent wants to teach the concept of interest, a useful way is to have the child deposit allowance money in his or her own bank account and watch the interest grow. As for taxes, analysis of a payroll check stub form (with names and numbers omitted) would tell about this reality of economic life.
 
MICHAEL G. BERGER
New York, Nov. 6, 1991

HEADLINE: 'A War Without Bloodshed'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Too American for Its Own Good?" (Oct. 27) claims Toyota has played by the rules. What rules? I assume your writer refers to following Lee Iacocca's challenge to build plants in the United States and to increasing jobs here and the purchases of American auto parts. But jobs and investment here simply take business from our own automobile producers. 
 International trade is really like war without bloodshed. The objective is to sell as much as possible at the highest possible price and buy little or nothing in return. The Japanese are doing this with great success in our country. They may be expanding their overall productive capacity here to increase their third-world market share for automobiles -- all this while continuing to exert heavy pressure on our automobile manufacturers.
Is there an economic conspiracy by Japan against the United States? Many people believe, as do I, that industries like steel and automobiles have been targeted by Japan. Also there are many who disparage the idea of economic conspiracy in international trade. If a bear that has discovered a honey pot and been joined by a number of his fellows is considered a conspiracy -- so be it.
 
THEODORE L. DIAMOND
New York, Nov. 8

HEADLINE: Filling the Unmet Labor Needs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Disability Dilemma" (Forum, Nov. 3) points out that employment prospects for people with disabilities are not as good as originally anticipated for white-collar jobs. But American business cannot fill many millions of jobs annually in fast-food chains, department stores and other establishments that require employees for customer contact, technical information processing, telephone marketing and back-room activities.
Most American companies are regarding the Americans with Disabilities Act as an unabashed disaster. The costs and administrative burdens cannot be denied. But some companies have happily recognized the value of hiring the disabled and more will eventually realize that the law has the potential to wipe out a chronic and future shortage of qualified entry-level and skilled labor plaguing businesses. The law also has the potential to turn 43 million formerly disenfranchised disabled citizens into consumers and taxpayers with spending power the economy badly needs.
 
STEPHEN E. MESSINGER
New York, Nov. 13

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
For Now, Anyway, Taking Hostages Just Doesn't Pay

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN the eight-year ordeal of hostage-taking in Lebanon, the release of Terry Waite and Thomas M. Sutherland last week was a breakthrough.
Mr. Waite, the Anglican Church envoy, was not only the last British hostage to be freed; he was also the most valuable, the one who had been both accused of spying and credited with resolving other Middle East hostage crises. The Iranian-backed captors made predictions that the remaining Western hostages would be freed within weeks or even days and offered concessions -- however hollow -- that the hostage-taking in Lebanon had all been a mistake. Finally, the captors dropped their insistence that Arab prisoners be released by Israel, simplifying matters and essentially dealing the Israelis out of what had been a three-way game. 
 Until five remaining hostages -- including Terry Anderson, the longest-held and best-known American -- go free, any celebration of the end of state-supported hostage-taking in Lebanon will be premature. Even if all are released, there is no certainty that another group at another time will not snatch another Westerner from the Beirut streets. But the phenomenon of taking hostages has changed from the days when zealous captors undaunted by death could damage a Presidency and pervert a country's foreign policy.
It was the relentless public eye on the seizure of the American Embassy in Teheran in 1979 that elevated the tribal practice of seizing captives for ransom to the international stage. Americans saw clusters of angry young men on their television screens screaming "Death to Carter" and burning the American flag in front of the embassy compound. Mr. Carter's desperate use of intermediaries and the ill-fated American military rescue mission in the Iranian desert clearly signaled to the clerical leaders in Teheran the importance of the 52 Americans held captive.
Similarly, the willingness of the Reagan Administration in the mid-1980's to violate its own stated policy and secretly sell arms to Iran in exchange for hostages held in Lebanon showed just how valuable a handful or so of Americans could become. There were unconfirmed reports that the governments of Germany, Saudi Arabia, South Korea, Spain, Switzerland and France got their hostages back by paying ransom or making other deals with the captors, moves that would have validated the practice of seizing captives. At one point the captors had the audacity to demand a payment from the French because the cost of feeding and housing their hostages had been so high.
 
Emotional Traps
 To hear the White House explain the most recent four-month flurry of successful United Nations-led negotiations, which resulted in the freeing of six American and British hostages, President Bush contributed to the process by avoiding the kinds of emotional traps his predecessors fell into.
Mr. Bush also got lucky.
To their captors, hostages become little more than commodities whose value rises and falls with external circumstances. In the last year and a half, the hostages in Lebanon simply lost their value.
"While this is not the end of an era, this is the end of a story," said Richard W. Bulliet, professor of Middle East history at Columbia University. "These people may have achieved some intermediate political ends. We don't know what they're getting from Syria or Iran to induce them, but whatever it is, it's enough to satisfy them, to buy them out of the political arena or to move them into different and probably non-terrorist activity."
First, the immediate reason for the capture of some of the hostages in Lebanon -- and a non-negotiable demand for their release -- evaporated overnight. In the confusion of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August 1990, 15 prisoners who were jailed in Kuwait for terrorist activities were set free. Suddenly, the captors lost their main rationale for holding the hostages, just as the death of the late Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlevi removed a key demand of the Iranians holding the American Embassy that he be tried for his crimes.
Second, Iran, which enjoys considerable, although not total, influence over the captors, decided that its own economic reconstruction and links to the West superseded its aims in Lebanon. Teheran's leaders finally got the message that the United States would do its best to block Iran's economic development as long as there were American hostages in Lebanon.
Third, the collapse of the Soviet Union made it apparent that no Arab country would again have a Soviet-supplied state-of-the-art army or would benefit very much from Moscow's patronage. Syria, which for years had used Lebanon as a playground for its own terrorist aims, decided to buy into games played by American rules: the coalition in the gulf war and the Arab-Israeli peace process.
 
Restoring Stability
 Fourth, a Syrian-Lebanese treaty of cooperation gave Syria greater control over Lebanese affairs, helping to restore stability to the country. "Part of hostage-taking was to build prestige, popular support and a connection with important countries," said Shibley Telhami, associate professor of government at Cornell University.
"When radical groups were fully engaged in a civil war and competing for popular allegiance, hostage-taking was one of the easiest ways for them to make names for themselves. But now Syria's dominant role in Lebanon and American acquiescence in allowing Syria to play that role have converged to create a different domestic situation. The captors have found themselves increasingly isolated, in a position of declining assets and no future."
Still, there is no fundamental transformation of many of the goals that contributed to hostage-taking in the first place: bridging the gap between rich and poor, reducing the influence of the United States in the region and creating a military balance of power with Israel.
And even with the promises of freedom for the remaining hostages, there are spoilers calling for their continued captivity. Infuriated by Washington's efforts to staunch the flow of any nuclear technology to Teheran, the newspaper Salaam last week called the release of Mr. Waite and Mr. Sutherland a "miscalculation."
Hojatolislam Mousavi Khoeiniha, the Iranian cleric who edits the newspaper, has considerable knowledge about hostages. For the 444 days that the American Embassy in Teheran was held, he served as spiritual guide to the captors.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Racial Politics: Back With a Vengeance

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
RACE-RELATED issues are a staple of modern politics, but rarely has the subject seemed as raw or as close to the surface as it does now, as the country heads into the 1992 campaign.
Some political professionals say racial issues may be more prominent in this election than they have been in 20 years, when the painful battles over busing and civil rights, and the candidacies of George Wallace, kept the subject front and center in Presidential politics. 
 This time, the issue is fueled by hard economic times, by the emergence of David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader who may run for President next year, and by the rulings of a conservative Supreme Court that has reopened the political debate over affirmative action and racial preferences -- just as it reopened the debate over abortion.
In the political world, among those who plan and man presidential campaigns, there is anger and suspicion all around. Democrats, some of whom feel they have paid a heavy electoral price for championing civil rights and affirmative action over the years, accuse Republicans of fanning racial fears to build up white majorities. Republicans assert that Democrats cry racism to stifle legitimate debate over issues like racial preferences, because they know that most Americans disagree with them.
But some of the sharpest divisions over racial policies are within the Republican Party. The powerful cross-currents surrounding President Bush were reflected last week by the Administration's strange and conflicted handling of new civil rights legislation, a bill overruling several recent court decisions that made it harder to sue for job discrimination.
The legislation, a compromise produced after a two-year battle between Congress and the White House, was expected to defuse the so-called quota issue for the 1992 campaign, but even as Mr. Bush moved to sign the bill, his legal counsel, C. Boyden Gray, was circulating a draft policy statement that would have rolled back some critical affirmative action policies covering the Federal Government and related Federal contractors. The Gray document was quickly and widely assailed as an extraordinary retreat on policies dating back to 1965, and Mr. Bush just as quickly disavowed it.
But the week left the President in a hard spot. Many conservatives remain outraged that he signed what they still believe is a quota bill, although Mr. Bush contends that it is not. The argument could be pressed next year by both Mr. Duke and Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator now considering a primary challenge to the President. Richard Viguerie, a conservative direct-mail specialist and fundraiser, asserted, "He signed a quota bill and we're going to hang it around his neck."
 
Republican Fissures
 At the same time, supporters of the civil rights legislation remain wary that the White House will, once again, try to undermine it.
Kevin Phillips, a conservative strategist, argues that Mr. Bush will increasingly feel these strains in the Republican coalition. Higher-income suburban whites are embarrassed and put off by the use of issues like racial quotas, or Willie Horton, the black convicted murderer used by Mr. Bush in 1988 as a symbol of Democratic softness on crime, Mr. Phillips said. At the same time, the analyst said, frustrated working-class whites seem ripe for campaigns against racial preferences, and there are some within the party who argue that such campaigns are justified and wholly legitimate.
The pressures on Mr. Bush have been heightened by the rise of Mr. Duke, who casts himself as a Republican and whose defeat in the recent gubernatorial election in Louisiana seems unlikely to halt his political maneuvering. Democratic presidential contenders have tried to tie Mr. Duke directly to Mr. Bush, portraying the former Klansman as the inevitable product of a generation of Republican racial politics. Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, for example, told a group of Democratic leaders in Chicago on Friday, "George Bush took the party of Abraham Lincoln and made it the party of David Duke."
Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska told the same group, "The Republican Party watered this tree of racism, it's now grown to maturity and it's dropped this fellow David Duke from its branches."
There has been an important shift in the Democrats' psychology since 1988, when Michael S. Dukakis, the party's nominee, and his allies responded with now- legendary caution to the Willie Horton issue. Only late in the campaign did Democrats begin to accuse the Bush campaign of practicing racial politics.
"We're going to be a lot tougher, a lot more aggressive," said Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee. "We're not just going to roll over when these kinds of despicable political tactics are used."
Still, some conservatives argue that the Democrats want to choke debate on an issue -- racial preferences -- that badly needs airing. "Democrats have basically said this is not a discussable issue, and that really helps create a vacuum that David Duke helped fill," argued Terry Eastland, who was a top official in the Justice Department under President Ronald Reagan.
In trying to hold on to their base among black voters while regaining the allegiance of the white middle class, Democrats have their own problems and pressures on racial issues. Polls show the majority of Americans now oppose giving racial preferences in cases where there has been past discrimination. More broadly, the Democrats have yet to find a way on the national level to reknit the biracial coalition that enables them to win many statewide races in the South.
 
'Forgotten Middle Class'
 Democratic strategists are pinning their hopes on new economic appeals to what Governor Bill Clinton of Arkansas calls "the forgotten middle class." The frustration of many Louisiana whites who voted for Mr. Duke came from economic decline, these strategists argue, not simple racism.
Indeed, Neil Newhouse, a Republican polltaker, argues that in the final analysis racial issues will pale beside economic realities next year.
"Racial politics right now is a 30-day wonder," he said. "In a bad economy, there are so many other issues for voters."
Still, it is a persistent issue for Mr. Bush, as it is for any President. And one year before the 1992 election, it seems very raw indeed.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Between Haiti and the U.S. Lies A Quandary

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti

 BODY:
FROM its inception, the persistent clandestine marine traffic of Haitians toward southern Florida and the return of the refugees by an ever-vigilant United States Coast Guard have been fraught with deep moral ambiguities.
Since the early 1970's, shady boat operators, often said to be acting in close collaboration with Haitian authorities, have preyed upon the poor; they sell the would-be migrants expensive spots on leaky wooden boats that are known to have only slim chances ofevading disaster or detection at sea. 
 These operators have been guaranteed a steady if darkly tainted income by Haiti's unrelieved poverty and repression, enforced by the very officials who assented in the trade. The dangers were underscored last week by a shipwreck off Cuba that took dozens of lives, and by a rescue at sea by the Coast Guard of 246 refugees packed into a 30-foot sailboat.
Now, however, with the United States' decision last Monday to try to repatriate the Haitians who fled their country following the bloody overthrow of its first elected president, attention has shifted sharply from the cruelties of Haiti alone. Now it is also on the American ambivalence toward a people in desperate need.
The decision to begin repatriating the Haitians, more than 3,000 of whom have been taken into American custody since September and many of whom had been stockaded aboard Coast Guard ships for weeks, prompted an outcry from some members of Congress and from immigration rights advocates; the decision, many of these critics said, was tinged with racism.
Only days before, the United States had expressed strong concerns over Britain's decision to allow the forcible return of Vietnamese from Hong Kong. Now the Bush Administration found itself groping to distinguish the treatment of Haitians from that of Vietnamese. The State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said that the situations were simply different, and that the United States's repatriation efforts were aimed at saving lives. The United States, she said, wanted to discourage Haitians from undertaking a voyage that experts say kills as many as half of those who set out from the country's Caribbean shores. But such arguments proved unconvincing for a Federal judge in Florida, who on Tuesday ordered the repatriation efforts halted.
For advocates of Haitian immigration rights, the line of reasoning had a familiar ring. They say that when it comes to Haitians, not even a long history of violent dictatorships and the worst poverty in the hemisphere have budged American immigration policies, which have consistently kept people from Haiti at the very bottom of the list of nationalities who are granted legal refuge in the United States.
So averse does Washington seem to allowing Haitians into the country, the immigration advocates say, that it devises one measure after another just to keep them out; early in the 1980's, for example, reports that Haitians might bring in AIDS were cited by officials as a reason to contain them in Haiti. Meanwhile, others with crises in their homelands -- notably Cubans -- are welcomed.
Since 1981, in fact, an agreement has been in force that allows the United States to pluck Haitians from international waters and return them to their shores. No accord like this exists with any other country, the immigration advocates say. Many argue that the agreement itself is tainted, since it was reached between the Reagan Administration and the Duvalier family at a time when the dynasty, in its declining years, was trying to get the United States to turn a blind eye to human-rights abuses.
In another step also applied only to Haiti, the United States canvassed other countries in the region at the start of the current refugee crisis, asking them to accept fleeing Haitians on the ground that allowing them to reach the United States would only encourage more to flee. This effort met with only limited success, because most of the countries that were approached agreed to take only symbolic numbers of the boat people.
 
Who Is an Economic Refugee?
 To those who have raised questions about the disparity between Haitians and Cuban boat people, who are immediately granted refugee status upon pickup by the Coast Guard and arrival in the United States, immigration and State Department officials say Cuba remains a Communist dictatorship, while Haitians are basically fleeing economic deprivation. Here again, though, immigration advocates cry foul, noting that many fleeing Cubans readily identify material hardships, not politics, as their motive. And interviews suggest that the latest surge of Haitians was impelled in good measure by fear of army violence and politically directed arrests.
"The attitude of the U.S. has been that if they are poor and black, they must be economic refugees," said Anne Fuller, associate director of the New York-based National Coalition for Haitian Refugees. "It doesn't occur to people that you can be poor and have political reasons for seeking refuge too."
In addition to race, which she said remained a factor in the treatment of Haitians, Ms. Fuller and others said the refugees were victims of a skewed ideological formula left over from the cold war.
"The whole thing has been terribly politicized," said Ms. Fuller of immigration policies since World War II. "If you come from a Communist country, you have a 60, 70 or 80 percent chance of receiving refugee status. But if you come from a right-wing dictatorship like Haiti, Guatemala or El Salvador, that has never challenged U.S. interests, you will find it extremely difficult to satisfy anyone that you deserve asylum."

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
After the Cold War, Different Times, Different Stations

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
NOT since World War II have the listeners from the British Broadcasting Corporation's overseas monitoring service been so busy. At their outpost in a former boys' school in rural Caversham, west of London, they work in relays before banks of dials and scanners, tuning in to the growing babble of faraway radio voices that fill the ether, bringing news of ferment and democratic rebellion in the Ukraine and Uzbekistan and Georgia.
Over the last four decades, the B.B.C., along with the Voice of America and Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, helped pry apart the first cracks in the Iron Curtain, their scratchy short wave broadcasts piercing the noise and static from jamming transmitters across the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. 
 Now the jammers are silent, but the Western broadcasters find they are confronted by another sort of interference. It is the explosion of new radio and television outlets, unleashed by the powerful cultural and political forces sweeping Eastern Europe and the old Soviet empire. With political liberalization and the growth of a free press, scores of new stations are beaming a richer variety of music and commentary to listeners numbed by years of state radio. Some, like Moscow's Europa Plus, have been backed by Western investors. Others, like Radio Vladivostok, are sponsored by local city governments.
The new stations present the staff at the listening post with a new challenge in monitoring that part of the world: it must now cast a wider net or it will miss the disparate voices that have supplanted the voice of authority. And the stations represent an alternative to Western state-sponsored broadcasters, who suddenly face home-grown competition for listeners.
"With the emergence of relatively free media institutions, people aren't as dependent on Western broadcast," said David Morton, head of the B.B.C.'s Russian service, which has an estimated 13 million listeners in the Soviet Union. "If we want to keep our audience, we have to do something different with our programming."
This is not to say that Western radio has lost its draw as a source of information. If television is the most powerful force shaping public opinion in America and the West, radio remains the dominant medium in the rest of the world -- relentless, inexpensive and instantly accessible, especially in times of crisis.
 
Adapting to the Times
 In the first uneasy days of the abortive Soviet coup last August, according to a recent B.B.C. survey taken in Moscow, about one of every four Soviet citizens tuned in to a foreign radio broadcast. Among them was President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who said he was kept informed by the V.O.A., the B.B.C. and Radio Liberty while under house arrest in the Crimea.
But the cold war's end and the emergence of the new radio days in the Soviet republics and East Europe has forced both governments and broadcasters to rethink their mission. President Bush has assigned a task force to examine the role and structure of American foreign broadcasting. A major consideration is the future of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, which were established at the end of World War II with the explicit mission of broadcasting on behalf of the captive people of Eastern Europe. The committee's recommendations are due this week. The Western broadcasters themselves, meanwhile, find they must pay more attention to marketing, programming and listener demands if they are not to be viewed as a cold war relic. "In Hungary under Communist rule, cabaret was popular because it was one of the few places where you could go to hear political commentary," said Bob Jobbins, the editor of B.B.C.'s World Service News. "These days, you can hear political commentary almost anywhere, and so the audience for cabaret has dropped off. We don't want the same thing to happen to us."
The B.B.C. is about to add a new Ukrainian-language service, and wants to begin an Uzbek service as well. And it recently launched a television news network to compete with the Cable News Network.
 
Tunes and Teaching
 Both the V.O.A. and the B.B.C. are juggling programming schedules, adding more music and instruction in the English language. John Tusa, the general manager of the B.B.C., now talks about what he calls "a Marshall Plan of the mind," which would use radio to bring instructional broadcasts in history, banking, accounting or communication to the emerging democracies of Europe.
Other Western broadcasters have also jumped into the competition. Radio France Internationale has increased its hours of foreign broadcasting. The Swedes have begun a new service aiming at the Baltic states. And Deutsche Welle, the German foreign broadcasting service, has leased and adapted old jamming transmitters from the Soviet Union to boost its signal into Asia.
Radio Free Europe makes an argument for its own future by broadcasting regular primers on democracy and free-market economics, a strategy that has been welcomed by officials in Eastern Europe. The new leaderships in Poland, Czechoslavakia and Hungary have all urged the United States to extend the life of Radio Free Europe, describing it as an "irreplaceable" resource.
At stake, ultimately, are not advertising dollars, but political and cultural influence.
With a nod to the effectiveness of Western propaganda in the cold war decades, Congress is now studying a proposal for a new target -- China. The idea for a Radio Free Asia, like the European service, is for a "surrogate" broadcast of news and commentary to China and other parts of the region, as if it were a domestic station.
"Cliche though it may be, information is what drives the world," said Eugene Pell, a former network television correspondent who is now president of Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty. "If you want your point of view considered, you've still got to find a way to get it in front of people."

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
Connecticut Developers Challenge the Power of Local Zoning

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
THE basic power that Connecticut towns have relied on to define themselves and guide their growth -- the control, through zoning, of what can be built -- is being challenged in a series of housing cases aimed at introducing affordable housing into expensive suburbs.
A state law that took effect last year enabled local zoning decisions to be appealed. Now officials must justify rejecting proposals that include affordable housing. And if they cannot show that concerns about health or public safety -- as opposed to esthetics or local character -- outweigh the need for the housing, a judge can order it built. 
 To bring such an appeal, a developer must dedicate at least 20 percent of a project to housing defined as affordable: within reach of a household earning 80 percent of the region's median income. In the Trumbull case, that would amount to annual earnings of $38,400.
The first of seven such appeals, recently heard in Superior Court here, involves the nation's largest builder of rental housing, Trammell Crow Residential, which is challenging the zoning in Trumbull, a bedroom community for Fairfield County with no apartment buildings.
However, the ultimate success of the law will depend on making inroads into long-held attitudes. Zoning, which spread across much of this country in the 1920's, was a way to guide development by designating certain areas of a town for residential and commerical use. Many towns, however, have also used it to exclude low-income people, especially those from minority groups.
Housing experts hope that suburbs will eventually yield as they recognize that cheaper housing is in their interest. The economy can't grow, they say, if exclusionary zoning makes housing too expensive. Housing prices soared in the 1980's in areas like Fairfield County as corporations relocated and the number of jobs increased far faster than the amount of housing in the region.
"Everybody says, 'My single-family house should continue to grow in value,' " said Charles Berman, the Northeast division partner of Trammell Crow, which wants to build 600 apartments in Trumbull, a town of 32,000 people. "But no one seems to realize that growth comes from increased demand, which comes from employers hiring people to come into the area."
 
A Carrot With the Stick
 Self interest works on several levels, and the Connecticut law, modeled after one in Massachusetts, employs a carrot along with its stick. According to Terry J. Tondro, a University of Connecticut law professor who helped propose the law, the intent is to encourage individual towns to negotiate with developers, rather than have state government impose a larger solution that would, he said, run "counter to what we call home rule, or the idea that towns define themselves."
The law exempts communities where 10 percent of the housing is subsidized or qualifies as affordable. Bridgeport, where 18.4 percent of the housing meets the standard, is exempt; adjacent Trumbull, with only 1.8 percent affordable housing, is not. The law allows a one-year exemption from appeals if a town finishes a project including affordable-housing units equal to 1 percent of existing housing and enters in a regional compact that aims to provide affordable housing.
Trammell Crow's plan, with 120 affordable units out of 600 planned, would qualify Trumbull for the one-year exemption, except that the town has refused to join the Bridgeport region's compact.
Supporters of the Connecticut zoning-appeals process point to the successful experience of Massachusetts, which enacted a zoning appeal process in 1969 after generous subsidies the state had offered for low- and moderate-income housing went begging for three years. The Massachusetts law established a state housing appeals committee while streamlining the entire approval process, which towns often dragged out in an effort to wear down developers. Unlike Connecticut, which enables a judge to approve housing that a zoning board has rejected, the Massachusetts law gives its appeals committee authority to overrule local zoning decisions.
In the first few years, said Maurice Corman, the 82-year-old chairman of the Massachusetts appeals committee, every housing application made under the law was rejected by local zoning boards, and "99 percent of them were then approved by the committee."
Eventually, some of the housing was built, and suburbs could see what they had been fighting. "It was the best-looking housing in town," Mr. Corman said.
Out of about 300 appeals decided by his committee, Mr. Corman said, about 100 were further appealed in court, several of them reaching the United States Supreme Court and were upheld.
Massachusetts housing officials credit the law for some 20,000 affordable-housing units built over the last 20 years. But it has also taken that long for Connecticut, as well as Rhode Island and New Hampshire, which both adopted similar laws, to follow their neighbor's lead.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
High Credit Card Rates: A Luxurious Necessity?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AS a matter of principle, Ralph Nader has no credit cards. He says they encourage reckless spending, raise prices and permit the creation of data banks that could lead to invasion of privacy.
He may be right. But few other people would accept the inconvenience of life without plastic. For the person with no credit cards, it is difficult if not impossible to rent a car, reserve tickets to the theater or sports events, travel without a dangerous wad of cash or engage in many other routine activities of modern society. Mr. Nader, in fact, caused a ruckus in a Princeton, N.J., hotel last week when he arrived to check in and could not produce a credit card. 
 More than three-quarters of all American households have a Visa card or Mastercard or both, and millions more have cards issued by oil companies, retail stores or American Express. Typical customers carry eight or nine charge cards and owe about $2,000 at any particular time. They usually pay between 18 percent and 20 percent annual interest on that debt.
Politicians normally pay little heed. But a few words by President Bush recently changed the picture. The commotion that followed has called attention to the credit card business, the way it operates and its effects on American life. In what seemed to be an offhand remark at a political fund-raiser in New York on Nov. 13, Mr. Bush urged banks to lower their interest rates on credit cards so consumers would spend more and give a jolt to the sluggish economy.
Mr. Bush did not specifically advocate a new law. But Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican, spotted an opportunity to boost his own re-election campaign. The next day, he offered an amendment to pending banking legislation to put a 14 percent cap on credit card interest. With barely half an hour of debate, the Senate approved the proposal by a vote of 74 to 19.
By last weekend, the Bush Administration and the banking lobby had begun damage control. Top officials like Vice President Dan Quayle and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady went on television to argue that the D'Amato amendment could put shaky banks out of business, cause millions of Americans with less than sterling credit to have their cards recalled and seriously harm the economy. Bankers flooded lawmakers' offices with telephone calls and faxes. Opponents of the credit card proposal said it had caused the 120-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average Nov. 15.
Last week, the politicians, even Democrats who reveled in the embarrassment the issue was causing President Bush, got cold feet. By week's end, it appeared that if any measure is enacted this year it will do little more than require a study of credit card interest rates by the General Accounting Office, the Government's auditor.
Senator D'Amato said, nonetheless, that he had achieved his main purpose: to focus attention on lack of competition in the credit industry and the danger of giving credit so freely to people who cannot handle it responsibly.
On the question of competition, Mr. D'Amato is only partly right. Six thousand different companies offer credit cards. (Mastercard and Visa are basically clearing houses. The banks and other institutions that issue the cards set the fees, interest rates and other conditions.) The biggest issuer of credit cards, Citicorp, has only about 4 percent of the market.
But the Senator is correct that the companies do not usually compete on interest rates. Seven of the 10 largest credit card issuers charge exactly 19.8 percent on unpaid balances, and that rate remained constant when other interest rates fell sharply in the last couple of years. Scott P. Marks, director of the credit card business at one of those companies, First Chicago Corporation, said the rate was a holdover from the late 1970's.
Mr. Marks said that companies do not win more customers with lower rates. Instead, they expand through marketing and by offering new services like product discounts and frequent flyer miles. "Rather than keeping credit conditions constant and lowering rates," Mr. Marks said, "most of us have expanded the credit risk profile we are willing to accept."
What that means is that more cards are being given to people with poor credit records, and that worries many experts. Twenty years ago, for example, men and women right out of college, even if they had good jobs and steady incomes, could not get credit cards unless their parents co-signed for them. Today, students are wooed the minute they enroll in college if not before. Mr. Marks said his 10-year-old son recently received a solicitation "from a large and well established competitor."
George Paine, a Federal bankruptcy court judge in Nashville, said excessive credit card debt was probably the most important factor in the swelling number of consumer bankruptcies in the United States in recent years. In one recent case, Judge Paine said, a businessman who owed $183,000 on 41 different credit cards received an unsolicited application for another card with a $5,000 credit limit. He got the card, immediately took a cash advance of $4,500 and charged $500 worth of goods. This was the straw that pushed him into bankruptcy.
"He didn't lie on his application," Judge Paine said. "They just never asked him how many other cards he had or what his unsecured debt was."
From the issuers' perspective, the best customers are not those who are the best credit risks. Lawrence W. Ausubel, an economist at Northwestern University, identifies three kinds of credit card users: people who pay their bills each month and are never charged interest, people who intend to pay their bills but at the end of the month cannot quite manage, and people who run up bills knowing full well they cannot afford them. The companies make little if any money on the first group, who are the best risks and make up about one-fourth of all card holders. They lose money on the third group, the poorest risks, because of defaults. "The middle group," Mr. Ausubel said, "is where the profit is for the banks."
And the profit can be handsome. The best-run banks in the country earn an after-tax profit of about 1 percent on their conventional loans and other assets. But industry figures show the profit margin on credit cards to be about 2 percent. With many banks strapped because of bad commercial real estate loans, the credit card business is a bright spot.
No solution is obvious. Banks will continue to issue cards freely as long as it is profitable to do so and will charge high interest rates as long as customers do not balk. A ceiling on interest rates would probably be counterproductive economically, and Government restrictions on who could have credit cards would never be acceptable politically.
Elizabeth Warren, a law professor at the University of Pennsylvania and an expert on consumer debt, said she herself could not imagine living without credit cards. But she said she was concerned. "A lot of people," she said, "are on the plastic edge of survival."

International 3-23
 
POLLUTION TRANSFORMS BLACK SEA
For centuries, the Black Sea produced dolphin skins and caviar and fish so plentiful that no one thought such bounty could ever end. But pollution is causing changes. Page 1 

HAITIANS FLEEING MISERY AND FEAR

HEADLINE: Fleeing Haitians Fear Army More Than the Perils at Sea

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTROUIS, Haiti, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Roger Emilien says his decision to leave his country aboard a rickety boat for the United States was made this month, when he saw soldiers on his street corner in a Port-au-Prince slum order an arrested man to sit, and then shot him, leaving him for dead.
Like scores of other Haitians who have decided that the risks of drowning or detection on the high seas are better than the misery and fear they face at home, the 56-year-old Mr. Emilien said the brutality of the army since the coup that overthrew President Jean-Bertrand Aristide nearly two months ago had clinched his decision to seek a new life in America. 
 "I can tell you now the whole country lives in fear," said Mr. Emilien, crying as he held tightly onto two small bags, which he said contained all of his remaining belongings, plus whatever food he said he could muster for a 700 mile voyage that he acknowledged might end in tragedy.
The United States Coast Guard has made an intensive effort to stem the perilous tide of Haitians trying to reach southern Florida by stationing cutters off Haiti's shores to intercept them. But dozens of people who have come from various parts of the country to this town, where they waited to sail to the nearby Haitian island of La Gonave, said they would not be so easily stopped from leaving their badly torn country.
In the space of a half hour standing in the dusty path to the sea here, a small crowd of voayagers, each carrying a bundle of belongings, assembled around a reporter to share their tales of hardship and explain how they had arranged to make the trip from La Gonave, which has become an important staging point for sea voyages to the United States.
While most of the Haitians said that their lives were rendered even harsher by an international embargo imposed to punish the country's coup leaders, they said fear and uncertainty had driven them to sell all of their possessions and borrow when they could to gather the $400 or so they said was required by the boat operators to escape their homeland.
"Its hard if you have children you can't feed, you don't have any money, and on top of that there is nothing but insecurity," said one a man in a straw hat who snapped his fingers for emphasis as he spoke. "Even if you own a house, you can't sleep in it anymore. The soldiers can come at any time, and by the time you hear the gunfire, it may be too late."
 
'We Had to Go'
 "We have heard all the stories about the danger of the boats," said another man in his 50's, who had just returned from Port-au-Prince to seek news of a brother who had left by sea earlier in the month and was now himself setting out for La Gonave. "We live with death everyday in this country. For us, the situation has become so bad we had to go."
Haiti's provisional Government and the military commanders who overthrew President Aristide say that only about 100 people died in the coup, and deny widespread reports of continuing repression in the country.
But reports from international relief agencies and church workers support stories of intimidation and violence that are commonly heard in once-crowded slums like Cite Soleil and throughout rural Haiti.
United States officials say that most Haitians fleeing their country do not qualify as refugees eligible for political asylum because they are leaving primarily for economic reasons. American officials say that while much of the intimidation and violence in the country is politically motivated, it is general in nature and therefore would not necessarily qualify people fleeing troubled areas for asylum.
Over the last three weeks, the Coast Guard has taken about 3,000 Haitians into custody, holding them aboard American vessels, at the United States Navy base in Guantanamo, Cuba, or at temporary centers in Honduras and Venezuela while the Coast Guard awaits a decision by a Federal court in Florida on whether repatriations to Haiti may be resumed. More than 500 were sent back by the Coast Guard under longstanding American policy before an injunction on the action was issued on Tuesday in response to appeals by refugee advocates.
In Port-au-Prince, the streets of Cite Soleil, one of the capital's most heavily populated areas, are now eerily barren, as many, especially young men, have fled the insecurity for the countryside.
On the drive to Montrouis along a highway emptied by the embargo on oil supplies, women sat in the shade with thick green clusters of bananas, hoping in vain for a ride to the city, where they could be sold before they rot.
From time to time, armed soldiers could be seen escorting prisoners on foot, their hands tied behind their backs. Others, with rifles slung on their shoulders, had apparently commandeered rides on the few civilian vehicles, including bicycles that moved along the road.
 
Flight From Insecurity
 Standing on a dirt road that leads to the sea in this small coastal town, an hour's drive to the north of the capital, Mr. Emilien, the man who witnessed the police shooting on his street corner, trembled as he told of his initial flight from his home in the tin-roofed quarter of Cite Soleil to several other towns in the country in a vain search for a respite from Haiti's climate of insecurity.
"I am already very hungry, and many people have told us we will never make it, because the boats never arrive" Mr. Emilien said in Creole, as he stood with an 19 year old nephew who is accompanying him on the voyage. "But everywhere we went the soldiers were arresting people and going through neighborhoods and shooting. I couldn't take it anymore."
On a small, rocky beach here that faced La Gonave in the blue distance, two 30-foot wooden boats rocked gently in the tide, while workers busily readied a third boat of the same type for the lucrative passenger traffic.
"People come with their bags and pay me to go to La Gonave," said one of the boat captains, who wore several gold chains and an expensive looking watch. "I don't ask them where they are going afterward. That is not my concern."
 
'I Am Tormented Here'
 But most of the other people gathered here were far less cagey, admitting after only brief hesitation that few have any business on La Gonave, a large, but arid and sparsely-inhabited island. Everywhere, the refrain was Miami.
"I am tormented here," said Jean Robert, 30, dressed in a Nike T-shirt and good leather shoes. "I supported Aristide and can be arrested at any time. Others feel that because you have a job, you must be some kind of Macoute, and they want to attack you."
Though his reference was to the Tontons Macoute, the dreaded Duvalier family militia, the word Macoute long ago became generic for bad guy.

HEADLINE: PENTAGON MAKING A LIST OF CHOICES FOR SPENDING CUTS

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23

 BODY:
Fearful of a Congressional stampede on the military budget next year, the Pentagon is quietly preparing options for deeper long-term spending cuts than were planned and that President Bush could use to reclaim the initiative on the domestic front, senior Administration and Defense Department officials say.
The cuts, which would affect fundamental military programs, including troops, weapons purchases and military bases, could free as much as $50 billion over the next five years for use in other domestic programs at a time when Mr. Bush is under growing attack by Democrats who assert that he has failed to address problems at home. 
 The Administration has made no final decision on the deeper reductions, which would probably require modifying last year's budget agreement, and publicly continues to resist cuts beyond the 25 percent reduction in forces envisioned by 1995 under current Pentagon plans.
 
'Pressures Are Growing'
 But Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and General Colin L. Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, have ordered a comprehensive review of future military needs that could result in the deeper reductions in troops, warplanes and aircraft carriers, and some officials said that Mr. Bush could announce an initiative early next year, possibly in his State of the Union Message in January. Under these cuts, the Pentagon's budget could decline to about $240 billion and possibly lower, from $291 billion in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1.
"The pressures are growing on the domestic front for reducing the defense budget beyond the present plan," said Senator John W. Warner of Virginia, the ranking Republican on the Armed Services Committee.
High-ranking Pentagon and Congressional officials say that such pressures have been building in the aftermath of the collapse of Communism, the failed Soviet coup and growing calls for the Bush Administration to give domestic programs higher priority in a Presidential election year. They say that increases the likelihood that the White House will reluctantly order additional cuts in military spending.
"The purpose is to prepare for the worst, but we're not sure the worst will hit," said a senior Defense Department official. "There's really nothing authoritative yet, but certainly people here are thinking that Congress will do something stupid to us."
The reviews are being conducted in extraordinary secrecy by members of the military's Joint Staff under Army Brig. Gen. William Fedorochko, deputy director for force structure and resources, and by senior Pentagon staff members under the guidance of I. Lewis Libby, the principal deputy undersecretary of defense for strategy and resources. Mr. Libby is a top aide to Paul D. Wolfowitz, the Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, who is Mr. Cheney's senior strategic planner.
One possibility under consideration, a senior Pentagon official said, calls for the Army to cut the number of active divisions to 10 by 1995 from 18 now. Under the Pentagon's current plan, Army divisions would be reduced to 12 by 1995.
 
No Plans for Marines
 The Air Force would reduce fighter wings to 20 from 36 now, instead of 26. The Navy would pare its carrier fleet to 9 ships from 14, rather than 12, as currently planned. The Marine Corps, already by far the smallest of the forces, is shrinking to 177,000 troops by 1995 from 194,000 now, and is not likely to suffer much deeper cuts.
Advanced weapons programs, including the B-2 Stealth bomber, the F-22 fighter jet and the Seawolf attack submarine, could be canceled or production schedules could be extended. Under other scenarios, these force reductions would be stretched out through fiscal year 1997.
Cuts would be made gradually, beginning with $3 billion to $7 billion in fiscal year 1993, to avoid large immediate layoffs in the military. Deeper cuts would come in the mid to late 1990's.
"It doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure out that the political process is taking a look at the resources available and how to spend them," said one officer involved in the planning.
Mr. Cheney and General Powell face an agonizing predicament. One of their choices is to stick to their existing plan, resist Congressional efforts to make further reductions and risk lawmakers' dictating additional force cuts to them in next year's budget process.
Or they can take the initiative by combining cuts in forces with further reductions in two areas that are sacred to lawmakers -- military bases and reserve troops, like the National Guard. In this way they would force Congress to share the pain and they would retain some control over the size and shape of the military. Pentagon officials say they do not like this approach because they fear that ceding some cuts to Congress would only whet lawmakers' appetite to pare more.
"Dick Cheney and Colin Powell know how to read the political tea leaves, and everything says the budget has to come down faster than their five-year plan," said Gordon Adams, director of the Defense Budget Project, a nonpartisan research organization here.
For now, though, Mr. Cheney's marching orders are to stand firm. He continues to emphasize that the Pentagon's current reductions will take the military to its lowest troop levels since 1950, and that military spending will be about 3.6 percent of the gross national product. As a proportion of the nation's total output of goods and services, it would be the lowest level of military spending since 1939.
In a number of recent speeches, Mr. Cheney has stepped up his criticism of people who are clamoring for deeper cuts, warning that such reductions could hurt training and readiness and could force the Pentagon to dismiss thousands of troops.
Mr. Cheney has saved his sharpest barbs for Congress, openly voicing frustration with lawmakers who insist on deeper military cuts but who balk at closing bases, trimming the National Guard and shutting down weapons plants in their home districts.
"The choices we're making aren't about jobs back home in the district, it isn't about the economic impact of the defense budget, it's not about how much pork a congressman's able to deliver for the voters back home on election day, it's preparation for the next time we go to war," he said in a speech at the State Department.
 
Posing an Economic Case
 And in a sign of growing desperation as the pressures build, he changed tack last week and tried to make the case that Pentagon cuts were actually prolonging the nation's recession and that deeper cuts could do further damage.
"The changes we're going through in downsizing the force, laying people off, I think is, in effect, slowing down the economy," Mr. Cheney said in an interview with The San Diego Union.
Economists scoff at this, saying that Mr. Cheney's comments are little more than political statements aimed at preventing further cuts. The military and its suppliers make up about 5 percent of the $5.5 trillion G.N.P.
"The effects are very, very small," said Robert D. Reischauer, the director of the Congressional Budget Office and Congress's chief economist.
With the collapse of Communism and the continuing disintegration of the Soviet Union, the American military has lost its main military foe of 40 years.
"There's no obvious, predictable threat out there anymore," Gen. Merrill A. McPeak, the Air Force Chief of Staff, said in an interview. "What we have now is generalized uncertainty."
The military is discovering that it is hard to sell senators and representatives on "generalized uncertainty."
Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, has said that the Pentagon has "got to go back to the drawing board on base force structure." He said he would soon convene hearings to study future national security interests and which forces will be needed to protect them.
And there are rumblings from the Budget Committees that last year's budget agreement preventing the shift of Pentagon money to domestic programs may need re-examining.
"Last year's budget agreement is no longer an adequate blueprint for this country's economic future," said Senator Jim Sasser, a Tennessee Democrat who heads the Senate Budget Committee.

HEADLINE: Fighting Obscurity on Tight Primary Budgets

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
If there is one piece of information that illuminates the difference between this Presidential campaign and the last one, it is this: By October 1987, Michael S. Dukakis had raised $8 million for his primary campaign. By October 1991, the six Democratic Presidential candidates together had raised one-quarter of that amount.
Hampered by a late start, a recession and an incumbent in the White House, several of this year's Democratic candidates are heading into the Presidential primary season with less money than it takes to run a credible campaign for Mayor of New York City. 
 Some of the candidates, like Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, are having so much trouble raising cash that they have already publicly revised their fund-raising goals. Others have done the same thing more quietly.
The candidates' relative poverty, political analysts say, is clearly a hindrance to the Democrats as they try to rally support against a well-financed President. Not only are the candidates fighting the incumbent's power and popularity, they are fighting their own obscurity, a battle best waged with heavy, and expensive, television exposure.
But some Democrats, struggling to make a virtue of necessity, insist that there are advantages to a cheaper primary campaign. They say the early primaries, at least, are likely to be a throwback to the days when the Presidential nomination was won not through television but through talking to voters.
"We're looking at a resurgence of retail politics," said Ann Lewis, a Democratic political consultant. "We're talking about going to coffees and answering questions. These candidates are going to have to earn the free media, because they can't buy the paid stuff."
 
The Inexpensive Path
 Many prominent Democrats also predict that the bargain-basement nature of the campaign will amplify the importance of early primaries. Only those candidates who show strength early on, they say, will attract enough money to survive. This is particularly true because Federal matching campaign money is running low.
New Hampshire holds the nation's first primary, and "the big kick comes this time after that," said Charles T. Manatt, the former chairman of the Democratic National Committee. "Whoever wins that can expect a big lift, both politically and financially."
The last time the Presidential candidates disclosed their financial condition was Sept. 30, just a few weeks after some of them announced that they were running. Filings with the Federal Election Commission show that as of that date former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, who the first Democrat to declare his candidacy, was leading the pack, with $792,000 in contributions.
 
Brown Trails the Field
 Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa was second, with $713,000. Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska and Governor Wilder each had roughly $200,000. Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, who has vowed not to accept any contribution over $100, had $48,000.
Since the last filing, most of the candidates have devoted at least half their waking hours to raising money, either on the cocktail circuit or on the telephone.
"Fund raising is a very important part of the schedule, and anyone who tells you otherwise is not telling the truth," said Lorraine Voles, press secretary to Senator Harkin. "I know it's 50 percent of the schedule; I just don't know if it's 70 percent."
All of the Democratic candidates say they have made advances in raising money since the end of September, although most refuse to give specifics. But the modesty of their financial gains has been underscored by President Bush's recent fund-raising triumphs. The President reported no contributions at all in the September filing, but at a handful of events over the last few weeks, Republican Party officials say he has raised more than $5 million.
The Democrats' fund-raising difficulties can be traced to all the usual problems of the party out of power, and several unusual ones as well.
The weak economy has clearly handicapped the Democrats, particularly since both New York and California, the party's traditional gold coasts, have been hard hit. "George Bush's recession is helping George Bush because it's hurting Democrats," said John A. Marino, chairman of the New York State Democratic Party.
The candidates are also disadvantaged by their late start; they have simply not been campaigning long enough to cultivate the kind of national fund-raising network that helped Mr. Dukakis clinch the nomination.
Finally, there is the problem of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York. Many potential donors, particularly in the Governor's home state, appear to be waiting for Mr. Cuomo to conclude his public agonizing before they sign a check. If Mr. Cuomo does enter the race, he is expected to attract substantially more money than any of his Democratic rivals.
"Until the bloody Governor makes up his mind," said one New York Democrat who has raised money for Presidential candidates in the past, "it is very hard to go with anyone else."
Mr. Cuomo has done no Presidential fund raising, and most of the $4 million in his campaign fund for governor cannot be used in a Federal election.
 
Giving Less, Eating Less
 The circumstances of the campaign have produced lower expectations all around. While the legal limit for Presidential contributions, $1,000 a person, was once the standard price for dinner with a candidate, Democratic Party officials report that $250-a-plate events have become common. Wealthy contributors who were once expected to assemble $10,000 or even $50,000 from their friends are now being asked to come up with $5,000.
Even the hors d'oeuvres have been slashed.
"We had one $1,000 event where there were literally two dinner plates of crudites with dip in the middle," said Ron Fried, finance chairman for Senator Kerrey's campaign. "We're thinking of doing a fund-raiser without any food or drinks at all."
Hard times have also prompted the Democrats to embrace some novel fund-raising ideas. Last week, for example, the Harkin campaign organized more than 1,200 birthday parties for the Senator, who was 52 years old on Nov. 18. Each party was supposed to raise about $300.
Mr. Brown's low-budget campaign has gone a step further, forgoing fund-raising events altogether and establishing a toll-free telephone number to accept pledges.
In any campaign, "early money" is the hardest to raise, and also the most important. A promising early fund-raising effort can confer front-runner status on a candidate even before a vote has been cast. "Money is the first primary," said Bob Farmer, who masterminded Mr. Dukakis's fund-raising effort in 1988 and is now helping Governor Clinton.
Unfortunately for the Democrats, early money, which is precisely what they are having so much trouble raising, is more crucial than ever this year. This is because the pool of Federal matching dollars for Presidential candidates is likely to run out before the end of the primaries.
To qualify for Federal money, a candidate must raise at least $5,000 in each of 20 states, made up of contributions of $250 or less. Once a candidate has qualified, all contributions of $250 or less are supposed to be matched by Federal money. So far, Mr. Tsongas is the only Democrat who has qualified for such financing.
But partly because of the decline in the number of taxpayers who have checked off $1 for the fund, Federal election officials estimate that the fund will be short by more than $2 million before the first 1992 primary takes place. Candidates who qualify for the missing money are supposed to be reimbursed eventually, as new payments to the fund are made. But in the early months of the campaign, few candidates are likely to be able to hold out.
"Their concern is that they need the money right then," said Scott Moxley, a spokesman for the Federal Election Commission.
Most of the Democratic candidates have been close-mouthed about their fund-raising goals, not wanting to suffer a public setback if they fail to meet them. But those like Governor Wilder who have announced a timetable for themselves have found it difficult to live up to.
Last week Mr. Wilder, the nation's first elected black governor, sent a letter to supporters bemoaning the nation's continuing racial divisions and appealing for donations. In the letter, the Governor quietly revised an earlier schedule; instead of raising $1 million by the end of the year, as he had planned, he said he now hoped to raise that amount by Feb. 1.
Even those candidates who insist publicly that they are meeting their goals are rumored to be falling short. Staff members for Senator Harkin, for example, say that their fund-raising efforts are on track and have brought in more than $1 million. But this amount falls short of the $5 million to $10 million that his aides are reported to have privately discussed as a goal.
Aides to Mr. Tsongas say they still hope to reach $1 million by the end of the year. But as Nick Rizzo, Mr. Tsongas's finance chairman, acknowledged, "It's been a fight all the way."

HEADLINE: Tax Protesters Vent Anger at Hartford Hearing

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 23

 BODY:
One man yesterday identified himself only as "a tax slave from Wallingford." Another stood and shouted like a prophet: "November's coming! November's coming!" A third told state lawmakers to show some spine and not be swayed by "Gestapo threats and tactics."
It was the first of three public hearings on what should be done with Connecticut's three-month-old income-tax law, and it was clear that the lawmakers holding the hearing were braced for the worst from the 500 taxpayers on hand. 
 Security was tight, and even included searches of people's handbags, an almost unheard of precaution in a building where the metal detectors are rarely used. Two handguns were confiscated, along with several cans of Mace and a knife, the police said.
 
Anguish and Humor
 Inside the committee room, there were moments of anguish balanced by flashes of humor, as members of the General Assembly's Appropriations and Finance Committees listened to scores of speakers for eight hours.
"You're on very thin ice," said one income-tax opponent, Walt Mattesen Jr. of Stafford Springs. Most people he knows have already decided to follow New Jersey's example and throw out the Legislature next November, he said.
And do not look to Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. to help you, Mr. Mattesen added calmly. "He's not going to care that you never hold public office again."
The unusual Saturday hearing, conducted by at the Legislative Office Building in Hartford, shed little new light on the state's tax debate. The vast majority of citizen speakers -- each allowed three minutes for an opening statement -- did not mention any of the various bills that have been proposed either to modify the income-tax law or to replace it, ostensibly the point of the hearing. Many were clearly there only to vent anger and would not even take questions from lawmakers.
Some attacked the process itself.
"Don't humor me and tell me that you want to hear our ideas and thoughts, because it's obvious that you don't," said Jon Garrity, a Bridgeport resident who came to the capital at 6 A.M. to be one of the first in line to speak in favor of repealing the wage tax.
Not all were against the wage tax, however. Some came to voice their support, saying the tax was fair because it fell less heavily on the poor than the old sales-tax-based system.
Others, including the first speaker of the day, Peter Smith, said that getting rid of the income tax could mean cutting state spending for the alcohol-abuse recovery program that he said had saved his life several years ago when he was living in the streets of Hartford.
"Those cuts are going to hurt a lot of people," Mr. Smith said.
The impact of the hearings, which continue on Monday and Tuesday, will not be known until votes are held in the Assembly next month on whether to repeal the tax, but lawmakers on each side of the question appeared ready yesterday to use the hearings to bolster their case.
"The fact that these are regular people who believe very deeply and are asking for relief has to have an impact politically," said Representative Thomas S. Luby, a Democrat from Meriden on the Appropriations Committee who supports replacing the wage tax.
Mr. Luby, a former prosecutor, compared the anti-tax speakers to crime victims, saying they would dramatize the human element in what is often discussed in only abstract terms.
Repeal leaders have said a strong majority stands ready to vote for scrapping the tax. But neither the House nor the Senate has apparently mustered the two-thirds majority that would be required to force repeal over Mr. Weicker's promised veto.
 
Income-Tax Supporter
 One income tax supporter, Representative Geri Langlois, a Democrat from Thompson, said he thought that emotional anti-tax appeals could very well aid his own cause: making the tax more fair by lowering the burden on the middle-class wage earners who were most heavily represented today.
Mr. Langlois, along with a group of other Democrats, proposed this week replacing the 4.5 percent flat-rate income tax, with one of two alternatives, both of which would raise the effective tax rate on upper income families earning above $100,000, thus allowing tax cuts for those people earning less.
"It may not be exactly what they want," Mr. Langlois said of his revised tax plan. "But quite frankly it's not possible to give people exactly what they want in this economic environment. At least that's responsive to what people are saying."

HEADLINE: CANADA RETHINKS ITS HEALTH CARE

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Nov. 17

 BODY:
An unparalleled round of hospital staff layoffs and bed closings has hit Canada's national health-care system as it struggles against the biggest crunch in resources since the Medical Care Act came into effect in 1966.
Ontario, the richest and most populous province, where more than a third of Canadians live, has lost nearly 5,000 hospital jobs and 3,500 beds over the last two years. In Toronto, the provincial capital, 2,900 of 15,000 acute-care beds have been taken out of service. 
 Other institutions in other regions have introduced similar cutbacks as budget deficits, high debts and spending ceilings at both the provincial and Federal level are shutting off flows of new money for the national health program, which costs $60 billion a year.
Judy Darcy, national president of the Canadian Union of Public Employees, representing 90,000 health-care workers, said, "Medicare is being dismantled before our very eyes."
 
Time of Soul-Searching
 Although not everyone agrees, shrinking Government revenue caused by Canada's recession, combined with exploding medical costs, are suddenly raising profound questions about the future of a health-care system that is almost as much a national symbol as the maple leaf and red-coated Mountie.
The soul-searching over new ways to finance medical care comes as the United States is going through its own debate about whether to adopt a Canadian-type system -- in which everyone is promised equal access to doctors and hospitals through provincial insurance plans covering practically all medical expenses.
For years, the system has been cited as a sign that Canada is a kinder, gentler country than its neighbor.
 
System of Contradictions?
 In the Pennsylvania Senate election earlier this month, the victor, Harris Wofford, a Democrat, came from behind with a campaign advocating national health care. If people have a fundamental right to a lawyer when accused of a crime, he argued, they should have a right to a doctor when they get sick.
In Canada, that right has existed for a quarter-century and has produced a high level of basic care for most Canadians. Yet today as hospital staff and beds are cut back, a number of influential commentators are warning that the system is beset by contradictions.
A recent editorial in The Toronto Star said: "We, the taxpayers of Canada, are not willing to pay for the level of service that we, the users of medicare, want. After 25 years of congratulating ourselves on having one of the finest health-care programs in the world, we have begun to wonder whether we can afford it."
 
Managing Finite Resources
 A best seller, "The Trouble With Canada," by William D. Gairdner, makes a similar point -- "the demand for an unlimited free commodity is infinite" -- and says the "Government must recognize it has made a mistake."
Yet the system is still so popular it would be political suicide to end it. The issue today is not so much dismantlement as how to manage existing, finite resources more effectively.
"To survive intact, our system will have to adjust -- and adjust quickly -- to a whole new set of realities," said Ontario's Health Minister, Frances Lankin.
 
Pressure for More Cuts
 In Manitoba, the provincial government is so desperate for revenue for its $2.5 billion health budget that it is studying the possibility of marketing health services to Americans. But critics say the plan could deprive Canadians of basic health care, or at least shuffle them to the end of surgery lists in favor of cash-paying Americans.
More than 300 hospital beds have closed in British Columbia this year, the Hospital Employees Union of British Columbia said, and with 30 percent of the province's hospitals saying they will be short of money next year, the pressure for cuts is likely to continue.
But nowhere are the difficulties so acute as in Ontario. "We are going through a period of unprecedented down-sizing and our projections are that it's going to accelerate," said Dennis Timbrell, president of the 224-member Ontario Hospital Association.
 
A Leader Contracts
 The 99-year-old St. Michael's Hospital in Toronto, one of the first in Ontario to perform open-heart surgery and the first in North America to do a muscle transplant, has just announced a severe contraction, cautioning that it will have "dramatic consequences" for patient service.
Even though the Ontario government is now run by socialist-leaning New Democrats, firmly wedded to the concept of national medical care, Health Minister Lankin said she was not about to ask for any increase in the $17 billion the province has allocated this year for its health budget.
The projected budget deficit for this year stands at a staggering $9.7 billion, and Treasurer Floyd Laughren is even having trouble meeting that target because of declining revenues. The $17 billion, moreover, represents about a third of the total provincial budget.
 
Different Financing Systems
 The Canadian national health-insurance system comes primarily under the jurisdiction of the 10 provinces and two territories, which share costs with the Federal Government. Ottawa used to contribute 50 percent, but this has been cut back over the years and today stands at 38 percent.
