HEADLINE: Science Publishers Bridging U.S.-Soviet Gap

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
For the first time since the end of the cold war, editors of 19 leading Russian physics journals met last week with American counterparts to discuss the broadening of scientific exchanges between the two countries. But underlying the camaraderie was some hard-nosed bargaining between the two nations' scientific publishers, each side hoping to cut costs in the face of mounting economic pressures at home.
As the two delegations sat down for talks at Loews New York Hotel in Manhattan, an American physicist asked, "Are you speaking for Soviet physics journals, or Russian ones?" After a long pause, one of the Russians replied: "We don't really know. But maybe they're the same thing now." 
 The rapid changes in the Soviet Union during the last year have deeply disrupted the organizational structure of Soviet science. Scientists employed by powerful state science institutes, who formerly were virtually guaranteed lifetime jobs in their professional specialties, now face uncertain futures. Another change expected soon is the abolition of a powerful Soviet state enterprise called the All-Union Organization for Authors Rights, which since 1975 has controlled copyright agreements between the Soviet press and foreign publishers. With the demise of this organization, each Soviet scientific group would be free to make its own deals with Western publishers.
The non-profit American Institute of Physics, an umbrella group serving all the specialized physics societies in the United States, organized last week's series of meetings with Soviet publishers. The A.I.P., which publishes many physics journals in specialized fields, has a contract with the Soviet copyright agency until 1993, but if the Soviet agency is disbanded soon, new contracts would have to be negotiated.
The subscription prices of American physics journals are high, and a large share of the A.I.P.'s foreign publishing earnings comes from the Soviet Union. But the Soviet journals formerly locked into a collective agreement negotiated by the Soviet Government may soon be able to seek better reciprocal deals with competing Western scientific publishers, like Germany's giant Springer Verlag.
"One of our big problems," said Dr. Yuri V. Shmartsev, an editor of the Soviet journal Semiconductors, "is the price of American journals. Soviet physicists can now read these journals freely, provided they understand English and can pay prices that are much higher than those of Soviet journals. Starting in January, though, the editorial board of each Russian journal can receive two free subscriptions to each American physics journal, and will make U.S. scientific literature more accessible to us."
American scientific publishers acknowledged that Soviet papers are rarely read in the United States, partly because Soviet science has been widely regarded by American scientists as spotty or inferior in quality. "But that bias is disappearing," said Dr. Robert Beyer of the A.I.P.
 
Costly Subscriptions
 Subscriptions to English-language translations of Soviet journals are also expensive. Dr. Beyer said that a year's subscription to a translated version of JETP, the Soviet Journal of Experimental and Theoretical Physics, costs more than $1,000.
Dr. Kenneth Ford, chief executive of the A.I.P., said that the new era of Soviet-American scientific cooperation had already led to quicker exchanges of publications. "The November issue of JETP has already been translated into English and is available to American scientists," he said.
Dr. Pyotr S. Isayev of the Dubna Institute, which operates one of the U.S.S.R.'s leading accelerator laboratories, said that many of the Soviet publishers in New York were also having their first face-to-face meetings with other editors of the Soviet scientific press. In the past, professional contacts were limited in the closed Soviet society.
The Americans and Russians found they had many common problems. But they also noticed an important difference. Russian scientists are allowed to participate in the selection of the jury of experts who judge their papers. American journals rarely allow that.

HEADLINE: Another Yale Panel Urges More Women and Minorities for Faculty

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 23

 BODY:
Eighteen times since 1968, committees at Yale have recommended that the university do more to recruit women and minorities for the faculty.
The latest committee said in a report released last month that "Yale's position and its national image in this area remains precariously close to the backwaters of academic progress, not in the position of national leadership we proudly seek and claim in other important areas." 
 On Wednesday, about 50 students demonstrated to protest the denial of tenure to Susanne Wofford, an associate professor of English who has won several teaching prizes for her courses on Shakespeare.
 
President Backs Diversity
 The university's president, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., responded to the report last week by endorsing the goal of increased diversity in the faculty and pledging to prevent budget cuts in Yale programs devised to meet that goal. But he did not offer any new proposals to increase the number of minority and women professors.
Of 725 tenured faculty positions, 70 are held by women and 45 by minorities, of whom five are women. Citing a 1990 survey by Harvard University of minority and women on the faculties at 17 private and public universities, the report said Yale ranked 15th in female faculty representation and 11th in minority faculty representation.
Without endorsing the notion of giving automatic preference to women and minorities, Mr. Schmidt said he expected the proportion of women and minorities on the faculty to continue to grow. "We will proceed toward this goal without lowering in any way Yale's very high standards of appointment," he said.
Mr. Schmidt endorsed the committee's proposal that each department appoint a permanent panel to identify talented minority and women candidates and to coordinate departmental affirmative action programs. But he rejected a proposal to create a panel to review all cases in which a department rejects a minority or woman faculty member for tenure, saying that would undermine the confidentiality of the process.
 
Giving Issue Prominence
 Gerald Jaynes, a professor of economics and Afro-American studies who is chairman of the committee, said he thought the president's response was "very positive," although he expressed disappointment that Mr. Schmidt had rejected some of the committee's recommendations.
"This is a significant improvement because it puts a process into motion that will force decision-making units to consider this issue every time they make an appointment," Professor Jaynes said.
The committee's report attributes the problems at Yale to the lack of a clearly defined set of affirmative action rules and procedures that could be enforced uniformly across all academic departments. "What has resulted is a corpus of procedures and policies that leave departments largely unaided and unrestrained in their individual approaches to the problem," the committee said.
In urging a standard, the committee said a woman or minority "should be deemed better qualified" and therefore selected when he or she is competing with an equally qualifed white male.

HEADLINE: Political Talk

BYLINE: By Sam Howe Verhovek

 BODY:

Stan Who?
 Even though recent election results show that the recession has made it a bad time to be an incumbent, Stan Lundine might like it if a few more people knew he was in office. 
 In a New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll taken earlier this month, only 6 percent of the 1,838 adults questioned in downstate New York could identify Mr. Lundine as the Lieutenant Governor.
Another 5 percent of those surveyed, when asked if they knew who the Lieutenant Governor was, named someone else. And 88 percent did not have a clue.
Still, Mr. Lundine joked that he did not mind the anonymity, given that the same poll showed high levels of dissatisfaction with Governors Mario M. Cuomo of New York, Jim Florio of New Jersey and Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut.
"What a great time it is to lay low," Mr. Lundine said. "If they don't know your name, how can they hate you?"
The poll was taken from Nov. 2 to Nov. 12 in New York City, Long Island, and Westchester, Rockland, Putnam and Orange counties as well as in New Jersey and Connecticut. It has a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points.
As a former congressman from Jamestown in the state's southwestern corner, Mr. Lundine has long recognized that his is not a household name in metropolitan New York. But the poll results indicate that his recent efforts to get known in New York City have yet to bear fruit.
Mr. Lundine has been Mr. Cuomo's hand-picked deputy since 1987 and has not disguised his ambition to succeed Mr. Cuomo as Governor. His name recognition would undoubtedly rise if Mr. Cuomo decides to run for President.
If Mr. Cuomo decides to resign as Governor, which seems highly unlikely, Mr. Lundine would take his place. But even if Mr. Cuomo runs for President while remaining Governor, Mr. Lundine would play a more visible role in the day-to-day operation of the government.
 
Shedding Civility
 In the annals of frosty relations between New York City Mayors and their Albany counterparts in the Governor's office, David N. Dinkins and Mr. Cuomo have managed to keep things relatively civil in public, even amid the tremendous tensions brought on by chronic budget problems.
Mr. Dinkins has refrained from calling Mr. Cuomo "an 800-pound gorilla," as Edward I. Koch once did, and he often says he would like to be in the "vanguard" of a Cuomo Presidential campaign if there ever is such a thing.
But it is no secret that there has been plenty of behind-the-scenes animosity in the last year, with heated arguments over pay raises granted by the city and local-aid cuts imposed by the state. And last week, after the Cuomo administration announced next year's state budget gap may be double its previous estimate, Mr. Dinkins offered an unusual public venting of his frustrations that amounted to a slap at the Governor.
"I can only say that if we were to come out with an estimate today and a week or so later say it's double that, almost to a person you all would say we don't know what we're doing," the Mayor told reporters.
Mr. Dinkins also pointed out that he had produced two budgets "on balance and on time" while Mr. Cuomo and state leaders were setting two consecutive records for lateness. It should be pointed out that in one the many Byzantine stretches of Albany logic, state law essentially forces the city to shut down if it does not have a balanced, timely budget -- a requirement from which state government has exempted itself.
If the Governor took any offense at the Mayor's rebuke, he certainly tried not to show it in public. "I have congratulated him for that over and over," he said of Mr. Dinkins's performance on his budget. "I say it very openly that he did it better than we did."
 
Identity Crisis
 The special legislative session now under way to consider the repeal of Connecticut's three-month-old income tax law has a powerful subtext agenda for many Democrats, who hold the majority in both chambers of the General Assembly.
John F. Droney Jr., the party's state chairman and one of the loudest and brashest opponents of the income tax, announced his resignation last month, and as the party battles within itself on the income-tax question, it simultaneously has to decide the ideology of the next chairman.
Should he or she reflect the majority of Democrats in the Legislature who voted for the income tax? Or should the next chair continue to be opposed, and so dispel the potential notion among voters that the Democrats are the monolithic party of the income tax?
Moderate Democrats in the House, who last week proposed a no-income-tax alternative that would extend a 2.5 percent "transactions" tax on almost every level of economic activity in the state, have said that sending a message of disunity is a primary goal, and that some of the tax struggles of the special session really reflect a sort of public identity crisis.
"It's a front for the battle," said Representative Carl J. Schiessl, a Democrat from Windsor Locks and a leader of the moderate group. "The direction of the party may be set by whoever wins."
 
A Familiar Voice Moves On
 New Yorkers all over the state have heard the rich baritone voice of the political reporter Walt Wheeler, who covered New York City's fiscal crisis in the mid-1970's for WCBS-AM and, more recently, kept tabs on Albany for the 16 stations he served on the Empire State Network News, a newsgathering cooperative he directed.
Mr. Wheeler seems to have such a perfect radio voice that politicians and even his fellow reporters have been known to ask him to repeat his questions just so they could hear him speak again. Governor Cuomo once joked that he wasn't sure he could tell the difference between the voice of God and the "voice of Walt."
Now, though, he is embarking on the radio reporter's equivalent of hanging up his cleats, his network having succumbed to the ravages of the recession. Reporters can still hear his voice -- his new job is as a spokesman for the state Division of Military and Naval Affairs -- but the tone of the state's airwaves will be a little less richer without it.

HEADLINE: BACKTALK;
Sports Are More Than Games in the Groves of Academe

BYLINE: BY ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
THE Footnote League has opened its season and the air is filled with flying hypotheses and the heady crunch of fresh ideas.
It is the time of academic conferences, and these days there are few meetings of historians or political scientists or sociologists without at least one session on the intricate relationship between sports and society. 
 In Chicago last week, for example, the 90th meeting of the American Anthropological Association included a morning devoted to the identity crises of women who pump iron and ride motorcycles. Among the papers delivered was Barbara Joans's "Dykes on Bikes Meets Ladies of Harley."
"It's part of what's happened in academia generally," said Peter Levine, a historian at Michigan State. "Those of us who came of age during Vietnam began to study history from the bottom up -- working people, blacks, women -- and sports is certainly something that affected millions of everyday lives."
Professor Levine is a Jacksonian, an expert in 19th century American political and social history, but he is best known for "A. G. Spalding and the Rise of Baseball" (Oxford, 1985), a lively tale of the original George Steinbrenner and the not coincidental emergence of the national pastime and the middle class.
"A very important book," said Professor Charles P. Korr, a historian at the University of Missouri-St. Louis. "I've ripped it off in half-a-dozen conferences, here, Hungary, Australia. It's part of the current movement to apply what we learn from studying sports to the real social problems of the larger culture."
Professor Korr's original area of expertise is 17th century Cromwellian foreign policy. He is currently writing a book on "the union that revolutionized sports," the Major League Baseball Players' Association. With his new expertise, Korr is on his way to a conference in Florence, Italy, sponsored by the members of the Common Market. They are facing the problem next year of not only unrestricted trade but of the unrestricted flow of foreign workers. How will this affect all the soccer clubs? And the national teams?
Twenty years ago, the relationship between sports and academia was far less intellectually rigorous and more likely to be either confrontational (such activists with doctorates as Richard Lapchick, Harry Edwards, Jack Scott and Mark Naison gave the profession some credible muscle) or sycophantic (thousands of men with leather elbow patches who sat at the 50-yard line to watch the players they were passing, but never teaching).
While interesting, pioneering work was being done, primarily in college physical education and sociology departments, in kinetics, behavior and the role of the emerging female athlete, the output was erratic. Too many papers had the words "anomie" or "agon" in the title, and there was a bit too much on the flip side: i.e., the Oedipal aspects of baseball in which the son (batter), waving a you-know-what, tries to interrupt the relationship between the father (pitcher) and the mother (catcher).
Traditionally, most academic departments looked down on sports studies. But in the 70's, when enrollments in many of the liberal arts slipped, professors began to scramble for sexy ways to repackage history and sociology and even literature courses. "The Rise of Baseball" was as good a way as any to study 20th century America and had a better chance of packing the hall. Not only did students flock to such courses, but many went on to take other, more orthodox, courses in the field.
And there has been research progress as well. In one recent thought-provoking study, two economists, Sumner LaCroix of the University of Hawaii and Torben Andersen of Red Deer College in Alberta, Canada, compared black and white baseball superstars who had similar performance statistics. While their salaries were comparable (the economists suggested that arbitration was color blind), the value of their trading cards were not. Collectors, mainly youngsters, paid higher prices for the cards of white players.
In recent years, the literature of sports has been enriched more by
Ph.D.'s than by sportswriters. Worth serious study are Bruce Kuklick's "To Every Thing a Season: Shibe Park and Urban Philadelphia" (Princeton, 1991); Elliot J. Gorn's "The Manly Art: Bare-Knuckle Prize-fighting in America" (Cornell, 1986), and William J. Baker's "Jesse Owens: An American Life" (Free Press, 1986).
The works of John J. MacAloon of the University of Chicago, Jules Tygiel of San Francisco State, Michael V. Oriard of Oregon State and Bruce Kidd of the University of Toronto have been outstanding over the years.
Professor Levine, at work on his study of Jews in sport, "From Ellis Island to Ebbets Field," sees even better seasons ahead.
"We tended to wait until we were tenured and secure before we studied sports," he said. "But there's a new generation of scholars who have come right into sports through black studies and gender studies and they will have a lot to say that's worth hearing."
Meanwhile, at Springfield College in Massachusetts, members of the Sports Literature Association are still talking about George Grella's recent paper on "Karl Marx: Tennis Anyone?" And out at Creighton University in Nebraska they are waiting for papers to fill their proposed volume, "The Psyche At Play," a volume on Jungian and Archetypal Approaches to Sports and Athletics.

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
Yankees' Fiscal Policy Offers Less for More

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
The signs are so unmistakably there, it's deja vu all over again, as Yogi Berra, who played for and managed both teams, maybe said. The Yankees resemble the Mets of the M. Donald Grant years, and the Yankees' fans may have to adopt the same strategy as the Mets' fans of those years.
Because Grant, who ran the team for Lorinda deRoulet, refused to spend money on free agents, contending that his way would be proved right, the Mets steadily deteriorated in the late 70's. Refusing to accept repeated last-place finishes, the fans dwindled too, reaching a franchise-low 788,905 in 1979. 
 Faced with severely declining revenue, deRoulet and her family were forced to sell the team, a transaction that led to the rebirth of the Mets and the return of the fans to Shea Stadium.
Now it's the Yankees who, for some unexplained reason, don't seem to want to spend money, even though they have lots to spend, and then some. The deterioration that got a running start under George Steinbrenner has continued without his presence (though possibly not without his input).
 
No Improvement Promised
 Not surprisingly, the attendance has deteriorated, too, falling this year to 1,863,731, second lowest for a full season since 1975.
But the Yankees aren't content with spending less; they want to take in more. Without promising instant improvement, the Yankees have announced the largest ticket-price increase in their history, topped by an additional $2 for a lower-level box seat.
What have the Yankees done to justify the increase? Obviously nothing. They are, in fact, asking their fans to pay more for less. Given their guaranteed revenue from local and national television, they appear to be greedy without being considerate of their fans.
The Yankees will receive between $35 million and $40 million next year for the local television and cable rights to their games. The next most lucrative local rights belong to the Mets, who will receive about $22 million. The Yankees also will get about $14 million from the CBS-ESPN package. There's no recession in those numbers.
This hardly seems like a team that has to save money by dismissing several low-level office employees and needs additional revenue from ticket sales.
 
Red Sox Revenue
 Baseball history teaches that winning teams draw more fans than mediocre and bad teams. If the Yankees had attracted an extra 500,000 fans this year, putting them at a level they have attained when they have been legitimate contenders, their revenue, at an average ticket price of $10.56, would have risen by more than $5 million on ticket sales alone.
The Boston Red Sox, in the race until the last 10 days of the season, had ticket revenue, based on a $10.30 average, of $26.4 million compared with $19.7 million for the Yankees.
Win, and they will come. Lose, and they will stay home. The Mets' fans did it. The Yankees' fans may learn from their experience.
As for the reason behind the Yankees' strange fiscal policy, some people in baseball suspect Steinbrenner. He still controls more than 50 percent of the team, and he is not a silent partner. The theory is he wants the Yankees to fail miserably for two reasons:
It would show that only he can operate the Yankees successfully (even though recent history says he can't), and people would begin clamoring for his return.
 
Reds Talking About Davis
 Give the Cincinnati Reds credit. Unlike many teams, they are prepared to trade a major player to a team in their division, unconcerned that the player could have an adverse impact on their chances for a divsion championship.
Barring some unexpected snag, the Reds are expected to trade Eric Davis before the winter meetings, which are in two weeks. They have mixed feelings because they suspect that Davis will have an outstanding season in 1992, but at least some people in the organization have grown weary of his presence and are concerned about the contract they would have to give him to keep him beyond next season.
"I can't characterize it as close," General Manager Bob Quinn said, talking about a Davis deal. "We're talking and exchanging ideas with two or three clubs."
The San Diego Padres appear to be the team most likely to acquire Davis, but the Los Angeles Dodgers also are a possibility. The Reds bolstered their starting-pitching rotation by acquiring Greg Swindell, a potential 20-game winner from Cleveland, but want to strengthen it even further.
The Dodgers are reluctant to give up a pitcher until they re-sign one or both of their free agents, Orel Hershiser and Mike Morgan, which could put them at a disadvantage because the Reds want to make a deal sooner rather than later.
 
'That's Their Baby'
 The Padres would reluctantly give the Reds a 26-year-old pitcher, Jose Melendez, who had an 8-5 record and a 3.27 earned run average in nine starts and 22 relief appearances this year. Bip Roberts, who can play anywhere, and Thomas Howard, an outfielder, could also be included.
Whoever gets Davis would be at risk because he can be a free agent next winter. Quinn said he would not agree to a conditional deal, by which the acquiring team would have to sign Davis to a new contract before completing the trade.
"We didn't do it with Swindell," Quinn said. "We wouldn't go that route. That's not the right way to approach a deal. That's their baby, just like Swindell is ours."
That means a team could have the center fielder for only one year. On the other hand, if a team were able to sign Davis to a multi-year contract, it would do so in the best tradition of caveat emptor. As one National League general manager said, "Once you sign him, say to a three-year contract, does that mean he doesn't play hard for two years, then plays hard the last year of the contract?"
 
Dollars, Not Sense
 Leave it to baseball club owners to blunder so badly they embarrass themselves and the commissioner of their sport.
The owners went out and hired Richard Ravitch to be head of the Player Relations Committee, their labor arm, and they gave him a $750,000 salary. Fine, but Commissioner Fay Vincent has a $650,000 salary, and the chief labor negotiator isn't supposed to be paid better than the commissioner.
The owners who hired Ravitch supposedly didn't discover their fiscal oversight until an Executive Council meeting a few weeks ago. It was agreed that the commissioner would have to receive a raise, but compounding the original blunder, instead of acting on Vincent's salary immediately, they delayed long enough for the development to be disclosed publicly.
Vincent will be restored to a commissioner's proper economic position. He, in fact, will join the 223 players in his sport who earned $1 million or more this year. His salary will not include "or more."
 
What McMullen Knows
 John McMullen of the Houston Astros has long been one of the most battered owners for his perceived wrong-headed actions. Yet McMullen seems to be the only owner willing to recognize that blacks have the "necessities" to work in critical jobs. He has had a black assistant general manager, Bob Watson, and now he has a black third-base coach, Tom Spencer.
Chris Chambliss learned yesterday that he was not among the final four candidates for the Chicago White Sox managing job. General Manager Ron Schueler called him with the bad news. Chambliss will manage Atlanta's Class AAA minor league team at Richmond.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Steve Smith Is Making His Point as a Rookie With the Heat

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY

 BODY:
WHEN Steve Smith was growing up, and growing up, and growing up, in the playgrounds around Detroit, his goal was to play point guard just like his idol, Magic Johnson.
Smith got the height nearly right -- 6 feet 8 inches -- and he got the college career right, becoming the leading career scorer at Michigan State. 
 But then Smith was drafted by a losing expansion team, the Miami Heat, which already had a regular point guard, squatty, shuffly Sherman Douglas.
Nothing is permanent, particularly in sports. Wally Pipp once had a headache, or so the legend goes, and maybe the headache came from the onrushing sound of Lou Gehrig, who was getting ready to play 2,130 consecutive games for the Yankees.
Sherman Douglas did not have a headache, at least not at first. He did, however, have a lapsed contract. And while Douglas holds out, and practices alone in a Washington gym, the Heat comes into New York on Tuesday as a winning team. Miami had a 7-3 record going into last night's game in Indiana, and the biggest reason was its new point guard.
Smith had a 14.9-point average in his first 10 games, and is being praised as unselfish by everybody, even Rony Seikaly, the Heat center, who is Douglas's best friend in the league, going back to their Syracuse days.
"They say point guards are a dime a dozen," Seikaly said after a victory over Sacramento on Friday. "But not 6-8 point guards who can see the floor."
Not only can Smith move the ball, he has also played shooting guard and small forward, although he has not gotten around to playing center, the way his hero did to clinch the 1980 N.B.A. championship when Kareem Abdul-Jabbar was injured.
Meanwhile, the Heat has changed from an uptight team that created more turnovers than a bakery on Sunday morning.
"You could see it in his first practice," said Kevin Loughery, the team's new coach. "Steve was a little late reporting, but when he did, he started moving the ball around. He would turn down shots."
Smith, who had played against Magic in summer games, was stunned when his hero retired early this month after tested positive for the virus that causes AIDS.
"You could see it affected him," said Alvin Gentry, a new assistant coach, "but Magic called him and talked to him, and he bounced back."
Smith does not want to talk much about Johnson; he wants to focus on playing in a league he says is even tougher than he had expected.
"You couldn't tell from exhibitions because there were a lot of free agents, and the veterans don't play that hard," Smith said. "But these guys jump even higher than you thought."
Who has impressed Smith the most so far? Charles Barkley. "He just takes over when he gets ready to take over," Smith said. "You know he's going to shoot, but he does it anyway."
Smith has not done badly. The Utah Jazz put its all-league power forward, Karl Malone, on him the other night when the guards couldn't handle him. On Friday, Smith cold-bloodedly scored 23 points over 5-foot-7-inch Spud Webb.
"Yeah, but Spud gave me trouble," Smith said. "He's so quick, he took the ball away from me."
The rookie's attitude is so professional that Lou Schaffel, Miami's managing partner, says Smith has the quiet poise of Julius Erving and Michael Jordan when they joined the league.
Schaffel, of course, is protecting his bargaining position with Douglas. Neither side gives specifics, but Douglas was making $325,000 last year and may have been offered a figure near the $2 million level approached by John Stockton, Terry Porter and Kevin Johnson, the best young point guards. Once Smith signed, the Heat lowered its offer, probably still above $1 million.
Douglas's agent, Eric Fleisher, was given permission to arrange a trade to a club that would meet Douglas's salary demands, but nothing has happened.
"If Sherman agreed to our current offer, we would do the right thing," Schaffel said. "We would love to have him."
In the meantime, Bimbo Coles is playing about half the game at point guard, defending hard and scoring in double figures, and Kevin Edwards is a better player because of his extra time. Even Douglas's supporters doubt he will ever play for the Heat again.
"He's not doing great," Seikaly said of his pal who threw him all the alley-oop passes in college and with the Heat. "I try to put in my two cents, but what can you say? The weird thing is, I would have loved to see Sherman and Steve together."
Will that ever happen? Seikaly shook his head and said, "No, I don't think so."
It is not clear whether Wally Pipp really did have a headache. But Sherman Douglas has a headache. It is called unemployment.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Point guard Steve Smith is turning Miami into a winning team. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Tough Choices as Bush Tries to Break His Slide1

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23

 BODY:
After one of the most battering weeks of his Presidency, George Bush faces crucial decisions on starting up his re-election campaign, the political viability of his chief of staff and how to heal a division that threatens the Republicans' image as the party best able to manage the economy.
The President, who was at Camp David today consulting by telephone with political associates, hopes to start his political rebound on Monday with the first of a quick series of damage-control trips intended to show that he does not have a detached attitude about domestic problems. 
 But as an increasing number of Republican lawmakers and members of his Administration urge Mr. Bush to take quick action on the economy, the trips may serve to underscore the way in which the President and the top White House aides have decided to treat the economy as a public relations problem, not a policy issue.
 
Hopes for the Future
 So far, Mr. Bush has stuck to his decision to wait until his State of the Union Message in January to offer economic proposals and try in the meantime to convince voters that he is engaged on issues that matter to them and that the economy is not as bad as it seems.
To that end, the White House is counting on an effort by House Republicans to force a vote on an economic growth package to shift attention from Mr. Bush's political problems to what one aide today called "a nice, distracting partisan brawl on Capitol Hill."
In the same way, Bush advisers are hoping his announcement of a campaign staff will give them a chance to reframe the political debate over the economy, so far dominated by Democrats and Republicans dissatisfied with Mr. Bush's leadership on the issue.
Republican strategists and Administration officials said today that Mr. Bush was now expected to name his campaign team as early as the first week of December because of mounting political pressure from Democratic attacks, the debate within his own party about tactics and the prospect that he will face challenges in the New Hampshire primary in February.
 
What About Sununu?
 But Mr. Bush still faces a central problem in choosing a campaign team: what to do about his chief of staff, John H. Sununu, whose action this week overshadowed White House efforts to change the subject, as it sought to do last Friday by scheduling a meeting between Mr. Bush and some leading economists.
Republicans close to the White House, uncertain what was in the mind of a President who has kept Mr. Sununu on despite his political gaffes, today offered a variety of options for the chief of staff's fate. Some see Mr. Bush easing Mr. Sununu out by asking him to resign. Others suggest that Mr. Bush might add a layer of campaign managers with direct access to the Oval Office as a way to diminish the chief of staff's power and dampen the impact of Mr. Sununu's stated intention to run the campaign from the White House.
A White House adviser suggested today that while there was "an awful lot of consternation" about Mr. Sununu, staff shake-ups could only further delay efforts to appear empathetic about the economy. "The present cast of characters, even though they may have stumbled, stands as good a chance or better than a totally new cast," this adviser said.
A senior Administration official said today that Mr. Bush has decided he needs to have his top campaign staff in place to respond to an active schedule of Democratic campaign events over the next month.
On Monday, Mr. Bush goes to Columbus, Ohio, to visit schools and day-care centers and talk about educating adults for jobs in medical technology. He plans to visit California, Hawaii, Mississippi, Illinois and Arkansas before Christmas.
 
Pressure on the Economy
 The economic debate within the Republican Party, meanwhile, has become a short-term fight over tactics and public relations, since the party's leading Washington figures are described as deeply divided over the proper prescription for growth.
Mr. Bush and a dominant group of advisers insist on patience, but a growing number of lawmakers and a restive faction within the Administration are calling for dramatic action.
Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp is reported to be urging the President to keep Congress in session and push for tax cuts. Vice President Dan Quayle has been quietly suggesting that the White House may need to revisit the 1990 budget agreement, which has been the unshakeable foundation of Mr. Bush's domestic policy for a year. And more than 80 House Republicans today asked Bush to appoint Mr. Kemp as a domestic policy czar who could "declare war on our domestic ills."
Adding to the conflict and the appearance of confusion is the lack of a basic agreement both within the Administration and between the President and Republicans outside the White House on the state of the economy -- is it in a real recovery, has the recovery stalled or is the recession still going?
This has produced an anomaly that no one in the party would have predicted a few months ago. For years, polls have shown that voters' trust in the Republicans' ability to manage the economy was the party's single strongest asset in domestic policy. But that strength has been steadily eroding, and the economy has emerged as the issue that is both hardest for Republicans to deal with and by far the most threatening for Mr. Bush.
"We have won elections because we reversed the Hoover legacy and became the party of economic growth and competent management," said Representative Vin Weber of Minnesota, a vocal critic of White House economic policy. "If we don't have that mantle going into 1992, it's going to be very difficult for us to win, at the Congressional level and the Presidential level."
 
Trying to Recoup
 Just a few months ago, Mr. Bush and his aides thought they were going to coast through the 1992 Presidential campaign on the strength of high approval ratings and another traditional Republican electoral asset: foreign policy expertise.
Now, as the White House gropes for a way to stop a steady downward spiral of Mr. Bush's popularity, it has tried ill-timed and poorly planned political gestures to demonstrate the President's concern for domestic issues. Each of them has either backfired or added to the impression that Mr. Bush is at a loss about what to do.
Administration officials say the White House has been operating on a basic decision that now is not the time to do anything drastic about the economy and on a commitment to the 1990 budget agreement, a commitment that drives all domestic policy decisions.
This approach is maintained by the White House budget director, Richard G. Darman, Mr. Sununu and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. And it has left the White House trying to argue that if only it did a better job of presenting its case, not only would its political troubles ease, but Americans' confidence would rise and the economy would do better.
But this approach smacks of President Jimmy Carter's politically disastrous "malaise" argument, and Bush aides concede that it pales against proposals like a tax cut for middle-income Americans, most of which are not considered fiscally sound by economists but which have enormous appeal.
"The budget deal has become a millstone around the Administration's neck," a senior Republican strategist said. "But people at the White House are proud of it, and they think that if we just keep rearguing it eventually everyone will agree."

HEADLINE: Japanese Charity Gives Millions to U.S. Groups

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
A new source of philanthropy has opened for Americans with a made-in-Japan label.
The Center for Global Partnership of the Japan Foundation began its gift-giving on Wednesday with 40 grants totaling $5.4 million to educational, research and cultural organizations in the United States. In Tokyo, 11 Japanese organizations received another $1.3 million from the charity created by the Japanese Government. 
 The center, based in Tokyo, plans to increase its charitable giving to $25 million annually starting next year. Only about 25 foundations in this country give away more money annually.
The center's gifts will support Japanese-American exchange programs and research on the environment, education, immigration, urban decay and the aging, as well as the exploration of trade and tariff issues.
 
Independence Is Questioned
 Friction created by Japanese trade position and acquisition of American companies is widely believed among American scholars and foundation officials to have led the Japanese Government to create the center with a $375 million endowment in 1990. Some scholars and foundation officials still regard the initiative as a public relations ploy to improve Japan's image and doubt it will be independent of government.
"The center's track record should provide the answers," said Tadashi Yamamoto, a member of the center's A Japanese company keeps a low profile in its New York City philanthropy. Business, page 21.
advisory committee, in an interview Tuesday at the organization's office in Manhattan. "This is not a fire-brigade operation to extinguish heated argument. Rather, it is a step toward Japan's assuming a more active role in world affairs. The center will build on its American experience, develop ties in other countries and become a multilateral partnership, tackling global concerns."
Prominent Americans are serving as special advisers, including former Secretary of State George P. Shultz; Mike Mansfield, a former Ambassador to Japan, and David Rockefeller, the former chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank.
 
Selections by American Panel
 Jun Wada, a 42-year-old economist who directs the center, said his goal was winning acceptance from American foundations and forming joint programs. Discussions are already under way with the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, the Pew Charitable Trust and the MacArthur Foundation, he said.
Recipients of the center's gifts were selected by an American panel from among 200 nonprofit organizations that responded when the center sent out 3,000 announcements in September explaining its guidelines. The gifts not only went to major universities, but also to Evanston Township High School in Illinois to enhance its Japan Education Center.
Other grants will finance exchange programs for teachers, women leaders and youth groups. The largest, a $670,000 outlay, went to the 21-year-old Close Up Foundation of Alexandria, Va., which has brought hundreds of thousands of foreign students to Washington to learn about the American political system.
The center gave $2.2 million for educational programs. Children's Museums in Boston and Indianapolis received grants for exhibits about Japan. The Aspen Institute, the Brookings Institution and the Council on Foreign Relations received grants, as did the Institute of International Economics, to measure the costs of trade and tariff barriers in the United States, Europe and Japan.
Among the other grants were $200,000 to American Public Radio in Minneapolis to develop and disseminate news programs; $55,000 to National Public Radio for news coverage of Japan, and $265,000 for the Roper Center for Public Opinion Research at the University of Connecticut to develop Japanese public opinion data.

HEADLINE: Congressional Roundup;
Foley Denies Weakness In Session or Leadership

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23

 BODY:
As lawmakers struggled all day to find the votes and the legislative language that would let them end the Congressional session on Tuesday, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley today defended Congress and himself personally against charges of ineffectiveness.
At a breakfast with reporters, he said Congress had made a "very good record" in adhering to last year's budget agreement as well as on domestic legislation from civil rights to the still incomplete banking, transportation and campaign finance bills. And he called it "the most constitutionally important Congress since World War II" for asserting war-making power in the Persian Gulf conflict. 
 But it was in defending himself against the largely anonymous grumbling of some House Democrats that Mr. Foley displayed the greatest intensity. "They want to hear me bash George Bush," he said, pounding his fist into his hand. "My job is to try and persuade, rather to try and just make speeches. I am not a basher.
"Somebody else is going to have to take on that particular responsibility, because it's not my way of communicating," he said. "I don't think people are going to find that a lot of Americans are persuaded by name-calling and partisan bashing."
 
Bush Is Seen as Wounded
 The recent criticism of Mr. Foley, a Democrat from Washington State, has come from Democrats who see the Bush Administration as wounded by the economy and its anti-abortion stand and who want him to lead them to the kill.
Mr. Foley did predict that, even without "bashing," he would become more partisan next year as the Presidential election nears. But he argued that it was important for Congressional leaders and the President to have some time to work on finding areas of agreement that would enable the Government to function.
If intense partisanship were a full-time obligation, he said, there would be a four-year election campaign and a "seamless web of forever and forever and forever political debate that has no conclusion and no purpose other than the election itself."
 
Criticism Called Unfair
 He also said it was unfair for him and Congress to be criticized for their inability to override any of Mr. Bush's 24 vetoes, including the Tuesday vote on which the President was sustained in barring federally financed family planning clinics from discussing abortion with patients.
Mr. Foley had predicted on Monday that this veto would be overridden, but the attempt in the House failed by 12 votes. Today he said: "My perspective is that the President should get no particular credit for sustaining a veto, and a lot of blame if he gets overridden. For the President to lose, he has to have some element of major repudiation by his own party members in the Congress, and that's very hard to achieve."
In fact, on Tuesday's vote, 53 Republicans deserted Mr. Bush, while only 113 voted with him. If 12 of the 43 Democrats who voted with the President had voted against him and with Mr. Foley, the veto would have been overridden.
 
Banking
 There was little progress today on ironing out the differences between a narrow House banking bill and a broader Senate measure that includes a limited version of the White House's proposal to ease restrictions on interstate banking.
Formal negotiations between House and Senate lawmakers on a banking bill are expected to begin on Monday, although aides to the lawmakers have already begun informal discussions.
Last week the House and Senate adopted the different bills after the House had rejected two other measures that included interstate banking provisions.
The two bills that have been approved contain taxpayer loans of tens of billions of dollars for the nearly depleted Federal insurance program that protects bank deposits. The Administration has said the loans will be repaid by the banks.
The loan provision has caused leaders of both houses to insist on passage before Congress can adjourn. Mr. Foley described both the bank insurance measure and additional financing for the Resolution Trust Corporation, which handles the savings and loan bailout, as "heavy lifting."
 
Spending
 The Senate passed and sent to the White House the last regular spending bill of the session, a $270 billion Pentagon appropriation.
While the measure closely tracks the legislation adopted Friday that would all but eliminate the B-2 Stealth bomber while preserving an anti-missile defense system, it drew sharp opposition from the chairman of the Armed Services Committee, Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia.
Mr. Nunn complained bitterly that the bill, as it came back from the Senate-House conference committee, included $3.3 billion for which no authorizing legislation had been passed. He said the money was earmarked for projects like creating museums at closed military bases and grants directed to specific universities.
Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, the chairman of the Appropriations Committee, who was one of the conferees, said House negotiators had been adamant on the issue. Mr. Nunn replied that "I do not believe there has been a very vigorous effort" by Senate conferees on the issue. He voted no but lost, as the bill was passed on a 66-to-29 vote.
On Friday night the Senate sent Mr. Bush the $205 billion appropriation for the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services and Education.
That was the last major regular domestic spending bill. The Senate also passed and sent to a House-Senate conference a $7.5 billion supplemental spending bill for items ranging from remaining gulf war costs to aid for children.
The bill included another effort to require the Defense Department to let servicewomen and dependents have abortions at United States military hospitals overseas if they pay for them themselves. That issue commands Congressional majorities that are short of veto-proof strength. Such provisions have repeatedly been dropped from bills in conference to avoid a veto.
 
October Surprise
 While the Senate on Friday night killed a proposal to spend $600,000 on an investigation of the "October Surprise," the House still plans to try to proceed on the issue. The term refers to allegations that Ronald Reagan's 1980 campaign conspired with Iran to see that American hostages were not released before the election.
A resolution authorizing a House investigation of the accusation is to be considered on the House floor Monday.
 
Supercomputers
 The Senate sent to the White House a $3 billion measure for developing a high-speed supercomputing network that would link Federal reserach centers, universities and corporations.
The five-year program, sponsored by Senator Al Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, would add $1 billion to the $2 billion already authorized in computer research, and fianance development of the switching systems and software needed to create what Mr. Gore today called "interstate highways of information."
Old-fashioned long-distance telephone lines do not have the capacity to deal with the bits of information used by supercomputers, but fiber-optic cables can be used for this purpose if appropriate switches and software are developed. Mr. Gore said the measure would "enable us to leapfrog the Japanese and make the best use of an area in which we hold a tenuous advantage."
The Bush Administration supported the bill, which passed on a voice vote Friday night after House passage Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Blame for New York's Budget Mess

 BODY:
If Gov. Mario Cuomo really wants to run for President, he'll have to convince America that New York's fiscal mess -- the "New York Nightmare," in Vice President Quayle's alliterative words -- is Washington's fault. Can Mr. Cuomo legitimately claim that responsibility for the state budget deficit, newly doubled to $3.6 billion, lies outside Albany? The short answer is no. The long answer is, there's plenty of blame to go around.
Mr. Cuomo cannot be blamed for the state's plunging economy, a product of the national recession. Nor is it his fault that states with large populations of the poor have suffered since the Reagan years from deep cuts in Federal social programs. 
 Still, New York could weather the recession more easily had it got responsible leadership from Mr. Cuomo and legislators in Albany. In good times, they spent liberally and used fiscal gimmicks -- borrowing, rolling over debt, one-shot revenues -- that have come back to haunt them.
Mr. Cuomo is not the worst offender. Republican lawmakers, while pretending to be fiscal conservatives, pushed for even more profligate financing gimmicks than the Governor allowed. But he went far enough, irresponsibly raiding the State Insurance Fund and failing to restrain legislators.
Consider the 1987 income tax cut. Mr. Cuomo first complained that it was too deep, but then went along and even took credit for it. Later he and legislative leaders had to freeze the cut because the state needed the revenues. Mr. Cuomo often encouraged the use of one-shot revenue-raising devices that helped mask budget deficits.
One-shots can serve as useful cushions in bad fiscal times, but New York has over-indulged. As Sam Howe Verhovek reported in The Times, one-shot revenues of $2.7 billion covered nearly 10 percent of the spending in last year's budget, a record; this year's budget includes $1.4 billion.
Now Mr. Cuomo proposes a multiyear budget to close the combined deficits in this fiscal year and the next. Theoretically, the idea has merit. With more time, the state can make true reforms and avoid harsh service cuts or abrupt tax increases. But a multiyear plan is also an invitation for abuse, allowing officials to push fiscal problems into the future by rolling over debt. Until Mr. Cuomo actually issues a plan instead of merely an idea, it is impossible to judge its fiscal integrity.
Unfortunately, the idea is mired in politics. Since the plan would smooth over the state's problems past the 1992 elections, Albany Republicans -- no doubt taking their cues from their national party -- resist it as part of Mr. Cuomo's Presidential strategy. But whatever the political implications, a responsible multiyear budget could be better than another quick fix of one-shot gimmicks.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The U.S.: A Pathetic Nation?

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
With the trillions spent to win the cold war, it will be pathetic if the U.S. fails to find $1 billion to combat famine and the danger of nuclear chaos in the Soviet Union.
Famine in Soviet cities this winter could kill the Soviet democratic experiment, and there is only one way to prevent starvation. That is by loading up U.S. military aircraft with food, flying to cities and overseeing the distribution. But aside from a few Democratic Representatives such as Les Aspin and Lee Hamilton, Washington sits on its hands. 
 The spread of Soviet nuclear weapons could present the greatest threat to world peace, and there is only one way to guard against their misuse, theft or sale. That is a crash joint effort by U.S. and Soviet specialists to secure them. But apart from an encouraging bipartisan group of senators joined by Mr. Aspin and Mr. Hamilton, Washington shows no urgency.
The risks of inaction and delay are clear and grave. Yet legislators, fearful of being accused of helping Soviets at the expense of Americans, shrink from doing what they know is right. And President Bush, who above all understands what must be done, is also frozen by such accusations and remains inexcusably silent.
The one thing Mr. Bush has done -- his now $4 billion "food aid" program -- raises serious questions about his competence and motives. Senator Patrick Leahy is not alone in charging that the President "is playing a deceptive game with American taxpayers."
The Bush $4 billion plan sounds good. It provides U.S. credit guarantees for the Soviets to borrow money from banks to purchase American grain. Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said the program "is aimed at alleviating food shortages and other dire humanitarian consequences . . . this winter."
But much of the grain won't even reach Soviet seaports in time to make a difference this winter. Much of what does arrive is bound to rot on the docks or find its way into the black market, if past experience with Soviet distribution is any guide. Most of the cargo is feed grain, destined for farms and animals, not people. This grain will help sustain livestock. But it will do very little to alleviate hunger in Soviet cities now.
This is no secret. Which is why Mr. Leahy and many others see the $4 billion as aimed more at raising American farm incomes than at helping needy Soviets.
Mr. Leahy is also rankled by what he sees as Mr. Bush's budgetary sleight of hand. The President is not asking Congress to appropriate $4 billion, and says the Soviet Union is creditworthy and will pay its bills. Mr. Leahy argues that there is little chance the Soviets will find the cash, and that the American taxpayer will eventually have to pick up the tab. The Senator is by all odds correct.
Here another fundamental issue is joined. If the $4 billion is essentially a gift to the Soviet Union and mainly a boon to American farmers, and if it won't do much to relieve famine this winter, why spend it at all? Or why not use the money to provide emergency relief for needy Americans?
Put this way, the Leahy stance is not frivolous or isolationist. Politicians could say in honesty that they would rather use the funds for America's emergencies than make a grand, but largely ineffectual gesture abroad.
But the choice should not be between a questionable food aid effort and American domestic priorities. It ought to be between those priorities and a food relief program that can work.
Mr. Aspin has put together a list of already-bought and ready-to-go foodstuffs, including $165 million in free food already allocated by Mr. Bush, and tons of food leftover from the Persian Gulf war. Europe is also loaded with excess stocks.
What is needed is transportation and reliable distribution inside the Soviet Union. U.S. forces fed the Kurds after the gulf war and could do it again on a much larger scale. They are also ready to help their counterparts gather and destroy Soviet nuclear weapons. The $1 billion needed for these vital tasks would come from existing Pentagon funds, not new money.
A nation loses its soul and spirit if it cannot act to protect its most basic interests and values. Soulless and spiritless we will enter our future if we fail to do what we can to forestall new dangers and dictatorship in the Soviet Union.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

HEADLINE: Limited Menu: Lots of Pressure To Fix the Economy, But Few Options

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
SOMETIMES the American economy in recession, like a kayak that has capsized, rights itself. So far, this recession has not been one of those times. And so the question is, who should try to make the economy grow again: the President, Congress, the Federal Reserve Board or you, the consumer?
 The New York Times, November 24, 1991 
In past recessions, the answer has often been all four. The President and Congress cut taxes, or found other ways to put money in people's pockets. The Fed lowered interest rates. And the consumer got his job back, or received more wages, and started spending again. But this time only the interest rates have been cut, and that has not worked.
 With the recovery that apparently began in May having come to an abrupt halt in October, the nation's top economic forecasters recently revised their opinions drastically, according to the Blue Chip Economic Indicators newsletter, which polls 52 prominent economists each month. And in Washington, Robert D. Reischauer, chief economist at the Congressional Budget Office, captured the flavor of the new thinking. "The motors that normally revive an economy are running, but they are running very slowly," he said. "Not that we have not had a recovery, but you need an electron microscope to analyze it."
 Naturally, there is much debate about what to do next. There are experts who argue that sometimes the best thing to do for an ailing economy is to do the least that is necessary; in trying to rush a recovery along, they say, the Government risks doing more harm than good. But the experts work with computer models, which do not vote.
 The New York Times, November 24, 1991
 Having pushed for lower interest rates, President Bush and the Federal Reserve say, in effect, sit tight; the lower interest rates will revive the economy by early spring, which would bode well for the Republicans in an election year. But the longer the recovery is delayed, the greater the pressure on the Adminstration to take further steps. On the other hand, the price of ending the recession through economic stimulants might very well be an increased Federal deficit and eventually inflation.
 But why hasn't this interest rate phenomenon worked yet? In an interview last week, David W. Mullins Jr., the Fed's vice chairman, offered an explanation that is also put forth by economists who advise President Bush. The upturn has been delayed because Americans are still retrenching, Mr. Mullins said. Rather than borrow to spend, they are paying off debts accumulated in the 1980's or borrowing to refinance mortgages at lower rates. Such behavior does not expand the economy. Similarly, corporations are also paying down debt, rather than hiring or investing heavily in new machinery.
 "The retrenchment process raises the possibility of subdued growth for the next couple of quarters," Mr. Mullins said. "It may be unpleasant, but there is no shortcut."
 The New York Times, November 24, 1991
 Mr. Mullins acknowledged that "subdued growth" could mean no growth at all from now until April, when he expects the retrenchment to be over. Nevertheless, the prospect of waiting until spring for growth to resume -- if the scenario outlined by Mr. Mullins works -- is prompting some politicians and economists to talk of priming the fiscal pump. They are beginning to wonder if, for the first time in years, the Federal Government should spread cash among Americans through such things as public-works jobs, tax credits, and more unemployment benefits than Congress recently authorized.
 "We are closer than I would have believed we could have gotten to where we are seriously talking about Depression-style programs to pull ourselves out," said Paul Krugman, a Massachusetts Institute of Technology economist.
 Still, the talk is hesitant. That is because the most effective pump priming makes the budget deficit rise, and neither Congress nor the White House has much stomach for the political risks of a rising deficit. The problem, however, is that growth is not likely to result when Congress simply takes money from one budgeted outlay -- nuclear waste disposal, for example -- and then spends it on another, perhaps airport construction. New money, in effect, must be created and spread through the population, a process that might end the recession while increasing the deficit. "It has to be a genuine increase in the transfer of
 The New York Times, November 24, 1991
money to the public, without higher taxes to pay for it," said Paul Samuelson, the Nobel laureate in economic science.
 Just such pump priming occurred during the 1981-1982 recession, although by coincidence rather than design. During the recession's worst months, President Reagan's big tax cut took effect, serving as a windfall for millions of Americans, but of course running up the deficit. In the 1950's, 1960's and early 1970's, pump priming was common. As late as 1975, President Ford pushed through an income tax credit to help end a recession.
 But in those days budget deficits were relatively small, and certainly not the mesmerizing issue they are today. Even Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland and chairman of Congress's Joint Economic Committee, hesitates to push for pump priming, although he favors it as a way out of the recession more than do most in Congress.
 Mr. Sarbanes' boldest proposal would go no further than what he calls front-loading the budget. Rather than wait, he would immediately spend money that was budgeted for, say, highway and bridge repair, with the funds spread out in the budget to last two or three years. Thus, he would adhere to the 1990 budget agreement, which prohibits absolute increases in spending. And to get
 The New York Times, November 24, 1991
the front-loaded spending more quickly into people's pockets, Mr. Sarbanes would funnel money to states and cities, where it would subsidize projects already under way.
 "We could go through the whole Federal budget and get some impetus for the economy by front-loading items," Mr. Sarbanes said. "Not much stimulus, but some."
 Mr. Sarbanes has not embodied front-loading in a bill. But recently introduced bills designed to prod the economy are similarly low-keyed. Many are revivals of someone's favorite tax proposal, involving I.R.A's, capital gains and tax credits. But they would be financed through an offsetting increase in revenue or a spending cut.
 The bill that comes closest to pump priming, in the view of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington research group, is a tax credit aimed at the middle class proposed by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois. A two-year credit of up to $200 for single people and $400 for married couples would be financed by raising the tax for the wealthiest Americans. The aim is to shift money from the wealthy to those more likely to spend it; the rich traditionally save a bigger percentage of their income than the middle
 The New York Times, November 24, 1991
class. But it is a proposal that Representative Bill Gradison, Republican of Ohio, says is likely to increase the budget deficit by $25 billion over the next two years, and stick the wealthy with a permanent tax increase.
 
The Lonely Consumber
 Beyond the Government stands the consumer. More than in previous recessions, consumers are on their own. There is no pump-priming to bolster their income, and jobs are disappearing as states and municipalities cut back to balance budgets. What's more, in a stagnant economy, jobs and raises are hard to come by, which means that the disposable income of the average American is growing more slowly than usual, if it is growing at all.
 In Germany, France and some other industrial countries, the consumer is not so much on his own. Public works spending is more robust. Jobless pay in Germany equals 63 percent of an average production worker's last salary compared with 50 percent in the United States, according to the O.E.C.D. Housing subsidies for the unemployed are generous in Europe, and in other industrial nations jobless pay usually runs much longer than it does here.
 The New York Times, November 24, 1991
 Such shortcomings add to the anguish of a prolonged recession and the pressures on the Bush Administration. Even Mr. Mullins at the Federal Reserve, which has been opposed to fiscal stimulus, says the day may come when that position could change. "I think we are not at the stage of putting forth fiscal packages," he said, "but I think it is worthwhile debating to see if we can design some policy actions that are useful here."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 8, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Nov. 24 about political pressures to strengthen the United States economy referred incorrectly to Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland. He is a Senator, not a Representative.
