HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Need for Action by U.S. Is Debated

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
With long-term interest rates seemingly stuck around 8 percent, a long-dormant debate has revived about whether the Treasury and the Federal Reserve Board should try to influence the bond market.
Talk about the issue has intensified as the yield curve, the interest rate differential between 30-year bonds and short-term notes and bills, has widened. Indeed, short-term interest rates have fallen to levels not seen since the early 1970's. 
 Moreover, the proliferation of proposals from Capitol Hill and the White House about how to stimulate the economy has injected a sense of urgency to the discussion.
 
A Record Spread
 Given the current gap between long-term and short-term rates, a strategy of bond-market intervention seems appealing.
At the end of last week, yields on two-year notes were more than 2.50 percentage points lower than yields on 30-year bonds, a record spread.
And the current spread of 3.45 percentage points between three-month Treasury bills and 30-year bonds is the second widest ever, according to Ramirez Capital Consultants, exceeded only by the gap of 3.74 percentage points after the stock market crash in October 1987.
Advocates of the intervention strategy argue that reducing the supply of new bonds to the market and issuing shorter-term maturities instead would lower the Government's borrowing costs and help bring down long-term interest rates. A decision by the Fed to buy outstanding coupon-bearing instruments in the open market would accelerate the process, they say.
 
'A Policy Instrument'
 "The fiscal policy ideas floated in Washington are at best neutral in their effect and at worst totally harebrained," said David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International. "The main thing we need to do to jump-start the economy is to get long-term interest rates lower. By issuing fewer bonds and 10-year notes, you have a policy instrument that is readily available and has the potential of lowering long-term rates."
But some analysts question whether long rates will indeed move lower. Moreover, they say it is unlikely that significant savings will be realized if the Treasury makes up for smaller sales of bonds and 10-year notes by raising the amount of shorter-term borrowings.
No matter how enticing, basing a change in debt management strategy on the current slope of the yield curve would pose risks for the Treasury, analysts said.
 
Hedging in Previous Recessions
 The yield curve has often been exceptionally steep in previous recessions as wary investors hedged their bets that monetary stimulus provided during the downturn might fuel inflation later on, said Paul D. Mastroddi, a vice president at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.
During the recession of 1973-75, those fears were realized and inflation and interest rates rose. But in the 1981-82 recession, the yield curve flattened when it became apparent that inflation was moderating.
Based on that experience, "I don't think the yield curve really tells you whether issuing long or short is a good bet," Mr. Mastroddi said.
 
Deflationary Forces Seen
 Richard M. Kelly, chairman of the securities firm Aubrey G. Lanston & Company and a Treasury official during the Carter Administration, said that deflationary, not inflationary, forces were at work in today's economy.
Nevertheless, reducing the size of the Treasury's bond offerings in favor of more short-term borrowing would be a mistake, he suggested.
"If the budget were in balance or close to balance, then the Treasury could have a more flexible approach to debt management," he said. "But the Treasury issues a lot more short-term debt than long-term bonds already."
About half the debt issued by the Treasury over the last year matures in two years or less, Mr. Kelly said. Increasing the size of short-term obligations would probably drive up short-term rates.
"If the curve flattens by short rates moving up, that is very costly for the Treasury," he said.
 
Need Seen for Other Moves
 "You don't do this to save money," said Henry Kaufman, who heads Henry Kaufman & Company, a money management firm. "You do it to have a beneficial impact on the financial markets and the economy."
Mr. Kaufman said the approach would work only if a reduction in bond sales were accompanied by Fed purchases of coupon-bearing securities in the open market, as well as a willingness on the part of the Fed to lower short-term interest rates even further.
"If monetary policy stops here, with the funds rate at 4.75 percent, and Treasury then says we are going to decrease the size of the bond auctions, it will have a negligible impact," on the economy and long rates, he said.
Some analysts wondered whether a reduction in 30-year borrowing rates, a maturity that is almost exclusively the preserve of the Treasury, would really mean much to the economy at large.
 
Mortgage Rates Linked to Notes
"Very little private-sector borrowing is done at 30-year maturities, as few borrowers have the credit standing needed to sell that sort of debt," said Louis v.B. Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates, an economic consulting firm, in a letter to clients.
As far as interest-sensitive sectors like housing are concerned, Mr. Crandall noted that while fixed-rate residential mortgages have nominal maturities of 30 years, they actually have weighted average maturities of less than 10 years because they are self-amortizing. As a result, fixed mortgage rates are based on the yield of Treasury notes, not bonds.
"This has been quite evident as 10-year and 30-year Treasury rates have diverged over the past three months," Mr. Crandall wrote. "Mortgages have rallied with the note sector rather than stagnating with bonds. If mortgage rates were not hurt by the underperformance of long bonds in the third quarter, there is no reason to think that mortgage rates would be helped by an improvement in long bonds relative to 10-year notes in 1992."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Little Enthusiasm For GTE Shares

BYLINE: By Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:
THE GTE Corporation is the sixth-largest telecommunications company in the world with $18.4 billion in 1990 revenue. Yet it has had a difficult time getting the attention of investors, despite a return on equity that outperforms others in the telecommunications group and its strong growth prospects.
Of course, it could be something in the tone of the analysts' recommendations. "It's a weak buy," said Charles W. Schelke, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. "Nobody is pounding the table for the stock." And Joanne C. Smith, an analyst at Nomura Research Institute, said, "Sure, the company is doing everything right, but it's already reflected in the stock." 
 After a run-up in the stock price of most telecommunications companies throughout the late 1980's, GTE's shares have bounced around near $30 a share for nearly two years. It closed Friday at $31.125, down 12.5 cents for the day, and off from the 52-week high of $33.875 set earlier this month.
The ho-hum investor reaction partly reflects the grab bag of businesses GTE has and is trying to sort out. Last month, the company announced it would probably sell its $2.3 billion electrical products group, whose best-known product is Sylvania light bulbs, to concentrate on telecommunications. The sales price would be at least $1.4 billion.
GTE also has a 20 percent passive interest in U S Sprint, the nation's third-largest long-distance carrier. GTE plans to sell that holding as soon as it finds the right deal. Like growth in local phone calls, long-distance traffic has also been slowed by the recession.
As population growth has slowed and the recession has hurt the talkative white-collar professional classes, the phone industry has been struggling with the stagnant domestic market for plain old telephone service.
So, like other companies, GTE has looked abroad for growth. Earlier this month, a GTE-led consortium won the bidding for 40 percent of the Venezuelan national telephone company, Compania Anonima Nacional Telefonos de Venezuela. The consortium bid $1.9 billion. GTE would own up to 60 percent of the stake, with A.T.& T., two Venezuelan companies and the Spanish telephone company sharing the rest.
At bottom, however, GTE is still a heavily regulated local-telephone monopoly. Its units operate in 31 states, as well as British Columbia, Quebec and the Dominican Republic. In March, it paid $6.6 billion in GTE stock for the Contel Corporation, which is based in Atlanta and is the 10th-largest telephone holding company in the United States, with a large cellular telephone business. GTE's principal markets are California, Texas and Florida, where regulatory authorities have a decidedly mixed attitude toward GTE. In California, and to a somewhat lesser degree in Florida, regulators tend to reward operating efficiency and allow higher profits. Texas is more erratic, with the regulatory climate often chilly toward profits, analysts say. Ms. Smith of Nomura notes that despite recent layoffs, GTE has a long way to go in terms of cost-cutting and getting a long-term improvement in its earnings prospects as expenses decline and margins rise. It has announced a 6.5 percent cut in employees by 1992. GTE, though, has about 60 workers per 10,000 telephone lines; the comparable figure is 40 workers at the 40 workers at the typical "Baby Bell" regional telephone company.
Analysts say GTE's work force seems especially large in light of the fact that 72 percent of the switching network uses up-to-date digital equipment, rather than the slower analog variety; the comparable figure at the Baby Bells is roughly 40 percent. "Digital means you just don't need the same number of people as you used to," Ms. Smith said.
Analysts also say GTE's balance sheet is more debt-laden than that of other telecommunications companies, at 60 percent debt and 40 percent equity, compared with a more typical 55/45 split.
The situation will only tip further toward the debt side, with last week's Venezuelan deal and its $1 billion of additional debt. But analysts figure some of that borrowing will be offset by proceeds from the sale of the 20 percent stake in U S Sprint. That should be worth at least half a billion dollars.
GTE's recent results have shown a modest improvement. Third-quarter earnings were $453 million, or 51 cents a share, compared with $427 million, or 49 cents a share, in the third quarter of 1990. Analysts say they expect more improvement in 1992 and 1993, as the economy recovers.
The current signs are good. Mr. Schelke of Smith Barney figures GTE's return on equity, the profit divided by the company's net worth, a key measure of financial strength, will be 17 percent for 1991, compared with 14 percent for the telecommunications group as a whole.

HEADLINE: Higher Demand for Oil Is Expected

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 24

 BODY:
The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will begin its annual year-end meeting in Vienna on Tuesday amid renewed indications that demand for oil will continue to increase gradually this winter despite the global recession.
And virtually all oil industry experts anticipate slightly higher oil prices this winter, in light of higher demand and a decline in Soviet oil output, regardless of any policy adopted by OPEC at the gathering. 
 As a result, many experts expect Saudi Arabia to press on with its year-old policy of maximizing its oil production and to continue to move to displace the Soviet Union as the world's largest producer.
Over the last two years, Saudi production has increased to 8.5 million barrels a day from 5 million. Soviet output has fallen to less than 10 million barrels a day, a decline of more than 2 million barrels.
Saudi Arabia has the ability to increase its production even more, while the Soviet Union is almost certain to experience more economic upheaval that will further depress its oil operations.
Analysts say world demand for OPEC oil, which now stands at 24 million barrels a day, will rise to 25 million barrels a day after January. The increased demand, they say, will be the result of gradual economic growth in the world -- particularly among developing nations -- even though the recession in the United States and elsewhere is limiting the overall pace of global growth..
When the recession ends, oil experts say, demand for oil will increase by more than 2.5 percent in the United States and more elsewhere.
 
Outlook for the Decade
 "From 1991 to the year 2000, oil demand will rise by 10 million barrels a day," says John Lichtblau, president of the New York Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. Some analysts even suggest that OPEC may not be able to pump enough oil to satisfy demand.
Joseph Stanislaw, an energy affairs expert with Cambridge Energy Research Associates, said, "If economic recovery is stronger than expected in the late fourth quarter, there may be even more demand for OPEC oil than there is technical capacity to produce."
In the weeks before the OPEC meeting, Saudi Arabia has been sending signals that it will increase its daily output to nine million barrels. That would raise the total Saudi share of OPEC output to more than a third of the total production by the organization's 13 members and make Saudi wishes tantamount to uncontestable decisions. Before the Persian Gulf crisis, Saudi Arabia's share of OPEC output was only 25 percent.
Saudi insistence on maintaining higher production levels is motivated by its need for revenue to make up for its enormous expenditures, estimated at $65 billion, during the gulf crisis. And the Saudi production policy, by helping keep prices lower than they might be under tighter production quotas, should insure continued growth in demand for oil.
With the decline of the Soviet Union as an oil power, experts say it is difficult to see how any other OPEC member can stand in the way of a Saudi decision to sell more oil and increase the country's share of world oil markets. Within OPEC circles, the evolution of Saudi thinking over the last two years has resulted in a "take it or leave it" negotiating strategy by Saudi Arabia.
At OPEC's last meeting, in September, Saudi Arabia's Oil Minister, Hisham M. Nazer, shocked many of the other OPEC oil ministers when he declared that Saudi Arabia regarded its current high production as a permanently acquired right.
The Saudi policy is strongly, but fruitlessly, opposed by Algeria and Iran. Both countries advocated that oil prices should be pushed higher and that OPEC should cut its production to bring this about.
Experts say the Saudis are comfortable with an oil price range of $18 to $23 a barrel. Algeria and Iran would much prefer a price that exceeds $21 a barrel.
Prices are now in the $20 range, and in the view of experts could stay there or slightly higher throughout the winter before facing what could be a steep decline in summer.
The agressive Saudi stance in OPEC assumes that despite a United Nations Security Council offer to allow Iraq to begin exporting oil to pay for food, the Iraqis will remain unwilling -- and unable, because of war damage -- to sell their oil for some time to come.
Iraq and Kuwait ceased exporting oil in August 1990, at the start of the gulf crisis, although Kuwaiti production resumed after the war and has recently picked up some momentum. But the Kuwaitis are exporting less than 300,000 barrels a day, meaning the country can play only a minor role in shaping OPEC policy.
Experts say these circumstances will favor the Saudi strategy to pump more oil, especially if coupled with a cold winter and a further drop in Russian oil exports.
 
Future of Quotas Uncertain
 In keeping with its increasingly assertive role in OPEC, Saudi Arabia has over the last five weeks signaled that it may even formally propose that OPEC scrap its quota system altogether. Such a move is unlikely to be accepted by others in OPEC, but is certain to increase bitterness about Saudi hegemony over oil prices and production decisions.
The Algerians and Iranians are likely to respond by advocating that OPEC should decide now how much Saudi Arabia would cut its output in the spring after demand for oil softens.
"We know there is a storm there, and I don't think we should go straight into it," said Nordine Ait-Laoussine, the Energy and Mineral Resources Minister of Algeria.
"The need to cut is inevitable," Mr. Laoussine said a few days ago in Paris. "We have to face up to the problem, and it is better to do it now."

HEADLINE: Fed Governor Is Confirmed Despite Regional Resistance

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24

 BODY:
The Senate has confirmed Lawrence B. Lindsey as a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, despite criticism by some members that as a New Englander he is not qualified to represent the First Federal District, which covers part of the Southeast.
Mr. Lindsey, a Harvard economics professor who has been on leave to serve as an adviser to President Bush, was nominated in February and approved by the Senate Banking Committee in July. 
 But a vote by the Senate was delayed because of resistance by a handful of senators from the Richmond Federal Reserve District, which represents Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina and South Carolina.
 
Debate Before the Vote
 In a debate before the vote late Friday night, Senator Terry Sanford, Democrat of North Carolina, argued that Mr. Lindsey had no practical experience in the region or direct knowledge of its particular agricultural and industrial interests.
"The people of the South deserve a representative who has been a participant and has been able to develop a clear understanding of their economic needs," he added.
Senator John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia, came to Mr. Lindsey's defense on the floor, predicting that he would work to pursue "growth-oriented, noninflationary monetary policy, a regulatory position which would not impede credit conditions, reform of the nation's financial system so that our banks can better compete internationally, and gradual reduction of inflation."
Mr. Lindsey has lived for the last three years in a suburb of Washington, across the Virginia border, fulfilling the statutory residency requirement for a governor. The Federal Reserve Board has six members, including the chairman and vice chairman.
But Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, charged that the spirit of the residency statute was being violated, adding, "I do not think that geographic requirement is something to be ignored or laughed at or simply brushed off."
Despite the criticisms, the Senate confirmed Mr. Lindsey by unanimous consent along with several other nominees as it tried to wind up its work before the Thanksgiving recess.
In testimony before the Senate Banking Committee in May, Mr. Lindsey promised to work for long-term growth without inflation. He talked, as Fed officials often do, of achieving a balance in which growth is not so rapid and inflationary that it drives up long-term interest rates.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Television;
Rivalries Give Way To Ratings

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
On Wednesday night, ABC will present what its executives consider to be its biggest and best special of the fall season. In fact, the network will be celebrating a competitor.
The special will mark the 10th anniversary of MTV, a cable network that competes for viewers every night with ABC in about 60 percent of American homes. But ABC's program executives say they have no hesitation about throwing a party for MTV, especially since MTV has the young audience that ABC and all of network television so sorely needs. 
 Certainly, it helps that the special is as star-smothered as an Academy Awards telecast, featuring Madonna, Michael Jackson, Tom Cruise, Mel Gibson, Spike Lee, Cher and Kim Basinger.
 
Open to Changes
But the special is also on ABC because that network, like NBC and CBS, is now open to almost any kind of arrangement that will bring creatively packaged and financed programs -- and a lot more viewers -- to network television.
"The business is changing so much the old rules just don't apply anymore," said Ted Harbert, executive vice president of ABC Entertainment.
Indeed, the boundaries that defined network competition in the past are being crossed -- and crossed out -- almost daily.
Last week, CBS announced a deal to buy a comedy series, "Davis Rules," that had been owned by ABC and was on that network's list of mid-season replacement shows. ABC allowed the producers to buy back the series so it could be sold to CBS.
In the first week of December, NBC will broadcast "Pearl," a fictional mini-series about the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. The program was originally broadcast as an ABC mini-series in 1978.
On Friday night, NBC broadcast the movie "Back to the Future III" for the second time in just a week. NBC believes audiences have been conditioned by cable channels like HBO and Showtime to expect the same movie more than once a week.
"We are going to be out there more and more pushing new ways to schedule television programs," Mr. Harbert said. "We have to. The old ways are what got us down from a 95 share to a 60 share."
Indeed, the willingness of the networks to take programs from each other and even from cable networks is directly tied to the economic pressures all of them are now facing.
In fact, there is some question whether the networks are acting desperate. Betsy Frank, a senior vice president of the ad agency Saatchi & Saatchi, said moves like rerunning a 13-year-old mini-series "make the networks look more like TBS."
TBS is a cable channel that specializes in old movies and repeats of series like "The Andy Griffith Show."
Peter Tortorici, the executive vice president of programming for CBS, said its acquisition of "Davis Rules" could not have taken place until now, when a network would rather recoup its investment in a show it might not use, even if that meant the show would go to another network.
"It's like two teams getting together because one has too much pitching and not enough outfielders," Mr. Tortorici said. In the past, he said, the networks would rather have taken a loss than see an unused show go to another network.
Certainly, NBC's decision to buy "Pearl," which ran twice on ABC, was inspired by the chance to get programming for a very low price.
Warren Littlefield, the president of NBC Entertainment, said he had been looking for some appropriate programming to mark the 50th anniversary of the Pearl Harbor attack. He noticed that ABC and CBS had each scheduled documentaries about the attack and thought an entertainment alternative could work well.
But he found the most likely prospects, including the movie "Tora, Tora, Tora," were already taken. Then Mr. Littlefield heard that "Pearl" was available. "Pearl" was a big success for ABC in 1978, scoring the eighth-highest mini-series rating of all time.
He took it. Mr. Littlefield would not disclose the price for NBC, but he said, "Let's just say the terms were extremely favorable. "
So, for a modest price, NBC will get five hours of programming ("Pearl" was originally a six-hour series but NBC has cut an hour -- and does not believe anyone will notice).
"Pearl" will run for five nights, ending Dec. 7. The network will thus be able to pre-empt five hours of its regular, more-expensive dramas, which, Mr. Littlefield said, would have needed to run as repeats about that time anyway.
"Instead, we get something we can bill as an event," he said.
ABC's incentive for buying the MTV special was also economic, but not because it was inexpensive. Mr. Harbert said ABC paid "a very healthy" fee to acquire the show. But he said the network was assured it was going to be a show with "the kind of big names we probably could never have attracted to ABC on our own."
The MTV special will be shown at 9 P.M. Eastern standard time on Wednesday.
ABC believed the appeal of Madonna and Michael Jackson would translate into premium advertising rates. According to Tom Freston, chairman of MTV Networks, it has. He said the special has sold 30-second commercials for up to $250,000, the kind of rate the networks usually get for attractions like the Olympics.
Mr. Harbert said the network expected the special to be a significant profit maker, particularly because ABC will run it a second time between now and June, when MTV itself will finally get a chance to carry it.
All those positive factors easily put to rest any concerns that ABC had about advancing the image of a cable competitor.
"I really can't believe ABC's putting on this show will make MTV any bigger than it is," Mr. Harbert said.
MTV saw only advantages in the deal. "It's a chance to have our birthday party at our neighbor's larger house," Mr. Freston said. "This is a great promotion for both MTV and cable."
Citing the huge price advertisers are paying, he added, "They're paying $250,000 for 30 seconds; we're getting 48 minutes of that kind of advertising for free."
And it is not a bad promotion for ABC, either. "We are telling our viewers to watch ABC," Mr. Freston said.
The only real concern ABC has about the show is that Madonna's performance -- which Mr. Freston described as "theatrical" rather than a song or dance -- may test the limits of the network's standards and practices division.
In her act, Madonna presents a love letter to MTV.
"It certainly goes farther than this network has ever gone before," Mr. Harbert said.
Nor will ABC go this far often, he said. "We will still be in the business of making shows that are distinct from what independent and cable stations do," Mr. Harbert said.
But he added that these kinds of special deals and special shows are going to continue to "fill out part of the 1,144 hours we have to program every year."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ignoring competitive boundaries, ABC allowed CBS to buy an unscheduled comedy series, "Davis Rules," starring Randy Quaid, top, and Jonathan Winters. (Bonnie Schiffman/ABC)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Federal regulators are moving more slowly in seizing banks because of the depletion of the deposit insurance fund, and the premiums that banks pay to support that fund are likely to rise sharply next year, the new chairman of the F.D.I.C. said. Both comments reflect a sharp departure from previous remarks by top regulators, and each bodes ill for the public purse. [Page A1.] 
 Congress appears likely to adopt a stripped-down banking bill this week that would primarily provide $70 billion in taxpayer loans for the nearly empty fund that protects bank deposits. [D3.]
The Senate confirmed Lawrence B. Lindsey as a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, despite criticism by some members that as a New Englander he was not qualified to represent the First Federal District, which covers part of the South. [D3.]
Turkey farmers have their eyes on a prize: the potentially lucrative market of fast-food restaurants. Dreaming of McTurkey, farmers are grinding up meat and experimenting with spices and seasonings in the quest for a place on America's menus. [D1.]
 
Companies
I.B.M. is preparing yet another overhaul of its operations, ushering out a stream of employees and trying to free areas of potential high growth, like personal computers, from the smothering effect of its more venerable lines of business. [D1.]
Alcatel Alsthom of France has surpassed A.T.& T. to become the world's largest maker of telephone equipment, and now it hopes to grow in the U.S. [D1.]
 
International
Boris Yeltsin's Russian republic intends to enter on the risky path of economic reform with or without other republics, taking many former central institutions with it. News Analysis. [A1.]
Just weeks before the European Community meets on the region's economic and political future, many Europeans are having difficulty determining how it will affect them. [A12.]
OPEC will begin its annual end of the year meeting tomorrow amid indications that demand for oil will continue to increase this winter despite the global recession. [D2.]
Trade negotiators have made progress on textile, arbitration, patent and trademark issues, but differences persist in agriculture, telephone service and wine labeling, a senior United States trade official said Friday. [D2.]
Japan will start to import shipments of plutonium sometime next year in lightly defended convoys, in a major step toward energy independence. [D8.]

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1220 words

HEADLINE: U.S. BANK BAILOUT HURT BY WEAKNESS OF INSURANCE FUND

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24

 BODY:
Federal regulators have had to move more slowly in seizing weak banks because of the depletion of the deposit insurance fund, the new chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said this weekend.
William Taylor, who was sworn in four weeks ago to replace L. William Seidman, also said that the premiums banks pay to the fund are likely to rise sharply next year. 
 Both comments reflect a sharp departure from previous remarks by top regulators, and each bodes ill for the public purse.
 
Raising the Costs
 The inability to deal promptly with large weak banks raises the cost of rescuing them. As big depositors move elsewhere seeking greater safety, the banks have fewer reserves when the Government eventually seizes them.
And the higher premiums for deposit insurance are passed on to banks' shareholders, as reduced profits, and to customers, who receive lower interest on deposits and pay higher rates for loans and other services.
Mr. Taylor, in a wide-ranging interview on Friday, seemed pessimistic about the banking industry and the real estate markets, in which banks have invested heavily. "Is it going to get worse before it gets better?" he asked. "Probably. I hope not, but probably."
Congress has been struggling to approve $70 billion in taxpayer loans to keep the deposit insurance fund afloat, and House and Senate conferees, who will meet on Monday, are expected to adopt a stripped-down bill bereft of all the Bush Administration's sweeping proposals to overhaul the banking industry. [Page D3.]
 
Holding Back on Seizures
 Mr. Taylor has been waiting in the wings to spend the money, which is intended to tide over the fund until it is replenished by bank premiums. Already, he said, Federal regulators have apparently begun to hold back on taking action against weak larger banks because of the condition of the insurance fund. As recently as last month, senior F.D.I.C. officials were saying that was not so.
"There's a general inhibition by the fact that the F.D.I.C. doesn't have much money," Mr. Taylor said.
Asked about the impact on other regulatory agencies, which consult with the F.D.I.C. about whether to seize banks, he said: "No orders have gone out or directives. But people throughout the organization say, 'We've got this $6 billion bank or $7 billion bank. Should we close it? We don't have any money.' The answer is: Probably yes, it has slowed it down."
The insurance fund administered by the F.D.I.C. stands behind more than $2 trillion in bank deposits. It currently has about $2 billion on hand and is expected to be out of money by the end of next month.
Mr. Taylor predicted that the annual premiums banks pay the fund would increase -- perhaps by as much as 30 percent -- to 30 cents for every $100 in deposits insured. Only five months ago, the premiums rose to 23 cents for every $100, a jump of 92 percent from 1990 levels.
When he succeeded Mr. Seidman, who retired after six years as head of the F.D.I.C., many people said Mr. Taylor had signed on to the most difficult job in Washington.
Mr. Taylor, 52 years old, arrived from the Federal Reserve Board, where he served as the head of the bank supervision division and the right-hand man and friend of the board's chairman, Alan Greenspan. Despite the added responsibilities, his new post pays him $35,000 less than his $150,000 salary at the Federal Reserve.
 
A Seasoned Professional
 Considered Washington's most seasoned professional on bank and savings and loan crises, Mr. Taylor recently served as the Government's senior regulator in London when authorities from around the world seized the Bank of Credit and Commerce International. He began the year as the Federal Reserve's top man for the rescue of the Bank of New England, which was seized in January.
Last year, he served a brief stint as the acting president and chief executive of the Oversight Board of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Cabinet-level body headed by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady that sets overall policy for the bailout.
Mr. Taylor, whose sixth-floor corner office has a panoramic view of the Mall dominated by the Washington Monument, spoke enthusiastically of a wide range of ways he is considering to make it less costly for the Government to treat ailing banks.
 
A 'Hospital' for Banks
 One idea is a "banking hospital," with a staff of bankers who would take over weak institutions on behalf of the Government and nurse them back to health before they are sold.
"Instead of liquidating it, closing it and destroying the good loans that are in the business community, you just put it in the hospital and appoint people to run it," he said. "They'd take their time and look at the thing and throw out the bad loans; throw out the people who weren't doing right; scale it back down; put it back in health, and then they would send it out the door."
Another proposal that may get wide adoption next year involves Government agreements with the buyers of weak banks to share in any profits, as well as losses, that might be posted.
But Mr. Taylor's innovations will not have easy going. From the President and the Treasury and Commerce Secretaries on down, Administration officials have publicly chastised bank regulators for being too tough on banks, creating what they call a credit crunch that has been stifling the economy.
 
Replaying a Debacle
 At the same time, members of Congress and critics of the Administration contend that any easing by the regulators could lead to a replay of the savings and loan debacle, which by some measures could cost taxpayers more than $500 billion over the next 40 years.
Some lawmakers expect Mr. Taylor to exert the kind of independent judgment that often set Mr. Seidman at odds with the White House, despite the fact that the Presidential election looms next year. Mr. Taylor's term lasts only until February 1993, three months after voters go to the polls, and he said that he would like to be reappointed.
Mr. Taylor insists politics will not shape his judgments.
"It would be terrible," he said. "I would be disappointed with myself. How would it possibly be worth it?"
 
No Improvement Soon
 He said he would vigorously oppose any efforts to jump-start the economy by reducing current standards to let banks maintain a smaller cushion against losses. Banks and savings associations will have to have capital of 4 percent of assets, adjusted for risk, beginning in January, although some lawmakers, particularly in New England, have said that level should be reduced to help ailing instutitions and encourage them to lend more.
With the continued weakness of real estate markets in the Northeast and California, Mr. Taylor does not expect the condition of the weak banks to improve anytime soon.
One sign of his difficulties, Mr. Taylor acknowledged, is that he does not know if even the new money Congress will soon provide the insurance fund will be enough to cover possible future losses from banks.
"I have no idea," he said. "Not the foggiest. Tell me what the economy is going to look like. Tell me what interst rates are going to look like. Tell me what housing starts and real estate activities are like. Tell me what prices are going to be like, and I'll have a better view."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 1911 words

HEADLINE: In Aftermath of Deadly Fire, A Poor Town Struggles Back

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAMLET, N.C.

 BODY:
What happens to a place like this after disaster strikes and the television crews and investigators have come and gone?
About 8 A.M. on Sept. 3, fire flashed through the decrepit brick factory where Imperial Food Products Inc. cooked chicken for fast-food chains. With all means of escape locked or blocked, except the main entrance, 25 workers died and 56 were injured. The 164 other employees were left without jobs because the plant closed. 
 Remarkable things have happened since then, most good, some ugly. Welfare agencies report custody battles for a few of the 20 children orphaned by the fire, because people who are appointed guardians get the children's benefits. And big-city lawyers have arrived, promising pots of gold from lawsuits.
 
Signs of Compassion
 More important, the weeks since the fire have disclosed a resourceful and resilient community of the rural poor. Survivors say the churches, 22 in this town of 6,196 people, and the deeply rooted families who live here, brought hope and sustenance. The fire has also wrought compassion from bureaucracies -- the Social Security Administration, the United Way of Richmond County and Imperial Food's workers' compensation insurer, the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company -- that began getting help to survivors before many knew to ask.
In the end, though, the loss of a major employer, compounded by the deaths, exposes an industrial backwater here. Hamlet's economy is sinking, and its people are too poor, too locked to their unsalable trailers and weather-scarred houses, or too bound to their families to leave. Poverty and unemployment rise when factories leave towns like this and not enough else moves in to take their place.
The tenant of a building on Main Street here is a soup kitchen where 30 or 40 people have been getting a meal a day since long before the fire. Upstairs in one building is a home for battered women. About half the other establishments downtown are abandoned, including the movie theater and a Royal Crown Cola bottling plant. City Hall is new and well kept, but with the closing of Imperial Food, it has lost a major source of the revenues that pay for city services.
The fire victims' death certificates in the Richmond County Court House, five miles west of Hamlet in Rockingham, represent a cross-section of Hamlet's people. Fifteen of the 25 dead were born within a 15-minute drive of the plant, and only three were born outside the Carolinas. Just one, Elizabeth A. Bellamy, 42, married, mother of two children, had been to college. Thirteen of the dead were white and 12 were black. Eighteen were women, and 10 were black women.
The youngest person killed was Cynthia Marie Ratliff, who was 20, single and a high school graduate. The oldest was Josephine Barrington, who was 63, married, a mother of five who left school after the fourth grade. A son, Fred Barrington Jr., divorced father of a teen-age daughter, worked at the plant, too. People here say he died trying to get his mother out.
Special disaster aid for the survivors ranged from about $40,000 that the AFL-CIO and out-of-town unions contributed, to the five 29-cent stamps one woman sent in. But that help has about run out. Every weekday, 10 to 20 former Imperial Food employees or the victims' spouses, parents or children go to the United Way office in Rockingham for help. They get vouchers for up to $250 a month for rent, $150 for utilities and $100 for fuel.
But Yvonne Loury, executive director of the agency, said that its disaster fund, which climbed to $177,000 after the fire, was down to $40,000 by mid-November and that the rate of contributions had slowed to $3,000 a month. A similar fund of $45,000 collected by the Hamlet Ministerial Alliance of churches is exhausted, so the alliance has closed a center where survivors went for money.
 
Food Stamps Already Up
 As the aid runs down, applications for food stamps are likely to rise. Mikkel M. Todd, director of the Richmond County Department of Social Services, said that with the recession and other plant closings, the county's food stamp bill -- money the Federal Government will have to find -- was already running nearly 50 percent higher than last year's.
One example of how people and institutions responded to help survivors is the family of Mary Alice Arnold Quick. The three children of Mrs. Quick, who was 38 and separated from Martin Quick, have moved to the new double-wide mobile home of Mrs. Quick's sister, Peggy Brown, 42, a divorced mother of three grown children who is a deputy county clerk.
The day after the fire, Robby Lowry, the manager of the Social Security office in Rockingham, said he called undertakers to track down children of the workers who died. For Mrs. Quick's younger two children, Nakisha 13, and Martin Jr., 12, he arranged $550 a month in survivors' benefits, which they will get until they are 18, or 19 if they are still in school. "In cases like this," Mr. Lowry said, "some people would not know to come in."
The children's half sister, LaRonda Brown, was ineligible for the benefits because she is 18 and through high school. But she is getting other help. The morning of the fire, she was enrolling at Richmond Community College in Hamlet for a year's preparation for North Carolina Agricultural and Technical State University in Greensboro. She had $100 her mother had given her to help pay for her first quarter tuition of $170 and for her books. Since the fire, the college has exempted her from the remaining two quarters of tuition payments.
 
Role for Churches
 The churches did their part. St. Peter's United Methodist Church in Hamlet gave each of Mrs. Quick's children $147. The Hamlet Ministerial Alliance bought new beds for the children and paid a $131 utility bill for Peggy Brown. The White Oak Grove Baptist Church in Greensboro "adopted" the children.
"We went up there to meet them," LaRonda Brown said. "We had to write down the things we would need. The women of the church got our sizes, and they're going shopping."
Said Flora Banks, 64, mother of Margaret Teresa Banks, 24, who died leaving a son, Michael, 6, and a daughter, Martika, almost 2: "When stuff like this happens, everybody comes together." Mrs. Banks, whose husband is a sanitation worker, has given up her job as a textile worker to raise the children.
Social Security benefits and workers' compensation will leave the family with less than when Ms. Banks was working, and more people to support. But she said some things were more important than paychecks. "I gave up my job because they're too small," she said of the children. "And I'm not going to put them in a day care center."
North Carolina, like much of the South, boomed in part because politicians helped create a friendly climate for business with low wages, low taxes and public indifference to unions.
Here, nothing compels an employer to curry community favor. Ms. Loury said the company, the town's largest industrial employer, never contributed to United Way or let her solicit donations from its employees. Lisa Blue, the acting Hamlet city manager, said the factory closed down owing $12,250 in back taxes, $8,207.22 in water and sewer bills, and $1,500 for police protection after the fire.
"I think they were very much a corporation in absentia," Mayor Abbie G. Covington, a Democrat, said. "It was not real well managed."
The state's occupational safety agency has acknowledged that because of short staff and modest resources, it did not inspecte Imperial Food in 11 years of operation here. But to protect consumers, the Federal Department of Agriculture stopped by daily to check for vermin and flies.
This month, newspapers in Charlotte and Raleigh disclosed that in June, an Agriculture Department inspector let the management stop an infestation of flies by locking a door to a trash bin outside the plant. In the fire, some workers tried to escape through the door and then fled to a cooler, where they died.
 
Company's Response
 A man who answered the telephone at company headquarters in Atlanta twice one day recently said Emmett J. Roe, the president of the company, was on another line but did not wish to comment.
A few days later, a woman who answered refused to identify herself but said Mr. Roe was not there. Asked about accusations of lax and irresponsible management, she said: "I'm sorry, I can't comment on that. I don't think anybody else would." Then she hung up. Mr. Roe and his son, Brad, who ran the plant, face 26 lawsuits in Federal and county courts.
Workers said they did not raise complaints about safety because they wanted to keep working. "People kept quiet for fear of their jobs," said the Rev. Harold C. Miller, pastor of the First Baptist Church in Hamlet and president of the ministerial alliance.
One of the plant's employees, Georgia Quick, 31, no relation to Mary Quick, may never work again. Mother of a 9-year-old daughter and pregnant, Ms. Quick barely escaped the fire. She spent 17 days in a hospital with collapsed lungs and damage to her vocal cords. "There could be some difficulty with the baby," she said.
For the present, Liberty Mutual is paying her $115 a month in workers' compensation. If doctors determine that she will be disabled for more than a year, she would get an additional $20 or so a month in Social Security disability benefits.
 
No Jobs Available
 In economic terms, the people hurt most are those who simply lost their jobs. Betty A. Dorsett, manager of the Rockingham office of the state Employment Security Commission, said not a single employer in the county is looking for people with the low-wage skills of the Imperial Food workers.
Audrey Teal, 36, a single mother of a 14-year-old daughter, escaped the fire uninjured. With wages of $500 a month, food stamps of $80 and child support payments of $100, she said she had no trouble paying the bills. She still gets the food stamps and child support, but with unemployment benefits of half her wages and with help from the United Way running out, she said she expected trouble making her $250 mortgage payment.
Linda Robinson, 44, is the mother of seven children, and the youngest three, aged 15, 19 and 21, are living at home. She earned $212 a week at the Imperial plant and she said now collects an unemployment check of $106 and vouchers from United Way.
Her husband is unemployed and does not get benefits, but he has ways of scrounging up money. "He'll help somebody rake straw or something like that," Mrs. Robinson said. "Straw" here means pine needles.
"They rake it up and bale it and sell it for mulch," Joseph G. Davis, a Rockingham attorney, said. "When you're trying to climb the economic ladder, that's about where you start."
To politicians in the capital of Raleigh, Hamlet's salvation lies in the offer of an enterprise they would not consider for Raleigh -- a 2,800-acre dump six miles from Hamlet. It would take low-radioactivity nuclear wastes from utilities in eight states. Over the dump's 20 years of use, Richmond County could collect $3.3 million a year in taxes and fees, about $1 million more than the wages Imperial put into Hamlet.
But the dump would produce few jobs, and most people in Hamlet say they have pride enough to say no.
"It's politics," said Jeanie Ederle, a volunteer in the soup kitchen. "You pick the poorest county in the state and stick it with it."

HEADLINE: ISRAELIS ANGERED BY AMERICAN MOVE ON MIDEAST TALKS

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Nov. 24

 BODY:
As Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir returned home today from an American journey, Israelis attacked the United States for his reception there, accusing Washington of having humiliated him -- and by extension, their country -- in the way it fixed the next round of Middle East peace talks.
Angry Cabinet members charged that the Americans had deliberately insulted Israel, demonstrating basic bad faith in the peace process. Phrases like "bullying tactics" and "double cross" were invoked by several officials to characterize Bush Administration actions. 
 On the political far right, ministers opposed to the peace process urged Mr. Shamir to reject the invitation the United States issued on Friday for resumed negotiations with the Palestinians and Arab states beginning on Dec. 4 in Washington.
 
Refusal Seems Unlikely
 Senior Government officials generally agreed, however, that there was almost no way Israel could turn the Americans down, certainly not when the issue is a procedural question of where the talks should be held. Although Mr. Shamir said he had asked Washington to reconsider the site, Government officials said that no matter how much they object to Washington and prefer a site closer to home, their options are limited.
But it seemed virtually certain tonight that the Israelis would not answer the United States invitation by Monday, as the Israelis said the Americans had asked in the invitation, and that when they do say yes, there will be conditions attached.
While the Israelis said Washington asked for a response by Monday, it was not clear if this was an etched-in-stone deadline and if there would be unpleasant consequences for missing it. In Washington, an Administration official said today that the United States had not set a firm deadline for responses but added that the Administration hoped to get responses soon.
Thus far, only Jordan has said yes to the Americans. Israel, Syria, Lebanon and the Palestinian delegation have all said they need more time to think about it.
"We're not working according to an American stopwatch," a highly placed Israeli official said tonight. A decision, he said, was not likely until the Cabinet meets in special session, probably on Wednesday. Even then, he added, the Israelis would probably attach reservations like a request that the talks be moved as quickly as possible after a Washington session somewhere closer to the Middle East. Cyprus has been mentioned as a favorite Israeli choice in recent days.
For his part, Mr. Shamir returned this evening from his 10-day trip to the United States saying that he remained committed to the peace process but that he had also asked President Bush to reconsider Washington as a site and to keep talking with Israel until an agreement acceptable to everyone was reached.
In Washington, Administration officials said Israel had suggested holding the next round of peace talks in the Middle East and had recommended several sites. The American officials said that they would consider Israel's suggestions, but that the Arab countries had not accepted the sites recommended by Israel.
 
Visit Cut Short
 The Prime Minister's journey had been expected to continue for another day or two, and officials here said that he had cut it short because he was upset over the way he had been treated in Washington.
But at an airport news conference, Mr. Shamir sought to play down the dispute, insisting that, despite the obvious disagreements with Washington, "there is no crisis of confidence, not personal and not any other kind."
As a sign of his reluctance to further heighten tensions, he skirted a question about a remark made earlier in the day by a political ally, Police Minister Roni Milo, who called the American deadline "an impudent ultimatum" and said the Cabinet should take its time before making a decision.
Mr. Milo reflected how rankled many Israelis were by the way in which the Administration had sent out its invitations several hours before Mr. Shamir called on Mr. Bush. In fact, the Prime Minister and his traveling companions woke up in Washington on Friday morning, turned on the television news and, to their dismay, listened as Palestinian representatives said that they had already received the call to show up in Washington on Dec. 4.
Not that they were surprised that the Americans had taken action. The United States had been warning for three weeks that it would set a time and place if the Israelis and the Arabs did not agree on their own how to pick up where they left off on Nov. 3 in Madrid.
But to have it happen overnight, before Mr. Shamir got to the White House to argue his case once more for a location in this region, was deemed deeply insulting here. While some peace campaigners said that Mr. Shamir had only himself to blame, because he has tended to act only when the Americans apply considerable pressure, a widely shared view was that the United States ad heaped one more indignity on a pile that many Israelis find to be growing uncomfortably high.
Relations with Washington began to nosedive in September, when Mr. Bush insisted on a 120-day delay of an Israeli request for $10 billion in American loan guarantees to resettle Soviet emigrants. That was followed by leaked reports in Washington denigrating Israeli's economic capabilities and by Administration criticism of Israeli surveillance flights over Iraq, which Israel felt were justified given the three dozen Scud missiles that Iraq had fired this way during the Persian Gulf War.
 
The Last Straw?
 Taking all this into account, many Israelis found the latest perceived snub of the Prime Minister to be too much.
Mr. Shamir confined himself today to saying that the Administration action was not "appropriate." Others used stronger language.
"This is a bullying Administration, and they use bullying tactics all the time," a high-level official said, adding that "at the end of the day, we may not always say yes to them."
Another official referred to the American action as "a double cross." Still another, Health Minister Ehud Olmert, a Shamir loyalist, complained that "we are speaking of an Administration that doesn't try or pretend to show, even for appearances, some amount of friendship."
Even Israelis who hold little love for their right-wing Prime Minister and consider him an obstacle to Middle East peace argued that the United States had acted insensitively. "This was a clear humiliation," said Yaron Ezrahi, a political theorist at Hebrew University in Jerusalem. "By doing this, they undermine the domestic resources for flexibility by this Government at the negotiations."
Israel would rather have its face-to-face talks with the Arabs alternate between this country and neighboring states because the presence of Arab negotiators here would amount to recognition of Israel. For that very reason, the Arabs do not like the idea.
As for Washington, Mr. Shamir argues that it is too far from here for easy logistics and that such a procedure would undermine the principle of unimpeded, direct negotiations. "The aim of the Arab side is not to negotiate with us but with the U.S. Administration, and with the help of the Administration to force unacceptable positions on us," he said today.
Israel has held out little hope for an agreement with Syria or Lebanon, but it sees a good chance for reaching accord with Jordan and establishing some sort of self-rule for Palestinians in the occupied territories.

HEADLINE: Once Abolished by U.S., Tribe Forges Future

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SILETZ, Ore., Nov. 21

 BODY:
Deep inside the coastal forest of Oregon, a small American Indian tribe is building the reservation of the future.
After clearing a swath in the woods, the Siletz Indians have constructed a new community of big homes and broad streets. Unemployment is well below the national average. Drugs and alcohol are not allowed. And the budget, enriched by tribal businesses and a portfolio of outside investments, is showing a healthy surplus. 
 But what is most remarkable about the Siletz is the simple fact that they exist, still holding millennium-old ties to this land. The Siletz, like nearly 70 other tribes and bands of American Indians, were offically abolished in the 1950's as part of a Government policy known as termination, which took their land, their sovereign status and their tribal identity. In return, the Government made cash payments to the Indians.
Since then, the 2,000-member tribe has waged a 35-year struggle for the restoration of what was taken. Reflecting the consensus view that the policy, which the Government said was intended to move Indians into the American mainstream, was a dismal failure, the Siletz say they are far better off with a reservation, even a tiny one.
But as they work to build a new reservation from the ground up, the Siletz are determined to avoid the mistakes of the past. There are no handouts or cash payments to individuals; they limit budget growth to 2.5 percent a year. They make some use of the old economic standbys, forests and fish, but are not afraid of trying new business ventures or investing in the stock market. And they still have ceremonies to the salmon god and teach children how to speak the tribal language.
"This tribe is a real prototype for the future because they are trying to take the best of both worlds," said Nelson Witt, an Oglala Sioux who was hired to manage the tribal business interests here. "They are a part of the outside world, but they have not driven the Indian from their hearts."
Most major tribes that were abolished under the policy from 1954 to 1970 have been restored by Congress. The Menominee, in Wisconsin, were the first to be brought back, in 1973. The Siletz, in 1977, were the second. Two tribal groups that were terminated, one in South Carolina and the other in California, have yet to win back their status as nations within a nation.
As they rebuild their nations, in some cases starting with nothing more than a one-room office in places where they used to own a third of a state, the tribes are trying to avoid the old cycles of despair. Many of the long-established Indian reservations, situated on land that was considered worthless by the Government, have unemployment rates in excess of 70 percent, bleak housing and minimal prospects for the future.
There is widespread feeling that the Siletz are a model for tribes whose status has been restored, like the Ponca Indians in Nebraska. The 1,200-member tribe had its status restored last year but has no land. Some of its leaders were on the Oregon coast this week studying the Siletz and the Coquille Tribe south of here that was restored in 1989.
The Coquille have but a single acre of land and a small tribal office in Coos Bay, a depressed Oregon mill town on the Pacific. The 600-member tribe adopted a new constitution in August and is working on a plan to be economically self-sufficient.
 
Change in Policy
 "It goes without saying that restoration will lead to a better life," said Don Ivy, a Coquille tribal leader. "But the fact is, we live in the 1990's and we need to try a modern approach. The Siletz, for us, have been a education."
Since 1960, the number of American Indians counted by the Census Bureau has tripled, to a current population of 1.8 million, mainly because the number of Americans who declare themselves as Indians has grown. A majority still live on or near reservations.
But it was not so long ago that Federal Indian policy favored removing reservations altogether. Oregon was particularly affected by that policy, as tribes like the Klamaths and the Siletz, who once had huge tracts of reservation land, were given cash payments and told that they no longer existed as a tribe. In the early years of termination, this was done without the consent of a majority of tribal members.
In their treaty of 1855, the Siletz were granted a reservation of 1.1 million acres. But the treaty was never ratified by the Senate, and land that was to have been set aside for them was given away in a series of Presidential decrees. This land includes some with the most spectacular scenery on the Oregon coast, where four-star resorts and art galleries now hug the cliffs of Highway 101.
When the Siletz were terminated in the 1950's, the Government gave each tribal member $560. In turn, the tribe lost 60,000 acres it still owned from the original 1.1-million-acre reservation. The tribe retained a small cemetery atop a hill in this town, the only visible landmark of a people who once lived from Northern California to halfway up the Oregon coast.
From the start, many in the tribe did not agree to give up its reservation, although some who lived in nearby towns told Federal agents they favored the idea.
"You never quit being an Indian just because your tribe has been terminated," said Delores Pigsley, the Siletz tribal chairwoman.
"Termination was a disaster, stripping us of language, culture, land, everything," she added. "It looked good to people who didn't live on reservations, so the Government would go to Indians outside the reservation to get their permission."
The Siletz spent two decades trying to get a Congressional declaration restoring the tribe. After 1970, when Congress and President Richard M. Nixon formally denounced termination, the path was cleared to bring back the tribe.
Parcels totaling 3,600 acres of Federal land were given to the tribe, and in 1977 it started anew. Members sold timber, built a community center next to the cemetery and made plans to construct new houses for Indians who began to move to the new reservation. They also revitalized the local community where their children attend public schools, non-Indians in the area acknowledge.
 
'Build for the Future'
 "Our goal was to build for the future, to always look ahead," said Manuel Rilatos, who is on the tribal council.
The Siletz decided, against the wishes of some here, not to give out individual payments from the proceeds of tribal enterprises. Instead, they elected to put the money into a community trust, and invest for the future. The timber enterprise grew, as did a business that sells native plants to nurseries. Money was put into the stock market. Last year, revenue of about $2 million was four times the size of the budget.
This year has been the best yet. The Siletz started a smokehouse that sells salmon to tourists in Depoe Bay. A medical clinic, serving Indians and non-Indians alike, has just opened. The tribe realized a longstanding dream and built 54 new houses, some of them with five bedroom, bay windows and two-car garages.
More than almost any other tribe that has been restored, the Siletz have prospered. But even tribes that have not done as well say coming back from termination has been a second chance at life.
"The significance of restoration is that this is the first time in American history that a major Indian policy actually began with Indian people," said Aida Deer, an educator at the University of Wisconsin who was instrumental in helping her native Menominees regain their reservation in Wisconsin.
Given the history of Federal policy, many Indians never thought they could get their tribal status or reservation returned, Ms. Deer said.
"The small tribes pulled this off, through strength and courage, and I think everybody was surprised," she said. "When termination occured, what people forgot was that Indians wanted to be Indians."
Don Miller, a lawyer with the Native American Rights Fund in Boulder, Colo., said restoration has been a rare success story in Indian country, but it should be placed in perspective.
"The tribes that were terminated have benefited greatly from restoration," Mr. Miller said. "But, of course, this doesn't mean they got very much of their land back. Only a sliver."
Looking at the big new houses here in Siletz, Mr. Rilatos, who was born here in 1923, said: "We went from a million acres to a graveyard, to this here. We are just now seeing some light."

HEADLINE: Talks on Haitian Crisis End in Impasse

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARTAGENA, Colombia, Nov. 24

 BODY:
Talks between Haiti's deposed President and his legislative opponents ended today in a stalemate, and with no concrete plans for further negotiations to resolve the country's crisis.
The weekend of meetings at this Caribbean resort marked the first occasion on which the ousted President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, has sat face to face with his foes since he was ousted in a coup on Sept. 30. 
 One issue proved insolvable: Father Aristide insisted that a joint statement by the two sides provide for his return to Haiti as legitimite President, while the opposition would only agree to more ambiguous phrasing. The Haitian lawmakers wanted simply to cite a constitutional clause stating that presidential terms last for five years.
Father Aristide, Haiti's first democratically President, had served only eight months when the military ousted him from power.
 
From Optimism to Failure
 The talks, mediated by the Organization of American States, had begun in a general atmosphere of optimism Friday evening. Today they dragged ominously past a noon deadline until both sides conceded failure at 6:30 P.M.
The two sides also clashed on ways of reversing a trade embargo imposed against Haiti in October by the 34-member Organization of American States to protest the military coup.
The embargo, which has aggravated the country's economic misery, lent a sense of urgency to the negotiations. Shortages of food and other necessities have prompted thousands of residents to flee the country, with many of them risking drowning by sailing toward the United States on rickety boats.
The Haitian legislative delegation demanded an unconditional and immediate end to the embargo, but Father Aristide said that its removal had to coincide with his naming of a new prime minister as a first step toward recreating his Cabinet.
"We were very surprised when Aristide's emissaries told us that he wasn't ready to do anything for the people that he loves if we don't agree to name him president," said Thomas Eddy Dupiton, who served as one of three Senate delegates at the weekend meetings.
 
Some Points of Agreement
 After the talks ended, Father Aristide assigned an aide to read a statement mentioning points on which the two sides had agreed: the creation of a police force under the jurisdiction of the Justice Ministry, steps to put the army under a central command answerable to the government, and efforts toward the immediate restoration of international aid.
The Organization for American States said after the meeting that it planned to send two delegations to Haiti to monitor human rights.
Though the outcome was viewed as a disappointment, the mediators suggested that the talks were at least a start. Observers emphasized that even a month ago, it seemed improbable that Father Aristide and his foes would meet to discuss the possibility of his reinstatement.
"The crisis won't be resolved in one day, in one city," said Augusto Ramirez Ocampo, who, as Colombia's O.A.S. delegate led the discussions. "We recognize that this is just the beginning in a long process toward achieving our goal."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Protest at Canadian Embassy
 PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 24 (Reuters) -- A group of 19 Haitians who have occupied a small waiting room in the Canadian Embassy since Wednesday pushed their way into the main part of the building today, demanding political asylum.
 A pamphlet signed by three of the group's leaders called for the burning of the Canadian and American embassies and added, "Long live Qaddafi, long live Castro, long live Aristide!"
 A Western diplomat said the group's action seemed to be aimed at discrediting Father Aristide and paralyzing the Canadian Embassy, which has played an important role in the negotiations to return the ousted leader to power.
 The Canadian Embassy said it would not grant refugee status to anyone in the group, and a spokesman for Father Aristide denounced the occupation of the embassy building.

HEADLINE: U.N. Leader Seeks A $1 Billion Fund For Peace Missions

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 24

 BODY:
In an effort to resolve the latest financial crisis to grip the United Nations, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar will ask governments, private corporations and wealthy individuals on Monday to set up a $1 billion Peace Endowment Fund to help pay for future United Nations peacekeeping operations.
In addition, Mr. Perez de Cuellar will ask the General Assembly to authorize him to start charging governments interest on unpaid contributions they owe. He also plans to more than double the United Nations reserve fund and allow him and his successors to take out loans from commercial banks to plug budget gaps. 
 The Secretary General will also ask members for advance payment of their 1992 dues so he can pay December staff salaries. The United Nations now has enough cash on hand to pay its 5,000 or so employees through the end of this month. But the organization's Deputy Controller, Susan R. Mills, said last week that unless it could quickly find $100 million more, it would be unable to meet its December payroll.
Mr. Perez de Cuellar, in a report he will send to the Assembly on Monday, says, "It is a source of profound concern to me that the same membership which sees it appropriate to entrust the United Nations Secretariat with unprecedented new responsibilities has not taken the necessary action to insure that the minimum financial resources required to carry out those responsibilities are provided on a reliable and predictable basis."
The reason the United Nations is once again on the brink of insolvency is that members, principally the United States, continue not to pay their dues fully and promptly at a time when the organization faces soaring new bills for peacekeeping operations.
To improve the organization's financial health and meet the cost of new peacekeeping operations, the Secretary General will ask for $500 million in new contributions from the membership before the 1991 General Assembly session ends next month.
Under his plan, $300 million would go to the proposed new $1 billion Peace Endowment Fund, with the United Nations asking corporations, foundations and wealthy individuals to put up the rest. Income from this fund would be used for peacekeeping.

HEADLINE: Duke May Seem to Be Wallace of '91, But Both Times and the Risks Differ

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAFAYETTE, La.

 BODY:
The speaker and his agenda may be new, but the scene at the David Duke rally at Evangeline Downs here earlier this month provoked a sense of political deja vu -- the same angry white men in baseball caps and jeans, the same railing against out-of-touch big government and high taxes, the same thinly veiled racial appeals.
Mr. Duke is tapping into the same frustrations and same constituency that former Gov. George Wallace of Alabama did in his campaigns for President in 1968 and 1972. But significant differences exist between now and then, both in the degree of frustration and in which political party is most at risk. 
 "The issues George Wallace raised in 1968 are the issues Duke is addressing now," said Merle Black, a professor of politics and government at Emory University in Atlanta. "When you talk about affirmative action, preferential treatment, busing for school desegregation, these are issues which came up in the 1960's in which whites were in direct opposition to blacks, and these are issues that have never been reconciled."
 
Losing Votes in Louisiana
 Still, it is unclear how much can be read into the career of Mr. Duke, who was thrashed Nov. 16 in his race for governor and then announced two days later that he was considering a run for President.
Mr. Duke, a Republican State Representative from suburban New Orleans, got only 39 percent of the vote for governor, after getting 44 percent a year ago in a race for the United States Senate. And in the second campaign, his support among whites dropped to 55 percent, from 60 percent, and he was running against a scandal-tinged opponent who was the perfect foil for his angry, send-them-a-message call for radical change.
On the other hand, Mr. Duke did win 665,000 votes for governor, despite his background in the Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazi groups, the opposition of virtually every interest group and public official in Louisiana and warnings that the state would face economic catastrophe if he was elected.
He did best with blue-collar and low- to middle-income whites, picking up 68 percent of whites with a high school education or less. He got the vote of 62 percent of white Protestants, 69 percent of whites who say they are born-again Christians, 56 percent of whites with annual family incomes under $15,000, 63 percent of whites with incomes of $15,000 to $29,999 and 60 percent of whites with incomes of $30,0000 to $49,999.
Mr. Duke also gained support among upper-income voters -- 49 percent of whites earning $50,000 to $74,999 a year and 34 percent of whites earning more than $75,000 -- a group that largely eluded Mr. Wallace in his Presidential campaigns.
 
The Wallace Vote
 In 1968, when Mr. Wallace ran on a third-party ticket, he carried five Southern states, including Louisiana. In his bids for the Democratic Presidential nomination he did well in primaries in such non-Southern states as Michigan and Maryland.
Mr. Wallace was very much in a tradition of Southern populism, using race and economic issues as ways to channel the frustration of working-class whites, first in the South and then in the nation.
Alan Brinkley, a professor of history at Columbia University, said that Mr. Duke tapped some of the same anger but that he came from a more purely racial perspective. In the latter stages of Mr. Wallace's political career in a changed Southern electorate, he won sizeable black support in his campaigns for governor. Few expect that of Mr. Duke.
To some the main difference between Mr. Duke and Mr. Wallace is which political party the candidate put at risk.
"I don't believe there's a new populism," said Curtis Gans, chairman of the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate, a research organization in Washington. "I don't see anything really new from the Wallace-Nixon days except this time it's going to split asunder the Republican Party instead of the Democrats."
The risks for the Republicans include not just the potential for a divisive Presidential primary fight, but also the degree to which Mr. Duke's association with conservative issues like opposition to preferential hiring of minorities could taint strong Republican issues.
"David Duke is probably the best thing that has ever happened for the Democratic Party," said Gary Jarmin, national political director for the American Freedom Coalition, a conservative organization. "He has neutralized those issues that Republicans could have used, but now everybody is going to scream 'racism' because they're associated with David Duke."
But if some see a reprise of the Wallace days with a different party, others see the possibility of broader-based racial politics. They say the longevity of the frustrations of white blue-collar and middle-class voters, the degree of social dislocation and pathology in inner cities and, most important, the lingering recession and the bleak prospects for blue-collar whites provide a fertile ground for racial politics.
"I think it's much more dangerous now," said Stanley Greenberg, President of Greenberg-Lake, a Democratic polling firm whose 1985 study of white voters in suburban Detroit reflected many of the intense racial resentments of the Duke voters in Louisiana. "Then, the country was in a period of rapid growth. What we have now is two decades of very slow economic growth, almost no income growth and for younger non-college graduate males, their income has gone down at least 25 percent. These people are natural material for a Duke-type campaign."
 
Divisions on the Message
 To liberals and most Democrats, Mr. Duke's rise reflects the failure of Republican economics combined with a Republican strategy that runs from Richard M. Nixon's Southern strategy of playing to white voters to George Bush's campaign advertisements playing on coded racial appeals.
"Duke's message is that if your life isn't what you want it to be, blame it on people who are black," said Harrison Hickman, a Democratic political consultant. "I don't think it's much more complicated than that. I think that the great failure here is the failure of Reagan and Bush. Reagan made it socially acceptable and Bush made it politically expedient to play in this arena."
But others, including some Democrats, say Mr. Duke's appeal is more complicated. He may be advancing a racial agenda, they say, but by focusing on crime and welfare dependency he is also playing on real issues that reflect real failings in American life. And some, including conservatives who reject Mr. Duke personally, say that part of the failure is the degree to which those issues have been forced out of the political debate.
"This is a 25-year-old battle that if you say you are concerned about crime, and you want law and order, hey, you're really a racist at heart," said Richard A. Viguerie, chairman of United Conservatives of America. "You want to cut back on welfare, you're a racist. You don't want special privileges, affirmative action by the Government -- quotas, let's just call that what it is -- you're a racist."
Another leading conservative, Paul M. Weyrich, said: "The funny part of it is, the minorities that I've dealt with, not just in the black community but in the Hispanic community and so on, they don't think it's racist. They know that these problems are real, and they care about this stuff, and they're glad when somebody is honest with them."
To many, the problem with Mr. Duke in particular and racial politics in general is that they offer scapegoating, not solutions.
"Duke isn't interested in solving problems," said Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, who is chairman of the Democratic Leadership Council, a gathering of moderates in the party. "He's interested in feeding on them."
William Julius Wilson, a University of Chicago sociologist who wrote an influential book on poverty, "The Truly Disadvantaged" (University of Chicago Press, 1989), said that both the poor and the middle class had a common interest in meaningful economic reform rather than racial polarization.
"What's needed is a political leader who can identify the breakdown in our society that has created these problems, not just for the poor but for the middle class as well," he said.
