HEADLINE: Political Memo;
An Early Report Card On the Democrats' Trail

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DES MOINES, Nov. 24

 BODY:
Democrats are now enjoying the unusual experience of watching Republicans in disarray, but sooner or later the Democratic Party will have to pre sent an alternative -- not a simple Bush basher, but a full-blown Presidential nominee.
This weekend, the six major contenders for the job engaged in a kind of rolling cattle show that began in Chicago, where the state Democratic leaders were meeting, continued in Des Moines before the Iowa Democratic Party's Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner, and ended up at the South Dakota Democratic Party steak fry in Sioux Falls. 
 When the jockeying was over, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas seemed the candidate most ready for prime time, judging by the response of the party professionals in Chicago. Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa remains the cruising-for-a-fight liberal, who can hit nearly every button imaginable in an audience of active Democrats. Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, who seemed to start the race with the most natural star quality, is still struggling for a message that uses it.
All six have their strengths and weaknesses, three weeks before a series of national television debates introduces them to the nation. Herewith, a preview:
 
Edmund G. Brown Jr.
Former Governor of California
Message: This is the candidate of rage, railing against the corrupting influence of special interest money, warning of continued national decline under a Government stacked against the people, urging term limits and a host of other measures to shake up the system. He gets increasingly apocalyptic as he goes along, warning of the consequences of business as usual. "This is not going to go gentle into that good night," he roared at Democrats in Chicago. "This is going to be an explosive ripping apart of the social fabric."
Problems: Mr. Brown's lifelong background in politics, including his stint as chairman of the California Democratic Party, tends to cut against his outsider message. He tries to present himself as a reformed sinner who truly knows how awful things are. "I'm not some academic," he told Iowa Democrats. "Even though you might not believe it, I didn't come in here off the moon."
 
Bill Clinton
Governor of Arkansas
Message: Mr. Clinton presents himself as the champion of the middle class, promising to reclaim the American Dream and restore the economy with a set of domestic policy prescriptions. What Mr. Clinton has acquired in his months of traveling -- which some think the New York-bound Gov. Mario M. Cuomo needs -- is a message that at least tries to reach out to the various parts of the Democratic coalition, North and South, left and right.
"I am a Democrat by heritage, instinct and conviction," he said in Iowa, where some look askance at his background as past chairman of the Democratic Leadership Council, a group that often feuds with liberals. Mr. Clinton now argues that the party needs to be pushed neither right or left, but "into the future."
Problems: There is a fine line between coalition-building and muddying one's message. When Mr. Clinton misses the mark, as he has on other occasions, he can sound mushy.
Also, communism may have collapsed and Americans may be ready for a President who spends more time at home, but doesn't the nation still need a foreign policy? Mr. Clinton's speeches covered a lot this weekend, but not that.
 
Tom Harkin
Senator from Iowa
Message: No chance of a muddied message here. Mr. Harkin wants to cut military spending sharply and embark on a major new public works program, rebuilding roads and the like. He says he does not mind being be labeled a protectionist. ("Well, la-di-da," he says.) He says he laughs at those who accuse him of preaching class warfare. "What the hell do they think we've had over the past 10 years?" he asked in Iowa. "We had class warfare -- and we lost."
This is unrepentant liberalism. "It's time for us to quit apologizing for being Democrats," he said, and the party faithful keep cheering him on. "I haven't lost my heart and I haven't lost my soul, and the Democratic Party hasn't either."
Problems: Hearts and souls aside, some Democrats wonder whether traditional liberals make the best nominees. Mr. Harkin scoffs at the notion that the party must fundamentally refashion its image to regain the White House, but there are many Democrats who disagree.
 
Bob Kerrey
Senator from Nebraska
Message: Mr. Kerrey has been trying to present himself as the candidate of change; he uses his plan for universal health care as an example of the change he seeks. "It's not just a moral imperative, it's an economic imperative," he said in Iowa.
But Mr. Kerrey got his best response this weekend when he was taking questions from the audience and when he was talking about his values and his life. "Were it not for the values of the Great Society when I returned in 1969, I would not be standing here today," said Mr. Kerrey, who won the Congressional Medal of Honor in Vietnam for a battle in which he lost a leg. "Today, we're led by the values of a grim society."
Problems: Mr. Kerrey's life story and personal style were two of the major strengths many Democrats thought he brought to the campaign; yet those qualities seemed buried under a mountain of health care information this weekend. "Kerrey was best when he went to Q and A," said Bob Slagle, the chairman of the Texas Democratic Party. "He sounded a little bit bored with his speech."
 
Paul E. Tsongas
Former Senator from Massachusetts
Message: This is the pro-business liberal, who says he wants Democrats to forswear corporate-bashing and adopt some serious measures, like a specific cuts in the tax on capital gains, to get the economy growing again.
He is professorial and earnest, urging his audience to read his white papers on health care and economic policy. He also urges his party to retain its traditional values on civil rights and women's rights even as it remakes its economics.
Mr. Tsongas is one of the wittiest of the candidates: On Saturday in Iowa, while arguing that the party must regain its credibility on economics to regain the White House, Mr. Tsongas said: "Let's try winning and see what it feels like. If we don't like it, we can go back to our traditions."
Problems: Bruce Babbitt, the former Arizona Governor who ran for the Democratic nomination in 1988, was also a witty, somewhat professorial man who urged the party to change; his candidacy did not last. Mr. Tsongas still has to convince many in the party that his candidacy is more than a very long shot.
 
L. Douglas Wilder
Governor of Virginia
Message: The Governor casts himself as the outsider who can reassert some fiscal discipline in Washington. He says it is time to "put America first," and proposes the Government give $35 billion in tax cuts to the middle class, with another $15 billion sent to cities for problems like crime.
Mr. Wilder, the first black American ever elected governor, has increased appeals for black support in recent weeks. And the very idea of his election continues to strike a powerful chord among many white voters. One of the strongest responses he got this weekend came when he was talking of the Framers and the inspiration he drew from their writings -- "those great Virginians who may not have envisioned me when they wrote them," he said with a slight laugh, adding, "Of course they didn't."
Problem: Mr. Wilder says his $50 billion "Put America First" program would be financed by eliminating waste in the Federal budget, but has yet to detail any cuts.
"I am telling you, based on my experience as Governor, I can find waste," he finally told reporters.

Bill Clinton of Arkansas, Senators Tom Harkin of Iowa and Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, and Paul E.Tsongas, of Massachusettes. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Sununu Is Given Thumbs Up As Bush Returns to Capital

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24

 BODY:
A smiling John H. Sununu was waiting to greet President Bush today as he returned to the White House from Camp David. The President gave a thumbs up when asked if he intended to keep his beleaguered chief of staff.
Mr. Sununu also got a kiss on the cheek from Barbara Bush, who earlier denied a report of having become disenchanted with Mr. Sununu. 
 The chief of staff usually is not on hand when Mr. Bush returns from weekends at the Presidential retreat. Asked why he was there, Mr. Sununu replied, "Just catching up."
There have been recent reports of bickering between Mr. Sununu and Mr. Bush's political advisers, including people who might be expected to lead a Presidential re-election campaign.
And Mr. Sununu had a confrontation on Thursday with a reporter he accused of erroneously blaming him for Mr. Bush's recent remarks on high credit-card interest rates.

HEADLINE: On Eve of Talks With Aid Donors, Kenya Is Under Pressure to Democratize

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 24

 BODY:
On the eve of a meeting between Kenyan officials and donors of vital foreign aid, President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya, one of Africa's most prominent remaining autocrats, is facing unparalleled pressures for political reform both at home and abroad.
Domestically, an opposition newly emboldened by democratic movements elsewhere in Africa has seen its support grow visibly as it confronts the repression by the Moi Government. 
 Internationally, growing disgust with the corrupt practices of the Government has led foreign benefactors to pull back, a development likely to pose great peril to Kenya's fragile economy and heighten discontent.
 
Conditions for Aid
 On Monday in Paris, the Western donors and the World Bank will meet to decide the amount of aid they will grant Kenya next year. In the past week, the principal donors -- the European Community, Britain and the United States -- have shown rare cohesiveness in condemning Mr. Moi's clampdown on the opposition and have indicated that they are likely to condition aid on Mr. Moi's willingness to move toward political pluralism.
Yet thus far Mr. Moi has refused to yield. While few predict that he will remain obdurate indefinitely, he has in the past proven tenacious and adroit in the face of political challenges.
One of the arguments that Mr. Moi repeatedly uses to justify his one-party rule is that a multiparty system would degenerate into tribal warfare. There are three major tribes in Kenya -- the Kikuyu, the Luhya and the Luo. The 67-year-old, barrel-chested Mr. Moi is a member of one of the country's smaller tribes, the Kalenjin.
"We have been having ethnic groups all over," Mr. Moi said last month in a rare interview with the British Broadcasting Corporation.
 
Tribes and Parties
 "See what is happening in Somalia. It has 102 clans, which means you can have 102 parties. In Zaire, 265 parties to represent 265 tribes. You cannot really develop the country with such divisions."
But critics say that Mr. Moi exaggerates tribal divisions in Kenya by continually referring to his opponents as "tribalists." Kenyans who have worked closely with Mr. Moi describe him as "paranoid" about the possibility that Kenya's largest tribe, the Kikuyu, will unseat him and unravel his large, illegally gained fortune.
In a veiled attack on Mr. Moi, Simon Nyachae, a former political colleague and head of the civil service until 1987, suggested in an advertisement in a Kenyan newspaper last week that recent violence between Mr. Moi's Kalenjin tribe and the Luo, Kenya's second-largest tribe, was deliberately fomented by the Government, a view held by many others. Mr. Nyachae is a member of the Kisii tribe.
Many urban Kenyans, particularly those between 20 and 40 years old, say that tribalism is less pervasive in Kenyan society than it was 10 years ago. Advocates of a multiparty system also note that since no tribe has more than 25 percent of the population, there would be a need for coalitions in a democratic Government.
Mr. Moi came to power through tribal politics. He was chosen in 1967 as Vice President by Jomo Kenyatta, Kenya's first president and a Kikuyu. Coming from the Kalenjin, a pastoral people who inhabit the Rift Valley west of Nairobi, Mr. Moi was thought to provide Mr. Kenyatta a neutral screen against the tribal pressures of the Kikuyu and the Luo.
Unlike Mr. Kenyatta's first vice president, the charismatic Oginga Odinga of the Luo tribe, Mr. Moi was a rather bland personality who posed no threat to Mr. Kenyatta.
When Mr. Kenyatta died in 1978, Mr. Moi succeeded him. Many sophisticated Kenyans believed that he would not last long as President.
But on coming to power, Mr. Moi adopted a high-profile populist style, travelling into rural areas and identifying himself with the ordinary people.
At the same time, he organized the rapid promotion of his ethnic compatriots and he gradually stripped the Kikuyu, widely regarded as the entrepreneurial class, of their dominance in the Kenyan economy.
In 1982, Mr. Moi appointed a longtime Kalenjin friend, Nicholas Biwott, to the job of Minister of Energy, giving him command over a large section of the Kenyan economy, including many big development projects involving foreign investors. Over recent months, Mr. Biwott became a liability Mr. Moi could no longer handle.
Both American and British diplomats complained to the Moi Government about Mr. Biwott's personal profiteering from his job through kickbacks and expropriations. As the allegations of corruption against Mr. Biwott mounted, he was named by a British detective in testimony last week as one of two "prime suspects" in the February 1990 slaying of Foreign Minister Robert Ouko. Mr. Moi was forced to drop Mr. Biwott from the Cabinet.
 
Opposition Parties Banned
 Mr. Moi survived a 1982 coup attempt staged by the Air Force and thereafter did all he could to consolidate his power. His first reaction was to ram through a constitutional amendment that made law what was already reality: a one-party state with his Kenya African National Union as the only legal party.
"I would like ministers, assistant ministers and others to sing like a parrot after me," Mr. Moi said in 1984. "That is how we can progress."
In the 1988 parliamentary elections, Mr. Moi replaced the secret ballot with queuing, a voting system under which voters stand behind the picture of the candidate of their choice. Voter turnout was low -- largely because people were intimidated by the system of voting. Moi.
While strengthening his political power and enhancing his personal wealth, Mr. Moi has left the Kenyan military relatively untouched. By African standards, the army is quite small -- about 20,000 for a population of 25 million -- and quite professional, Western military experts say. Recruitment is heaviest among Mr. Moi's Kalenjin tribe, but promotions appear to be largely based on merit, the experts say.
How Mr. Moi is going to deal with the extraordinary pressures that are cascading in on him is not clear.
His decision last week to arrest 12 opposition figures and to send riot police with tear gas and truncheons to stop several thousand people from reaching an opposition rally angered already disaffected Western donors and strengthened a disorganized opposition.
The United States and Germany were further antagonized by the Kenyan Government's accusations that their embassies here had tried to take opposition leaders to the rally in embassy cars. Germany recalled its Ambassador. The American Ambassador, Smith Hempstone, called the allegations "lies." The current Foreign Minister, Wilson Ndolo Aya, , called the outspoken Mr. Hempstone a "racist."
As the political atmosphere has become more charged, the economic situation continues to deteriorate. Rural farmers are complaining about inflation and openly blaming the Government. In the cities, unemployment "is soon going to become a threatening problem of security," Mr. Nyachae warned.
Last week, The Weekly Review, a magazine that has been supportive of Mr. Moi, talked about the need to "manage change," a concept that it seemed to suggest was out of Mr. Moi's grasp.

HEADLINE: London Journal;
Britain Puzzles Over a Peril: Crossing the Street

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
It is a familiar if somewhat chilling scene, played out regularly at intersections across London. A group of tourists approach a busy street, glance to their left and then confidently step off the curb -- and nearly into the path of a bus bearing down on them from the right.
With its right-hand traffic flow, this city has always been tough on foreign pedestrians, who can often be observed at street corners wearing the slightly startled look of deer edging alongside a freeway. It was for them, mostly, that London officals years ago began painting reminders along curbs suggesting that pedestrians "look left" or "look right" before venturing into the street. 
 Then, last month, beginning a new $2.1 million safety campaign intended to reduce the number of children killed or injured in pedestrian accidents in Britain, the Princess of Wales and government officials made it clear that foreigners were not the only ones imperiled by London's congested and sometimes disjointed traffic patterns.
According to government statistics, there are few places in the world where crossing the street can be so fraught with danger, a situation officials attribute to urban drivers who drive too fast and with too little care.
 
Traffic Fatalities Decline
 While the overall number of fatalities and serious injuries resulting from traffic accidents in Britain has declined steeply over the years, as a result of safer cars and the mandatory use of seat belts, pedestrians, and especially children who are pedestrians, remain at an unusually high risk.
Nearly one of every three traffic deaths in Britain involves a pedestrian run over by a car. In France, the United States and Italy, where the rates of traffic casualties in general are much higher, only about one in seven deaths involves a pedestrian.
Since December 1990, according to the United States Embassy here, five Americans have been killed in separate accidents in Britain when they stepped off the curb into the path of vehicles.
Two-thirds of all accidental deaths involving schoolchildren are a result of traffic accidents, most of them when the children are pedestrians, a record that Malcolm Rifkind, Britain's Transportation Secretary, describes as "dreadful."
While Mr. Rifkind noted that the average number of pedestrian deaths involving children had declined from 563 a year in the early 1980's to 417 in 1990, a fact that may be explained in part by the decline in overall numbers of children as the birth rate in Britain has dropped, the per capita casualty rate remained about the same.
The total number of people killed on the roads in Britain may fall below 5,000 this year, the lowest it has been since 1949. Over the same period, the number of cars on the roads has risen from 1.7 million to 24.2 million.
"On a per capita basis, we have one of the best overall road safety records in the world," said Simon Jones, a spokesman for the Automobile Association, a club that represents more than 7.5 million British motorists. "But we have one of the worst records in terms of pedestrian and children fatalities."
An analysis this year by the Policy Studies Institute, which examines social and economic trends, concluded that fear of traffic had become so great among parents in London that many no longer allowed their children to cross the road alone.
According to the report, a 1971 survey disclosed that 80 percent of 7- and 8-year-old children in Britain went to school on their own. Last year the institute went back to the same schools and discovered that the figure had dropped to 9 percent, a decline the analysts attributed mostly to fear of traffic.
"Although the environmental harm done by cars is increasingly conceded, there is a widespread reluctance to acknowledge the social damage they do," said John Adams, a professor at the University College in London. "As traffic increases, other opportunities are reduced. Children are prevented from playing in the street and elderly people fear to cross it."
To help reduce pedestrian deaths, the Government enacted new laws this year aimed at careless and dangerous drivers and began a new advertising campaign around the slogan: "Kill your speed. Not a child." Safety experts say that if drivers reduce their speed by 10 miles an hour, the chances of a child surviving a pedestrian accident are greatly increased.
Part of the problem also involves the growing number of cars in older residential areas in London and other cities, where there is little off-street parking. Government analysts predict the congestion will only get worse.
 
Danger at the Intersections
 Andrew Howard, the head of road safety for the Automobile Association, said motorists tend to drive too fast in urban areas along streets lined with parked cars, where there is limited visibility.
"We always tell people not to cross between parked cars, but often there is no other choice," Mr. Howard said.
In addition, fewer police resources are devoted to dealing with traffic violations and traffic rules involving pedestrians are much more ambiguous in Britain than in the United States.
A common complaint is that cars turning into an intersection will seldom yield to pedestrians already in the roadway, even if they are crossing with the light. "The Highway Code of Conduct says that pedestrians have the right of way," Mr. Howard said. But in practice, he conceded, it usually doesn't work that way.
"The sad fact is that any pedestrians who insist on their rights while crossing a street soon tend not to have anything left at all to argue about," he said.

HEADLINE: Environmental Rules: How They Dictate Region's Agenda

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER

 BODY:
For decades they have been little more than fantasies: Automated people movers gliding swiftly between New York's airports, and electronic fare cards shepherding drivers effortlessly through the city's tolls.
Nice ideas, it has often been said, but hopeless. Yet, for an unlikely reason, the visions have recently come alive. They are now considered essential because rigorous new air quality standards demand them. 
 After years of indifference, the city has also embarked on a vast program to install water meters in hundreds of thousands of homes and apartment buildings. Again, the reason was indirect. Without them, punitive rationing measures would soon become inevitable. Almost by default, environmental regulations -- and the relentless advocates who use them most effectively -- have begun to dictate the physical shape and priorities of the region.
From the most ambitious bridges to the smallest playground, from airports and highways to shopping malls and boat slips, legal requirements and protests rather than planning now orchestrate nearly every decision a builder or government can make.
"We plan by not doing," said Robert J. Pirani, director of environmental projects for the Regional Plan Association. "The mechanism is all backward. Fear is the driving force. Instead of sitting around and saying what kind of place do we want to become, we are wondering what punishments we can avoid."
While laws with brutal sanctions provide handy ammunition for opponents of growth, so has the recession, which has dimmed the vision of many of the regions most ambitious developers.
 
Unfinished Projects
 The combined results are easy to see. From Westway, which never was built, to the contested Meadowbrook Parkway on Long Island, which was, projects have been delayed, scuttled, diminished. Often those that proceed -- like the huge Metrotech office and research complex in Brooklyn or the final stretch of Interstate 287 in northern New Jersey -- do so only after years of negotiation and a stream of concessions.
Except for Los Angeles, air quality does not get much worse than in the three states of the metropolitan region. Together, they have been violating the Clean Air Act for two decades. But a set of new sanctions that could ultimately force millions of drivers from their cars, has done more to promote mass transit -- and to discourage new highway construction -- than any politician possibly could.
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, for example, has retreated from any serious plans to erect another bridge between New Jersey and Staten Island, even though many of its planners say traffic patterns argue for it strongly. The recession has played a role, of course. But the Clean Air Act, which gives this region 15 years to resolve some of its most intractable pollution problems, has proven far more compelling.
The New York metropolitan region already has nearly twice the permissible amount of ozone in its atmosphere. The area stands to lose all highway funds if it does not begin to comply with Federal standards. In southern California, Federal officials have already begun to take away people's barbecue pits and gas-powered lawn movers. New York could face a similar fate.
In addition, beginning this year, Federal law dictates that all new sources of pollution have to be more than compensated for by reductions nearby.
The practical effects could be significant. For every major road that generates 1,000 new miles traveled by automobiles each day, for example, local officials must find a way to eliminate 1,200 miles traveled elsewhere. If they fail, the ratio will nearly double in the next decade.
"We are all beginning to realize that we are going to have to make profound and continual adjustments to what we build and how we live," said Anthony E. Shorris, deputy executive director of the Port Authority. " It isn't just a question of whether it would be nice to alter our behavior. The regulations make it financially impossible for us to do anything else. All the incentives have changed, probably for good."
Federal and local statutes are not the only deterrents. Skillful campaigns by those opposed to development have become routine, and routinely successful.
 
Battle Over Airport
 In Westchester, local officials have long envisioned an expanded county airport as a fitting anchor to development in the area. But with opponents bitterly insisting that bigger runways would bring intolerable levels of noise, water and air pollution -- in addition to unwelcome new traffic -- planners wonder if even their most modest goals may be impossible to attain.
For more than a decade, the Postal Service has been trying to build a $100 million processing center in Westchester, to serve an area that the Postmaster General last year called the worst in the nation for mail service. Yet, after seeing its environmental-impact study assessing the risks to the region, New York City sued, contending the center would pollute important reservoirs. A Federal judge blocked its construction earlier this year.
"If you build and you ignore the environmental consequences," said Michael Gerrard, an environmental law expert at the Manhattan law firm of Berle, Kass & Case, "you do so at your own peril. We are now living with the consequence of generations of thoughtless development. It's time we learned our lesson."
Mr. Gerrard has interceded dozens of times, usually with success, on behalf of clients who say a project presents unacceptable environmental risks. He currently represents three towns north of Hartford that challenged Connecticut in an attempt to prevent the creation of a nuclear waste site in Ellington -- although the state will soon be unable to ship such waste to South Carolina, as it has done for years.
"If it needs to be done," said Mr. Gerrard, voicing a sentiment shared widely by those who oppose such projects, "this is not the place to do it."
The days of autocratic development, embodied most blatantly by Robert Moses, who sliced up neighborhoods and carpeted New York with highways, won't be back, planners, developers and environmentalists all agree. And few would argue that they should return. But people are starting to worry about what has replaced them. Without a coherent vision of where to place the roads, sewage plants, bridges and other essentials that all communities need -- those who scream the loudest have turned into those who make the rules.
 
Permissions the Hard Part
 Seeking permission to widen a road or build an incinerator has become more difficult than the actual construction.
The Bronx Lebanon Hospital will be the first to use a new $20 million incinerator in an industrial section of the Bronx when it is completed next year. If local residents do not revolt. The incinerator was designed to handle medical waste, and it was placed where it would do the least harm to neighbors. Few complaints were heard until recently, as the project nears completion. Without it, New York will have to continue to export waste at great cost.
To some this sort of activism is a telling achievement of the environmental movement. Yet, to others it is a disturbing combination of idealism and inflexibility. Many of those who worked hardest to guarantee that tough regulations would serve as a solid check on thoughtless expansion or greedy builders have been surprised by the speed with which opponents of development become "environmentalists."
"Growth has to be driven by decent environmental protections and increasingly it has," said Thomas C. Jorling, commissioner of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation. "But we all hear the loud whine of people who use the environment to refuse to bear any responsibility for community well-being. I am just as scared by them as I am by polluters."
The balance between producing sensible public works and protecting the land has never been harder to puzzle out. Eventually, critics and even some environmentalists are starting to ask, where will we find all the places to put the glamorless necessities on which most of life relies?
"We need to respect the natural resources we have," said Ara K. Hovnanian, president of Hovnanian Enterprises in Red Bank, N.J., one of the nation's largest residential developers. "But if I only had a nickel for every person who opposes growth by calling themselves an environmentalist."
 
Real Concerns From Tirades
 Officials say they can have a hard time separating legitimate environmental complaints from standard no-growth tirades.
In Connecticut, for example, the relationship between a soaring rate of driving and dangerous levels of air pollution is easy to understand. Between 1970 and last year, Connecticut drivers increased the miles they traveled in automobiles by more than 63 percent, turning a once-quiet state into one of the most congested in the nation. Perhaps no highway in the state has become as impassable as Interstate 95.
Several proposals have been put forth to widen the highway at strategic points, but engineers from the state Department of Transportation have grown understandably wary because any such action will only increase their struggle over air pollution.
"All of the gains mandated by the Federal Clean Air Act would be wiped out in about six months by the increased traffic," said Donald Strait, legal director for the Connecticut Fund for the Environment. "How could you possibly do it?"

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Dinkins Lets His Bitterness Show

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins returned to New York City from South Africa last week buoyed and emboldened by the homecoming to the continent of his heritage, but also deeply embittered. He blamed the press for singling him out for unnecessarily negative coverage.
Mr. Dinkins typically speaks softly but sometimes seems to carry a big chip on his shoulder. Since his trip, he has pumped up the volume and more than once has given voice to deep resentment that he usually suffers in silence. 
 "The press has seemed not to understand the importance of the trip," Mr. Dinkins said last Tuesday. Yesterday, addressing congregants at the Rev. Herbert Daughtry's House of the Lord Pentecostal Church in Brooklyn, Mr. Dinkins elaborated, saying: "It was a bit of a shock for me -- and perhaps the Reverend Daughtry I think would agree with this assessment -- that the media attention we received on this trip had more to do with how many bodyguards surrounded me and how many guns they had and who in the Government I was scheduled to see, more things like that than the human tragedy that the apartheid regime has created."
Why did the media fail, he has wondered, to fathom either the potential economic benefits for the city or the profound personal experience that the journey represented for the Mayor? Why, in particular, had they been so much more accepting when his predecessors went overseas to tour their ancestral homes or to cultivate political roots in places other than Africa?
That question goes to the heart of Mr. Dinkins's litany. It suggests that he is being judged by a different standard. And to Mr. Dinkins, the major difference between himself and the nearly 100 New York City mayors who preceded him is his race.
"I try to be pretty careful before I call someone a racist or say someone's motivated by race, so with respect to why people criticize me for wanting to come to Africa, I don't know," the Mayor said on his final day there. "My answer always is, 'I don't know. You figure it out.' "
To Mr. Dinkins, the media are a daily irritant. Its representatives are also often the most visible manifestation of a society in which most social and economic power is still wielded by whites.
But the Mayor demonstrated that his mistrust, even antipathy, toward the press is by no means defined solely by race when he railed against Bob Herbert, a Daily News columnist, for once describing Mr. Dinkins as a "slick suit."
"There has been coverage of Dinkins that has been unfair, but there's coverage of all politicians that has been unfair," Mr. Herbert said. "He doesn't understand the adversarial relationship between the press and politicians."
Mr. Herbert also suggested a more fundamental conflict:
"I think Dinkins has a chip on his shoulder about race," said Mr. Herbert, who is black. "So do I. I think most black people have a chip on their shoulder about race. But it's one thing to have a chip on your shoulder and quite another to be a mayor of all the people of the City of New York."
The Mayor declined last week to be interviewed about press coverage. But his sentiments are no secret. They reflect his abiding belief that he is the victim of a double standard and that he and his administration are never given the benefit of the doubt.
"We never hear about the glass being half filled," said Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch. "In fact," he said, "if we found a cure for AIDS, I'd want someone else to announce it."
 
A Double Standard?
 Is there a double standard? Editors, reporters and columnists generally maintain that there is not; not one inspired by racism, anyway. Most say any differences are inspired by the vivid contrast in style between Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Koch; by Mr. Dinkins's misfortune in presiding during a recession, and by bruising competition among the tabloids.
"I am told by those who are close to him that he believes that the travails of his administration are based on two problems," said Jerry Nachman, editor of The New York Post. "One, horrendous timing, and I agree with him on that. And two, adverse coverage by a racist white press. I disagree with him on that. I think he only need look at coverage of Ed Koch's final term in which the press essentialy eviscerated him to know that what he's reading and watching are not unique to this mayoralty or to elected officials of color."
But one of Mr. Dinkins's political mentors, Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem, maintains that most black elected officials are treated differently.
"The example of the Mayor's disadvantage is classically displayed by the tremendous political and journalistic advantage that a totally incompetent politician named Andy Stein has," Mr. Rangel said, referring to the City Council President, who is expected to challenge Mr. Dinkins in 1993.
 
Waiting and More Waiting
 "Andy Stein shatters the myth of white supremacy forever," Mr. Rangel said. "But David Dinkins ain't no Andy Stein when it comes to influence. Stein was raised at the feet of power. Dinkins got to where he was by waiting tables, waiting in line, doing public service and by waking up to be the Mayor of the City of New York." .
"David is not considered by most whites to be the Mayor," Mr. Rangel said. "He's considered to be the black Mayor. Every black that I know would be an outsider in that position."
To whatever degree Mr. Dinkins figures he has been singled out for criticism because he is black, some people argue just the opposite: that he has been spared a more severe verdict for the very reason that critics and potential ones are sensitive to the political, social and personal implications of ganging up on the city's first black mayor.
To be sure, some of the criticism of Mr. Dinkins seems race-related. And the proud and proper Mayor, scarred by criticism and questions that pre-date his mayoralty, hardly feels that critics have been holding back.
He has complained that his administration receives sparse or begrudging credit for having balanced its budgets on time, for promulgating an ambitious public safety plan, for luring the Democratic national convention to New York and for intervening aggressively to defuse racial tension in Crown Heights, Brooklyn.
Instead, he has at his fingertips a litany of grievances on coverage, ranging from articles on personal finances to his penchant for tennis.
Then came the South Africa trip. Mr. Dinkins seemed unwilling or unable to understand why his initial failure to fulfill a mission that he had elevated to such emotional heights (the trip had to be postponed when fund-raising for it fell far short), questions about contributions from companies with city business and his insistence on traveling with a vast retinue might also constitute a metaphor for his administration. He berated more than one reporter about coverage. In complaining about coverage by The New York Times in particular, he said he held the paper to a higher standard than "the tabloids."
"We considered the details of the trip, like the number of people with him, a legitimate news interest and I don't think it implied a criticism," said Joseph Lelyveld, The Times's managing editor. "I don't see anything in our coverage that was unusual except the theme of the Mayor's sensitivity to the coverage of the trip.
"Any mayor with the fiscal problems this city faces would be getting just about the same coverage," Mr. Lelyveld said.
When some black mayors in other cities slumped, they rallied their political base by challenging the predominantly white-run media. Mr. Dinkins has generally not done so, by dint of personality and because he was elected as a healer.
Mr. Lynch, who is black, was more blunt. "When I have a race discussion," he said, "I never win."

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Not Will Cuomo Run; Will He Stop?

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:

Tonight, I quit these walls,
 The thought my soul appalls,
 But when stern Duty calls,
 I must obey. -- The Pirates of Penzance, Or, The Slave of Duty 
 FOR weeks now, people have been asking whether Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is running for President, when the real question is, will he withdraw?
Yesterday, he displayed no withdrawal symptoms.
In fact, Governor (Don't call me Mario) Cuomo is already a candidate by most conventional standards, if one is defined by his enemies, by his increasingly confident forays into national economics and foreign affairs and by his stubborn refusal so far to be railroaded into a formal announcement just to satisfy party leaders and potential primary opponents.
The Governor has hurdled every potential obstacle that he had erected in his head except for one: New York's projected budget gap, which has assumed such gigantic proportions that, as one financial analyst said, the deficit will make it either impossible or imperative for Mr. Cuomo to seek the Presidency.
For New Yorkers, he said yesterday in a television interview, that his candidacy "could be good or better or not good at all." He seemed inclined toward good or better.
Already, he has convinced himself that he would be as good or better than the six declared Democratic candidates, that money is no object, that his family's reservations would evaporate once he announced (this time, though, his mother is too ill to weigh in with her customary savvy advice) and that President Bush is surprisingly vulnerable.
Also, Mr. Cuomo has all but decided not to quit as Governor, a decision that makes him more dependent on the state of his state.
After meeting privately last week with members of the state Financial Control Board, the oversight group that he heads, the Governor seemed more persuaded that New York City will avert fiscal calamity this year and that, in any case, his intervention will not be viewed as indispensable to the city's solvency.
Today, Mr. Cuomo is to confer with legislative leaders after presenting his reduction plan for the state deficit. Their response could be pivotal to his political calculations.
Forecasts being drafted by his staff to assess whether the Republican-led State Senate will hold the budget hostage may provide fodder for Mr. Cuomo's introspection, although when he thinks aloud it is not always clear for whose benefit he is speaking.
Mr. Cuomo is not up for re-election next year; New York legislators are. Will Republican incumbents running in reapportioned districts worry that they'll go down with the Governor if they balk at a multiyear budget compromise or exact too heavy a price?
Could a Cuomo Presidential campaign actually prod Republicans into a compromise on the budget, when their recalcitrance and its impact on New Yorkers might be perceived as a cynical plot engineered by the White House? Would some fear offending a Governor, much less a potential President, with a reputation for being unforgiving?
Prospective bond buyers learned last week that the state deficit might double. What did Mr. Cuomo know and when did he know it? When did he first suspect that the deficit's dimensions would prompt his impossible-or-imperative choice of rationales?
If the Governor is, indeed, grappling with whether the gap will be a potential political weapon or a crippling liablity, can anybody give him a definitive answer within the next week or so? Probably not.
Meanwhile, he has frustrated only his Democratic rivals, political reporters and gag writers whose comparisons of the Governor to a latter-day Hamlet -- when his behavior more often invokes Machiavelli's advice to a different prince -- may have peaked before Mr. Cuomo's popularity does.
Once again, he and Hamlet have gotten a bum rap. The Governor isn't agonizing. He is sifting advice, assessing the budget stalemate, enjoying the attention, honing his skill at transforming defense into offense, as his virtuoso performance yesterday on ABC-TV's "This Week With David Brinkley" demonstrated, and biding his time. He is typically accused of being indecisive. Rather, he procrastinates, delaying decisions until he believes it is absolutely necessary to make them. In this case, that could be months from now, except that party leaders are beginning to persuade him that to delay much longer harms the Democratic cause. (Should he withdraw, though, don't be shocked if he is importuned again next spring if no other candidate catches fire.)
From Mr. Cuomo's bullying of callers to a radio program earlier this month -- reassuring them that crime is worse in Dallas -- to fencing with Vice President (Don't call me Danforth) Quayle, his campaign so far sometimes seems less like tragedy than operetta.
It recalls Gilbert and Sullivan's "Pirates of Penzance," in which young Frederic was mistakenly apprenticed to a pirate instead of a pilot. He dutifully serves until his 21st birthday and is about to flee when he is informed that he was born on Feb. 29, which means that he is not 21, but "a little boy of 5." Frederic finally can run away once the authorities invoke a higher being, which may also be how Mario Cuomo achieves his majority.
Is Mr. Cuomo running? "Not at this moment," he said yesterday.

HEADLINE: Yugoslavia Sanctions Can Only Do Harm

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Serbia's Spiteful War" (editorial, Nov. 6): I would like to offer my opinion as a writer who is American and Yugoslav, and has just returned from months in Yugoslavia. My interest is not to discuss who is right or wrong in this sad, murky civil war. 
 I am against economic sanctions of Serbia (or Croatia) because they hurt people who most need it -- the poor, the old, the very young. The population of Serbia is only about 65 percent Serbian, so you would also punish Albanians, Croats, Germans, Hungarians, gypsies. Sanctions would stop the healthy process of establishing a multiparty system and freedom of the press, despite the war. In Belgrade, newspapers attack each other and argue as much as the people do on the street and at home.
The sanctions would stop the growing middle class and businesses just starting. They would add to the feelings of rage and injustice many have: Serbia lost a million people in World War I and was bombed again in World War II. The bulk of the anti-Fascist partisan army was Serb, only a small fraction of it Communist.
This is a family feud in which much patience and forgiveness will be needed on both sides. There are three million children of mixed marriages, and the United States should not increase rage and separations. Help everyone equally, or 20 years from now, you'll have a new generation raging with memories of injustice.
If you want to help, stop the arms deliveries on both sides. Yugoslavia has become a dump for outmoded West European machinery you can't get parts for. Serbs and Croats are killing one another with dumdum bullets, which were outlawed after the Vietnam War. Doctors in Belgrade told me they had never seen such wounds: the bullet explodes inside the flesh, tearing it apart.
Weapons are not in short supply in Yugoslavia, and somebody out there must be making a profit. So why economic sanctions on Serbia? Why not sell Serbians, at very low prices, what they'll need: food, medicine, a way to rebuild?
 
NADJA TESICH
New York, Nov. 7, 1991
 
The writer is author of "Shadow Partisan," a novel about the Balkans.

HEADLINE: Coming Back;
Clear New York's Bloodstream

 BODY:
New York City's incomparably complex transport system ties together its scattered population and maintains its contacts with the outside world. Without the vast network of air, sea, land and subsurface transportation links, New York's offices would be empty and its world trade and tourism would wither.
New York has made great recent strides in revamping its subways and streets. But key elements of the transportation network are still deteriorating. For the city to climb back to economic health, it needs, as much as anything, to clear its circulatory system and invest in transportation. 
 Streets. The city's 18,000 miles of streets and highways require periodic reconstruction and repair of the mains, sewers, pipes and conduits that run below. The city has reconstructed many thoroughfares that were in deplorable condition, like Manhattan's Second and Sixth Avenues. But bridge repairs now will force the limiting of future street repairs to simple repaving.
Many of the city's five tunnels and 872 minor bridges are also seriously deteriorating. The city estimates that it needs $5.2 billion over 10 years, but only two-thirds of that now seems available. The shortfall can only be met by finding new funds or by neglecting all but primary thoroughfares.
Manhattan Bridges. Three of the four bridges over the East River are in dangerous condition, and all eight bridges over the Harlem River need major work. Estimated cost: $1.6 billion. One promising source of funds is tolls on all bridges leading to Manhattan.
Subways. The subways, once feared and filthy, may now be the brightest link. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has replaced and rehabilitated its entire fleet of 6,200 cars and improved its shops, using much of the $16 billion it raised in the 1980's. The system still needs to modernize tunnels, tracks, switches, elevated structures, and signaling and control systems. It also seeks to rebuild stations that are unsafe, connect the 63d Street tunnel to the main Queens lines and start a new fare collection system.
The system is seeking $10.6 billion from the state, Federal and city governments to cover some 60 percent of its capital needs in the next 10 years. Where the balance will come from is a serious question affecting the future of the city.
Airports. The city's airports are strangling in congestion even as they face increased competition from other airports. At Kennedy airport, passenger movement between terminals is primitive and vehicle circulation is deplorable. Newark lacks an internal rail system.
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey sensibly plans to spend $3 billion to improve passenger movement at both airports and $1.6 billion earmarked for transit systems to facilitate movement from central Manhattan to Kennedy airport.
Ocean Shipping. New York remains the largest port on the Atlantic coast, measured by value of goods shipped, but its lead is eroding. The Manhattan and Brooklyn piers are now almost totally useless because they lack storage areas for the big containers that dominate shipments.
Only the vision of the Port Authority in developing Ports Newark and Elizabeth, N.J., with ample storage, managed to save a share of containerized ocean freight. But competition remains severe. The Port Authority needs to keep the ports competitive and convenient and hold stevedoring costs in their present range.
New York, with as fine a natural harbor as can be found anywhere, continues to attract business because of the size of the vast population within 50 miles. No one who cares about the region can afford to take its ocean transport for granted. No one who cares about the return of the city to strength can tolerate skimping on transportation in general.

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Bushwhackers

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Foot-in-mouth disease has become so rampant in the Bush Administration that Mikhail Gorbachev is trying to think of ways to help his friend shore up the center in Washington.
The White House counsel, trying to give conservative coloration to a surrender on quotas, circulates a policy that the President has not even seen; and the new Attorney General, after the political trouncing of the old, is shown to be out to lunch. 
 The tottering chief of staff, having suggested that the President zap the banks by calling attention to usurious credit-card rates, says publicly it was a Bush ad-lib -- turning the President into a lightning rod for the chief of staff, a political first.
The groundhog of American prosperity comes out, looks around, and decides to go back into its hole, presaging a winter of discontent.
As a result, a less cocky President retreats to Camp David to consult the Great Catoctin Spirit about ways to bring a second wind to his heavy-breathing Presidency.
The Spirit said: (1) Throw John Sununu off the sled to satisfy pursuing wolves; (2) show interest in health care and crime to prove you are not fixated on foreign affairs; (3) blame the Democratic Congress for the droopy economy and attack "liberal carping" as the source of bushwhacking.
That advice is defensive, other-directed and un-Presidential. Here is a better way to avoid following Herbert Hoover and Jimmy Carter into one-term Presidencies:
1. Recognize the New Hampshire Republican primary as your spring battleground, the result of which will color the coverage of all pre-convention politics and affect poll ratings.
This means your early theme should be to save the country from defeatist isolationism (represented by Pat Buchanan) and populist-coated bigotry (represented by David Duke). If these dark forces take over your party, they will not be stopped by the weak Democrats; insist that "only George Bush" can save the country from the America-firsters of the right and the government-firsters of the left.
Have John Sununu declare "I shall go to New Hampshire." Assign him the task of running your campaign there, providing him not only a face-saving exit from Washington but making use of his undeniable New Hampshire organizational talents.
You will, of course, lose in New Hampshire, just as President Johnson was deemed the loser even after winning numerically. That's because New Hampshire Republicans have a free vote to register their discontent in March before returning to the fold in November; and the headline sought by so many in the media is "Buchanan-Duke Forces Stagger Bush."
The trick is to turn that primary tactical "defeat" into a campaign strategic asset. Here's how:
2. Boldly grab and widen the safe right-of-center. You're an authentic moderate; this means the left considers you mean-spirited and the far right condemns you as unprincipled, and both are partly correct, but it also means that your real self is neither the Willie Horton-basher nor the new tax seller-outer.
Your closest aides are afraid to tell you that you sound whiny playing Reagan and shrill posing as Truman. But the real you is where the votes are; your Democratic opponent will know that and compete there, but that won't be the real him, and swing voters will sense that.
The economy will either react to low interest rates and stimulating deficits and turn up soon or it won't; cut out the losing combination of fretting and jawboning. Instead, rally the people to your cause, which can be more than tough love at home, spasmodic assertiveness abroad.
First, take advantage of a beatable challenge: Fight for the soul of your party against the Wrong Right, whose members always despised you and now seek your ruin. You can beat them on everything but abortion, where they can out-anti you, but you're stuck with your minority position there; so present it to centrists as an example of principle over popularity.
Then use your convention to declare war on both selfish isolation and intrusive statism. Your '88 strategy won't fly in '92; Democrats are preparing for a repeat, so cross 'em up.
If you run as a phony rightie against a centrist-appearing lefty, you'll lose. If you run as an unabashed moderate against the extremes of right and left, you'll win.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Litton Profit Is Up by 5%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Nov. 25

 BODY:
Litton Industries said today that quarterly earnings rose 5 percent on an 11 percent increase in sales. Improved commercial results more than offset declines in the company's military business, Litton said.
In its fiscal first quarter, ended Oct. 31, Litton earned $41.5 million, or $2.02 a share, compared with $39.6 million, or $1.76 a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales rose to $1.36 billion from $1.23 billion. 
 Orion L. Hoch, Litton's chairman, said the company was pleased that its investments in its industrial automation and oilfield services businesses were paying off, even during the recession.
Litton shares closed up 87.5 cents today, to $87, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Caterpillar Sets Additional Layoffs

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: JOLIET, Ill., Nov. 25

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc. said it would temporarily lay off an additional 200 workers at its Joliet hydraulics plant because of a strike at two of the company's assembly plants. The Caterpillar hydraulics-fabrication unit laid off about 600 people last week because the company did not want to build up a surplus of parts that are assembled at Caterpillar plants closed by the strike. 
 "These layoffs are the result of the company's labor dispute with the United Auto Workers," said a Caterpillar spokesman, Don Weir. He said the workers would be eligible for unemployment compensation and supplemental unemployment benefits. Mr. Weir said it was unknown when the workers would be called back to work. The new layoff takes effect Dec. 2.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Precious Metals Post Losses After a Week of Big Gains

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Precious metal futures prices fell yesterday as news of weak auto sales prompted traders to take profits from last week's strong gains.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for delivery in December fell $1.30, to $368.30 an ounce, and December silver fell 6 cents, to $4.072 an ounce. Platinum for January delivery dropped $2.30, to $371.50 an ounce, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. 
 Some analysts said the metals were due for a downturn after six straight days of gains in the gold market and a week in which platinum's price rose more than $8 an ounce and silver's price climbed more than 10 cents.
The selloff may have been started by reports of weak United States auto sales during the mid-November period. Vehicle sales over all were down 18.6 percent, with Ford Motor reporting a drop of 33.6 percent and Honda's sales down 7.3 percent.
The auto figures carried two messages to metals traders: United States consumers are still not buying cars, and industrial demand for platinum, a crucial component of automobile catalytic converters, is not rebounding. The pollution-control devices account for about 40 percent of global platinum consumption.
Silver, another precious metal with industrial applications, also suffered from the implication of continued economic weakness. Gold was pulled lower by silver and platinum and by perceptions that inflation remains under control.
"It's all being underpinned by the fact that we have a recession and no real inflation," said James Steel, metals analyst with Refco Inc. in New York.
He said platinum futures were also under pressure from reports that a labor disturbance at an Anglo American Corporation mine in South Africa had been quelled.
Oil prices rose on the New York Mercantile Exchange, but refined petroleum product futures were mixed as traders awaited news from a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries that formally begins today.
Some of the buying in oil came after Iraq's oil minister, Osama A. R. al-Hiti, said his nation would continue to resist the terms of a United Nations plan to allow Iraqi crude sales to resume.
Crude oil for delivery in January rose 21 cents, to $21.42 a barrel; December home heating oil rose 0.41 cent, to 62.47 cents a gallon; December unleaded gasoline fell 0.30 cent, to 62.18 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Lower Overseas, Then Turns Mixed in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
After settling lower in foreign markets yesterday, the dollar turned mixed in United States trading as dealers concentrated on other currencies.
The dollar fell against the Japanese yen and rose against the German mark, but the trading focus was each of the other two currencies. 
 The Japanese yen moved higher following comments overnight by Yasushi Mieno, Bank of Japan governor, who said he preferred a stronger yen.
"The yen broke through key technical support levels, and the dollar came down sharply," said Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
The dollar rose, however, against the German mark. Analysts said Germany's Bundesbank entered the market to sell marks and buy the British pound, which was tumbling. The intervention was successful, and the pound began to strengthen again.
"The move was somewhat expected," Mr. Donney said. "There is an obligation on the part of central banks within the European Monetary System to come to the aid of other currencies to keep them supported."
The Bundesbank is considered a powerful force within the market, and the move had a deeper impact than similar moves by other European banks over the last few weeks.
Much of the day's action occurred overnight in Asian trading and in Europe. Trading became more subdued when activity shifted to domestic markets.
Traders in New York "really did nothing but lighten up on long mark positions," said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Mitsubishi Bank Ltd.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 1.12 yen, to a closing 128.53 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 127.75 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 127.90 yen, down from 129.40 yen on Friday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7995, from $1.7975 late Friday. In New York it cost $1.7945 to buy one pound, unchanged from Friday.
Against the German currency, the dollar rose in New York to 1.5885 marks, from 1.5835 late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.4125 Swiss francs, up from 1.4090; 5.4290 French francs, up from 5.4135; 1,201.75 Italian lire, up from 1,199.50, and 1.1383 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1390.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Push in Congress On Drug Prices

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
CONGRESSIONAL critics of pharmaceutical companies are again pressing them to slow the rapid rise in drug prices, which is running at 10.2 percent, or three times the general inflation rate.
The industry is divided on the issue. A few drug companies like Merck & Company and Pfizer Inc., which are rich in strong-selling products, favor moderating the increases to fend off criticism. But most do not seem to have changed their pricing policies, and no other drug maker has endorsed Merck's proposal to brake prices, with annual rises no greater than the Consumer Price Index. 
 Senator David Pryor, the Arkansas Democrat who initiated the 1990 law that requires drug makers to give rebates to state Medicaid programs, introduced a new proposal last week. The Pryor bill, co-sponsored by Senator William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine, would reduce a drug company's Federal tax credits for production in Puerto Rico if its prices rose faster than general inflation. The bill would also lean on the industry by opening an official study of Canada's drug price review board, which can restrain increases deemed excessive.
Urging the Senate to reject the Pryor bill, the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association called the measure "unwise and discriminatory" and said it would hinder economic growth in Puerto Rico. The association also contended that prescription drugs, regardless of price, actually held down health-care costs by averting expensive surgery and hospital stays.
The Pryor bill is still more threat than reality and is unlikely to be taken up until next year, Senate Finance Committee aides said. For one thing, the Puerto Rico tax credit is a politically charged issue that touches nerves on the statehood and independence questions and on overall Federal tax policy.
Lobbyists predicted that the industry would be able to defeat the Pryor proposal, unless the Bush Administration supported it as a deficit-reduction measure, as happened with Senator Pryor's 1990 bill. But Senator Dave Durenberger, a Minnesota Republican who is a member of the Finance Committee's health subcommittee, warned in a floor speech last week that if drug "prices continue to rise, Government regulation will not be far behind."
Senator Durenberger said he was not ready to support Senator Pryor's proposal, but the Pryor bill was endorsed by 40 advocacy groups. They included the American Association of Retired Persons, Consumers Union, A.F.L.-C.I.O. and a number of other labor organizations, and National Small Business United.
On a related front, the Senate Labor Committee is negotiating with drug industry representatives for a compromise version of a bill sponsored by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts. It would require drug price breaks for Government clinics operated by the Public Health Service and other agencies, using the 1990 Medicaid provision as a model.
The House Veterans Affairs Committee, meanwhile, has approved a bill to restore drug discounts for veterans hospitals, which some drug makers withdrew last year. Under the 1990 law, some companies would have been forced to give the state Medicaid programs the same price breaks they had given to the veterans hospitals.
Losing the discounts would raise the veterans hospitals' budgets at least $45 million this year, said Stephen W. Schondelmeyer, a professor of pharmaceutical economics at the University of Minnesota who is a consultant to several Congressional committees. Over the five years of the 1990 law, he added, the price increases may cut $250 million to $300 million from the $3 billion in projected savings on Medicaid drug prices.
In an amendment to the Veterans Affairs Committee appropriation, which the President has signed into law, Congress urged the Secretary of Veterans Affairs to try to get the discounts restored, and it removed the veterans hospitals' drug prices from the Medicaid computation.
Representative Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, has introduced in the House the Kennedy bill on drugs for Federal clinics, but he said in an interview that it was time to try another tack. He suggested creating "a big pool of drug buyers," which would jointly represent the veterans hospitals, public health clinics and Medicaid. He said the purchasing pool could wield "Government clout and do some hard-nosed negotiating with people like the drug companies." Mr. Wyden's idea has already attracted some support. A staff member of the Senate Committee on Aging, which is headed by Senator Pryor, said that Senators Kennedy and Pryor, Mr. Wyden and Representative G. V. Montgomery, the Mississippi Democrat who heads the Veterans Affairs Committee's Subcommittee on Health, would work together next year on "a comprehensive solution" to try to help all Federal and private drug purchasers. "The pressure is on the drug makers," the committee aide said. "They can't expect to be left out of the debate over health-care price containment."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Tenneco Sets $632 Million Sale to Enron

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Tenneco Inc. said today that it had agreed to sell its natural-gas liquids operations and some related assets to the Enron Corporation for $632 million.
Natural-gas liquids, which include ethane, butanes and propane, are derived from the processing of natural gas. They have been the only buoyant sector of an otherwise depressed natural-gas industry during the last two years, as both demand and prices have risen. 
 Many petrochemical and chemical producers have substituted natural-gas fuels for crude oil as a primary raw material, as natural-gas fuels proved more economical. The market expanded, too, as large chemical plants opened in Texas, along the Gulf of Mexico, this year.
 
Part of Tenneco's Revamping
 The deal with Enron marked a significant step in a fast-moving corporate revamping begun in September by Tenneco's new president, Michael H. Walsh, to raise more than $500 million in cash by the end of the year. Write-offs at the diversified company, mainly at the J. I. Case farm- and construction-equipment unit, could exceed $1 billion this year.
The selling price was higher than many analysts, as well as the company, had anticipated. As a consequence, shares of Tenneco, based in Houston, rose $1.875 each, to $34.75, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange today. Shares of Enron, also based in Houston, fell 25 cents, to $71, in Big Board trading.
The sale to Enron includes a plant under construction in La Porte, Tex., that will produce at least 15,300 barrels a day of a component for cleaner-burning gasoline, called methyl tertiary butyl ether, or MTBE.
Contracts ranging between three and five years have already been signed for about 75 percent of the MTBE output, said Kenneth L. Lay, chief executive of Enron. Refiners could face a shortage of the component after tougher Federal anti-pollution laws take effect next year. Industry analysts estimate that demand for MTBE could surge to 400,000 barrels a day by 1995.
Enron was formed in 1985 in the merger of two big pipeline companies, the Internorth Corporation of Omaha and the Houston Natural Gas Company. It is the nation's largest diversified natural-gas company and the fifth-largest processor. But it has raised output this year and could rise to the No. 3 ranking among processors, said Diane Bazelides, an Enron spokeswoman.
 
A Captive Market
 In effect, Enron will have a captive market for 15,000 barrels a day of butane required at the new MTBE plant. Enron's current butane output is about 11,000 barrels a day, Ms. Bazelides said. The plant will also use large volumes of methanol produced by Enron, she said.
The company said it would finance the transaction by selling most of the assets, after they are acquired from Tenneco, to a syndicate of banks headed by Citicorp for $550 million. The balance of about $80 million will be financed directly from Enron's cash reserves. Enron has agreed to long-term leases covering most of the Tenneco properties being acquired by the Citicorp-led syndicate. Most of the properties are near the Houston Ship Channel.
Enron said it would pay $523 million in cash at the closing, set for Dec. 31, and would assume an estimated $102 million in costs related to completion of the MTBE plant, plus another $7 million in debt.
Mr. Lay said the deal should increase Enron's net income slightly in 1992, and by about $40 million in 1993, the first full year of operation for the MTBE plant.

HEADLINE: O.E.C.D. Forecasts Slow U.S. Recovery From Recession

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 25

 BODY:
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today that the United States economy would recover far more slowly from its recent recession than it has from most other recessions of the last three decades.
The Paris-based organization predicted that the economy would grow by 1.4 percent in the second half of this year and by 2.5 percent next year, which compares with an average growth of 6 percent in the four quarters immediately after the last seven recessions. 
 In its annual report on the American economy, the organization said the expansion phase of the cycle is expected to be muted compared with those of typical recoveries.
The report said a shallow recession was likely to be followed by a weak recovery because not much spending was forgone in the downturn to fuel the upturn.
The organization, comprising 24 industrial nations, projected that by the end of 1993 the United States unemployment rate would fall to 5.75 percent (it was 6.8 percent in October) and the inflation rate would drop to 2.9 percent (from the 3.9 percent predicted for this year).
The organization said United States exports would continue to expand, but more slowly than in recent years. It forecast that exports of goods and services would grow by 4.7 percent this year and 7.1 percent next year, compared with double-digit jumps in 1988 and 1989.
The increases in exports will help stabilize the United States' current-account deficit at about $60 billion, the organization forecast, compared with annual deficits of more than $100 billion from 1985 through 1989.
It said the major components of private-sector demand were expected to rebound, but it added that the excessive supply of commercial real estate from the late 1980's would dampen activity in this sector for some years.
The organization praised the Bush Administration's banking proposals, which call for allowing unrestricted interstate branch banking and common ownership of commercial banks and investment banks. The report said the proposed changes would increase the efficiency of the financial sector as a whole by increasing competition, and should pose little risk to the stability of the financial system.
 
Stance on Deposit Insurance
 The organization questioned proposals to limit deposit insurance coverage, saying depositors might not be able to impose effective discipline on bankers. But proposals to increase capital requirements for banks were praised as a possible aid in restoring market discipline by insuring that the owners of a bank have a large stake in its financial health.
Discussing energy efficiency, the report noted that energy prices were far lower in the United States than in most other industrial countries and that the United States consumed far more energy per capita than most other nations. Gasoline in the United States sells for less than one-third the price in France, Italy and the Netherlands, largely because of those countries' high energy taxes, which seek to encourage conservation.
Raising energy taxes would be consistent with both environmental goals and enhanced energy security, the report said.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Unilever Shares Termed a Value

BYLINE: By Steven Prokesch

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
AFTER Unilever reported unexpectedly strong quarterly earnings this month, the price of the British-Dutch giant's stock surged. Although its shares and American depository receipts are trading near their high for the year, many analysts view them as undervalued compared with other consumer products companies.
With the shares trading at 11 or 12 times expected 1992 earnings, several analysts recommend buying them now. Even more see them as a good long-term investment. 
 Of the two types of A.D.R.'s trading on the New York Stock Exchange, analysts suggest buying those for the Dutch shares, which have been trading at a discount of 6 to 7 percent to the A.D.R.'s for the British stock.
One reason may be the historical relationship of the dollar to the Dutch guilder and the British pound -- a justification that analysts say should fade in coming years because the values of both the pound and the guilder are now tied in the European Monetary System. Also, A.D.R.'s for the Dutch shares are much more actively traded and therefore may have been more depressed by investor worries about the anemic American economy and swings in the value of the dollar.
A.D.R.'s for Unilever N.V. Dutch shares, closed yesterday at $94, up 25 cents, only slightly below the $95.25 reached last week. The A.D.R.'s for British Unilever P.L.C. shares, whose 52-week high is $60.25, closed at $60.375, up 37.5 cents. The A.D.R.'s have to be compared with the shares of the underlying companies, and not with each other.
"We like the long-term strategic direction and evolution of the company and think the discount it endures against other companies in the food arena is excessive," said Les Pugh, an analyst at Salomon Brothers International Ltd. For the short term, he recommends buying the Dutch shares and A.D.R.'s and holding the British shares and A.D.R.'s.
Analysts say that even if the American economic recovery stalls and the one believed to be starting in Britain is not robust, Unilever's profits should not deteriorate. On the other hand, they add, Unilever's progress in cutting costs and introducing new products should enable its food, detergent and personal-products businesses to benefit handsomely once those two markets recover. Products that are new or being expanded into new markets include Lever 2000 skin-care soap, Wisk Power Scoop powder laundry detergent and Elizabeth Taylor's White Diamonds and Calvin Klein's Escape fragrances.
"We think there are surprises on the upside in Unilever's profitability," said Tim Potter, an analyst at Smith New Court Securities Ltd. "Unilever has disposed of underperforming assets and made strategic acquisitions in higher-margin areas, principally personal-care products." The acquisitions included Chesebrough- Pond's, Elizabeth Arden, Faberge and Calvin Klein Cosmetics.
In the third quarter, Unilever's net profit rose 12 percent denominated in pounds, 11 percent in guilders and 2 percent in dollars. Analysts were especially impressed by the performance in North America, where Unilever benefited from lower extraordinary charges and cost cuts at its Lipton food unit.
"What we have seen is margins are recovering on the back of restructuring benefits," said Sylvain Massot, an analyst at Morgan Stanley International Ltd. Operating profit margins in North America rose to 8.8 percent, from 6.1 percent a year earlier. Mr. Massot says he believes Lipton has been increasing its share of the American market for margarines, oils and teas.
Some analysts also expect profits of the American detergent business to improve. "Clorox has dropped out of the business, and Colgate doesn't seem to be competing as much on price," Mr. Potter said. "Over the long run, that should mean it will be a slightly more profitable business for the industry leaders: Procter & Gamble and Unilever's Lever Brothers division."
Edouard de Boisgelin, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, foresees a profit surge from personal products once consumer spending picks up in big markets like the United States and Britain. "What they acquired was high quality," he said.
Analysts say Unilever's worldwide unit sales volume will grow by 2 percent this year and by 2 to 4 percent in 1992. They also expect more cost-cutting -- especially in Europe, which accounts for more than 60 percent of sales and operating profits.
Analysts expect Unilever to reduce its annual costs in Europe within four years by $300 million to $450 million as it achieves the economies of scale being made possible by the single market that the European Community is creating. Unilever is centralizing big portions of its manufacturing and distribution operations, especially for detergents and personal care products.
