HEADLINE: U.S. Sales Of Vehicles Drop 18.6%

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks declined 18.6 percent in mid-November, the auto makers reported today. Analysts said the figures provided further evidence that the auto industry was in a second recession after slightly recovering from its slump earlier this year.
"It strongly suggests that a double-dip recession is taking hold," said Jack V. Kirnan, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody in New York. He said the industry was unlikely to muster a recovery until the second quarter of next year at the earliest. He also asserted that the Big Three American auto makers would probably have to pare down their optimistic production schedules for early 1992. 
 Recent sales reports have dashed industry hopes that were lifted in late summer by improving sales. The gains were later attributed to purchases by rental-car companies and other fleet customers.
 
Reluctant Lenders
 Several dealers and analysts said consumers' shaken confidence over the security of their jobs continued to hurt sales. Dealers also said that banks were more reluctant to write loans for customers than they were a year ago. "The banks are being very, very selective," said Ike Reinis, general sales manager of Balzekas Motor Sales in Chicago, which sells Chryslers and Plymouths.
Gordon Corey, general sales manager of Sam Galloway Ford in Fort Myers, Fla., figures he is losing about 5 percent of his sales because customers who would once have been creditworthy are being rejected by banks. Mr. Corey's sales have also been hurt by lower interest rates, which have cut the investment income of many older customers to the point where they are holding back from buying cars. "I'm just not seeing the retirees that I used to see," he said.
 
Car Sales Off 19.6%
 Some dealers noted that while showroom traffic was down, the shoppers they were seeing were committed to buying, largely because they had to replace high-mileage older cars. "The market is definitely need-driven," said Mark Herrmann, owner of Mark Buick in Yonkers. "Sometimes cars are in need of extensive repair."
Car sales fell 19.6 percent, to 159,461, between Nov. 11 and Nov. 20. There were nine selling days in the period, compared with eight in the period a year earlier. On a seasonally adjusted basis, cars made in North America, which are considered domestic models, sold at an annual rate of 5.9 million in mid-November. That compares with 7.1 million in the period of 1990. Sales of light trucks, which include pickups, dropped 17.1 percent, to 101,507.
The Big Three posted a collective decline of 21.8 percent in car sales in mid-November, while the Japanese companies that build cars in North America reported an overall drop of 7.8 percent. These "transplant" manufacturers raised their share of the American car market to 17.6 percent in mid-November, from 15.3 percent a year earlier. The Big Three's share of the market for domestically built cars declined to 82.4 percent, from 84.7 percent a year earlier.
Of the Big Three, the General Motors Corporation's car sales dropped 10.1 percent, adjusted to reflect the different number of selling days in the two periods, to 78,442. Its light-truck sales dropped 22.8 percent, to 38,341 units. G.M.'s best-performing car division in the period was Buick; its sales declined only 1 percent, largely because of the strong sales of its redesigned LeSabre model.
The Ford Motor Company reported a drop of 33.6 percent in car sales, to 36,901, and a 13.2 percent decline in light-truck sales, to 36,746.
The Chrysler Corporation's car sales dropped 36.2 percent, to 16,050, based on estimates by Ward's Automotive Reports, a trade publication. Chrysler's truck sales were estimated to have declined 15.4 percent, to 21,750. Chrysler reports its sales monthly.
The Honda Motor Company sold 11,747 American-built cars, a drop of 7.3 percent. The Toyota Motor Corporation reported a sales drop of 15.7 percent in the period, to 8,555 cars.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Banks Give the Maxwells Breathing Room on Debts

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Kevin and Ian Maxwell got some breathing room today, as officials from about 25 banks gave them at least 10 days to work out a plan for defusing the debt crisis threatening the global publishing empire their family controls.
Both sides described as constructive the tone of the meeting between the Maxwells and the bankers. And the bankers agreed to set up a steering committee of at least five banks to consider proposals made today by the brothers for dealing with the crucial issue: inadequately secured loans to the family's private companies. In a statement issued tonight, the Maxwells said the steering committee would report back within 10 days. 
 "We have had a meeting which was constructive, frank but in no way acrimonious," said a spokesman for National Westminster Bank. "The banks are actively exploring the way forward." The big British bank, which has one of the largest exposures to the Maxwell empire, will head the steering committee, whose other members are believed to include Midland Bank and Lloyds Bank in Britain, the Swiss branch of France's Banque Paribas and Sumitomo Bank of Japan.
 
Reprieve From Swiss Bank Corp.
 The Swiss Bank Corporation, which had been demanding that its 55 million ($99 million) loan be repaid or that it be provided with adequate collateral, said today that it would take no immediate action. The bank had threatened to push one of the Maxwell family's private companies into receivership if its demands were not met. If that happened, it could set off events that might cause the Maxwell empire to collapse.
Kevin Maxwell described the tone of the meeting as "extremely constructive, very helpful and frank." He and his brother assumed the helm of the family's collection of private and public companies after the death of their father, Robert Maxwell, on Nov. 5.
When asked in an interview whether there was a deadline for a plan, an adviser to the Maxwells who requested anonymity said it would take "weeks, but not very many."
 
Bond Proposal
 One of apparently several proposals made by the Maxwells to reduce bank debt was to issue a bond that could be converted into shares of the family's 51 percent owned Mirror Group Newspapers Ltd. if bondholders were not repaid on time.
There was no indication that the sale of The Daily News in New York was actively under consideration at the moment, bankers said.
Shortly after their father died, the Maxwell brothers said they would not sell The Daily News or The European, a pan-Europe weekly newspaper introduced last spring. But in recent days, Kevin Maxwell has said, "There are no sacred cows."
 
Notion of Auction Played Down
 There have been rumors that another proposal was to auction off the Maxwell Communication Corporation, whose operations are mainly in the United States. They include Macmillan publishing, Official Airline Guides and Collier's encyclopedias. But the Maxwell adviser seemed to play down both that possibility and the notion that they might sell some of Maxwell Communication's major businesses.
Maxwell Communication is itself heavily indebted, with a net debt -- or debts minus cash on hand -- of about 1.4 billion, or $2.51 billion. So, presumably, its lenders would be reluctant to allow its assets to be sold to reduce the debts of the Maxwell family's private companies.
The Maxwells said today that they had appointed N. M. Rothschild & Sons Ltd., the London-based investment bank, to work with the existing financial adviser to their private companies, the Bankers Trust New York Corporation.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Shift at I.B.M. Alters Succession Outlook

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
In what is expected to be the first step in a far-reaching shake-up at I.B.M., an executive widely viewed as a potential successor to the chairman, John F. Akers, yesterday was handed what many industry executives called a demotion.
George H. Conrades, senior vice president of I.B.M.'s struggling United States business, was named to what is considered a lower-ranking position, senior vice president for corporate marketing and services. 
 In his new position, Mr. Conrades will report to another senior vice president, C. Michael Armstrong. Until yesterday, the two men had been the most frequently mentioned candidates for the chairmanship of the International Business Machines Corporation, the world's largest computer maker.
Mr. Armstrong, who is 53 years old, now appears to have the inside track to succeed Mr. Akers, who is 56 and is scheduled to retire as chairman when he reaches 60. The only other I.B.M. executive ranked higher than senior vice president, Jack D. Kuehler, the president, is expected to retire before Mr. Akers.
Mr. Armstrong is a member of the management committee -- the five-man inner circle at I.B.M. -- and is chairman of I.B.M. World Trade, the subsidiary responsible for I.B.M.'s substantial foreign business. His office is down the hall from Mr. Akers's at the company's Armonk, N.Y., headquarters. Mr. Armstrong was a protege of another top I.B.M. executive, Kaspar V. Cassani, I.B.M.'s retired vice chairman.
I.B.M. is expected to make a broad set of changes next week that may include offering more financial autonomy to some of its divisions and trimming more employees from its payroll, particularly at the domestic field-sales level. Although the company has a no-layoff policy, it has become increasingly insistent that some of its employees depart.
Mr. Conrades, who joined the company in 1961, will continue as a member of I.B.M.'s corporate management board, according to a company announcement, but several industry executives said they were not certain that the 52-year-old manager would stay with the company.
An I.B.M. spokesman, Rob Wilson, described yesterday's management change as a routine rotation of executives. In his new job, Mr. Conrades will develop and manage strategic corporate and international marketing issues, the company said. Mr. Conrades was not available for comment on his new role.
Robert J. LaBant, who has risen to prominence based on the success of I.B.M.'s AS/400 line of minicomputers, will take Mr. Conrades's old position as senior vice president and general manager for I.B.M. United States, reporting to a senior vice president, Terry R. Lautenbach.
Mr. LaBant, who is 46, will be replaced by John M. Thompson, who has been named vice president and general manager for the application business systems line, reporting to Mr. Kuehler. Mr. Thompson, who continues as chairman of I.B.M. Canada, was a vice president for corporate marketing and services.
 
Reward for a Rising Star
 Mr. LaBant was praised yesterday by people who follow I.B.M. for his role in helping the company in a difficult economic climate. He is said to be a rising star who is being rewarded for his performance.
"The key to the whole thing is that he did a good job with the AS/400," said Sam Albert, a consultant and a former I.B.M. executive. "They've taken a very successful guy and they put him in the key marketing job. He's a seasoned performer."
Not every analyst agreed with the assessment that Mr. Conrades's fate was sealed in yesterday's shift.
"It's too early to call," said Rick Martin, an industry analyst at Prudential Securities Inc. "The corporate marketing position has always been one of the most powerful of the staff jobs. It's not a clear indicator that he's in the penalty box."
However, some people in the computer industry who follow I.B.M. suggested that Mr. Conrades was one of the first victims of the company's search for accountability for poor performance in recent years.
"Anybody inside I.B.M. recognizes that Conrades was basically publicly shot," said an industry executive who insisted on not being identified.
Others suggested that Mr. Conrades was paying the price for not having been in Mr. Akers's favor for some time.
"From a business standpoint, it's grossly unfair considering that 1990 was the first year in the recent past the U.S. has shown growth," said Robert Djurdjevic, an industry consultant who is president of Annex Research in Phoenix. "Conrades's efforts had finally started to produce results."
In a widely reported internal memo based on remarks that Mr. Akers made to a management class that was given to a number of newspapers this May, the chairman was reported to have called the performance of the company's United States business unsatisfactory. He was reported to have said that although the company had transferred 5,000 people into sales positions, there had been no evidence of financial return.
"Where's the beef? What the hell are you doing for 'me'?" the memorandum reportedly quoted Mr. Akers as saying.
Mr. Djurdjevic said he thought Mr. Akers's remarks had been directed at Mr. Conrades.

HEADLINE: Stocks Slip, With Dow Off 0.67, to 2,902.06

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks closed narrowly lower yesterday in choppy trading, as many investors moved to the sidelines. The Dow Jones industrial average was off 0.67 points, to end at 2,902.06.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was fairly heavy, at 175.9 million shares, down from 188.3 million on Friday. Losing issues outpaced gainers by 1,057 to 629. 
 Blue-chip stocks recovered somewhat from earlier losses, but many investors stayed away amid lack of confidence in the economy and the stock market. Even a 1 percent gain in the October sales of existing homes, after a 4 percent decline in September, was no spur to buy.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks slipped 0.80, to 375.34, as the Big Board composite lost 0.59, to 207.57. Moderate trading lowered the American Stock Exchange composite by 2.24, to 371.04.
Trading on the Nasdaq pulled the composite down 3.58, to 522.88, as the Russell 2,000 lost 1.25, to 176.12.
Blue-chip issues and the broader market were under pressure throughout the day, with the Dow a little stronger than the broad market. Some traders noted that equity mutual funds, which have posted gains all year, are beginning to increase selling.
John C. Brooks, a technical analyst for Davis, Mendel & Regenstein in Atlanta, noted that there was a moderate amount of program trading yesterday. "The real story, however, was in the advance-decline line, where we again had over 1,000 declines," he said. "I think the market is facing some problems."
Mr. Brooks said he thought it was a bit late in the year for professional traders to risk coming in and buying for a year-end rally. He saw them as more interested in retaining their current yields. "The 2,850 level is a more logical point were buyers would come in," he said.
Ford Motor reported mid-November car sales down 33.6 percent, and its stock fell 3/8, to 24 1/4.
The share price for Information Resources, which provides analytical information on consumer purchases, rose 2 1/8, to 22 3/8, after the company said it was buying back a stock purchase warrant from a unit of Citicorp and expanding its Infoscan business.
Continental Airlines Holdings, whose stock was halted on Friday at 1 1/8 a share on the Amex, said over the weekend that it planned to come out of bankruptcy by giving its employees and unsecured creditors a stake in the airline company. Its stock fell 1/2, to 5/8.
Kerr Glass Manufacturing said it had agreed to sell its commercial glass-container business unit to Ball for about $161 million, resulting in an after-tax loss of about $2 million. The deal is subject to approval by Kerr's board. Kerr stock was off 3/4, to 7 3/8, while Ball fell 1, to 31 7/8.

HEADLINE: Tax-Break Extension Now Seen as Probable

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Moving quickly and without dissent, tax-writing committees of the House and Senate voted this afternoon to extend a dozen expiring business and individual tax breaks for six months.
Unless some lawmaker mounts unexpected, last-minute opposition, the measures, which are identical and had been languishing for months, should clear Congress promptly and move to the White House before Thanksgiving, Congressional officials said. Although President Bush has not formally backed all of the items, he has endorsed many of them, they said, which should assure his signature. 
 The incentives, all of which are due to expire by the end of the year, would cost nearly $3.2 billion to extend. That cost would be offset by speeding the collection of taxes on large corporations.
 
'Welcome News for the Economy'
 The most significant items, as measured by their cost over five years, are credits ranging from 30 percent to 70 percent for investors in new or substantially rehabilitated rental housing for the poor, and a 20 percent credit for qualified spending on research and experimentation.
"These actions are very welcome news for the economy," said Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, who is a member of the Finance Committee. "The provisions serve important national needs and create jobs and economic activity," he said.
But Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Chicago Democrat who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, warned in convening a 70-minute session of his panel that this would be the last temporary extension for the measures.
 
A Plan for Case-by-Case Review
 Mr. Rostenkowski said that he would hold hearings on each item early in 1992 and that separate votes would then determine whether each was incorporated permanently into the tax law or abandoned.
The sudden revival of the legislation, which had appeared all but doomed last week, was at least partly spurred by the rapidly accumulating evidence of a fading economic recovery.
The 12 so-called extenders are generally supported by both parties but had been bottled up until now for fear that any tax measure would become a vehicle for other tax proposals, like a cut in the tax on capital gains. Mr. Rostenkowski pointed repeatedly to the risks of sending a bill to the Senate, where it is particularly difficult to control amendments.
He also insisted on rigid adherence to the principle that any revenue-losing measure be accompanied by a plan to raise money elsewhere in the budget.
 
5-Year Cost: $3.18 Billion
 The House and Senate's Joint Tax Committee estimates that if all the elements remain in effect for five years, the costs will be $3.18 billion and the revenue $3.20 billion. The Treasury would gain $405 million in the current fiscal year and $170 million in 1995 but lose money in the other three years.
The 10 tax breaks besides those for low-income housing and research and experimentation, ranked by their five-year costs, involve: foreign allocation of research expenses; exemption for locally issued mortgage bonds for housing; deduction for interest on bonds to finance small manufacturers; exclusion from taxable income for employer-provided educational assistance; credit for hiring people in nine targeted groups of the poor or disabled; deduction of 25 percent of the health insurance premiums of the self-employed; exclusion from income for employer-provided group legal services; credits for business use of solar and geothermal energy; a minimum deduction for the appreciated value of charitable gifts of tangible property like artwork, and a credit for developing so-called orphan drugs for rare diseases.
All would be extended until June 30, 1992, except for the foreign research-allocation provision, which expired on Aug. 1 and would run six months from then, to March 1.
The new revenue would come from requiring that corporations with taxable income of $1 million or more for any of the three preceding years raise their estimated tax payments to 95 percent of current-year liability by 1995. The current level of 90 percent would rise in the interim to 93 percent in 1992 and 94 percent in 1993 and 1994. Companies would retain the option, however, to pay on the basis of 100 percent of the preceding year's liability.

HEADLINE: Bush Threatens to Veto Crime Bill, Saying It's Too Soft on Defendants

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25

 BODY:
President Bush vowed today to veto an anti-crime package that would extend the death penalty to many drug-related crimes and impose a waiting period on the sale of handguns, arguing that the legislation was not tough enough on criminals.
The veto threat came only hours before the House of Representatives was scheduled to vote on the bill, a compromise between competing House and Senate versions that was approved Sunday evening along partisan lines, the Democrats in favor and the Republicans opposed. 
 But Mr. Bush's action, combined with intense pressure from the gun lobby and groups opposed to the death penalty, forced a delay on the vote until at least Tuesday because Democratic leaders feared they might not have enough votes to pass the bill tonight.
 
Hopes for Tougher Rules
 Democrats accused the President of trying to thwart the strongest anti-crime bill to advance through the Congress in the last decade, and they said that the threatened veto would set the stage for crime as a major issue in the 1992 campaign.
Although the bill included a number of tough measures he had sought, Mr. Bush had hoped the legislation would include tighter restrictions on habeas corpus appeals, the hearings in Federal courts in which prisoners raise constitutional challenges to their sentences or convictions in lower courts, particularly for death-row inmates facing execution. Mr. Bush had also favored a provision in an earlier version that had allowed some evidence gathered without a search warrant to be introduced in trials.
But over the heated objections of Republican negotiators, a House-Senate conference committee approved the bill in Sunday night in a form that granted criminal defendants more rights than Republicans wanted.
"I would have to veto this bill because it would weaken our criminal justice system," Mr. Bush said in a brief aside in an address in Columbus, Ohio.
Later in the day he told reporters that he had just met with a group of police officers who "want to see a bill that supports the law enforcement officers, not one that gets watered down at the last minute and goes against what I've been standing for."
By pledging a veto, he put himself in the potentially uncomfortable position of having to explain how he could strike down an expansion of the death penalty to 52 Federal crimes, a provision he has long supported and one that is considered popular among voters. The death penalty is now allowed for only two Federal crimes: airline hijacking that results in death and certain drug-related murders.
 
Influenced by Gun Lobby?
 Democrats were quick to charge that Mr. Bush and the Republicans were unduly influenced by the gun lobby, which strongly opposes the Brady bill, a provision in the legislation that would require a five-day waiting period on the purchase of handguns. The provision is named for James S. Brady, the aide to President Ronald Reagan who was gravely injured in the 1981 assassination attempt on Mr. Reagan.
"Now he can whisper to the National Rifle Association, 'I did your bidding,' " Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who sponsored the legislation, said at a news conference called after the President announced his intentions. "It's going to be awfully hard for the President to convince the American people he is being tough. The veto will hurt him as much as the unemployment compensation vetoes, but he doesn't know it yet."
Mr. Reagan strongly endorsed the Brady bill last March, saying, "It's just plain common sense that there be a waiting period to allow local law-enforcement officials to conduct background checks on those who wish to purchase handguns." Mr. Bush said he would support the Brady measure, but only if it were part of a larger anti-crime bill that broadened the rights of the police to investigate crimes and limited defendant appeals.
The anti-crime legislation would provide more than $3 billion in Federal aid to an array of law-enforcement programs, including drug testing and treatment in local prisons, creation of neighborhood policing programs, and modernization of police equipment and training. It would also establish scholarship programs for college students willing to undergo some police training and then join a police auxiliary force after graduation.
Reinforcing the recent Supreme Court decision in McKlesky v. Zant that narrowed the circumstances under which defendants can appeal their convictions or sentences in Federal court, the bill sets a one-year deadline on habeas corpus appeals.
The bill has attracted much opposition from the gun lobby and local prosecutors, who want to do away with most habeas corpus appeals that can delay executions for years. But gun-control groups have strongly backed the legislation, even though provisions to ban the manufacture and sale of many assault rifles were defeated in the House.
Michael Beard, a lobbyist for the Coalition to Stop Gun Violence, sharply criticized the President's decision, saying, "The only people this veto will help are criminals and gun runners."
 
Bill a 'Retrenchment'
 Mr. Bush's announcement, however, was received enthusiastically by many Congressional Republicans. "His decision to veto is a wise decision because this is not a strong crime bill," said Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, the ranking Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee.
Representative Henry J. Hyde, the Illinois Republican who is a ranking member of the House Judiciary Committee, said: "This is supposed to be a tough bill. It is a retrenchment. It is a stepping back." He called the conference committee that worked out the final language in the bill "a kangaroo court."
Republicans in the Senate, hoping to kill the bill this session by preventing a Senate vote before the holiday recess begins later this week, have threatened to filibuster when the bill moves to the Senate after House action.
In a letter to Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House minority leader, Mr. Bush explained that he could not support the conference bill because it violated Administration goals to "end frivolous post-appeal challenges brought by convicted criminals."
He objected to the conference committee's rejection of his appeal to allow for an exception to the "exclusionary rule" forbidding evidence derived from police searches without a warrant in cases where officers acted in "good faith," or without consciously abusing the rights of the defendant.

HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS NEAR $151 BILLION PACT ON TRANSPORT BILL

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25

 BODY:
After spending the weekend in legislative gridlock, House and Senate negotiators reached virtual agreement today on a compromise bill establishing highway and mass transportation programs worth $151 billion over six years.
Under the provisions of the bill, the Federal Government would grant the states about $32 billion for mass transportation and $119 billion for highways. The spending would begin immediately and grow steadily over the years. Most of the money would come from taxes on motor vehicle fuels. 
 The negotiations were stalled late today by wrangling over the allocation of money to individual states, with several lawmakers contending that their states would not get their fair share. But the prospects for final agreement still appeared to be good, with passage by the Senate and House likely before Congress adjourns for Thanksgiving. President Bush is expected to sign the legislation.
 
Thousands of Jobs Affected
 Hundreds of thousands of construction jobs would be affected by the legislation. Some states began to lay off workers after Federal highway aid stopped flowing on Sept. 30. Nobody in Washington wanted to be blamed for the collapse of a bill that sponsors said would stimulate the economy in the short term by putting people to work and in the long term by easing traffic congestion.
Across the political spectrum, lawmakers, lobbyists and Federal and state transportation officials said the bill would leave a permanent mark. It would make substantial changes in the structure of transportation programs, greatly diminishing the Federal role in determining how states spend transportation dollars, while substantially increasing the amount of Federal money sent to the states each year. It would also use transportation programs as a tool to achieve other goals, notably helping the states to meet the demands of the Clean Air Act, which passed last year.
The bill's broad outlines were slowly becoming known throughout the day, even as its finer points, including how much money each state would receive, remained open for negotiation.
 
Declaring Victory
 Exhausted by the struggle to bring as much of the money as possible home to their constituents, the House and Senate leadership as well as the Administration seemed inclined today to declare victory in the prolonged bout over the transportation bill and to endorse the compromise that emerged overnight.
House and Senate leaders put out the word tonight that the compromise was, as one highway industry lobbyist said, "a take-it-or-leave-it proposition."
Administration officials said that the bill would achieve their major goals of reshaping an array of Federal grant programs into a relatively few programs, giving the states more flexibility to choose how the money was spent. But they acknowledged that the compromise would allow more spending than the Administration had wanted and would not require the states to pay as high a proportion of transportation costs as the White House had sought.
But it seemed likely that the political imperative of generating jobs would overcome any lingering doubts over the legislation.
A principal question during consideration of the bill had been how much emphasis to put on highways rather than mass transportation and, in particular, whether to endorse the Administration's plan to concentrate spending on a coast-to-coast network of major highways, including the existing interstates and other primary routes. The Administration wanted to spend about $10 billion a year for this program, which it called the National Highway System.
As the compromise emerged, the bill would include nearly $38 billion over six years for improving and expanding these major highways, an amount that was close to what the House had passed and considerably more than what the Senate had allowed.
 
What Administration Sought
 The Administration welcomed this provision today. But lobbyists who opposed the Administration's highway goals said that Congress had not completely accepted the Administration's vision of the National Highway System.
For example, they said, the Administration had initially requested nearly $44 billion for this program over five years. They said the compromise also would require that Congress vote on the program again in 1995, after the states and the Department of Transportation defined what roads would be included. Further, they said, $17 billion, or half the money for the national highway program, would be set aside for maintaining existing interstates.
All these constraints could be seen as a victory for the Senate, where Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a New York Democrat who was a principal author of the bill, had sought a bill that would not give first priority to highways.
Mr. Moynihan said he was "immensely happy, hugely encouraged" by the outcome.
"What we have done here is to create the opportunity to move from a period of system building to system performance, and it is a tremendous opportunity," he said. "The bill says to people: Think harder about what you have got, what you might want, a better way of doing it. Think productivity."
 
Increase for Mass Transit
 The bill would include a big increase for mass transportation, although details of the mass transportation program were still being worked out today. The measure would also continue the practice of providing operating subsidies for big city transportation programs.
It also would set the Federal share of transportation programs at 80 percent, with the states providing 20 percent.
Both the increase for mass transportation and the cost-sharing provisions represented defeats for the Administration.
What delayed the compromise wasthe need to sort out differences on how the money should be allocated among states. No matter what formula was used, one state or another came up short. In the end, the negotiators designed a formula that would satisfy as many members as possible, inventing several new financing categories in the process. Then, to insure acceptance of the bill, a bonus was thrown in to satisfy powerful lawmakers in Illinois, Wisconsin, Minnesota, Pennsylvania, Arkansas, Maine and West Virginia.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "How the Transportation Bill Shapes Up"
 
Financing
 $151 billion over six years, including $119 billion for highways and $32 billion for mass transit. The Administration wanted $17.8 billion a year for highways, and the bill provides $19.8 billion a year, on average. The Administration wanted $3.2 billion a year for transit, and the bill provides $5.25 billion a year.
 
Apportionment
 For many lawmakers, the crucial question was whether individual states would receive Federal aid equivalent to the amount of fuel taxes each pays. After repeated attempts to write a formula that would win enough votes, with grants linked to factors like gasoline consumption, highway mileage, state population and historical levels of financing, the negotiators decided simply to set aside chunks of money for several major states. Not everybody was satisfied, through, and the formulas continued to be debated today.
 
National Highway System
 The negotiators have allowed $38 billion for a 155,000-mile network of interstate highways and other major roads. The Administration had sought $44 billion, but over five years. Even so, the Administration said that it was satisfied since other money would probably be spent on related projects like bridges and highway maintenance.
 But those who did not want to commit money to the program are also declaring victory. They said that the highways have not yet been formally chosen. Theyalso said that Congress must approve the program again after the highways are chosen and that states have the choice of civerting up to half the highway money to other purposes.

HEADLINE: New Yorkers Giving Dinkins Low Marks

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Nearly halfway through his term, Mayor David N. Dinkins's political support has slid sharply, with fewer than a third of all New Yorkers approving of the way he is handling his job, and two-thirds saying it is time to give someone else a chance, according to a citywide New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll.
Battered by the city's fiscal crisis, rising social problems and the dashing of many of the high expectations that greeted his narrow victory as the city's first black mayor, Mr. Dinkins has an approval rating of 29 percent, with 58 percent disapproving -- almost exactly the reverse of his ratings in mid-1990. 
 The new rating is roughly equal to the lowest marks ever given to former Mayor Edward I. Koch, in June 1989, when his approval rating was 33 percent. That was after 11 years in office and a major corruption scandal, and just three months before Mr. Dinkins decisively defeated him in the Democratic primary.
Polls are only a snapshot, subject to the vagaries of the economy and events. And after any dramatic development, the public can rally to its leaders and job ratings can rise. At the moment, other political chief executives around the region are suffering similar slumps.
More than half of black New Yorkers, 59 percent, still approve of Mr. Dinkins's performance, but about a third, 30 percent, disapprove and say it is time to give someone else a chance. That is a major erosion for a Mayor elected with more than 90 percent of the black vote. His standing among whites was starkly lower, with just 17 percent approving of his stewardship and nearly three-quarters disapproving of his performance and saying it was time for a change.
In one potentially ominous sign, given Mr. Dinkins's campaign on a platform of racial healing two years ago, most of those surveyed said he had had no impact or a negative impact on race relations in the city, with only 29 percent saying he had had a positive impact. A little more than half of both blacks and whites said race relations were worse in the city than five years ago.
"It is of concern to me, of course,"the Mayor said in an interview yesterday. But he noted that the steady drumbeat of bad budget news in the region had made incumbents lightning rods for dissatisfaction. He said he would rebound when judged against his opponents, instead of against an ideal.
"The poll that really matters is one that will be taken in 1993, in the primary in September and the general election in November, and I feel confident that we will do well," he said. "The reason is that people will be obliged to weigh those others who've suggested they can somehow or other do it better."
The poll was based on telephone interviews with 824 New Yorkers, including 482 whites and 208 blacks, conducted Nov. 2 to 12, the week before the Mayor's trip to South Africa and at the time that Mr. Dinkins announced his plan to keep the budget balanced by cutting the work force and freezing property taxes for two years. The poll has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
 
Can't Blame Predecessor
 Political experts said the new ratings -- much worse than polls of 18 months ago but only slighter worse than those in other recent polls -- reflected not only the Mayor's accumulated political problems but also the natural cycle of a politician's term.
"He's been in too long to blame the previous incumbent, and it's too soon to start trying to proclaim his accomplishments in a campaign," said Lee Miringoff, director of the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. "So you're in that middle zone, which is the low ebb."
Dennis Rivera, head of Local 1199 of the hospital and health care workers union and one of Mr. Dinkins's earliest backers who has lately been critical of him, said: "Two years is a lifetime in politics. If he can rebuild his coalition, he will have a formidable chance of getting re-elected."
But that coalition of liberals, labor and minorities has been splintered by the fiscal problems that have forced the Mayor to forsake much of his agenda of social programs while spending to hire more police officers. The Times/WCBS-TV News Poll did not include a large enough sample of Hispanic New Yorkers to make their views statistically reliable, but other polls have shown Mr. Dinkins faring badly with that important segment of his supporters.
Mr. Dinkins's chief political aide, Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, said of the new poll, "The only thing I would say about it is we're not taking it for granted or being cavalier about it, we'll just redouble our efforts, just work harder." He said the administration had not yet begun to do polling of its own in anticipation of the re-election campaign, but would do so in the coming months.
 
Still, Some Optimism
 Underneath the obvious bad news and strong disapproval ratings are some signs of a silver lining. While all New Yorkers' approval of the Mayor's job performance has slipped steeply, the percentage of black New Yorkers who have a generally favorable opinion of him is in the high 50's, the same level as before his election.
Some blacks who said they disapproved of the Mayor's performance in the poll said in follow-up interviews that he had a very hard job and had not always been treated fairly by the press.
"Well, it looks like things got worse and didn't get any better," said Mary Harris, a 66-year-old retired nurse from Harlem, who said she would have to think very hard before voting for Mr. Dinkins again. "It doesn't seem like he's helping anything. I voted for him, but I've been disappointed." But she added: "I don't think he's been treated quite fair. He had problems when he went in there, and there's been a lot of pressure on him."
Jan Zaccor, 43, a commercial real-estate broker in Flushing, Queens, who supported the Mayor in 1989 said she would vote for him again. "I don't think that job is doable for any one person," she said. "He seems to be a wise man, though very limited in what he can do. Let's put it this way: I don't think he's hurt anything."o
She added: "He has his shortcomings. I guess he's not as outspoken as maybe he should be. But I think black people expected him to crusade for black rights, which he didn't do to any great extent, and maybe they're angry at that. But that's one of the reasons I like him is because he didn't pick any one group."
Such comments distill Mr. Dinkins's problem as he tries to rebuild support among his core constiuency without alienating the liberal white voters who helped propel him to a two-point victory over Rudolph W. Giuliani. He returned from a week in Africa buoyed by his trip and bitter at his critics, vowing to "tell the truth" on those who had been "telling lies" about him.
Another poll, to be published in this week's issue of The New York Observer, had even more negative findings, with 75 percent of respondents rating Mr. Dinkins's job performance unfavorably and only 25 percent favorably. That poll was based on telephone interviews with 500 New Yorkers by Johnson Survey Associates. It had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor David N. Dinkins, whose approval rating is slipping, talking with Deputy Mayor Milton Mollen yesterday at City Hall. (Jim Estrin for The New York Times)
 
Graph: "The New York Times/CBS News Poll" shows responses to question "Do you approve or disapprove of the way David Dinkins is handling his job as Mayor?" June, 1990-Nov. 1991 (Pg. A1)
 
How the Survey Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Nov. 2 to 12 with 824 adults throughout the five boroughs of New York City.
The New York City poll was part of a broader project in which 3,212 adults were interviewed across the entire New York metropolitan region.
The sample of telephone numbers called was generated by a computer, based on random digit dialing techniques. It was drawn by Marketing Systems Group of Philadelphia.
Within each household one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the poll.
The results have been weighted to take into account household size and the number of telephone lines into each residence. The results have also been adjusted for variations relating to race, sex and age.
In theory, in 19 of 20 cases the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all adult residents of New York City.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for black respondents in New York City it is plus or minus seven percentage points.
Besides sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: Senate Votes Aid to Soviets to Scrap Atomic Arms

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25

 BODY:
The Senate approved a stripped-down plan today to transfer up to $500 million from the Pentagon budget to help dismantle Soviet nuclear weapons.
The Senate also approved the treaty that cuts NATO and former Warsaw Pact non-nuclear forces in Europe. 
 House leaders and the Bush Administration have expressed support for the revived Soviet aid package, enhancing its prospects for final approval before Congress adjourns this week.
Senate approval of the Soviet aid plan capped a startling comeback for a proposal that nearly died two weeks ago after the measure's sponsors failed to line up broad political support and the White House balked at openly endorsing it amid charges that the Administration was paying too much attention to foreign affairs.
 
A Less Ambitious Plan
 The vote today was 86 to 8, with 52 Democrats and 34 Republicans in support. Eight conservative Republicans voted against the measure.
The revised plan is cheaper and less ambitious than the original version sponsored by Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia and Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin, both Democrats, but is still aimed at averting instability in a crumbling nation that has 30,000 nuclear weapons. Mr. Nunn is chairman of the Senate Armed Service Committee. Mr. Aspin is chairman of the House Armed Services Committee.
Focused narrowly on helping the Soviet Union store, dismantle and destroy its arsenal of nuclear and chemical weapons, the revised plan has a clearer and more persuasive payback for American national security than the earlier version.
Under the revised plan, the Administration has discretion to transfer up to $500 million from this year's Defense Department budget to Soviet aid, instead of $1 billion under the original plan, and deals mainly with assisting Moscow's efforts to destroy its nuclear and chemical arsenal.
"The former Soviet Union, still a nuclear superpower, is coming apart at the seams," Mr. Nunn said. "The danger of proliferation of existing weapons, weapons materials and the weapons know-how is growing as both the Soviet economy and traditional Soviet control mechanisms lose effectiveness."
The plan extends aid only to the Soviet Union or any republic that invests in dismantling its nuclear and chemical weapons, foregoes modernizing its military except for defensive needs and complies with arms treaties.
The revised plan eliminates incentives to American companies that invest in converted Soviet military industries and a provision to help the Soviet Union retrain its military officers. Both provisions drew heavy criticism from Republicans and Democrats, who feared a public perception of favoring the plight of foreigners at a time when the American economy is suffering.
Backers of the original plan worked in tight secrecy and consulted closely with few of their colleagues until the last minute. This time, Mr. Nunn enlisted influential Republicans, including Senator Richard Lugar of Indiana and Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate Republican leader, to broaden political support for the resurrected measure.
"It's not a question of aid to the Soviet Union," Mr. Lugar said, trying to dispel the notion of a giveaway. "It's a question of destroying weapons that we've spent a very great deal of time, effort and defense money over the past to destroy."
Several senators also credited warnings of impending chaos in the Soviet Union from the United States Ambassador in Moscow, Robert Strauss, with helping to break the impasse.
Later the Senate agreed, on a voice vote, to give the Soviet Union enhanced trade status. The granting of most favored nation treatment for imports from the Soviet Union, approved last week by the House, comes 40 years after that status was revoked at the height of the cold war.
The Soviet assistance package for scrapping weapons, which also contains a provision to use Air Force planes to transport humanitarian aid, was attached to legislation that carries out the provisions of the treaty governing conventional forces in Europe.
The House has already approved a similar bill, minus the aid plan. Lawmakers will now negotiate a compromise version that is all but certain to include the Soviet assistance.

HEADLINE: U.S. BUILDING CAMP FOR HAITI REFUGEES

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25

 BODY:
The Bush Administration dispatched a military task force to the Caribbean tonight to erect an emergency refugee camp at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, for thousands of Haitians who have fled the political turmoil in their country and whose exodus by boats to the United States has been blocked by the Coast Guard.
Led by Brig. Gen. George A. Walls Jr. of the Marines, the military group, made up of hundreds of troops from all four military services, is to build a tent city at the American base on the eastern tip of Cuba to handle the more than 4,000 Haitians rescued at sea thus far and the hundreds more fleeing each day. 
 A senior Pentagon official said today's action could be open-ended and the size of the tent city was as yet undetermined. "We need to unload the Coast Guard and Navy ships because they are overwhelmed right now," the official said, referring to the Haitians being plucked from the sea by United States vessels.
The sudden response by the Administration reflects growing concern at the unfolding refugee drama prompted in part by an American-supported trade embargo against Haiti seeking to reverse the overthrow of the country's first elected leader, the Rev. Jean Bertrand Aristide.
 
800 Plucked From Sea
 The emergency response came after more than 800 Haitians were plucked from small boats by Coast Guard cutters on Sunday, the largest daily rescue toll since the exodus began nearly a month ago. More than 2,300 Haitians were said to be aboard 10 Coast Guard cutters today and more refugees were in custody on ships at anchor off Guantanamo.
The Guantanamo naval base, located on the southeastern corner of Cuba, covers about 28,000 acres. A total of 3,400 U.S. personnel are stationed at the base, which was ceded to the United States under a 1903 treaty with Cuba. President Fidel Castro's Communist Government came to power in 1958.
A United States District Court order to suspend the forced repatriation of Haitian refugees temporarily also caught the Administration by surprise last week and has led to unfavorable comments about how its policy in Haiti conflicts with American policy in Southeast Asia, where the United States opposes Britian's attempt to forcibly repatriate Vietnamese boat people from Hong Kong.
United States officials argue that most of the Haitian are economic refugees and do not qualify for political asylum in the United States. Moreover, American officials said they do not want to encourage a mass exodus by allowing the Haitians into Miami.
About 120 of the Haitians have been granted asylum, a State Department official said. In addition, the State Department said today that of the 538 Haitians whose repatriation was monitoried before the court order went into effect, none were harasssed or arrested as they cleared the port of return, collected a cash stipend from the Red Cross and returned home.
"To date, we have received no confirmed reports of mistreatment," a department statement said. "Since we began this program in 1981 we have had no indication that any Haitians have been persecuted for trying to leave Haiti."
 
Announcement Is Surprise
 The Pentagon did not appear anxious to take on the additional refugee mission and many officials were surprised by the abrupt announcement of the operation. General Walls is not expected to arrived in Guantanamo until Tuesday, but officials said it would not be difficult to start getting tents up within one day.
"Clearly the best thing would be if they didn't leave Haiti at all because it is dangerous on the high seas," the senior Pentagon official said, "The answer is not to empty the country out, but to solve the problem there."
But there was anything but positive news on the diplomatic front today, as mediation efforts between the ousted Father Aristide and a delegation of Haitian legislators meeting in the Colombian capital failed to make any progress on a rconciliation that would pave the way for the return of Father Aristide, who was deposed in a military coup on Sept. 30. The Organization of American States condemned the coup in an emergency meeting in Washington and on Oct. 8 imposed the trade embargo.

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
For Bush, the Kemp Thing Reappears

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Jack Kemp rarely ran the ball when he was a quarterback. Now he has it and is running for daylight. The problem is, he's going in the opposite direction from the White House team.
This has made the former Buffalo Bill who runs the Department of Housing and Urban Development a hero among conservative Republicans and a heretic among top White House aides. 
So as Mr. Bush plummets in the polls, Mr. Kemp -- who is a former rival of the President and who is widely regarded as one of Mr. Bush's least favorite Cabinet members -- basks in the approval of much of the Republican Party. Just Saturday, 81 Republican House members wrote to the White House asking that Mr. Kemp be appointed the "domestic policy czar" of the Bush Administration.
This means that with the Republican Party in turmoil over economic and domestic policy and the political competence of the White House staff, Mr. Kemp has seized the moment and decided to defy convention by speaking up about his differences with the President and his top aides on economic policy.
 
A Loyal Soul?
 Mr. Kemp says he is the soul of loyalty. The President's men are not so sure. But in any event, Mr. Kemp has become the epicenter of an economics debate that one White House official describes as "a battle for the soul of the Administration."
Mr. Kemp favors "a growth package" that would include the kind of tax cuts that Mr. Bush supports in principle but not as an instant remedy. Mr. Bush and his top economic advisers favor hunkering down and waiting for the economy to get better on its own.
While Mr. Kemp has been careful to suggest that his ideas are also those of the President and not to criticize Mr. Bush, White House officials say Mr. Bush's chief of staff and his budget director are "very annoyed" that Mr. Kemp is "off the reservation."
Mr. Kemp's supporters say he is trying to save Mr. Bush, even if it means hurting his standing at the White House; his detractors say that Mr. Kemp, who challenged Mr. Bush in the Republican primaries in 1988, is simply trying to set himself up as the true heir to Ronald Reagan for the 1996 campaign.
The split got even more embarrassing for the President over the weekend when the letter signed by 81 of the 166 House Republicans was delivered to Mr. Bush. "We need one leader with the energy, enthusiasm and national clout to tackle our domestic agenda," said the letter, co-written by Representative Curt Weldon of Pennsylvania and Dan Burton of Indiana.
The "one leader" they wanted, it turned out, was not George Bush. "We must declare war on our domestic ills," the lawmakers wrote. "Jack Kemp is the man to lead that war."
 
'I'm Flattered'
 Those close to Mr. Kemp said the Secretary was informed about a month ago that the members wanted to get such a letter in the works, but that he never heard more about it. Representative Burton said the group did not tell Mr. Kemp they were sending the letter this weekend, for fear that he would be accused of conspiring to "feather his own nest," as Mr. Burton put it.
"I'm flattered but I'm somewhat embarrassed," Mr. Kemp said tonight about the letter. "In reality, I think the letter was sent out of frustration, a sense that there isn't enough attention being focused on the issue of growth and what it means to jobs and opportunity and the poor and the inner cities."
Although the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, was said to have dismissed the letter as "grandstanding" by the House Republicans, some others in the White House and the party saw it as one more warning that Mr. Bush is drifting into a vulnerable position.
"Obviously, this has only happened because Bush allowed there to be a perception of weakness," said Edward Rollins, a Republican consultant who was chairman of Mr. Kemp's Presidential campaign in 1988. "No one would have done this to Reagan, Nixon, Johnson, or even Carter."
Some of those who signed the letter say their criticism is aimed not at the President, but at Mr. Sununu and the budget director, Richard G. Darman, both of whom have been very unpopular on Capitol Hill since what has been widely perceived by House Republicans as their high-handed and inept lobbying attempts on behalf of the 1990 bipartisan budget deal.
Mr. Sununu, Mr. Darman and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady tried to muzzle Mr. Kemp two weeks ago, after he went on the CBS television program "Face the Nation," and proposed "a joint Bush and Congressional tax rate reduction, not to bust the budget, but to get America growing again."
 
Views on Economy
 Mr. Brady called a meeting of the Economic Policy Council, and Mr. Sununu and Mr. Darman told Mr. Kemp that everyone was expected to keep a low profile until the President announced his own economic plans in the State of the Union Message in January. A participant said Mr. Kemp told the President's men: "I will not stop talking about growth and jobs and opportunity and housing. That's what the President picked me for."
A few days later, Mr. Kemp was back on television, on the "Evans and Novak" program on Cable News Network, making the same activist arguments about the economy and tax cuts on behalf of Mr. Bush.
Mr. Kemp apparently is not worried. He feels liberated, his friends say, because, after an unhappy year struggling in vain with the White House and Senate to get through programs for his agency, he is finally speaking out about something in which he believes.
In a sentiment echoed by many disillusioned Republicans, Mr. Rollins said that the problem stems from the insistence by Mr. Sununu and Mr. Darman to stick to the 1990 budget deal they struck.
"Darman and Sununu cannot admit that they made a significant mistake in 1990, that world events have changed and that that agreement from a year ago is now bad economic and political policy," Mr. Rollins said.
Mr. Kemp's friends also point out that in a way, now that he has gone public with his criticisms he has more leverage. They say the White House staff would not want to fire him and make him a martyr to conservatives before the primary in New Hampshire, where Mr. Kemp got 12 percent of the vote in 1988.
Asked about those who see his outspokenness as an effort to position himself as a Presidential candidate in 1996, Mr. Kemp said: "Gosh! If I didn't speak out about poor people and minorities, they would complain I was being silent in the face of their distress. If I do speak out, people say I'm trying to position myself. The only thing I can do is tell the truth as I see it and let the chips fall where they may."

HEADLINE: Casting Doubts: Economy Stinging Bush

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25

 BODY:
A striking loss of confidence in President Bush's economic leadership is leading Americans to reassess the Bush Presidency, setting the stage for a competitive election next year, according to the latest nationwide New York Times/CBS News Poll.
Only one American in four now approves of Mr. Bush's handling of the economy, a level of discontent unmatched since the days of double-digit inflation under President Jimmy Carter. Mr. Bush's overall job approval rating is now at 51 percent, a drop of 16 percentage points since mid-October. The declines seemed to reflect a month of bad economic news and turmoil in the White House. 
 Mr. Bush can take comfort from the fact that his overall approval rating is still well above the lows reached by Presidents Ronald Reagan and Jimmy Carter. Also, such ratings of Presidential popularity often swing sharply, and past incumbents with similar or lower ratings have gone on to win.
 
A Close Hypothetical Race
 Still, for the first time in the Times/CBS News Poll, Americans are evenly divided when offered a choice between re-electing Mr. Bush or some unnamed Democrat: 39 percent of registered voters said they would probably vote for Mr. Bush, while 37 percent said they would probably vote for the Democrat, according to the telephone survey of 1,106 adults, of whom 840 were registered voters.
Support for Mr. Bush's re-election has undergone a striking erosion among voters from the age of 30 to 44; among middle-income voters, earning $30,000 to $50,000; and among voters in the West.
These are all considered important swing voters in any Presidential election, and they are voters the Democrats are scrambling to peel away with promises of tax cuts and a new sensitivity to the middle class.
While Americans seem ready to give the Democratic Party a hearing, the poll indicates that they know little about the six major candidates vying for the party's nomination. More that half of those who said they planned to vote in the Democratic primaries said they did not have a favorite candidate.
The poll was conducted Nov. 18-22 and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points for the total sample, and five percentage points for respondents who said they usually vote in Democratic primaries or caucuses.
Recent history suggests other caveats for the Democrats: Ronald Reagan's approval rating was at 53 percent in a Gallup poll at this stage of his Presidency, but he went on to win 49 states against former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, the Democratic nominee. President Richard M. Nixon was at 48 percent in the summer of 1971, 18 months before his landslide over George S. McGovern, and Harry S. Truman was at 36 percent in the spring of 1948, just months before his re-election.
Still, an election that seemed a formality last spring in the aftermath of the Persian Gulf war, when Mr. Bush had a record 88 percent approval rating, now seems very real.
 
Indifference and Glee
 Charles Black, a top Republican adviser, said the President's decline in popularity in the poll was only to be expected. "There's no doubt that the economic frustration and pessimism are growing and he's been in a political slump," Mr. Black said. The Republican adviser said there was ample time to correct the President's problems, and noted that Mr. Bush would not be running against a generic, idealized Democrat next year. Unlike real Democrats, "that's something that has no negatives attached to it," said Mr. Black.
Democrats were gleeful at the latest poll results. "This is what free fall looks like," said Paul Tully, political director for the Democratic National Committee. "He wasn't elected to blame and scapegoat and pass the buck. They saw him do things back in the spring, with the war in the gulf, and they're asking, 'Where did that guy go?' "
The latest poll shows a public unconvinced by the Administration's contention that the recession is over and the recovery is under way. When asked to rate the condition of the economy, 74 percent said it was "fairly bad" or "very bad," while 24 percent said it was "very good" or "fairly good."
This measure of economic pessimism had risen 10 percentage points over the past month alone, and was the highest level recorded since the Times/CBS poll began asking this question five years ago.
 
'Better Off?' 'No'
 In another measure of discontent, 39 percent of Americans now say they are "worse off" than they had expected to be at this stage in their lives, while just 16 percent said they were better off. In contrast, in January 1986, when the Times/CBS poll began asking this question, 20 percent said they were worse off than they expected to be, while 38 percent said they were better off.
These findings are ominous for a party whose political strength rests to a large extent on its competence in managing the economy -- a party that returned to power in 1980 with Mr. Reagan's memorable question, "Are you better off today than you were four years ago?"
The level of approval for Mr. Bush's economic stewardship, 25 percent, is lower than any reading taken by the Times/CBS poll during the Reagan Administration, and 8 percentage points lower than in mid-October. Mr. Reagan's low point was 35 percent, and occurred in the recession in August 1982 and again in January 1983. The last time Americans gave an economic approval rating equal to or lower than Mr. Bush's was in July 1979, when just 15 percent said they approved of the way Mr. Carter was handling the economy.
Over the past month, one of the most significant erosions in Mr. Bush's economic approval rating occurred among Americans earning $30,000 and above.
Mr. Bush's overall approval rating, at 51 percent, essentially ties the lowest previous reading of his Presidency, in October 1990. Then as now, it was economics that was front and center, as Mr. Bush struggled to reach a budget agreement with Congress.
Mr. Bush's political appeal has long been tied to his foreign policy expertise, and while his approval rating dropped here as well, it is still at a healthy level for most Presidents, 57 percent.
Like many of the political professionals, the public seems to be reassessing just how competitive next year's election will be: 47 percent said they expected Mr. Bush would "definitely be re-elected President," while 42 percent said they agreed that "a Democratic candidate can win the election." A month ago, only 26 percent said the Democrats had a chance.
But the field of candidates remains little known, and the contest is still unsettled because of uncertainty about the plans of Governor Mario M. Cuomo of New York, who has yet to announce whether or not he will run next year. When likely Democratic primary voters were asked to choose among the six announced major candidates, 56 percent said they did not have a favorite; 11 percent chose former Governor Edmund G. Brown Jr., and the rest were in single digits.
When Mr. Cuomo was added to the list, he was the choice of 26 percent. Nearly half said they thought Mr. Cuomo should run for President, while 26 percent said he should not.
On another matter, only 7 percent in this survey said they had a favorable impression of David Duke, the former grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan who ran unsuccessfully for Governor in Louisiana and is now considering a Presidential campaign next year; 56 percent said they had an unfavorable view. Just eight percent of those who identified themselves as registered voters said they would consider voting for Mr. Duke.

How the Survey Was Taken
 The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Nov. 18 to 22 with 1,106 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened so that calls would be placed to residences only. Within each household one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the poll.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for those who say they vote in Democratic primaries or caucuses, it is plus or minus five percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. (pg. A18)

HEADLINE: Home Is on Their Minds

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Congressional leaders in both parties are trying to adjourn this session by Tuesday night or early Wednesday, if they can complete action on a few remaining issues in both houses.
As this rancorous session seems to have run out of legislative steam, leaving town before Thanksgiving has been an increasingly attractive objective. Out of Washington, the lawmakers will rest, hold hearings, raise campaign money and generally plan for the next Congressional session as well as next fall's elections. 
 Moreover, only a credible deadline for getting home is generally considered to be a sufficient incentive to win passage of unpopular legislation like the bills replenishing the fund that insures deposits at banks and refinancing the Resolution Trust Corporation, which is managing the savings and loan bailout.
The most important other item on the short "must" list -- which means that failure to enact the measures would almost certainly bring Congress back to work in December -- is the $151 billion transportation program. Because that bill translates immediately into construction jobs, it is considered an economic and political necessity.
The compromise crime bill is regarded by most leaders as a step below the others in importance.
Some House Republicans have demanded that Congress remain in session to work on a package of tax cuts to spur economic growth, but Democrats have said they would only do so if President Bush asked them to stay, and he has not.
Any measures left unfinished will remain on the agenda for the second session of the 102d Congress in January.

HEADLINE: A Quick Trip to Columbus Provides Bush With a Break From Frustration

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 25

 BODY:
President Bush left behind the frustrations of the big economic picture today for the small-scale politics that he loves: shaking the hands of local dignitaries, watching pre-school children play "Fish Derby" on a computer and exclaiming as high school students drew fake blood from artificial arms with real needles.
Accompanied by Education Secretary Lamar Alexander, Mr. Bush swooped down on Columbus in his Boeing 747 for less than four hours. He sped through a visit to the Fort Hayes Metropolitan Education Center, a speech in a Veterans Memorial Auditorium filled with sleepy high school students and interviews with local television reporters. 
 After weeks in which Mr. Bush has tried to grapple with national economic and political problems in an effort to counter the impression that he is not engaged on domestic issues, today's trip, the first of four he will take around the country before Christmas, reflected a return to an older White House strategy of selling the President in small groups and to local news outlets.
 
The Value of 'Micro-Events'
 Mr. Bush's press and political advisers concluded early in his Administration that one of the President's greatest strengths is his ability to perform in "micro-events" like the ones today, which give him a chance to portray the avuncular President, not the partisan infighter who battles with Congress.
On today's trip, each of Mr. Bush's events seemed little more than a chance to appear before television cameras with friendly people or before a hospitable audience. For Mr. Bush, those must have been especially welcome opportunities at a time when the White House has been reeling from attacks by Congressional Democrats, Mr. Bush's sagging standing in public opinion polls and missteps by top members of his staff.
One of those aides, John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, who often travels with Mr. Bush, stayed in Washington today. The former New Hampshire Governor, who had undergone a bruising week in which there were new rumors that he was in trouble with the President, made a point of appearing at the White House on Sunday evening with his wife, Nancy, and one of their children, to greet Mr. Bush on his return from Camp David.
 
Computers and Dinosaurs
 In Columbus, Mr. Bush visited a child-care center at the Fort Hayes experimental education complex, where high school students in blue smocks were seated with their small charges at low tables in a room decorated with paper turkeys and a big sign welcoming the President.
Mr. Bush went from table to table, stopping for only a minute or two at each. At the first table, he smiled for the cameras as a teen-ager worked with four children who were identifying sounds that she played on a tape recorder.
The President put on his reading glasses at the next table to look at a colorful computer screen on which a small girl was playing "Fish Derby," a game involving different types of fish. He proclaimed his delight at a group of children who were gluing bits of colored paper in holiday designs and then encouraged two boys and a girl who were working at a small table filled with sand.
"You dug up a dinosaur," he told one proud little boy.
With a quick wave and a cry of "Good to see you guys," Mr. Bush went off to another room, where high school students were being trained as medical technicians.
Mr. Bush used the stop, where he watched two students push needles into false arms as an exercise in how to safely draw blood, as an example of what he said is the "flexibility" of his own education programs.
 
Echoes of the Campaign Trail
 Later, in a speech to an auditorium filled with high school students, Mr. Bush sounded more than ever as if he was on the campaign trail, although he has yet to formally announce his candidacy for re-election. He thanked more than a dozen people for their help in organizing the event and made a point of thanking the high school band that played "Hail to the Chief."
Seemingly mindful of the political trouble the President has been having, Gov. George V. Voinovich, a Republican, introduced Mr. Bush to the audience as "a President who cares deeply for the children of this nation" and "a President who has shown us the way through his unprecedented historic leadership."
The President's speech was devoted to a promotion of his "America 2000" education program, which Ohio joined today, providing a ceremonial occasion for the visit and thus making it possible for the White House to call it an official trip and not a campaign stop.
"Our schools were designed for another era," he said. "They must catch up with the times. We want you to have good lives and good jobs when you are adults."
White House advisers are counting on quick, small-scale trips like this one to help Mr. Bush send his message to voters. But the atmosphere seemed almost contrived at some of the stops, including his speech, during which at least a third of the high school students were clearly asleep in the overheated auditorium, waking up only to applaud politely.
Mr. Bush did not get through the day without a reminder of his larger problems. At the Fort Hayes laboratory classroom, a reporter shouted, "Mr. President, are you going to be able to stop the bleeding at the White House?"
Looking chagrined, Mr. Bush turned to the students, jerked his thumb over his shoulder at the reporters and said with a small laugh, "That's the way I make my living."
