SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 1025 words

HEADLINE: Buchanan Seeks 'None of the Above' Vote in New Hampshire

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Nov. 22

 BODY:
Karen Hutchinson, a New Hampshire state legislator, has a message that she would like to send President Bush. She could send him a note, or even call his office, but she thinks she has found a more effective way to communicate her discontent.
"I am voting for Pat Buchanan in the primary," she said. "It's a protest vote." 
Ms. Hutchinson said she did not believe the President really understood how bad the economy here was. New Hampshire's unemployment rate, almost 7 percent in September, is the highest it has been since 1976.
"I think Bush has blinders on," Ms. Hutchinson said. "He's not seeing and he's not listening."
Last week, Mr. Buchanan, a conservative columnist and a former aide to President Ronald Reagan, said that he was giving serious consideration to entering the New Hampshire Republican primary but that he would not make a final decision until after Thanksgiving. Without even putting himself on the ballot, Mr. Buchanan already appears to have won a substantial following among many unhappy Republicans in New Hampshire.
 
Going for the Disgruntled
 Even supporters of the President are warning that Mr. Buchanan could make a strong showing here, and deal a significant public relations setback to Mr. Bush, simply by winning the state's disgruntled vote.
"I've already told the White House that they better get their act in gear up here," said Gordon Humphrey, a New Hampshire state senator who supports Mr. Bush. "Anyone who is running is going to get a big protest vote over the economy."
This protest vote, Mr. Humphrey predicted, could amount to as much as 40 percent of the total. "That," he said, "would be highly embarrassing for the President."
Many Republicans here and in Washington give Mr. Buchanan virtually no chance of winning the Presidency and say that what his candidacy represents is an effort to gain control of the party's conservative wing and to position himself for 1996.
But people close to Mr. Buchanan insist that his will not be a symbolic candidacy and that if he does enter the race, he will run a credible campaign against the President. They are not at all shy, though, about acknowledging that Mr. Buchanan's goal is to reassert the dominance of the Republican Party's right wing.
"He has said literally that this is an effort to take back the party, to release it from the kind of Rockefeller Republicans who control it now," said Greg Mueller, an aide to Mr. Buchanan. He said Mr. Buchanan would consider 10 percent to 15 percent of the primary vote here to be a good showing.
 
Other Challenges?
 Mr. Buchanan is not the only politician who could reap the benefits of an angry electorate. David Duke, the one-time Ku Klux Klan leader who recently lost a runoff for Louisiana governor, has said he, too, is exploring the possibility of running against President Bush.
Some analysts say that a bid by Mr. Duke would hurt Mr. Buchanan because the two would be lumped together as right-wing extremists. Mr. Buchanan appears to be anxious about any association with Mr. Duke, and recently went so far as to denounce "White House mites" who, he said, were trying to link him to the ex-Klansman.
But here in New Hampshire, a state so conservative that it is not uncommon to hear President Bush branded as a "liberal," Republicans insist there is no danger that Mr. Buchanan's brand of rightist politics will be confused with Mr. Duke's.
"We make a big distinction up here between Buchanan and Duke," said Hugh Gregg, a former Governor of New Hampshire whose son, Judd, now holds the office. "I can't think of a single Republican activist out there working for Duke, but I can think of several working for Buchanan."
Paul Nagy, a data processor who has devoted himself full-time to conservative politics since he was laid off last year by the state, is one of the Republicans laying the groundwork for a Buchanan campaign in New Hampshire. Mr. Nagy said he had not yet had time to make calls soliciting support.
"I've been too busy returning calls from people asking what they can do to help Pat," he said. "There just seems to be an outpouring."
 
Voices for Buchanan
 Indeed, Mr. Buchanan does seem to enjoy strong support among New Hampshire Republicans. In random interviews with Republicans who said they planned to vote in the primary, almost half said that if the election were held now, they would vote for Mr. Buchanan.
Thomas Maurice, a planner for an electric company, said he would vote for Mr. Buchanan just to vote against Mr. Bush. "I just don't think he really realizes what's going on," Mr. Maurice said. "I'm not very happy with the way the economy's going."
Bruce Gamsby, an engineer, said he would vote for Mr. Buchanan because "it sends a message" to the President. "I want to reinforce the idea that his base is derived from the right," he said.
If the prospect of a heavy protest vote is not enough to trouble the President, many politicians here say, the championing of Mr. Buchanan by The Union Leader should be.
 
An Influential Ally
 The Manchester newspaper, one of the nation's quirkiest and most conservative, is the only one in New Hampshire with statewide circulation. Studies by a political science professor at the University of New Hampshire, David Moore, suggest that its cheerleading for Mr. Reagan was instrumental in helping him defeat Mr. Bush in the 1980 New Hampshire primary.
In recent weeks, the paper has taken up the cause of Mr. Buchanan in front-page editorials, urging him to challenge Mr. Bush and his "disastrous course of accommodation with the implacable liberal Democratic opposition."
On Friday, it ran an editorial denouncing Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York as "a sissy," and another praising Mr. Buchanan for being a "true believer in the mainstream conservatism that the President chose to disavow when he reneged on his 'no new taxes' pledge and signed on to a civil rights bill that deprives the accused of even the basic presumption of innocence."
Mr. Buchanan "will have an impact all right," Mr. Gregg, the former Governor, said, "because The Manchester Union Leader will support him."

HEADLINE: Behind Jobless Figures, A Rise in Poor Children

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25

 BODY:
A disproportionate number of Americans who are losing jobs during the recession are under 25 years old, a study by a children's advocacy group says, adding that the trend threatens to push more children into poverty.
All in all, more than 1 million of the 1.2 million jobs that workers lost since the recession began in July 1990 were lost by workers 16 to 24 years old, according to the study, which was released today by the Children's Defense Fund and the Center for Labor Market Studies at Northeastern University in Boston. 
 "Job losses among young workers, often the parents of America's youngest and most vulnerable children, are creating a devastating cycle of declining earnings, declining family incomes and rising child poverty," said Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund.
Even though the recession did not start until mid-1990, 841,000 children were pushed into poverty last year, the Defense Fund said. In all, more than 13 million American children were living in poverty last year, it said.
In 1990 a family of four was considered to be living in poverty if the household's annual income was $13,359 or less. In 1989 the standard was $12,675.
The report, based on Labor Department statistics, noted that while hundreds of thousands of workers 25 years old and older have lost their jobs in the recession, those losses have been offset by the creation of jobs for other workers in the same age group. But there have been no such offsetting gains among workers 24 years of age and younger.
Douglas Besharov, a researcher with the American Enterprise Institute, a Washington study center that specializes in social policy, said he was skeptical that the net job loss for younger workers would amount to such a large chunk of the overall number of jobs lost since the recession began.
"I'm surprised at the report because it says the net job losses have been suffered almost totally by young workers," he said. "I thought the unemployment caused by the recession was much more widespread than that."
But Mr. Besharov added: "Young people, especially those who've dropped out of school, have been having a progressively tougher time in our economy. They have the lowest seniority and the lowest educational attainment, and many of them are competing with low-wage workers around the world for jobs."
James Weill, general counsel of the Defense Fund, said the losses could be accounted for by young workers who have lost low-paying jobs in the service industries.
The group recommended that Congress enact a children's tax credit to reduce taxes for middle- and low-income families.
Mr. Besharov, of the American Enterprise Institute, said he believed more money should be pumped into the country's schools.
"If we look at the nature of the underlying trend, which is fewer opportunities for those with lower educational levels, then we would realize we ought to be spending money and improving their schools so that they can compete in what has become a post-industrial Western economy," he said.

SECTION: Section B; Page 7; Column 1; Style Desk; Fashion Page

LENGTH: 896 words

HEADLINE: Patterns

BYLINE: By Woody Hochswender

DATELINE: MIAMI BEACH

 BODY:

American St. Tropez?
Greetings from Miami Beach, America's hottest new style center, where you can barely walk down the street without running into camera crews, models, hairdressers and fashion editors. It's practically fashion gridlock.
There was Jenny Capitain, a fashion director of Vogue, towing a group of hairdressers, stylists and the model Elaine Irwin (the one with the blond hair and black eyebrows), for a fashion shoot over the weekend. 
 Or Bruce Weber, the photographer, down to do some Ralph Lauren ads. Or Frederic Fekkai, the New York hairstylist, exchanging bon mots at Brasserie Le Coze, a branch of Le Bernardin that opened in Coconut Grove two weeks ago.
For all its reputation as a tacky retirement place, Miami Beach is emerging as an American St. Tropez, with new boutiques, chic restaurants and a rare blend of beauty, talent and converging cultures.
In addition to the wonderful light, which makes winter catalogue photography a piece of cake, the big draw has been the distinctive Art Deco hotels along Ocean Drive and Collins Avenue, streamlined odes to the last stylish American architecture before the numbing sameness of Bauhaus set in.
The South Beach area of Miami is a visual dream. Everything is pink and aqua and coral and sapphire, soothing by day and electric with neon by night. Against this backdrop unfolds a polyglot style parade like nowhere else: fresh-faced teen-age models in linen sundresses; tattooed bikers in studded leathers; ponytailed executives who look as if they've been lightly brushed with olive oil; sunburned Germans and Scandinavians in black nylon socks and sandals.
Tara Gilani, a Miami writer, calls it Touro-Style, a variation on Euro-Style, but based on local fashions and the influx of foreign tourists.
"You get everything from Linda Evangelista, fresh from the Milan collections, wearing a T-shirt, Levi's and a baseball cap," Ms. Gilani said, "to what I call a 'full Cleveland.' " That, she said, is a man at least 50, visiting from the Midwest, wearing white patent-leather shoes, white belt and white slacks with a colorful polyester shirt and sunburned head.
The amount of skin people show on the beach and on the street seems to be inversely proportional to how in shape they are. Large-bellied men seem to prefer to wear bikini-style briefs or even string pouches. Chiseled young men go for baggy surfer jams, almost to the knee.
The notorious thong bikini is more popular than one would expect, given the obvious visual hazards. People wear beach clothes on the street as well as coordinated exercise clothes. "Anywhere there is a big husband market, people wear expensive exercise clothes," said Susannah Shubin, the fashion director of Saks Fifth Avenue in Miami.
 
They Call It Agency Row
 So many modeling agencies line Ocean Drive, a 15-block strip of Art Deco buildings facing the beach, that one area is now called Agency Row.
Models sun themselves topless between shoots across the street at Glamour Beach. And the scene has attracted a new genre of nighttime barflies: the "causeway crowd," people who travel over the bridges linking Miami Beach with the mainland, the equivalent of New York's "bridge and tunnel people."
Zoli Management opened an office in the Park Central Hotel, a blue jewel right on the beach that also houses a branch of the TriBeca restaurant Barocco. Ford Models recently moved into offices above the popular News Cafe, a 24-hour beachfront restaurant that is perpetually jammed. Just down the street is Michele Pommier, one of several thriving local agencies.
"After Thanksgiving, there's no light in Europe, no leaves on the trees up north," said Colleen Goujjane, a booking executive at Zoli, explaining the Miami fashion phenomenon. "You know, this whole thing was started by Germans, who came here to shoot spring and summer catalogues, and ended up investing in real estate."
This is also the land of "baby girls," or models who have barely reached puberty.
"They start them at 12," said Justin Greenberg, a stylist. "I had a job with a 12-year-old recently. You could hardly talk to her. But if she's tall and wears women's sizes, she can get work."
Agency executives said their one concern was that editors would get tired of using Miami backdrops.
"Nothing at the beach, nothing at the hotels," proclaimed Ms. Capitain of Vogue, as she ate lunch with her crew by the Ritz Plaza pool. "I've done it all a thousand times."
 
Retailing's Latin Beat
 Miami has been called the northernmost city in Latin America. Along with its large expatriate Cuban population, the city is home to many wealthy Venezuelans, Colombians and Argentines whose spending power has shaped the retailing scene.
At Dadeland, one of the largest and most successful malls in Miami, 75 percent of purchases are made by Latin Americans, a recent article in The Miami Herald said. Nearly all the salespeople at Dadeland's Saks Fifth Avenue store are bilingual.
Hispanic clients represent about 60 percent of business at Martha, a branch of the New York store in Bal Harbour. Business in Miami has been good, retail executives said, but the recession is being felt.
"It has started, but it came much later than in New York," said Rosemarie Weisburger, the manager of the Martha store in Bal Harbour. "The high-priced merchandise moves slower."

SECTION: Section C; Page 13; Column 4; Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 1202 words

HEADLINE: As a Double Opening Nears, A Studio Head Has the Jitters

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 25

 BODY:
As the holiday season approaches, are Mike Medavoy and the Sony Corporation about to enter Never-Neverland?
Mr. Medavoy is the chairman of Tri-Star Pictures, the studio that is producing "Hook," one of the year's most expensive and widely anticipated films, and "Bugsy," a risky and costly love story about a gangster and his moll. 
 For Sony, which owns Tri-Star as well as Columbia Pictures, the two movies are a chance to show that the company's multi-billion-dollar investment in the film industry is finally paying off. Their failure, on the other hand, could well shake confidence in Sony, whose huge investment in Hollywood has already been widely criticized as profligate.
"Hook," the Steven Spielberg extravaganza about a grown-up Peter Pan, stars Robin Williams, Dustin Hoffman and Julia Roberts; it is to open on Dec. 11. "Bugsy," a Barry Levinson film with Warren Beatty as the doomed gangster Bugsy Siegel and Annette Bening as his girlfriend, opens two days later.
Mr. Medavoy, 50 years old, who has been the chairman of Tri-Star since early 1990, is very much in the spotlight in the insular, intensely competitive and often backbiting upper echelons of Hollywood. The success of the two movies would cement his position as one of the top executives in town. Failure -- ever present in Hollywood -- would leave him vulnerable.
"If both of these pictures are a bust, a lot of people will be unhappy, including me," Mr. Medavoy said with a smile.
"I hadn't been nervous until recently," he said in his elegant conference room at Sony Pictures Entertainment in Culver City. "I wasn't nervous during the process of making 'Hook.' But as we get closer to the opening date, it does provoke a certain nervousness. There are nights when I've lost sleep. But I know it's no longer up to me."
 
Equal Time for 'Bugsy'?
 The mounting intensity surrounding "Hook" was underlined today as weekly Variety reported that not only was the studio spending huge amounts of money to promote the fantasy adventure, but also that the makers of "Bugsy" felt short-changed by the studio. Both films are competing for advertising, theaters and promotion, Variety said, and "Bugsy" seems to be losing out.
There is also some concern among some Sony executives that audiences are weary of gangster movies -- especially after the flop "Billy Bathgate," starring Dustin Hoffman -- and that Mr. Beatty is miscast in "Bugsy." "The film is a love story about a man who had the vision to invent Las Vegas," Mr. Medavoy said. "It's not a traditional gangster story. We didn't even think of 'Billy Bathgate' when we designed the campaign."
Mr. Medavoy, a cherubic, 50-year-old executive with a fringe of red hair, spoke carefully this morning about the two movies. "I think the people from the 'Bugsy' set know we're giving a lot of attention to that movie," he said. "Each film has its own dynamic. 'Hook,' in some ways, is its own phenomenon. We can't go out and create a hype. We haven't. It's there."
 
Big Spending
 It is the finances of "Hook" that have, in some ways, stirred the most talk. The film will need to take in enormous amounts of money for the studio to earn a profit. Although the costs of the movie -- not including the salaries of Mr. Spielberg and the three stars -- have been estimated at $70 million, Tri-Star executives insist that the figure is closer to $62 million, but advertising and publicity will account for millions more. "Bugsy," on the other hand, cost about $32 million.
On "Hook," the studio, under a complex deal negotiated by the Creative Artists Agency, has agreed to give an unusually high 40 percent of the initial gross proceeds to Mr. Spielberg and the three leading actors. A number of film executives insist that the film must gross $120 million from all sources -- including the studio's share of box-office receipts as well as video sales and foreign rights -- to break even. To start making a profit, these executives insist, the movie will have to gross as much as such successes as "Rocky," "City Slickers" and "Total Recall."
Mr. Medavoy insists that the movie makes economic sense. "It's obvious that there are some special circumstances where certain movies, event-type movies, while risky, are worth making," he said.
Another reason, other executives say, is that while the film most certainly is financially risky, Sony is delighted at the notion of a splashy, big-budget Steven Spielberg movie underwritten, essentially, by the Japanese company. Mr. Spielberg is one of the most popular film makers among Japanese moviegoers, and Sony expects "Hook" to be a big success there.
So far, "Hook," and "Bugsy" have been kept under wraps by the company, although in recent days there have been some screenings. Many major exhibitors saw "Hook" last Friday, editors and writers from news magazines saw it last week and a preview audience saw it in Dallas. Early word on the film, which runs about 2 hours and 15 minutes, has been positive.
 
Responsibility on 2 Fronts
 Mr. Medavoy has a moderately good track record. In some ways, he is a member of a rather exclusive club of men who have dominated the film industry for the last decade, moving from lucrative job to lucrative job as studio chiefs regardless of their accomplishments.
Formerly a top agent, he has a reputation for leaving creative film makers alone and is especially popular among directors like Woody Allen, who is making a new film at Tri-Star. Earlier, as part of the senior management team at United Artists and then Orion Pictures for a total of 16 years, Mr. Medavoy played a central role in creating hits including "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," "Rocky," "Annie Hall," "The Sting," "Amadeus" and "Platoon."
But as one of the founders of Orion, he is also sensitive to accusations that his creative decisions involving films that failed may have played a role in the financial turmoil engulfing that studio.
"That's really unfair," he said. But he added: "I do bear a certain amount of responsibility under very difficult circumstances, both of the positive side as well as the negative."
Mr. Medavoy has a reputation for being a secure executive in a wholly insecure business, a man who does not have the sharklike qualities of some of his rivals. His background is relatively unusual. He was born in Shanghai to Russian immigrant parents, and moved to Chile with his family when he was 7 years old. He later majored in history at the University of California in Los Angeles and, while a student, began working in the mailroom of Universal Studios. As an agent with International Famous Agency, a predecessor of International Creative Management, he represented clients who included the directors Mr. Spielberg, Francis Ford Coppola, George Cukor, Phil Kaufman and Terence Malick.
In looking ahead to prospects for his two upcoming movies, Mr. Medavoy said the unexpected success of "The Addams Family," about a ghoulish family, was a positive omen. Paramount Pictures said the film grossed a huge $24.2 million this weekend.
"Business this past weekend was 7 percent above business at the same time last year," he said. "It augurs well for us, doesn't it?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: "If both of these pictures are a bust, a lot of people will be unhappy, including me," said Mike Medavoy, chairman of Tri-Star Pictures. He was referring to "Hook" and "Bugsy," both costly productions. (Bart Bartholomew for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: City Wants Previews Labeled, but Producers Balk

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
The city's Department of Cultural Affairs announced yesterday that it would meet with representatives of Broadway and Off Broadway producers next Tuesday to resolve a dispute about whether shows that have not yet been reviewed by critics should be clearly labeled as previews in advertisements.
Mark Green, the Consumer Affairs Commissioner, issued a warning letter to two producers' groups last Wednesday, saying, "Consumers are entitled to know exactly what they are buying when they purchase theater tickets." 
 Since ticket prices for previews and for performances after the opening are often the same, "Consumers should be put on notice when they are seeing a work-in-progress as opposed to a finished product," Mr. Green wrote.
He cited ads for the Broadway productions "Nick and Nora" and "The Crucible" that did not use the word "preview" or mention the official opening dates: Dec. 8 for "Nick and Nora," Dec. 10 for "The Crucible."
Mr. Green's letter said that if advertisements in the future did not declare that a play was in previews, and the date of the official opening, the department would impose fines of up to $500 per ad, "as well as restitution for aggrieved consumers." But the department said it would not take action until after next week's meeting.
 
Intervention Questioned
 Spokesmen for the League of American Theaters and Producers and for the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers, the two groups warned by Mr. Green, questioned the application of consumer fraud statutes to theater producers' marketing decisions.
"Where does it say the government can intervene in our industry's ability to freely promote its shows?" said Harvey Sabinson, executive director of the League of American Theaters and Producers.
He said that Broadway previews cost more than regular performances because of the additional expense of daytime rehearsals and overtime for backstage workers. "The economics of the business often makes full-priced previews necessary," Mr. Sabinson said.
He added that he had asked The New York Times and other newspapers to lower the cost of their ads for previews, but that "they charge the same for previews, too."
Daniel Brambilla, an attorney for the league, said: "The next thing they'll be doing is ask us to publish the bad reviews. It's absurd. There is nothing deceptive about this. It's been going on for decades."
George Elmer, secretary-treasurer of the League of Off-Broadway Theaters, said that Mr. Green's letter opened up "the prospect of ever more intervention by government."
"Will the owner of a new restaurant now be required to say that the restaurant is in previews until it has been commented on by food critics?" Mr. Elmer asked.
Linda Sachs, the assistant commissioner of Consumer Affairs, responded. "I can't believe that a Broadway producer would compare a theater production to a plate of food," she said, and added that the lack of a preview designation would fall under the deceptive-trade-practices provisions of Section 20-701, Provision 2, of the New York City Consumer Protection Law.
Mr. Sabinson expressed surprise that Mr. Green would issue a threatening letter without any advance notice or consultation with the league. He said the city should be trying to support the theater industry in a time of economic recession instead of issuing reprimands. "After all," he said, "there has been no public outcry on this matter."
Ms. Sachs said that the agency had received no consumer complaints about unlabeled previews, but was responding "to complaints that were reported in the media." She mentioned a column by Linda Winer, the Newsday writer, protesting unlabeled theater previews.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Seeks Deeper Cuts In Fiscal Plan

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 25

 BODY:
In an announcement with implications for both state and national politics, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo called on the Legislature today to return to Albany immediately to make deep spending cuts aimed at closing a state budget gap he said had now grown to about $875 million.
Mr. Cuomo declared at an afternoon news conference that time had run out on his negotiations with the Legislature over an unusual multiyear budget plan. That plan was intended to close in a single step both the $875 million gap in this year's $30 billion budget and next year's projected gap of $4 billion, theoretically making it easier for Mr. Cuomo to run for President. 
 Although in his public comments, Mr. Cuomo seemed to abandon discussion of a multiyear plan, some legislative aides said they saw today's events as part of a calculated strategy to revive the negotiations. By proposing an alternative plan with something to offend virtually every lobbyist in Albany, Mr. Cuomo incited a riot of public reaction that will spread quickly to the offices of the state's 211 legislators.
 
Igniting Voter Discontent
 The legislators are up for re-election next November, and legislative leaders have paid close attention to the anti-incumbent sentiment registered by voters in elections earlier this month. Sometimes with gallows humor, top legislators said today that they dread the prospect of igniting voter discontent by cutting state aid to schools, firing hundreds of state workers and possibly forcing local governments to raise property taxes.
Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, a Democrat, took a break from his Federal fraud trial in Brooklyn to assess Mr. Cuomo's proposal. "I don't know what's worse," Mr. Miller said in a telephone interview, "jail or this."
Mr. Cuomo, who has repeatedly linked New York's fiscal situation to his ability to run for President, said little about what impact today's fiscal developments would have on his deliberations.
"I don't know how to calculate it," Mr. Cuomo said. "This has to come first."
 
Excruciating Process
 But the Governor predicted that passage of a revised budget would be an excruciating process that would then have to be duplicated early next year to close the gap in the 1992-93 budget.
"I suspect that doing it in two steps, at least, will prove more than twice as difficult," Mr. Cuomo said. "But I am left with no choice but to insist that we deal separately with our immediate problem."
Mr. Cuomo called on the Legislature to return to Albany as soon as Friday, but aides to Mr. Miller and the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, said it would be impractical to convene a special session the day after Thanksgiving.
In proposing his deficit reduction plan, Mr. Cuomo raised the amount of the budget gap projected for the fiscal year that ends on March 31, to $875 million. His budget office had released an estimate of $689 million in late October.
The Governor then published an austere plan to close the gap without raising taxes.
Mr. Cuomo's budget director, Patrick J. Bulgaro, estimated that the Governor's plan would cut $1 of every $5 remaining in the budget that is not legally required to pay interest on debts, entitlements for the poor and benefits for state workers.
The Governor's latest proposal would cut state aid to schools by $256 million, with the cuts for each school district averaging 3 percent of its total state aid package. No school district would bear a cut that would reduce its overall annual budget by more than 1.5 percent. That cut would come after the state's school aid budget has been cut by $660 million to $8.32 billion in the last 11 months.
Lawmakers warned that local property taxes might have to be raised to make up for the cuts.
New York City would lose $95 million in school aid, contributing to a net loss of $110 million for the city. The city's budget director, Philip R. Michael, said the burden for absorbing the cuts would be spread across city government.
Mr. Cuomo proposed that Medicaid and other social service programs be cut by $214 million through a variety of measures. The largest would save $100 million by indefinitely delaying one of the state's weekly Medicaid reimbursement payments to hospitals, doctors and other health-care providers.
Other savings would be generated by imposing co-payments for some Medicaid services, by limiting the number of hours that Medicaid recipients can receive personal care services, by eliminating dental services for adults from Medicaid coverage, and delaying increases in reimbursement rates for nursing homes and hospitals.
Mr. Cuomo also proposed to save $21 million through a complex mechanism that could lead private insurance companies to pass on increased costs to consumers. The Governor said he would double the state reimbursement differential that allows Blue Cross/Blue Shield to pay health-care providers at cost, while forcing private insurers to pay higher rates. The state would keep the money generated by the higher rates.
Mr. Cuomo's plan would eliminate 1,500 state jobs by April, including 500 through layoffs. During the next fiscal year, the Governor has proposed trimming the workforce by 6,000 employees, requiring up to 1,200 layoffs.
The Governor abandoned the idea of a three-day furlough for state workers after negotiations broke down with unions representing state employees. He proposed a 3 percent reduction in the budgets of the Executive Branch, the Legislature and the Judiciary.
Even these severe cuts would not close the budget gap completely. Mr. Cuomo said the state would have to borrow for the fourth consecutive year to close a deficit, this time by selling $95 million in short-term deficit notes.
The plan drew quick criticism from the state's legislative leaders, who retreated to their traditional positions on fiscal issues.
The Senate majority leader, Mr. Marino, a Republican from Oyster Bay, L.I., said the plan did not go far enough to control spending on social services.
"I will not agree to any deficit reduction plan that cuts our schools and raises local property taxes in order to pay for uncontrolled growth in Medicaid and other social welfare programs," he said in a statement.
Mr. Miller, meanwhile, suggested that the social services cuts were too deep. "The Assembly continues to believe that the deficit cannot be closed solely by cuts in services for the elderly, the poor and the middle class, those most adversely affected by the national recession," the Brooklyn Democrat said.
It was the same fundamental difference that caused the breakdown of the talks on the multiyear budget, even though all sides endorsed the general concept of a two-year budget.

HEADLINE: Yes, Subway Nirvana Does Exist: Just Go to Newark

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
People have said for 20 years that wherever urban America is heading, Newark would get there first. Would that it were true in mass transit.
Through the heart of this city, commonly associated with images of urban despair, runs one of the country's most pleasant and efficient subways -- and one of the least well known. 
 "Completely charming" is how one commuter, Bob Hartman, a graphic designer, described the city subway. "Quaint," "clean" and "safe," said another user, Robert Salazar, a student at the Newark branch of Rutgers University.
A 12-minute trip from Pennsylvania Station in the heart of downtown Newark to Franklin Avenue, the end of the line near the border with Belleville, confirms these claims. While transit officials in New York and other cities struggle with aging equipment, huge deficits and potential fare increases, the managers of the Newark line oversee a system that runs like clockwork -- every two minutes during rush hour -- and manages to please passengers and even turn a profit.
 
Short, Pleasant Journey
 Part of the secret lies in the scale. The one-car trains travel a line that is 4.3 miles long, has just 11 stops and is used by 14,000 people a day.
To traverse the line is to recapture the past and imagine the future of urban rapid transit. It evokes the days when Newark was a bustling manufacturing and retailing center, with a network of streetcar lines that linked neighborhoods with grace, ease and speed. And it suggests the kind of simple, relatively inexpensive light rail line that could help untangle many contemporary cities clogged with cars.
There are few hints of the system's charm as one waits at the terminus, deep in the bowels of Penn Station, below the busy Amtrak, New Jersey Transit and PATH lines upstairs. Long before the subway car comes into view, it can be heard rounding a sharp curve, its wheels growling ferociously.
Then it appears, hardly threatening at all: oval shaped, with a black-and-white exterior with a bright, wide stripe of blue, purple and orange slashing down each side. Inside and out, the car is spotless. The seats are cushioned in beige and blue. Two sets of windows line the sides: one row for seated passengers, and above them another for those who must stand.
 
A Visual Delight
 There is much to see. At each of the first four stations, striking tiles that date from the Depression depict scenes of the construction of the Morris Canal; the subway runs in the old canal bed. The line heads west through the fourth stop, Warren Street, then curves north and rises from underground, running just below street level in a culvert. At Orange Street, the sixth stop, the line comes up to grade and crosses the street, the only time it does so, with the loud clanging of a bell and a smooth, silent rush.
The tracks then slice through Newark's northern neighborhoods. On the right is Branch Brook Park, a large, rambling oasis above which rises the spires of the Cathedral of the Sacred Heart. On the left are old factories, then small houses and apartment buildings.
The stations slip by. At Park Avenue, a man who has been munching french fries exits, depositing his $1 into the fare box next to the motorman. At Bloomfield Avenue, a woman with Sesame Street birthday balloons pays and steps down to a station with clean white tiles and glass-enclosed waiting areas.
At Franklin Avenue, precisely 12 minutes after leaving Penn Station, the car comes to a halt. Passengers walk toward buses waiting just beyond the small landscaped plaza to take them to the surrounding suburbs.
 
'Completely Charming'
 Stephenie Waller waits for a bus that will take her to Nutley, where she works as a data-entry operator. Mrs. Waller, who lives near downtown Newark, has commuted on the subway for two years. "It's very reliable, fast and on time," she said. "I don't think most people even know it exists. I didn't know until my job moved to Nutley."
Other passengers are caught up in the poetry of the subway: the cars, built in the late 1940's and refurbished in the early 1980's, when the state took over the line and spent $20 million to rebuild it; the cleanliness, and the small-town friendliness that pervades the system.
"It's completely charming," said Mr. Hartman, the graphic designer who begins and ends a commute between his home in north Newark and his job in midtown Manhattan with the subway. "It's small scale. People are always very courteous to each other, getting up to let others sit down. You don't get grumpy commuters."
Mr. Salazar has been riding the subway for three years as part of his regular trip between his home in Union and Rutgers-Newark. "It's dependable and clean," Mr. Salazar said. "I think it's safe."
Others were not so sure. Michael Magdziak, the superintendent of the subway, said there is very little crime on the cars, but passengers have to exercise caution going to and from the stations late at night. "We're in an urban environment," Mr. Magdziak said. "You have to be street savvy."
Since the state pumped money into rebuilding the subway in the early 1980's, the 55-year-old line has pretty much paid for itself, Mr. Magdziak said. It costs about $2.8 million a year to operate, and takes in about $3.4 million in revenues. The profits go to New Jersey Transit to help subsidize other bus and railroad lines.
Ridership of the Newark subway grew by 27 percent between 1986 and 1989, but it has fallen by 10 to 15 percent in the last year, presumably because of the recession, he said. The next major investment is scheduled for 1996, when the first of the system's 24 cars will be 50 years old and will require replacement. The cars were bought used in 1953 from the Minneapolis streetcar system, and similar ones are still in use in Pittsburgh, Philadelphia, Boston, Toronto and San Francisco.
But such details mean little to the line's loyalists, who would prefer as few changes as possible. Mr. Hartman, for example, describes his early morning subway ride as "by far the nicest part of my day."
Some of the motormen share that enthusiasm. "I love it," said Samuel Watson, who has worked in the subway for 10 years and who drove a bus in Newark for 12 years before that. "I have no problem with automobiles. When I start out in the morning, I know I'll be on time at the end of the day."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A passenger emerging from a subway car at the Davenport Avenue station in Newark, which has a transit system that is one of the country's least well known. The line runs like clockwork -- every two minutes during rush hour -- pleases passengers and even turns a profit. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Marriott's Debt Is Downgraded

 BODY:
The senior long-term debt ratings of the Marriott Corporation, the hotel operator based in Bethesda, Md., have been downgraded by Moody's Investors Service to Baa3, from Baa2. The ratings agency also assigned a prospective Ba1 rating to Marriott's shelf registration covering $230 million in convertible preferred stock. 
 Moody's said that about $3.1 billion of securities were affected. It said it had lowered the ratings because Marriott's expected sale of some assets, mostly real estate, would take a longer time than previously believed because of the recession and the weak real esate market.

LENGTH: 529 words

HEADLINE: Help Russia; Push Russia

 BODY:
For all his skillful management of foreign affairs, President Bush remains oddly limp on a crucial topic: economic aid to beleaguered Russia. True, Mr. Bush has proposed emergency food aid and debt deferral, and true, the Senate finally seems headed for enactment of a modest package to help dismantle nuclear and chemical weapons. But the gravity of Russia's circumstances, and the monumental opportunity for the West, beg for more than these pinched responses.
Americans, unprepared, ask why their scarce dollars should be sent anywhere abroad at a time of sinking fortunes at home. There are compelling answers, but the case has to be made at the top, by the President. So far he's been barely audible. 
 With collapse of the Soviet Government, Western attention naturally turns to Russia. The Russians are moving to democracy; they're about to leap to markets. The Western stake in these revolutions transcends Russia. If its economic reform bogs down, other republics will find their move to markets more difficult. And economic collapse in Russia could easily breed political collapse, with alarming possibilities for dictatorship, equipped with nuclear weapons at that.
The situation cries out for intervention. And according to Jeffrey Sachs, an economics professor at Harvard who advises the Russian government, it won't take much sacrifice by the West. He outlines a Western aid package costing $15 billion a year, about $3 billion of it from the U.S.
If the package succeeds in coaxing Russia into the world of free economies and away from further militarization, the U.S. will save many times $3 billion in defense spending alone.
In the Sachs plan, aid would be targeted and conditioned on market reforms. Based on the plan adopted by Poland, about $5 billion would be used for emergency food aid, $6 billion for imports to keep factories operating and $4 billion to stabilize the value of the ruble -- the first step in opening up to foreign trade and investment.
Such a coherent aid package shines by comparison with the piecemeal response of the Bush Administration, which is at once too generous and too stingy. It gives too little aid -- and it doesn't condition the aid it does offer on irreversible market reforms.
Indeed, the Administration's plan envisions handing over food aid without any requirement that the Russians privatize agricultural markets. That, however, is probably the only way to end a system that allows food to rot in the fields and black market speculators to siphon off much of the rest.
Russia's plans sound good. President Boris Yeltsin has announced a truly radical economic reform, and backs it by appointing economic advisers who are committed to markets. They've begun to put parts of the program in place and, to prove their commitment, invited the International Monetary Fund to supervise reform.
Still, so far the Russian economic transformation is talk and no leap. That makes it all the more important to push the Russians forward, for everyone's sake. To do that, the President needs to explain to a skeptical public why the best use of a few billion dollars is to send them far, far from home.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Down With the Palace Guard

BYLINE: By Dick Armey; Dick Armey, a Texas Representative, is the ranking Republican on the Congressional Joint Economic Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
President Bush is dangerously out of touch with the American public. Instead of listening to the elected people in his party most in touch with the average voter -- House Republicans -- he remains cloistered with aides who avoid action and favor blaming others for the nation's economic, and their boss's consequent political, woes.
House Republicans are increasingly frustrated with the White House's wait-and-see attitude on the economy. We hear our constituents' genuine concern about their prosperity and sense resentment that the Administration seems to show little regard for that concern. Unfortunately, our calls for quick action are rebuked by unelected officials like Richard Darman, the budget director, and John Sununu, the chief of staff, who advocate waiting for a more politically opportune moment to push for an economic growth package. 
 These are the same people who, when the House Republicans passed my "no new taxes" resolution during last year's budget summit, urged the President to accept a package that called for new taxes and to try to push it past us anyway.
Mr. Darman recently counseled the President to wait until the State of the Union Address in January to announce an economic plan, saying this timing would be better because "in the general public's mind, there's a ritual, a rhythm of renewal . . . to the State of the Union."
For uttering such an absurd statement, he should be thrown from the front door of the White House the way unsavory characters were ejected from Texas saloons. What "general public" does he have in mind -- the general public in the White House cafeteria? The real general public is more attuned to the prospect of a bleak Christmas than to rituals so dear to Mr. Darman.
Just to see how much this "rhythm of renewal" exists in the American mind, I conducted an unscientific but objective telephone poll, asking 10 people at random one simple question: "When is the State of the Union Address?"
Seven did not know: a Nebraska video store manager, an auto parts clerk in Missouri, a Pennsylvania financial planner, a San Francisco publicist, an out-of-work New Jersey car salesman, a Texas small-business owner and a Washington cashier. I'm willing to bet that the 70 percent of respondents to my poll who are not in rhythm with Mr. Darman's "general public" would closely match the results of a more scientific poll conducted across the land.
The House Republican conference on Friday endorsed immediate enactment of a comprehensive growth plan, including a partial restoration of passive-loss real-estate deductions to help bolster home values, a reduced capital gains rate, a repeal of job-killing excise taxes on boats, aircraft and jewelry, and a bill allowing families to tap individual retirement accounts for first homes.
Representative Tom DeLay, a Texas Republican, recently sent a letter signed by 113 of the 166 House Republicans urging Speaker Tom Foley to keep Congress in session until such a pro-growth package is passed. Representative Frank Wolf, Republican of Virginia, is seeking signatures for a similar letter urging President Bush to call Congress back if it adjourns without passing such legislation.
Regrettably, our message doesn't seem to be getting across at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue. John Sununu recently lectured House Republicans that politics is "a matter of seasons" and that this is not the right season for the President to go on television to push a growth package.
It's no coincidence that the only person in the Administration pressing for action, Housing Secretary Jack Kemp, was himself a House Republican less than four years ago. George Bush left the House more than 20 years ago, but he should remember how close a Congressional seat is to the people back home, and heed our call now, rather than later.

HEADLINE: Economy Needs Return to I.R.A. Deductibility

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Blame Bush for the Recession" (Op-Ed, Nov. 12), Jude Wanniski's argument for reducing or eliminating the capital gains tax to stimulate the economy is based on a specious analogy. We are asked to think of a horse race in which a 40-to-1 long shot wins but those who bet on it are stripped of all but $4 of their winnings by Internal Revenue Service agents, creating "an even-money payoff." 
 Using the approximately 30 percent rate assessed on higher incomes, including capital gains, the payoff would be more on the order of 28 to 1. Mr. Wanniski also fails to note that what created the long odds on his horse was the comparatively small number of people willing to bet on it.
The tax break that will bring a large number of people to bet through investing is not capital-gains related, but the return of deductibility to individual retirement accounts and Keogh-plan payments. This is the real world of the salaried middle-income American, not that of trickle-down tricks. Let me cite a case.
Thirty years ago, my twin brother decided to become a lawyer; I chose to go into teaching. We earned the same quality and level of graduate degree, but he now earns 20 times my salary. The Tax Reform Act of 1986 had the effect of greatly reducing the income tax rate paid by my brother; it increased my taxes slightly. I didn't like that, but I accepted it as part of the package designed to eliminate preferential tax breaks.
In 1986, I lost even the tax exemption on my annual $2,000 I.R.A. contribution. That money had been coming out of earned income and was therefore being introduced for the first time into the investment pool. The middle class's I.R.A.'s were truly the fresh influx of venture capital the President claims he seeks with his reduced capital gains tax. But what he would be getting in most cases would be merely a turnover of funds already in the investment pool.
Reinvestment or consumption of goods by the rich, who are too few to reduce the odds on long shots, will not bring new funds into the capital investment picture -- as they did not in the Reagan 1980's. They will not represent new savings the way our I.R.A.'s, when pooled in retirement plans by the millions, did and can.
It seems George Bush has intended all along that the kinder, gentler society puffed in his campaign would be kinder and gentler chiefly to speculators, to brokers and to those relative few with a lot of discretionary income.
 
C. WEBSTER WHEELOCK
New York, Nov. 13, 1991

HEADLINE: What Business Improvement Districts Can Do

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am pleased that "The Business of Business" (editorial, Nov. 2) recognizes New York City's Business Improvement Districts as examples of involvement by businesses in cleaning up commercial neighborhoods. 
 However, in citing only two of these districts, in the Grand Central and Times Square areas, you miss an opportunity to show just how successful this program has been. There are, in fact, 24 such success stories throughout New York City.
Most Business Improvement Districts exist not in high-visibility areas in midtown Manhattan, but in neighborhoods as diverse as Steinway Street in Queens, Brighton Beach in Brooklyn and Third Avenue in the hub area of the Bronx. Each district is tailored to be responsive to the needs of a specific community, no matter its size or economic profile.
Business Improvement Districts are financed by property owners, who pay special assessment fees, which are set by the local sponsors in consultation with the city. Through these assessments, Business Improvement Districts can provide a range of supplemental services, which include marketing and promotion, security, sanitation, maintenance, special street lighting and landscaping.
These improvement districts are the result of a partnership between the city and its communities. The New York City Department of Business Services works with each group to provide assistance and service aimed at strengthening individual communities and businesses.
Along with merchants associations and civic groups of all kinds, Business Improvement Districts play a key role in the economic vitality of New York City.
 
WALLACE L. FORD 2D
Commissioner of Business Services
New York, Nov. 8, 1991

LENGTH: 283 words

HEADLINE: Economy Needs Return to I.R.A. Deductibility;
Cut Capital Gains Tax

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Son of Kemp-Roth: Still Wrong" (editorial, Nov. 13) is your usual editorial against cutting the capital gains tax. You state that reform directed toward past investments "couldn't possibly spur future investment." Dead wrong. Capital for new investments comes from selling old investments, and right now $1 trillion of old investments is locked up by investors who won't sell under this tax rate (in New York City, it's 40 percent). A lower rate would encourage capital fluidity, and a rearrangement of assets between conservative and speculative investors would yield more funds for new ventures. 
 Then you object to the profit for rich families. Of course, the rich don't deserve anything; they got too much in 1986. But a capital gains tax reform could be crafted to help mostly the middle-class investors who were penalized in 1986. The House Democrats should be congratulated for their previous effort to provide a $100,000 lifetime exemption, which would help a small retiring businessman to salvage his life savings, but which would mean little to the wealthy. Any remaining benefit for the rich could be
recouped by a higher tax rate on their regular income.
Finally, you state that capital gains cuts will cost the Treasury revenue. Not so. The Treasury gets zero revenue from transactions that do not take place because the tax rate is too high. A low tax rate on many transactions yields more revenue than a high rate on few transactions.
A skillfully written capital gains reform would be beneficial; the simplest approach would be to go back to the situation before the Tax Reform Act of 1986.
 
KENNETH GROVES
Forest Hills, Queens, Nov. 16, 1991

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Clean Air, At What Price?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
IF Americans can land a man on the moon and even brew a decent cup of decaf, why can't they make city air clean enough to breathe? No good reason, most analysts would argue. But the current, high-stakes battle over reformulating gasoline shows it's not only a question of how clean you make it, it's how you make it clean.
While gasoline is a major source of hydrocarbons in urban air, the fuel's contribution to smog is plummeting because new cars are far cleaner than their predecessors. Thus James W. Kinnear, chief executive of Texaco, argues that Federal orders to squeeze the last few percent of hydrocarbons out of auto tailpipes in nine heavily polluted cities will make only a marginal difference to human health -- and will certainly not prove cost-effective. 
 Texaco's real worry, though, is what happens outside New York, Los Angeles, Chicago and the other six pollution capitals. If whole states voluntarily adopt parallel gasoline standards (as now seems likely), Mr. Kinnear believes that the economic waste will reach colossal proportions.
In the 1970's, cars spewed about nine grams of hydrocarbons per mile. But thanks to emissions controls achieved relatively cheaply, the average will be down to 1 1/2 grams by 1995, and hydrocarbons from all mobile sources combined will slip to just a quarter of total emissions in the typical city. Nevertheless, tough Federal gasoline regulations, aimed primarily at reducing the rate of evaporation of unburnt fuel, will go into effect that year in the nine offending cities.
The 6 cents a gallon spent on cleaner gasoline will bring the cost of removing an extra ton of hydrocarbons from the air to about $10,000 -- roughly 10 times the per-ton cost of removing the first 95 percent from urban air. But the 1995 gasoline standard may still prove a relatively efficient means of eliminating the next few percent, which computer simulations suggest will be needed to meet Federal air quality standards.
The next turn of the anti-pollution screw, however, is far more problematic. Unless the law is modified, gasoline will have to be reformulated again in the year 2000 at a cost of about 15 cents a gallon. And this time, the benefit will be hard won: Texaco reckons the cost per ton of hydrocarbons removed will exceed $200,000 -- 20 times as much as the first-round reformulation.
That is grim news for the nine cities, which must compete for business and tax base with less polluted places. Severely reformulated gasoline is almost certainly not the cheapest way to reduce their emissions, argues Robert Hahn, an environmental economist at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington. Nor is it even likely to be the cheapest way to put the squeeze on auto exhausts: Charging for the use of congested roads at peak hours is fast becoming a practical means of keeping traffic moving -- and would probably be worth doing if it did not slash emissions.
But super-clean gasoline could prove grimmer news yet if other regions follow California, which last week adopted a gasoline standard for the whole state that is almost identical to the Federal standard for the most polluted cities. Tens of millions of motorists living in places without serious air pollution could end up paying billions annually to no constructive end.
In the fight to ease the California standard and prevent its spread to other states, Texaco argued it would be far more cost-effective to scrap heavily polluting older cars. Mr. Hahn, who was part of the Bush Administration team in the Clean Air Act negotiations, would take an entirely different tack. He would set a cap on total emissions, and then leave the business of finding the least-cost method of reducing pollutants to the private market. Existing polluters would be given allowances to pollute, which would decrease over time; new polluters would be required to buy allowances from those already polluting.
This idea was raised by the Bush Administration in 1989, then quietly dropped. "We wanted to push for a market solution, Mr. Hahn laments, "but we couldn't find any industry support out there."
Most Americans assume that Big Oil is more than capable of defending its interests. Perhaps. But in this case, the companies were hardly prepared to go to the wall to fight gasoline reformulation since they will always be able to pass on the costs to motorists. ARCO actually championed Draconian standards for California, reportedly because the immensely successful oil company already has the technology and the refineries to reformulate at a lower cost than its rivals.
Environmentalists won a great victory in the Clean Air Act of 1990. It may prove Pyrrhic, however, if the price of regulating away pollution proves to be more than Americans can afford.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Sharply Higher After Drop Early in the Day

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar took a wild ride yesterday, first tumbling on gloomy news about the economy, then surging on word that Germany's top economics aide had said the dollar's value was too low.
Gold prices ended lower. The Republic National Bank quoted bullion at $365.25 an ounce as of 4 P.M., down $2.05 from Monday. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery was down $1.90 at $366.20. 
 Currency dealers said the dollar slumped early in the trading day on word that the Conference Board's widely followed consumer confidence index had skidded in November to levels below that of the 1982 recession.
"That brought us to the thinking that 'hey, this dollar has got to go down,' " said Zlatko Glamuzina, a senior currency trader at the Banco di Sicilia's New York office.
Traders reasoned that interest rates in the United States, which have been falling for months, must go lower still to stimulate lending and reinvigorate the economy. But lower rates hurt the dollar's value by making investments denominated in the currency worth less.
The dollar fell in Asian and European trading until traders heard that Germany's Economics Minister, Jurgen Mollemann, said in an interview that he believed the dollar's exchange rate against the mark should be about 1.6500 marks. The dollar was trading at about 1.5840 marks when his remarks hit the market.
Many traders were surprised, partly because the assertion seemed to go against the grain of German economic thinking. A more expensive dollar would mean a cheaper mark, which would tend to stimulate inflation, which Germans particularly dislike.
Traders who had sold dollars earlier in the day quickly scrambled to buy them back, heightening the velocity of the dollar's rebound. "People were caught short on dollars," said John Lyman, a dealer at the Bank of Tokyo's New York branch.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.23 yen to close at 128.30 yen. Later in London the dollar was quoted at 128.15 yen, before Mr. Mollemann's remarks. In New York trading, the dollar fetched 130.15 yen, up sharply from 127.90 yen late Monday.
The dollar was at 1.5795 marks in European trading, down from 1.5835, before the German minister's remarks were reported. But later in New York the dollar surged to 1.6115 marks, up from its 1.5885 exchange rate late Monday.
The British pound fell in London to $1.7975, from $1.7995 late Monday. Later in New York the pound brought $1.7730, cheaper than its $1.7945 value late Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday, were: 1.4265 Swiss francs, up from 1.4125; 1.1363 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1383; 5.4055 French francs, down from 5.4290, and 1,217.00 Italian lire, up from 1.201.75.

HEADLINE: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Dip

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were moderately down for the week ended yesterday.
According to The Bank Rate Monitor, an interest-rate publication based in North Palm Beach, Fla., the outlook for yields is gloomy, with the slide definitely going into 1992. "Weak indicators and a public lack of confidence are hurting the ability to recover from the economic slump and in turn hurting bank savings yields," Robert K. Heady, its publisher, said. "The drop this week is surprisingly stronger than last week, even three weeks after a prime-rate cut." 
 Analysts noted that this week's decline in C.D. yields offered by banks in the New York market was about the same as declines in C.D. yields at other banks across the country.
 
Bill Yields Off Smartly
 At the Treasury Department's weekly bill auction held on Monday, the average discount rates for both the three- and six-month bills were off smartly and down for the fifth consecutive week. At auction the three-month bill fell 14 basis points, to 4.44 percent, while the six-month bill fell 8 basis points, to 4.50 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The largest yield changes in New York area banks this week were at Midlantic Banks, which lowered its money market account by 26 basis points, 4.60 percent.
European American Bank and Connecticut National Bank both lowered the yield on three-month certificates by 16 basis points, with European American's yield at 4.34 percent and Connecticut National's at 4.75 percent. For a six-month C.D., Connecticut National and National Westminster Bank had the biggest declines, each knocking off 16 basis points, to 4.91 percent and 4.39 percent, respectively.
 
Commercial Banks' Rates
 Yields at commercial banks were off slightly more than at savings institutions. An average commercial money market account was down 4 basis points, to 4.29 percent, while the average three-month certificate was down 8 basis points, to 4.36 percent. The longer six-month certificate was off 10 basis points, to 4.44 percent.
For depositors at savings institutions, the cuts were not as deep, but they hurt, one analyst said. The average money market was off 4 basis points, to 4.99 percent, while the average three-month certificate was down 6 basis points, to 5.02 percent. For the average six-month certificate, the decline was 8 basis points, to 5.20 percent.

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeks Sanctions On China

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26

 BODY:
The Administration today announced the failure of trade negotiations with China aimed at stopping the piracy of American patents, copyrights and trademarks, and began the legal process for restricting some Chinese imports in retaliation.
The decision by the trade representative, Carla A. Hills, is the first time that the United States has sought trade sanctions because another country did not protect American inventions. It represents a further deterioration in American-Chinese relations. 
 The Administration's announcement today came after House and Senate staff members struck a deal late Monday night on which conditions to attach next year to the annual renewal of China's most-favored-nation trade status.
 
House Vote of 409 to 21
 The full House passed the compromise measure tonight by a vote of 409 to 21, with 1 vote of present, considerably more than the 313-to-112 margin by which the original House bill passed.
But Representative Philip M. Crane, the Illinois Republican who led opposition to the measure, said after the vote that the Administration had not put pressure on Republicans this evening to vote down the measure. The Administration has wooed enough Senators to prevent any override of a Presidential veto, he added.
The Senate is not expected to vote before it adjourns for Thanksgiving.
 
100% Tariffs Possible
 A list of restricted imports, which could be subject to tariffs of 100 percent, will be published on Wednesday, and that will immediately disrupt trade between the United States and China, said Richard A. Brecher, the director of business advisory services at the U.S.-China Business Council, a Washington-based group of companies trading with China.
Importers will be racing to change or cancel orders to avoid being stuck with goods that could end up costing twice as much as they anticipated, wiping out any profits, he said.
But with the restrictions possibly going into effect within two months, many importers may not be able to move fast enough, he said, adding, "Everybody's going to be scrambling."
Neither the total value of the imports to be affected nor the types of products involved were available tonight.
The Chinese Embassy in Washington had no comment.
The prohibitive tariffs allowed under Special 301, the legislation dealing with foreign violations of American inventions, would be even more devastating to importers than a revocation of China's most-favored-nation status, which allows Chinese products to enter the United States at the lowest available tariffs. Removing the trade status, as some Democrats proposed last summer, would have increased average duties on imports from China to 40 percent, from 8 percent, while Special 301 provides for 100 percent tariffs.
The final list of restricted products could be revised during a 30-day period of public comment beginning next week, during which negotiations between the United States and China could produce a deal canceling the sanctions. But six months of negotiations, including almost continuous talks in Washington for the last six days, have not resulted in any progress.
"The United States made every effort to reach an agreement," Mrs. Hills said in a statement. "However, China's proposals were ultimately insufficient."
 
Aiming at State Companies
 In choosing products for the sanctions, Administration officials have indicated that they would seek to inflict economic pain on the Chinese Government rather than entrepreneurs in China and Hong Kong, and cause minimum disruption to the American economy. So the American officials have been trying to select products made and shipped by state-owned companies in China.
Last year, the United States exported $4.81 billion worth of goods to China, particularly wheat, agricultural chemicals and aircraft, and imported $15.22 billion worth, especially toys, shoes, clothing and fabric.
Mrs. Hills began patent and copyright trade cases against China, India and Thailand on April 26, and was required by law to announce for China and India today whether she would assess sanctions, extend the negotiations for three months or drop the cases entirely. Mrs. Hills extended the negotiations with India for three months, citing some progress by negotiators and the complexity of the issues. The talks with Thailand are on a separate schedule, with deadlines in December and March.
 
Softer Compromise Bill
 The compromise bill is slightly softer than House and Senate bills passed in July; it gives the President a little more leeway in renewing China's access to American markets. But the President has promised to veto the legislation.
Congressional Democrats have used the China trade-status issue to make the President seem to take a position favoring China at a time when that country's human rights policies, large trade surplus and exports of missiles and nuclear technology to the Middle East are the target of international criticism.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Rise on Strong U.S. Sale

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher yesterday, pushed up by a successful auction of new five-year notes and two surveys showing that consumer confidence had fallen to its lowest level in close to a decade.
Dealers, who had expected demand for the new notes to be good, said the strong bidding at the 1 P.M. auction for $9 billion worth of securities muted the market's reaction to the surveys by the Conference Board and the University of Michigan. 
 The surveys showed that confidence, which had turned up after the Persian Gulf war, reversed course in November and fell to lows not seen since the 1982 recession.
"There is no precedent for consumer confidence to double dip like this," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell Inc. "It is hard to see how the recovery remains sustainable when confidence falls below levels we saw during the war. And it is particularly troubling when this is occurring against a backdrop of falling interest rates."
 
Chance of Contraction
 Mr. Yardeni, who had been cautiously optimistic that the economy would not fall back into recession, said there was now a 60 percent chance that growth would be flat or negative by as much as 2 percent in the current quarter and for the first half of 1992.
At the five-year note auction, the securities were sold at an average yield of 6.54 percent, well below the 6.92 percent average yield at the last five-year note sale on Oct. 24. The yield was the lowest on a new five-year Treasury security in more than five years. On Aug. 27, 1986, five-year notes were sold at an average yield of 6.51 percent.
The new five-year notes traded well after the auction, and by late in the day were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.52 percent. Rare
 
Rare Action by Fed
 During the day, the Federal Reserve added reserves to the banking system by buying coupon-bearing securities rather than short-term Treasury bills. It was the first time since April 1989 that the Fed made such trades.
Analysts, who had been expecting the Fed to add reserves, said that the fact the central bank chose to do so by buying longer-dated issues had no policy significance.
"I consider this move to be primarily technical in nature, and not to affect the yield curve in any significant way," said Darwin L. Beck, an economist at the First Boston Corporation.
In recent days, some economists and credit market participants have speculated that the Fed and the Treasury may try to narrow the difference between short-term and long-term interest rates to help stimulate the economy. Purchases by the Fed of longer-dated issues would be one part of that effort.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 100 22/32, up 1/2 point, to yield 7.93 percent, compared with 7.98 percent late Monday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7.5 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 21/32, up 10/32, to yield 7.4 percent. And the outstanding 6 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 18/ 32, up 5/32, to yield 5.79 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates moved lower. In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.38 percent, down four basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 4.44 percent.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the Georgia-Pacific Corporation offered $250 million of new 20-year notes through an underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers.
The 9.5 percent securities, which mature Dec. 1, 2011, were priced at $99.875 to yield 9.628 percent, 1.65 percentage points more than the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent bonds of 2021 at the time of pricing.
The issue is rated Baa-3 by Moody's Investors Service and BB+ by Standard & Poor's.
The improved tone in the Treasury market had a beneficial impact in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds. Traders said prices of most issues rose from 1/4 point to 3/8 point.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of most widely quoted issues improved by about 1/4 point, dealers said.

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Is the Lowest Since 1980

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

 BODY:
American consumers' confidence in the economy has fallen beneath the lowest level recorded during the 1982 recession, the Conference Board said yesterday in a report that indicates growing unease over job security and general disbelief in the Bush Administration's contention that a recovery has taken hold.
The index of consumer confidence compiled by the board, a widely followed business research group, declined to 50.6 from 60.1 in October. The figure is more than three points below the worst rating of the 1982 recession, when the nation's output of all goods and service, as measured by the gross national product, dropped almost 6 percent in a single quarter and unemployment climbed over the 10 percent mark. 
 "We're about as low as historically we've ever been," said Fabian Linden, executive director of the board. "This is rock bottom in terms of the malaise of the consumer." Referring to the Federal Reserve Board's attempts to stimulate the economy by cutting interest rates this year, he added that "obviously, the use of monetary policy alone is not working."
The plunge in consumer confidence contributed to a big morning decline in stock prices, although the market later staged a recovery. In the credit markets, however, the gloomy news helped to raise prices of Treasury notes and bonds and to lower yields. [Pages D6 and D13.]
The report appeared to increase pressure on the Administration and Congress to act to stimulate a recovery through tax cuts and domestic spending programs, which have been used to overcome past recessions but until now have been shunned by President Bush for fear that tax relief could deepen the budget deficit.
"This unquestionably turns up the fire another notch on Congress and the President," said Robert D. Reischauer, chief economist at the Congressional Budget Office. "There is widespread despair out in the country, we've tried monetary policy, and the question now is, will the political system do something?"
Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at Manufacturers Hanover, also urged what he called "a good, old-fashioned fiscal stimulus." He suggested that the board's report showed that "we're not as depressed statistically as in the 1930's, but we're as depressed mentally, and you need pump-priming to break that vicious cycle."
But an Administration official, who insisted on anonymity, sought to play down the significance of the report. "The economy is not healthy," he said, "but it's growing inch by inch and we'll eventually get a stonger recovery." He declined to predict when that would happen but suggested that existing policies -- including the recent extension of unemployment benefits -- should be enough to spur stronger growth.
 
Similar Data in Separate Survey
 The sour consumer sentiment was reflected in the University of Michigan's consumer confidence index, the country's other main barometer of consumer feeling. The index fell to 69 in November from 78.3 in October, according to economists who have seen the unpublished report.
Such reports are widely thought to provide an accurate reflection of the consumer attitude but do not necessarily indicate where the economy itself is heading. "You get a good idea of where we are, but not necessarily where we're going," said Stephen Roach, the senior economist at Morgan Stanley.
Still, consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of all national spending and is a crucial factor in the country's economic performance. With the vital Christmas shopping season approaching, consumer reluctance to spend seems likely to spell tough times for retailers and could act as a further drag on the economy.
 
Dim Outlook for Retailers
 "These figures come at the worst possible time for retailers, and they put the economy at risk for a renewed recessionary decline," said Richard T. Curtin, the director of consumer surveys for the University of Michigan.
In statistical terms, the recession ended last May, when the economy started growing again, albeit slowly, and employment levels began to rise. Growth, as measured by the gross national product, amounted to 2.4 percent in the last quarter.
But the erosion of consumer confidence -- far worse than what might be expected on the basis of the key economic indicators -- suggests that Washington has failed to come to grips with several factors that are darkening the moods of Americans, several economists said.
 
Insecurity About Jobs
 Chief among these is the issue of employment. Although the unemployment level in October was 6.8 percent, compared to more than 10 percent during the 1982 recession, and even though the growth of jobs resumed in the last quarter, an unease seems to have taken hold. Many people now know somebody who has been laid off.
"People who had raised their hopes earlier in the year have now given up on the prospects of improved hiring and income possibilities," said Mr. Roach of Morgan Stanley.
Mr. Linden of the Conference Board said that the survey, based on questions sent to 5,000 households across the country, showed that only 4.8 percent of people thought jobs were plentiful, while 47.9 percent thought jobs were hard to get. Last month, 43.5 percent of people thought jobs were difficult to find.
He added that 20 percent of those interviewed had personally experienced a spell of unemployment in the past year and, of those, 48 percent found themselves making less money when they returned to work.
 
Other Measures of Doubt
 The survey also revealed that 49.1 percent of the respondents considered business conditions to be bad, the worst showing in more than a year.
The number of people planning to buy a car fell to 6.6 percent from 7.5 percent last month, while those planning to buy a house over the next six months fell to 2.7 percent from 3.3 percent. Both figures suggest that attempts to stimulate the economy through interest rate cuts are having scant effect.
