HEADLINE: Dow Recovers From Drop to Finish 14.08 Higher

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
Largely on the strength of a promised restructuring of the International Business Machines Corporation, the Dow Jones industrial average recovered yesterday from a 52-point tumble to finish the day 14.08 points higher, at 2,916.14.
I.B.M., one of the 30 stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average, said yesterday that it would take a fourth-quarter charge of $3 billion charge and trim its ranks by an additional 20,000 people. The company said the moves would ultimately save it $1 billion next year and $2 billion annually thereafter. I.B.M., whose work force will shrink to about 330,000 after the cuts, had already eliminated 20,000 jobs this year. 
 On the strength of the announcement, the company's stock rose 2 3/4 points, to 97 7/8, pulling up the Dow average and igniting a modest rally in several other indexes as well, analysts said.
"Basically, people look at this as a positive step, which should improve the company's profitability," said Paul J. Kronlokken, a technical analyst with Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood.
Although trading usually slows near Thanksgiving as people take off early for the holiday, volume on the New York Stock Exchange was a heavy 213.8 million, up from 175.9 million on Monday. Gainers narrowly outpaced losers, 869 to 779.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks finished 2.62 points higher at 377.96, while the Big Board composite index also posted a modest 1.20-point gain, closing at 208.77.
The other major indexes were down at the closing bell -- but only by a whisker. The Russell 2,000 finished at 175.58, down 0.54. The American Stock Exchange index fell 0.38, to 370.66. And the Nasdaq composite index dropped 0.65, to 522.23.
All in all, it was an up and down, then up again, day. Within the first few minutes of trading, the market rose 20.57 points, but seemed to lack conviction. Without warning, it did a sharp about-face and plunged 52.33 points by about noon.
Analysts attributed the sudden selloff to a worrisome monthly survey by the Conference Board, which showed that consumer confidence remained stubbornly below levels recorded in the 1982 recession.
They also cited comments made by President Bush at a picture-taking session yesterday, suggesting that he was now supporting an 11th-hour House Republican tax package that could raise the deficit. "Anything that increases the budget deficit just does not sit well with this market," said Dennis Jarrett, chief market analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Company.
I.B.M. alone accounted for 35 percent of the Dow's movement yesterday, according to Birinyi Associates, a stock market research firm in New York. Other factors were six buy and six sell programs that Birinyi noted had a combined impact on the Dow of 19.65 points, and bargain hunters who sought to take advantage of recent bearishness. "A lot of investors have used 2,850 to 2,900 as their zone to do some buying," Mr. Jarrett said.
AIDS-related news continued to drive many stocks, as has been the case since Magic Johnson, the basketball star, disclosed that he had been exposed to the HIV virus. Shares of Proteus International P.L.C., a British company that uses computers to develop drugs, closed up on the London Stock Exchange. Analysts said the recent AIDS-related death of the pop singer Freddie Mercury had kindled interest in the company.
Merck & Company, on the other hand, saw its stock drop 2, to 143 1/4, after it said it had largely abandoned a once-promising AIDS drug after the virus developed resistance to it.

HEADLINE: Fewer Are Late On Mortgages

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26

 BODY:
The percentage of Americans behind on their mortgage payments improved slightly during the July-to-September quarter, but analysts warned that the improvement would be only temporary given the weakness of the economy.
The Mortgage Bankers Association said today that the proportion of mortgage holders 30 days or more late on their payments improved to 5.07 percent in the third quarter, compared with 5.28 percent in the April-to-June quarter. 
 The second-quarter delinquency rate had been the highest in nearly five years.
Analysts said they thought the improvement was a temporary pickup reflecting the fact that the economy began growing again during the July-to- September period after declining for three consecutive quarters while the country struggled with recession.

HEADLINE: Final Push To Finish Bank Bill

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26

 BODY:
In the hours before Congress was to begin its Thanksgiving recess, lawmakers worked today to resolve differences on a slimmed-down banking bill that would provide new money for the bank insurance fund, as the Administration had asked. But the bill included none of the broad changes in the half-century-old laws governing the banking industry that the White House proposed in February.
By late in the afternoon, House and Senate negotiators had agreed to drop provisions in the Senate bill that would have eased barriers to interstate banking. The interstate banking measure had been the last significant White House recommendation left.
 
Measure Bogs Down
 But the bill bogged down in the evening over a variety of smaller provisions that would give regulators greater authority to take over weak institutions and limit the insurance coverage on bank deposits sold by Wall Street investment houses. 
 The key provision of the legislation emerging from the conference committee tonight would provide an increase to $30 billion, from $5 billion, in the credit line that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has with the Treasury. The loans would be repaid through higher premiums paid by banks to the fund.
The legislation would also provide tens of billions of dollars more in loans that would be used as working capital and repaid from the proceeds of the assets of ailing banks seized by regulators. The loan amount is unspecified.
 
Administration's New Tack
 Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady conceded today that the Administration had lost its yearlong struggle with Congress, and began to express a new Administration strategy charging the lawmakers with failure on the issue. "Continued Congressional inaction is a recipe for trouble," he said.
This kind of attack will doubtless be adopted by the White House once President Bush's re-election campaign moves into high gear, even though the President himself never really put any serious lobbying effort behind the Administration's recommendations.
Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., the Michigan Democrat who heads the Banking Committee and has been the Administration's strongest ally, moved swiftly to defend Congress. "We need the President's help," he said. Asked whether Mr. Bush had done enough for the legislation, Mr. Riegle said, "The answer is clearly no."
In the days leading up to the conference, the White House left the legislation entirely in the hands of the Treasury Department.
Congress has been prodded this week to move swiftly to refinance the rapidly depleted fund that insures bank deposits. The fund, which protects about $2 trillion in deposits, is worth about $2 billion and is expected to be out of money by the end of next month, battered by a wave of bank failures.
At a meeting on Saturday, the nation's top bank officials told Mr. Riegle that even after Congress provided new money, the insurance fund would still be unable to handle a failure of one of the nation's largest banks. They also expressed concern that a large bank collapse could lead to a regionwide financial crisis because the Government did not have the money to act swiftly and avert runs.
The meeting was called by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and its participants included William Taylor, the new head of the F.D.I.C., and Senate aides.
Aides said the meeting deeply concerned Mr. Riegle, who tried with no success to set up a meeting between Mr. Greenspan and the President to discuss problems in the banking industry.
 
Fund in Trouble
 On Friday Mr. Taylor also described the difficulties of the fund, saying in an interview that its depletion had begun to slow regulators in seizing bigger banks. At an emergency hearing yesterday, Mr. Taylor urged the lawmakers to lay aside their differences and quickly provide new money for the insurance fund.
Through this afternoon and into the evening the lawmakers haggled over the fine print of the legislation, going over it line by line in a room jammed with lobbyists representing banks, Wall Street, the insurance industry and consumers.
Other measures stripped from the Senate bill would have reduced the potential liability of lenders for environmental damage by borrowers and put a 14 percent cap on the interest rates that banks charge their credit card customers.
Since the Treasury Department issued its recommendations for a comprehensive banking overhaul in February, Congress has already rejected the proposals to permit banks to enter the insurance and securities business more freely, and to be owned by industrial enterprises. The lawmakers also rejected the Treasury's recommendations to combine four regulatory agencies into two and to put modest limits on the coverage of deposit insurance.
 
Seriousness of the Situation
 "It is shocking to me that some in Congress are only now coming to realize the seriousness of the situation," Mr. Brady wrote in a letter today to Mr. Riegle. "Fundamental reform of our banking laws, already delayed, is not a we-can-get-it-later issue."
Congressional leaders also said they expected the House and Senate to provide new money for the savings and loan bailout before Congress adjourned, although by early evening it was unclear how much would be provided and when decisive votes on a spending measure would be cast.
Key lawmakers in the Senate appeared close to an agreement that would have given the Administration the $80 billion it has requested to continue the bailout, which has already cost nearly $80 billion since it began more than two years ago.
 
Risks of Symbolism
 But in the House, a financing measure was still in question, because a wing of the Republican party, led by Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, had sought to attach what it called a broader economic stimulus package to the legislation. The Bush Administration has praised the package, and thus found itself on the verge of perhaps losing the savings and loan bailout financing for the symbolic support of a program that it knew stood no chance of being adopted today.
The lawmakers have had enormous difficulty providing new money for the unpopular program, and some members of Congress today predicted that a spending bill might not be taken up until the early hours of Wednesday morning.
Last year Congress adjourned without providing additional money for the rescue effort, but regulators received $18 billion in new financing after the Adminstration found what it said was a drafting glitch in the savings and loan legislation that permitted the additional money.
In March, the House rejected four bills before it finally approved one that provided $30 billion for the bailout.

HEADLINE: Broker to Let Soviet Citizens Trade U.S. Shares

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26

 BODY:
A brokerage firm here announced today that it had made an arrangement that would allow people in the Soviet Union to buy and sell the stocks of American companies for the first time.
The firm, Montgomery Securities, does not expect Soviet citizens to stampede to snap up shares of A.T.&T. or I.B.M. Still, by allowing Soviet investors to participate in one of the central institutions of American capitalism, experts said the agreement represented a significant step toward the development of capital markets in the Soviet Union. 
 Fledgling stock exchanges in the Soviet Union "have been reaching out to Western broker-dealers," said James L. Cochrane, chief economist and senior vice president of the New York Stock Exchange. He said that the Montgomery agreement was the first he was aware of, but that he expected others to follow.
 
Restricted to 8 Stocks
 Seth J. Gersch, chief administrative officer and a managing director of Montgomery Securities, said trading would begin this Friday and would at first be restricted to eight companies. They are A.T.&T., Apple, BankAmerica, Boeing, Compaq Computer, Hewlett-Packard, Intel and I.B.M.
Mr. Gersch said each stock had to be approved by Soviet authorities and were chosen because they were considered high-quality companies that would be familiar to people in the Soviet Union.
Under the new arrangement, Soviet citizens and institutions will be able to place orders for the American stocks with Sovlex Ltd., a two-year-old Soviet brokerage firm that has a seat on the new Moscow Central Securities Exchange. Sovlex in turn will place the orders with Montgomery Securities, which will buy and sell the securities on American exchanges and hold the stock in the United States.
Mr. Gersch said his expectations about how much trading would be done in the Soviet Union were so low that "it will be very difficult not to exceed my expectations." But the venture could give Montgomery a leg up in eventually selling Soviet securities to Americans, he said.
Dozens of stock exchanges have been springing up in the Soviet Union in the last year. The Moscow Central Securities Exchange, one of the largest, trades shares in about 20 Soviet companies, according to Benjamin Lyon, an adjunct professor of Soviet law at the University of San Francisco who first introduced Sovlex to Montgomery in September.
But trading has been slow to catch on. The concept of buying and selling stocks in the Soviet Union is new and there have been questions about the legal status of stock ownership. In addition, many of the exchanges are barely more automated than the New York Stock Exchange was 200 years ago when brokers first met under a buttonwood tree in lower Manhattan.
Since Montgomery will not accept payment in rubles, a big question is how much hard currency is available in the Soviet Union for stock purchases. Mr. Lyon said that one Soviet study estimated there was as much as $19 billion in foreign currency in the Soviet Union that people were reluctant to invest in Soviet companies.

HEADLINE: AID DONORS INSIST ON KENYA REFORMS

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 26

 BODY:
The United States and other aid-donor nations told Kenya today to introduce political and economic reforms and improvements in human rights or face major cuts in aid in six months.
The warning to the Government of President Daniel arap Moi, which has been widely accused of corruption and political repression, amounted to a rare, publicly acknowledged intervention by aid donors into the domestic political affairs of a developing nation. Governments and international lending institutions that give foreign aid usually link aid strictly to economic reforms, although political motivations are often seen behind aid programs. 
The talks took place as Mr. Moi came under growing political pressure, largely as a result of a public judicial inquiry into the 1990 slaying of Kenya's Foreign Minister, an opponent of corruption. As officials met here, Mr. Moi today ordered the arrest of two close associates who have been linked to the killing. However, Mr. Moi also suspended the public inquiry. [Page A9.]
"We sent a very strong message," said John R. Westley, a member of the American delegation and head of the Nairobi office of the Agency for International Development. "I don't think it's ever happened before -- no performance, no money in certain areas."
The 12 donor governments, which include Britain, Canada, France, Germany and Japan, criticized what they called the Moi Government's misuse of public funds. They also called for respect for human rights and backed opposition demands for greater pluralism in the one-party state.
The donor Governments said that while Kenya would continue to receive aid, they were refraining from their annual practice of making specific pledges of assistance. Instead, they imposed a stern, six-month probation period on the East African nation, linking full aid to reforms and improvements in human rights.
 
$800 Million a Year
 Donor nations and international institutions like the World Bank have given Kenya about $800 million in development aid over each of the past two years -- a figure equal to perhaps a third of the Kenyan Government's annual budget, although not all aid counts as Government budget revenue.
This fiscal year, Washington plans to grant $48 million in aid for agriculture and other economic programs, but American officials say that aid next year could be less that half that level unless reforms are forthcoming.
Kenya has long been one of the largest recipients of aid in Africa south of the Sahara because in the past the former British colony was a bright spot for economic development and political freedom in Africa. But in recent months aid donors have reconsidered their aid to Kenya as repression has grown and economic policies have stumbled.
Foreign aid is considered vital to the economically struggling country of 29 million people, which has one of the highest population growth rates in the world. In recent years the assistance has helped Kenya compensate for its chronically large external payments deficit, which in 1990 amounted to $476 million.
Over the past month, the Moi Government has arrested top opposition figures and used guns and batons to break up a pro-democracy march. Mr. Moi and close associates of his in the Government are widely believed to have become wealthy men over the years.
 
Arrest of Two Colleagues
 Two of Mr. Moi's closest associates, former Energy Minister Nicholas Biwott and and Hezekiah Oyugi, a former head of internal security, last week were publicly named in the Kenyan judicial inquiry as prime suspects in the slaying of Foreign Minister Robert Ouko, who was reportedly investigating high-level corruption. Toward the end of today's meeting, delegates learned that the two men were arrested today.
In their communique, the donor nations said, "Delegates underlined that good government is a prerequisite for equitable economic development and would therefore be a major factor influencing aid allocations."
With economic growth slowing and inflation climbing, the donor nations called for slashing the budget deficit, reforming the bloated civil service and privatizing many state enterprises. They also called on Nairobi to reduce capital flight and increase private sector confidence.
 
Consultation in Six Months
 The donor nations said that in six months they would consult again about aid to Kenya. Several delegates said they were optimistic that President Moi, facing strong pressure at home and abroad, had finally become serious about political and economic reform.
"What Kenya's partners were saying was we would like Kenya to maintain its leadership position," said Callisto Madavo, director of the World Bank's Eastern Africa Department. "We think that some of these issues that came up in the recent past could undermine that leadership. The donors are not walking away from Kenya. What the donors are saying is that a number of areas must be addressed."
Kenya's Vice President and Finance Minister, George Saitoti, said he was "very much satisfied" by the meeting, commenting that it was helpful to have a frank exchange between donor nations and Kenyan officials about its policies and problems. He also said that he was heartened that the donor nations said they would continue granting aid to his nation, even though they threatened cuts in aid.
Mr. Saitoti is among the officials named in the Kenyan judicial inquiry as having demanded bribes from foreign companies seeking business in the country.
At a news conference, Vice President Saitoti repeatedly asserted that his Government was serious about introducing a multi-party system and rooting out corruption.
"The basic point is Kenya is not opposed to transformation to a multiparty system," he said. Later he added that it was clear that the donors "want us to speed up the reforms on the political front and economic front."

HEADLINE: Transit Bill Seen as Boon to Metro Area

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26

 BODY:
With its heavy reliance on mass transit, the New York metropolitan region should be a major beneficiary of the six-year, $151 billion transportation bill nearing approval in Congress.
Although it is certain to cause temporary inconvenience, legislators from the region were ecstatic about the bill. They said it has many plums for the region and will jump start highway and mass transit construction throughout the area. 
 "Gone are the days when the mindset down here was to pave America coast to coast," said Sherwood L. Boehlert of Utica, N.Y., the senior Republican Representative from the region on the House-Senate conference committee. "Now we recognize the interconnections of all kinds of transportation. The concept of flexibility is everywhere you look."
The House and Senate are expected to approve the bill and the President is expected to sign it. The funds would begin to be available immediately since Federal transporation aid expired on Sept. 30, the end of the fiscal year.
In a radical philosophical change that should provide a major boost to mass transit, the bill ends the era in which superhighways were built to weave todether the country's regions into a nation and relegates the Federal Government to the role of a benevolent banker handing out money to the states, who are to decide how to spend it.
That will allow the region, which completed most of its interstate highway network years ago, to dedicate a greater proportion of its money to mass transit. While the bill retains Federal operating subsidies for mass transit at current levels, making a scheduled fare increase on New York City subways and buses almost certain, it almost doubles mass transit financing for capital spending, according to preliminary figures.
 
Rare Good News
 The Federal Government will also be giving much more money to New York and New Jersey for highway maintenance and construction. New York will receive $6.1 billion in the next six years, an average of $1.02 billion a year, compared with $3.647 billion in the last five years, $729.4 million a year, according to preliminary figures. That is an increase of 40.4 percent a year. New Jersey will do even better. It will receive $3.3 billion in the next six years, an average of $546.5 million a year, compared with $2.1 billion average for the last five, or $419.6 million a year, according to the preliminary statistics. That is a jump of 57 percent a year.
But Connecticut's share of Federal transportation money will fall. It will get $2 billion in the next six years, or an average of $333 million a year, compared with $1.9 billion in the last five years, an average of $390.4 million. That is a 14.7 percent drop.
Legislators emphasized that the figures released today provide little more than a basis for comparison with financing from previous years.
The bill is one of the few pieces of good news for a region buffeted by the recession and state budget gaps, which are forcing sharp cutbacks in services and thousands of layoffs. The first major rewrite of the country's highway program in 35 years, the legislation is expected to create thousands of jobs and should touch every family in the country, helping to set everything from the price of bread to real-estate values.
"Transportation is the bedrock of the economy; it's where everything starts and ends," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who is credited by legislators from both parties with masterminding much of the legislation.
New York State will also receive $5.9 billion over the six years for mass transit, an average of $983 million a year, compared with $2.8 billion in the last five years, or $550 million a year.
"It's great for New York," said Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York. "It brings in big-time dollars and that means real jobs. This is bringing home the bacon and not the baloney."
Connecticut officials were as jubilant as their counterparts in New York and Jersey. Legislators said the decline was deceptive since the state delayed spending on the interstate program. They said the bill gives Connecticut $1.70 for every $1 it sends here in fuel taxes and that the amount it receives in apportionments would jump to $2 billion in the next six years.
"We did wonderfully," said Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut. "It's big money in tough times. It will produce lots of jobs. It's good medicine."


GRAPHIC: Besides general road and rail maintenance and upgrading work, the region's three states plan to use some of the money to be provided by the Federal transportation bill nearing approval in Congress yesterday for major projects. Here are some projects to be wholly or partly financed by the new Federal money.
 
NEW YORK
 
WIDEN LONG ISLAND EXPRESSWAY: Add a fourth lane in each direction in Nassau and western Suffolk counties.
 
REBUILD GOWANUS EXPRESSAY: Major rehabilitation in Brooklyn and Queens, including road resurfacing and viaduct work.
 
NEW IND SUBWAY LINK: Exjtend the 63d Street Tunnel, which carries the B and Q trains from Manhattan to Roosevelt Island before ending at 21st Street in Long Island City, Queens, to a new connection with the E and F lines near Queens Plaza.
 
NEW JERSEY
 
NEW RAIL TRANSFER HUBS: In Secaucus, a new hub station to allow transfers among five North Jersey rail line. In Kearny, a new track connection allowing trains from several additional lines to be routed directly to Penn Station. Currently the lines end at Hoboken, where riders must switch to PATH trains to cross the Hudson.
 
WATERFRONT TRANSIT LINE: A trolley and bus line along the Hudson waterfront from Edgewater to Bayonne.
 
HUDSON TRUCK ROUTES: Improved routes for the trucks that haul goods between rail terminals along the Hudson for shipment onto New York and New England.
 
CONNECTICUT
 
ROUTE 384 EXTENSION: Add 11 miles to Interstate 384 in Eastern Connecticut, from where it new ends in Bolton to a point near Willimantic, where it would connect with U.S. Route 6.
 
WIDEN I-95 AND ROUTE 1: Add capacity to both main roads serving the crowded coastal corridor in southwestern Connecticut, indluding high-occupancy vehicle lanes on the interstate.
 
UPGRADE METRO NORTH LINES: Station and track upgrades on the Metro North comuter railroad main line and branches in Connecticut.

HEADLINE: Compromise Is Reached on $151 Billion Bill Revising U.S. Transit Financing

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26

 BODY:
House and Senate negotiators today unanimously endorsed a compromise on a transportation bill and said it was likely to have the support of big majorities in both chambers.
The Bush Administration also endorsed the bill, which is to provide $151 billion over six years: $119 billion for highway programs and $32 billion for mass transportation. 
 The breakthrough to a compromise, after what one participant called "a war of attrition" lasting two weeks, came when lawmakers who had been holding out for more money for their states accepted provisions guaranteeing every state a share of the transportation money equal to at least 90 percent of the Federal fuel taxes collected in that state.
In some cases, that meant that members of the conference committee shifted big blocks of money to one state or another. For example, it appears that Florida won an additional $300 million at the insistence of Senator Bob Graham, a Democrat. It is unclear which states were the losers in this particular shift.
The negotiating and trading were necessary because under Senate rules any senator could have blocked a vote on the bill long enough to thwart the leadership's goal of passage before the Thanksgiving recess.
 
How Money Will Be Allocated
 Of the bill's $151 billion total, $114 billion is to be apportioned among the states using complex formulas involving highway mileage, population, gasoline consumption and other factors. But the negotiators found it nearly impossible to devise formulas that would satisfy the necessary number of lawmakers in each house, and in the end they resorted to making bonus grants to a number of states.
Of the $114 billion to be handed out under the bill's highway allocation formulas, $6.1 billion is for New York State, putting it behind only California at $10.5 billion and Texas at $7.1 billion. New Jersey is to get $3.3 billion, and Connecticut $2 billion.
But the New York City metropolitan region will also be a major beneficiary of mass transportation grants that are not governed by the highway formulas. The bill nearly doubles the rate of transit spending nationally, to $32 billion over six years. How that money breaks down by state is not yet known.
The bill's eventual approval had been foretold Monday, mainly because members viewed it as an economic stimulus.
"This is a jobs bill as well as a transportation bill," said Representative John Paul Hammerschmidt, Republican of Arkansas.
But it took all night to massage the dollar figures from complex financing formulas so that its acceptance could be insured.
 
Praise From Administration
 Some refinements in the bill's language were still being made today, before the measure was sent to the floor of the House and then to the Senate.
Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner praised the legislation. "Although this piece of legislation was long overdue, Congressional leaders from both parties deserve credit for passing a win-win compromise," he said.
Secretary Skinner said most of the Administration's main ideas were included in the final bill, if not in the exact form originally proposed. But he conceded that the Administration lost on some points, including its early insistence that the states pay a greater share of transportation costs.
"We lost that because the states are broke," Mr. Skinner said. "Had I known how broke the states were going to be, I might not have been as aggressive."
Federal aid to states for highways and mass transit expired Sept. 30, the end of the last fiscal year, and since then contractors for state projects have begun to lay off thousands of construction workers.
The new legislation departs from transportation programs of the past 40 years, the era that saw the construction of the Interstate highway system, by giving states vastly more flexibility in deciding whether to spend Federal money on highways or on mass transit. The bill also gives much more discretion on spending to local governments. In the past, such aid has been earmarked in Washington for one purpose or the other.
 
Aid for Air Quality
 The bill is also expected to give states $6 billion that will be specifically intended to ease congestion and help meet air quality standards established by the 1990 clean air law.
It includes $24 billion in one fund that can be used entirely for transit or highways, as each state sees fit, and most of this money must be spent in major metropolitan areas, where the cities will have the power to decide how the money is to be used.
William J. Roberts, legislative director of the Environmental Defense Fund, termed the legislation "a strong environmental bill and a strong energy bill, too."
"Congress finally put a stop to the backward policy that penalized states for using transit and other programs that conserve energy," he said. "Congress finally broke the highway interests' stranglehold on transportation funding."
Of the $151 billion total, $32 billion is for mass transit, nearly doubling the annual amount available for these purposes. There are new transit projects planned in many locales around the country, including Los Angeles, New York, Chicago, Portland, Ore., Northern California and New Jersey.
The bill also promises to pay for technological innovations, like $500 million for high-speed trains that would ride on magnetic cushions rather than steel wheels, a favorite project of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York. It will also finance "smart" cars and highways equipped with computers to help speed the flow of traffic, a $660 million project backed by Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey.
Safety provisions in the bill will make big differences in automobile design, including airbags for both drivers and front-seat passengers in new cars beginning with the 1998 model year.

HEADLINE: Without Wife at Side, He Loses Zest for Job

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 21

 BODY:
It started as a summertime romance between two college kids in the 1950's. He was working on the Oakland waterfront tossing boxes in a warehouse; she was keypunching computer cards in the office. He thought she was "cute."
They married in 1958 and ultimately rose to the top of the University of California, he as president of the nine-campus system, she as the official associate of the president, his constant companion in all matters private and official. 
 But last Feb. 8 when Libby Gardner, 55 years old, died of a rare bone cancer and the congestive heart failure it caused, the process of leaving one of the most prestigious posts in higher education began for David P. Gardner. On Nov. 14, after nine months of grieving, he announced he could no longer serve as president without the woman he loved.
"This job as an all-consuming position," he said in an interview a week later in the 22d-floor office near downtown Oakland from which he oversees the 166,000-student university. "I cannot find my way clear to reconstruct my life, to rebuild it, as long as I'm doing this job. What I am now doing alone, we had been doing together. And it's not the same thing."
He said he had not made any plans except that he wanted to remain active in education.
 
Rebuilt University
 The 58-year-old Mr. Gardner is widely credited with having rebuilt the university after about 15 years of suffering at the hands of governors and legislators resentful of its role in antiwar and other protests. He will leave office next Oct. 1 with the university once again in financial crisis, but this time because of recession.
"As I leave, there is not an unwillingness to fund it, but an incapacity to fund it," he said. "So even though we are confronting some perilous fiscal waters, it is for a completely different set of reasons."
He proudly catalogued his accomplishments since 1983: the university recovered just about all the state support it lost under Governors Ronald Reagan and Edmund G. Brown Jr.; faculty salaries, which had dropped to 16 percent below those at similar universities, are now comparable again; the construction of $3.7 billion in new buildings; plans started for a 10th campus, in the San Joaquin Valley; an expanded education-abroad program, and a broadening of access to students from historically underrepresented minority groups. There were also conflicts, like his losing battle against the regents' insistence on divesting the university's stocks in companies doing business in South Africa.
His job is not to administer the campuses, which enjoy considerable academic autonomy under local chancellors, but to protect the system politically and deal with political leaders. If his style seems a little remote, imperial and moralistic to some, none can deny that Mr. Gardner is one of the most powerful university presidents in the land. He earns $243,500, which makes him by far the highest paid state official in California; he oversees a budget of more than $6 billion a year.
A moderate conservative politically, he is widely regarded as extraordinarily adept at the intricacies of California politics. Polished, unflappable and analytical, Mr. Gardner speaks extemporaneously as though he had written it all down and carefully edited his words.
"He is about as good at running big complex institutions as anybody I've ever seen," said Ira Michael Heyman, until recently chancellor of the flagship Berkeley campus, who had a number of disagreements with the president.
Mr. Heyman, now a professor of law at Berkeley, said he had sensed that Mr. Gardner would quit six months ago, when the president came to his home for dinner and discussed his mourning. "It's a very tough job to do all by yourself," Mr. Heyman said.
The job is likely to get tougher. The university's share of the state budget is declining, and its implied promise to accept the top eighth of all California high school graduates is in jeopardy, as are Mr. Gardner's efforts to expand access to minority students. Mr. Gardner said he had decided to stay on until October because he regarded the upcoming budget year as crucial, not one for a new president "unacquainted with the key players, issues and eccentric politics of California."
 
At His Side
 In all his jobs, Mr. Gardner was accompanied by Elizabeth Fuhriman Gardner, who worked as dental hygienist in Berkeley until the first of their four daughters arrived. His jobs, as a vice chancellor at the Santa Barbara campus, as president of the University of Utah and now at California, all involved of public relations and travel, and Libby Gardner was usually at his side.
"Instead of going off at night by myself, we would be together," he said. "We found it to be a very attractive set of employment conditions that caused us to come together rather than be pulled apart because of the demands of the position."
In 1987, the university conferred on Libby Gardner a new title, associate of the president, an unpaid position that recognized her supportive role. Numerous other universities followed suit, recognizing the supportive function of the spouses of their presidents.
After his wife's death in February, Mr. Gardner spent most of May in Asia on a mission for the Asia Foundation, hoping that the time away would help him recover. But he returned home to the empty house in Orinda, and matters did not improve.
He said he did not make his decision until Nov. 9, when he was in Hawaii for the dedication of the university's new Keck Telescope on the Mauna Kea volcano. After the dedication on the chilly peak, he returned to his hotel, suffering from a bad case of influenza, and wrote his letter of resignation. The words reflected his deep Mormon faith in an afterlife:
"Death has now dissolved our partnership, at least for this life, although according to our faith not forever; and it has become clearer with each passing month since Libby's death that without her I cannot remain as president of the University of California."

HEADLINE: Veteran Strategist and Outsiders' Champion Shows Up in Brown Campaign

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 26

 BODY:
They are the political odd couple of the year: Edmund G. Brown Jr., the ascetic former Governor of California who recently completed a seven-year sabbatical from politics, and Patrick H. Caddell, the political strategist who has made a career of trying to ride alienated outsiders to victory over the establishment and who also appears to be trying to make a political comeback after several years of self-imposed exile.
Mr. Brown, Jerry to friends, kicked off his third bid for the Presidency on Oct. 21 with an iconoclastic declaration that America was in decline, a blast at the two main political parties and greedy, corrupt politics and a pledge not to accept campaign contributions larger than $100. With him that day at Independence Hall in Philadelphia was the imposing bearded figure of Mr. Caddell, a man widely credited with devising a similar outsider strategy that Jimmy Carter used to gain the White House 15 years ago. 
 When Mr. Brown, a Democrat, announced in September that he was exploring a possible Presidential bid, Mr. Caddell said in an interview: "My role is nothing. I am a friend of his. I will never be a political consultant again."
 
An Increasing Role
 But since then, Mr. Caddell's role has appeared to be larger and larger. He often travels with the candidate, told reporters in Philadelphia that he helped craft the announcement speech, and helped arrange visits with potential supporters on a recent visit by Mr. Brown to the Boston area. And he gave to Mr. Brown a political treatise that has played a significant role in what Mr. Brown calls "our insurgent campaign to take back America."
The 145-page treatise was written in September by Richard N. Goodwin, a former speech writer and confidant of Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson who is an old friend of Mr. Caddell. Titled "From the Concord Bridge: A Declaration," the unpublished document calls for a new movement to arrest what Mr. Goodwin saw as growing unfairness, political corruption, economic class divisions and "our slow descent from greatness."
In announcing his candidacy, Mr. Brown took significant passages verbatim from the Goodwin essay and paraphrased others without mentioning the source. They were part of a much longer speech that included other themes apparently not drawn from the Goodwin document.
Interviewed Sunday at his home in Concord, Mass., Mr. Goodwin said he did not know that Mr. Brown had used some of his words, but that he was pleased the candidate had given them wider currency.
"That's fine," he said. "I have to admit I'm delighted." Mr. Brown spent a night at Mr. Goodwin's home on the recent visit to Boston.
Mr. Goodwin said that earlier this year he had spent a few hours discussing his ideas with Mr. Brown.
 
'Thelma and Louise'
 The Brown-Goodwin connection underscores the guiding role of Mr. Caddell. He said that he has known Mr. Brown since 1974, but that he had grown increasingly close to him in the last year and a half as Mr. Brown at first announced his candidacy for a Unites States Senate seat, then dropped that in September to explore a Presidential bid.
Political commentators have dubbed them the "Thelma and Louise" of politics, an allusion to the film about two rebellious and self-destructive women.
The 53-year-old Mr. Brown, son of another California Governor, Edmund G. Brown, served from 1975 to 1983 and made two failed stabs at the Democratic Presidential nomination, in 1976 and 1980. He lost a Senate race in 1982. He then withdrew from politics, studying Zen Buddhism in Japan and working with Mother Teresa in India. He returned as chairman of the California Democratic Party in 1989, raising millions of dollars from the political fat cats he now denounces.
His is a grass roots campaign aimed at energizing average people and capitalizing on a perceived alienation from the political system. On television and radio talk shows he urges people to call a toll-free 800 number to pledge $100 each -- one-tenth the legal limit for individuals -- and volunteer their time.
 
A Professional Outsider
 If the outsider role is somewhat new to Mr. Brown, it is not to Mr. Caddell. Many who know him say he is a professional outsider and critic of the establishment. "It's always death to tyrants, down with the walls, burn and pillage," said John Gorman, a former business partner. "He's always wanted to have the French Revolution at his doorstep."
After Mr. Carter's loss in 1980, Mr. Caddell tried to ride two other Presidential horses, former Senator Gary Hart of Colorado and Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, but they both went lame. By 1987, the assertive and often abrasive consultant had fallen out with many of his associates and he moved from Washington to California to go into television and film production, swearing off politics.
In an interview today, the 41-year-old Mr. Caddell said he remained only an unpaid adviser to Mr. Brown but left open the possibility of a more formal role. "I've give Jerry some advice as a friend," he said. "I've given the campaign some ideas, information, advice. That's the way I would define it.
"I don't do politics professionally any more. If I support a candidate I do it as an individual. If that situation were to change, I will say something. My dilemma is that I feel very strong about the message Jerry Brown is speaking. I am reluctant about the political combat. I understand what this business is about and the prospect of being more deeply involved that I had envisioned carries all the trepidation of going off the wagon. I'm a friend for the moment. That leaves the door ajar because it does not say. It implies that maybe something will alter, maybe not."
Mr. Caddell has the reputation of casting a Svengali-like spell over candidates with his forceful personality and keen intellect. But Mr. Brown's associates say they doubt that the intellectual Mr. Brown can so easily be controlled. Nathan Gardels, a former economics adviser to him as Governor, said that Mr. Brown deeply felt the alienation that he is expressing.
Joe Costello, Mr. Brown's press spokesman, played down the Caddell role. "Pat is a friend of the candidate," he said. "He has no official title within the campaign." He said Mr. Brown wrote his own speeches.
Requests for interview of Mr. Brown placed through both Mr. Costello and Mr. Caddell got no response.
The connection with Mr. Goodwin is a curious political twist. Widely regarded in his youth as a political thinker, Mr. Goodwin served as a speech writer and adviser to Presidents Kennedy and Johnson. He later went on to teach at Harvard University, where Mr. Caddell went to college.
 
A Cry for Change
 The treatise Mr. Brown used is to be published by Times Books, a subsidiary of Random House. He said he had sent drafts to a number of political leaders, including Governor Mario M. Cuomo of New York and Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, a Democratic candidate for President.
The document amounts to an anguished cry over the state of the American political economy. For nearly a quarter of a century, he wrote, the basic American precept of opportunity and the chance to better oneself has been seriously eroded. "Instead increasing numbers of Americans must struggle to maintain what they have already achieved. And for many it is a losing battle," he wrote.
Strong echoes, some verbatim, of the Goodwin treatise can be found in the words of Mr. Brown. In his Oct. 21 speech, Mr. Brown stressed the "whirlwind of decline" facing America and denounced "an unholy alliance of private greed and corrupt politics."
"In reality, there is only one party: It's the Incumbent Party," Mr. Brown told his audience in front of Independence Hall, in one section that closely matched the Goodwin essay. "There are, of course, two major political organizations with different names, but at their core they are the same. They share the same world view and they serve the power of the same private interests."
Mr. Goodwin wrote: "The reality is that we no longer have a two-party system. There is only one: It is the Washington Party. There are, of course, two major political organizations with different names. But, with several honorable exceptions, members of both parties gratefully receive huge sums from the same corporate and individual oligarchy, serve the same interests."
 
Similar on Ideology
 There were also similarities on the question of the lack of partisan ideology. "When there are no substantial differences, there is no choice to be made," Mr. Brown said. "And without choices, there is no democracy."
Mr. Goodwin's essay said: "For without substantial divisions of ideology, there is no choice to be made. And without choice there is no democracy."
Mr. Brown does not appear to have adopted the full message of the Goodwin essay. The essay was far more radical than Mr. Brown's speech, calling, for instance, on the United States to erect protectionist barriers to shield its economy from foreign competition.
Mr. Caddell expressed anger that the similarities with the essay would figure in a news account. "Tell me one candidate who writes every word himself," he said. "Jerry Brown came up with this campaign. He is responsible for his own ideas. To suggest that he is not genuine about this is an outrage."
He demanded that other candidates' messages be given similar scrutiny. "If that is the level of concern, will it be applied to every other candidate, or it is a selective concern?" he asked.

HEADLINE: Son, Stepdaughter, 3 Others Held in Sergeant's Killing

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELVIDERE, N.J., Nov. 26

 BODY:
Five people, including a son and stepdaughter, were charged today with murder and conspiracy in the ambush slaying of a campus police sergeant outside his home on a country road in rural Allamuchy Township Saturday night.
The Warren County prosecutor, Richard C. Hare, said the five had plotted to kill the sergeant, Revell Quince, a 43-year-old shift supervisor on the police force at the New Jersey Institute of Technology in Newark, because in the 1980's he had been accused of sexually and physically abusing his stepdaughter, Cynthia Gregory, a 22-year-old supermarket cashier. 
 State officials, including the Division of Youth and Family Services, investigated Ms. Gregory's charges at the time, but were unable to substantiate them, said Lieut. Gary P. Dundon, a detective on Mr. Hare's staff, and no charges were brought against Sergeant Quince. Neither Lieutenant Dundon nor Mr. Hare would comment further.
 
Half-Brother Charged
 Besides Ms. Gregory, those charged today were her half-brother, William Quince, 20, a mailroom clerk; her boyfriend, Donald A. Lucas, 24, of Columbia, N.J., a foreman at a muffler shop; his brother, Jeffrey Lucas, 18, of Columbia, who is unemployed, and Brian C. Bastedo, 24, of Mount Bethel, Pa., who is also unemployed. Mr. Bastedo was identified as a boyfriend of Sergeant Quince's other stepdaughter, Susan Ahart. Ms. Ahart was not charged.
William Quince, Cynthia Gregory and Susan Ahart are the children of Mr. Quince's first wife. His current wife, who was at home at the time of the killing, is Diane Quince.
Christopher Quince, an 18-year-old son of the sergeant who was shot in the foot during the attack, presumably as his father tried to defend himself, also was not charged.
The five suspects were arrested at about 11 P.M. Monday after extensive questioning, the investigators said.
 
Second-Hand Rifle
 Mr. Hare said the five purchased a second-hand .308 rifle for $206 and a used .32-caliber handgun for $205 at a gun store in East Bangor, Pa., a few weeks ago.
Mr. Hare said Jeffrey Lucas, the gunman in the plot, hid with the rifle in a rocky outcropping 50 yards from the Quince home, waiting two hours for Sergeant Quince to return from work. As the sergeant approached his front door, he was shot three times.
Mr. Lucas then fled in a car driven by Mr. Bastedo, Mr. Hare said, and returned to the Lucas home, where the other three suspects were waiting. The five then devised an alibi, he said, and threw the rifle and two spent shell casings into the Paulinskill River near Columbia.
He also said the five, using the same plan, had attempted to ambush Sergeant Quince at his home on Oct. 25, but the rifle failed to fire because of a broken firing pin.
This morning, State Police divers recovered the rifle from 15 feet of water in the Paulinskill River, Mr. Hare said.

HEADLINE: Do Arrests Increase the Rates Of Repeated Domestic Violence?

BYLINE: By DANIEL GOLEMAN

 BODY:
WHEN the police arrest men who are assaulting their wives or lovers, it can sometimes lead to more attacks once the men are released, according to a major new study of domestic violence.
The new findings suggest that factors in the men's lives, like whether they have jobs, affect the likelihood that they will strike again. As a result, the findings call into question the current wisdom among criminologists, that arresting their attackers is the best way to protect battered women from further violence. The findings also challenge the effectiveness of recent laws in 15 states and the District of Columbia that require arrests in all cases of domestic battery. 
 But experts cautioned against wholesale legislative changes based on the new research. Some said the new findings suggested that lawmakers had moved too quickly after earlier research.
 
Role of Joblessness
 Those law changes were based on an influential 1983 study showing that arrests helped ease domestic violence. But the new findings, from 1,200 cases of domestic violence in Milwaukee, show that arrested men who were unemployed were 44 percent more likely to assault their mates during the year after being released from jail than were men who had jobs. The rate was 750 repeat assaults per thousand unemployed men and only 503 assaults per 1,000 employed men.
But among those who had jobs, being arrested led to a 16 percent lower rate of violence toward their mates over the course of the year. The rate was 599 repeat assaults per 1,000 men after a warning and 503 repeat assaults per 1,000 after an arrest.
"The evidence forces us to confront the fact that mandatory arrests in domestic violence cases may cause more violence against women in the long run," said Lawrence W. Sherman, a criminologist at the University of Maryland, who led both the current research and the 1983 study.
"In communities with high unemployment, the net effect of an arrest policy is more violence," Dr. Sherman said. "But in cities where there is little unemployment, arrests should lead to an overall decrease in domestic violence." He said police officers who intervene should have more flexibility in deciding whether to warn or arrest the offender, to have the man leave for several hours or to take the victim to a safe place.
Violence from men is a major cause of death and injury for American women. In about one-third of killings of woman, the killer is her spouse or boyfriend, said James Mercy, an epidemiologist at the Federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. Homicide is the leading cause of death among black women from 15 to 34 years old, and the fourth leading cause of death among white women in that age range.
The Milwaukee study found that a woman had a 7 percent chance of being assaulted again immediately after the police left if they did not make an arrest and a 2 percent chance of being attacked by the man as soon as he returned from jail if he was arrested.
But the protective effects of arrests do not last long. Within two months of an incident of domestic violence, there was no difference in the rate of assaults between men who had been arrested and those who had only received a warning. And for men who were out of work, over the course of the following year they were 12 percent more likely to repeat the violence if they had been arrested than if they had only been warned.
"It sometimes may be better to have the woman leave the house in police custody and go to a relative's home or safe house where the suspect can't find her while he's angry," Dr. Sherman said. "But it's not always necessary or advisable to arrest the man to protect the woman."
Forensic experts have been uneasy about the substantial impact the 1983 study had in changing arrest laws in domestic violence.
"It's always premature to base a legal policy on a single study," said Dr. Albert J. Reiss Jr., a sociologist at Yale University who is chairman of the National Academy of Sciences panel on violent behavior. "If the mandatory arrest laws have a negative effect, it's a good reason to go back to discretion of local jurisdictions."
Dr. Sherman said he believed his 1983 study showed that arresting men who are assaulting their mates decreased later violence because it was done in Minneapolis, which at the time had a very low rate of unemployment.
The new findings are from one of six studies set in motion by the Justice Department in an attempt to verify the findings of the 1983 Minneapolis experiment.
In all the studies, the response of police officers to calls of "moderate" domestic violence, where there was no severe injuries, varied at random on whether they arrested or warned the man involved. Researchers later interviewed the victims and tracked police reports to see whether the man repeated the violence.
Studies in Omaha and Charlotte, N.C., whose results were announced last year, did not find that arrests had a deterrent effect in domestic violence. But when Dr. Sherman and colleagues later re-analyzed the Omaha data for the effects of employment, they found that arrests lowered rates of later violence for men with jobs, but not for the unemployed.
Other experts in criminology, however, are more skeptical about the new study's implications, saying it may be premature once again to change laws based on one or two research findings. "I'm not willing to say what conclusions you should draw until I can examine the findings from all six studies," said Dr. James Q. Wilson, a sociologist at University of California at Los Angeles, who is chairman of the Police Foundation, a private research organization in Washington.
"There are so many reasons you can be unemployed that I can't see why a grab-bag category like that would have a particular effect," Dr. Wilson said. "It might have to do with a hidden factor, like impulsivity. The whole question needs more careful study before the policy implications are clear."

HEADLINE: Is a Turkey Forgotten A Turkey Forgone?

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
THANKSGIVING doesn't exactly come as a surprise. It is always near the end of November, and always on a Thursday. But for some reason, a lot of people don't know until the very last minute -- like tonight -- what they will be doing or whom they will be doing it with.
Maybe there are so many Thanksgiving procrastinators because it's so easy to put off planning for the holiday. It's not like Christmas. You don't have to run around and buy gifts for people you rarely see or barely know. With Thanksgiving, you can decide at the last minute to celebrate, and you don't even have to cook. This is definitely why restaurants were invented. 
 More than any other holiday, Thanksgiving has remained uncommercial and true to a certain limited goal: to give thanks and eat. And for most people, it is a time to be with family. But eating isn't always so simple, and families rarely are.
"I'm absolutely terrified of being sucked into any family arrangement," said Corinna Harmon, who lives in New York near many of her relatives. "I get claustrophobic. You are expected to stay inside or go for a military walk. Then you are expected to eat at a time you've never eaten. Then you make yourself sick. Then you're so upset at how much you ate that you get drunk. And then you have a hangover. And somebody always expresses disapproval of somebody's husband."
It's not that she doesn't like her relatives. "I think they're all great," she said. "I like to visit them any other day of the year." But on Thanksgiving, she said, "too many dynamics are floating around." Over the years, she and her husband have trained their relatives not to invite them, though they have the option to show up at the last minute. They rarely do. Tomorrow, she will probably go to a movie, or maybe a Japanese restaurant.
But procrastination doesn't always stem from fear of family. A woman who works as a secretary in a Manhattan publishing house, and who insisted that her name not be used, said she and her boyfriend would like to have a traditional Thanksgiving, but they live in New York and the relatives and friends they really like all live far away. She said she finds that sad but, seeming not at all sad, she pointed out that "it's the post-modern malaise."
The woman, who wanted anonymity to avoid insulting the relatives who do live nearby, said she and her boyfriend would probably rent a car and go for a drive. "The question is where," she said. Going to a restaurant for turkey is out.
"We were at P. J. Clarke's last year," she said. "It was very depressing. Just the idea of paying for this family meal . . ." Cooking is out, too. "I wouldn't know how to," she said. "I would be completely overwhelmed."
She is not alone in being intimidated by Thanksgiving cooking. Most people, in fact, don't make their own turkey. Seventy-five percent of Americans will eat turkey on Thanksgiving, but only one in four households will actually prepare it, said Harry Balzer, who studies eating habits for the NPD Group, a market research company in Chicago. "The moral of the story is be a guest," Mr. Balzer said.
Everybody knows that someone, somewhere, is probably cooking a dinner, and that if they wait long enough, the right invitation will come. Arline Bronzaft, a professor of psychology at the City University of New York who has studied motivation, said procrastinators are often actually quite efficient, because they have discovered a clever way for someone else to take care of a problem. "It gets resolved because somebody else steps in and does it," she said.
That's exactly what Paul Wachtel is waiting for. Although not by nature a procrastinator, he decided this year that he didn't want to cook for Thanksgiving because he had just given a big birthday party for a relative. In the past, he said, his mother has offered to have him and his wife and daughter for Thanksgiving, and he has always said: "Oh no. Come to our place." Strangely, his mother hasn't made the offer this year.
"We've been waiting for her to ask and she hasn't said a word," said Mr. Wachtel, an economist who teaches at the New York University graduate school of business. If his mother doesn't come through, what will he do?
"That's a good question."
His 4-year-old daughter, Rachel, knows Thanksgiving is coming and expects to celebrate. "If my mother doesn't come through in the clutch," he said, "we'll have to do something for her."
Even for those who don't have a Thanksgiving tradition, the holiday can be a wistful time. Nina Newby is a native, but she was reared in New York by her grandparents, who were European immigrants. "They didn't celebrate Thanksgiving," she said. "It's always a weird time. You know the world is out there, doing something."
Slavko Slavov is from Bulgaria, but he said he considers Thanksgiving one of the best holidays. "You give thanks for being alive and healthy, all together," he said. But he has no family in this country. Although he is occasionally invited to someone's house, he usually doesn't go. "I feel like I'm a stranger," he said. "This is a family holiday."
So today, just as he did last year, he will probably call some friends and organize an impromptu Thanksgiving at a restaurant.
Even natives who have been dedicated followers of the rites become exhausted with the process. After years of cooking huge meals, with six or seven pies to top them off, Gloria Nicholson is finished with Thanksgiving. Her four children are grown and scattered all over the world.
Mrs. Nicholson, a homemaker in Queens, doesn't know exactly what she will do on Thanksgiving, but it will probably be something very quiet, like fixing a Cornish hen and having dinner with her husband. "After you do one thing for 20 years," she said, "you want something different."
This year, Lexann Richter definitely wanted to avoid days of cooking and crowds of people in her Manhattan apartment. "I'm pregnant, so I thought I'd give myself a break," she said. Ms. Richter and her husband decided to go away to an old inn in some quaint place like Nantucket or Sag Harbor, L.I. "We would tiptoe down this lovely staircase to a wonderful dinner someone else had cooked," she said.
But when they called around last week, "every place was closed for the season or fully booked," she said. Anxiously, she began querying her friends, but they turned up no appealing last-minute possibilities; one friend, in fact, was planning to have Chinese food.
Yesterday morning, growing desperate, she called the inns again, hoping for cancellations. There were none. Then, she said with the glee that every procrastinator knows, "a friend called out of the blue."
 
Fast Food It's Not, but Fast Enough
ALTHOUGH a Thanksgiving dinner usually requires hours in the kitchen, it is possible to make a good meal quickly. The menu might include turkey, stuffing, fresh cranberry sauce, sweet potatoes mashed with a little milk, frozen peas and a store-bought pumpkin pie. Shopping and cooking takes two hours or less. It may not be fancy -- we're not talking chutney or fresh roasted chestnuts -- but it will be tasty and traditional, and custom made for the most time-defying procrastinator.
 
The Turkey
 Buy a fresh turkey with a thermometer already embedded in the flesh. Most supermarkets have them. The thermometer simply pops up when the turkey is done. Cook the turkey at 325 degrees. Don't be foolish and decide to trust the clock instead of the thermometer. Check the turkey often. A nine-pound turkey was supposed to take three hours. The thermometer popped up 45 minutes earlier than expected, but the turkey was perfect. To double-check with a meat thermometer, insert into the thigh without touching the bone. The Federal Government recommends a temperature of 180 degrees to insure against salmonella growth.
 
Cranberry Sauce
(Adapted from an Ocean Spray cranberry package)
 
Total time: 20 minutes
 
 1 cup sugar
 1 cup water
 1 bag fresh cranberries, washed.
1. Put the water and sugar in a medium-size pan and bring to a boil.
2. Add the cranberries and bring back to a boil.
3. Reduce heat and simmer 10 minutes.
4. Let cool at room temperature. If there is time, refrigerate before serving. If not, don't worry.
Yield: 2 1/4 cups
 
Quick Stuffing
(Adapted from "Thanksgiving Dinner," by Anthony Dias Blue and Kathryn K. Blue; HarperCollins, 1990)
 
Total time: 20 minutes
 
 1 tablespoon unsalted butter
 1/2 cup diced onion
 1/2 cup diced celery
 1 teaspoon dried sage
 Pinch dried rosemary
 1 cup water
 5 cups crisp, dry bread cubes.
1. Melt butter in a skillet. Add the onion and saute 1 minute. Add the celery, sage and rosemary; saute 2 minutes. Add the water and bring to a simmer over medium heat. Cook 5 minutes.
2. Remove vegetables from the skillet with a slotted spoon. Set aside. Raise the heat and boil the liquid about 1 minute.
3. In a large bowl combine the cooked vegetables with the bread cubes. Spoon the liquid from the skillet over the mixture and toss gently.
4. Loosely stuff the cavity of the turkey and cook as above.
Yield: Six cups, or enough for a turkey weighing 8 to 10 pounds.

HEADLINE: LACKING SUPPORT, DEMOCRATS GIVE UP ON CRIME MEASURE

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26

 BODY:
House leaders abandoned an anti-crime bill Tuesday night in the face of President Bush's veto threat. And even though negotiators reached an agreement on a transportation bill and neared one on keeping the bank insurance fund afloat, House Democrats discussed extending the session into next month.
Speaker Thomas S. Foley said the House Committee on Ways and Means would hold hearings on tax proposals next week. He said it had not been decided whether the entire House would come back to work in December. 
 Mr. Bush's threat that he would veto the crime bill because it was not tough enough left it crippled, without support from House Republicans. Moreover, backing from enough Democrats to pass it was not available because of defections by liberals who disliked its death penalties, Southern conservatives who agreed with Mr. Bush and opponents of its handgun control provisions. Lacking the votes, House leaders would not bring up the bill.
 
Uncertain Schedule
 On the banking legislation, negotiators appeared to lose steam during the night after considerable progress during the day. They had scrapped provisions to ease interstate banking, the last of the changes in fundamental banking law the Administration has been seeking all year as it sought to strengthen the industry. They agreed to do little more than increase the credit line of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which insures deposits and is nearly insolvent. [Article, Page D1.]
House Republican pressure to force a vote on tax cuts, which they said would stimulate economic growth, led to the uncertainty about whether Congress would adjourn before dawn today, as it had planned. Seeing an opportunity to make some political capital of their own, Democrats met for more than an hour late Tuesday night, discussing the advantages of a counter-offensive on tax cuts for the middle-class.
 
Senate Recesses
 The difficulty of getting all details of essential bills settled was also a factor in the delay. But Senate leaders from both parties publicly urged the House to finish its work and send the bills to the Senate so both bodies could leave for the year by morning.
They displayed much less interest than did House leaders in any December session. Shortly after midnight, the Senate recessed until morning, when it expected some legislation to have arrived from the House, starting with a $7.5 billion catchall spending bill, which included aid for the Soviet Union. That was the first bill on the House floor early today, with the transportation measure expected to follow.
The transportation bill, a six-year, $151 billion measure that would increase state leeway in spending decisions and double Federal spending on mass transit, made more progress than the banking bill. House and Senate conferees announced agreement Tuesday afternoon, and the Bush Administration endorsed their compromise.
At the Capitol Tuesday, the atmosphere was disordered and cranky, as if the Congress seemed bent on displaying in what it hoped was its last night all the major flaws, from fragmentation to bitter partisanship, that had dogged it after the heady days of January when it had voted to let President Bush make war on Iraq.
For most of what lawmakers had hoped would be a windup session, the pace was deadly slow. But they also moved quickly at times to finish work on an issue like extended unemployment benefits, that had taken four months of sharp debate, in a matter of minutes with voice votes in both chambers. They also handled bills dealing with Medicaid, a park in the California desert and enhanced trade status for China.
There was a note of frustration, especially in the House. Mr. Foley had told one Democrat a few days ago, "We're not going to leave with these guys shooting at our heels." A daylong series of skirmishes with Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip, over adding tax cuts to a bill providing more money for the savings and loan bailout, which most leaders considered essential, plainly left him under fire. Democrats said it would be a mistake to leave town for two months and give Mr. Bush and the Republicans the chance to attack them unhindered.
But Mr. Bush's Tuesday morning endorsement of the Gingrich plan also gave them a sense of political opportunity. After he said, "Put me down as enthusiastically for it," the Democrats were plainly eager to renew one of their favorite themes from last year's budget fight, the argument that Mr. Bush supports tax proposals that would help the rich far more than the poor or the middle class.
 
Crime

Mr. Bush's threat on Monday to veto the anti-crime package appeared to sink it for this year. After polling members throughout the day, Democratic officials said they were 26 votes short of passage.
They saw no chance of overcoming the opposition of Republicans, liberal Democrats and the Southern Democrats who support stiffer restrictions on habeas corpus appeals.
Many other members oppose a provision that would require a five-day waiting period to buy a handgun. "Members are thinking of this as a gun vote," said Representative Bill Richardson, Democrat of New Mexico, a leading supporter of the legislation.
Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, who is the chief sponsor of the bill, suggested he would be willing to scuttle most of it in favor of a provision imposing the waiting period for handguns, known as the Brady bill. The measure is named for James S. Brady, the press secretary to President Ronald Reagan who was gravely wounded in the assassination attempt on Mr. Reagan.
"If the President says he'll sign Brady, we'll be quick to peel it off in the first days of next year," Mr. Schumer said.
Mr. Bush has said he would support the Brady bill only if it is included in a larger crime package that expands the rights of police to search for evidence without a warrant and limits the rights of criminals to appeal their state cases in Federal courts.
 
Tax Cuts
 In the House, Democrats and Republicans quarrelled all day Tuesday over a package of tax cuts that some Republicans proposed late last week in an effort to give a jolt to the economy. They wanted to attach it to legislation that most lawmakers agreed was essential, an already imperiled bill that would provide new money for the savings and loan bailout.
Among the Republican proposals were a lower capital gains tax rate, new tax breaks for small businesses and real estate investments, new tax incentives for savings and a repeal of the excise tax on expensive boats, cars and aircraft.
Democrats refused to agree to a procedure under which the tax proposal could be proposed as an amendment, saying it would cost the Treasury more than $25 billion over the next five years and releasing figures showing that the bulk of the tax savings would go to the wealthy.
This morning, Mr. Gingrich declared on the House floor that the Democrats would bear responsibility for the sorry economy because they were blocking the Republican tax plan.
Then Mr. Foley stepped down from the Speaker's chair where he presides over House debates, went to a microphone and said he would keep the House in session as long as needed to debate the tax plan if the President asked him to do so. "The time has come for an end to the gamesmanship," Mr. Foley said.
The dispute continued throughout the day and into the evening in floor speeches and news conferences.
 
Medicaid
 The Senate on Tuesday approved by voice vote a measure to allow states to continue their current Medicaid practices until Sept. 30, 1992. Thereafter, in line with a compromise negotiated by the Administration and the National Governors' Association, states would be less able to raise money for the program of health insurance for 27 million poor people by using money collected from hospitals, as either taxes or voluntary donations.
Last week the House approved a bill that imposed a moratorium, also until Sept. 30, 1992, on the Administration's ability to implement such regulations. The vote was a veto-proof 348 to 71.
A House-Senate conference committee will seek to resolve differences between the two bills.
Under the plan passed by the Senate, the Federal Government would not be required to match money donated to the states by hospitals. States alsowould be barred from imposing taxes only on hospitals that treated Medicaid patients, and no more than 25 percent of what the states put up for Federal matching could come from special taxes on those hospitals.
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee, said he supported the measure despite some reservations.
 
Aid to the Soviet Union
 House and Senate negotiators agreed on Tuesday to spend up to $500 million from the Pentagon's budget to help destroy Soviet nuclear weapons.
On Monday, the Senate approved a stripped-down aid package that resurrected a proposal originally sponsored by Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia and Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin. That proposal, which would have allowed the Pentagon to transfer up to $1 billion, died amid criticism that lawmakers were overly attentive to foreign problems amid growing troubles in the American economy. The House is still considering separate legislation.
Mr. Nunn argued that the revised plan was a valuable investment for American national security.
 
Unemployment Benefits
 Congress passed and sent to the President on Tuesday the final legislation to provide either 13 or 20 weeks of extended unemployment benefits for about three million people out of work at least half a year.
The bill, which President Bush has said he will sign, replaced an earlier version in which workers in 23 states were eligible for only six weeks of benefits.
Under the $5.4 billion measure adopted on Tuesday by the Senate and then by the House, workers in every state who exhausted their regular 26 weeks of benefits between March 1 and last week, and who are still unemployed, can claim those extended benefits. Under the earlier bill, workers in 16 states were not eligible for extended benefits unless they exhausted their regular benefits after Nov. 17.
Last night's action brought to a conclusion a four-month political battle in which President Bush twice killed earlier versions of the bill and Democrats charged that he cared more about foreigners than about destitute Americans.
The measure had been delayed for nearly a week by Senate resistance to including provisions for duty-free imports from Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador and Peru. The bill also extends most favored nation trade status to the three Baltic states, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, and to Czechoslovakia and Hungary.
 
Budget
 Often, Congressional sessions wind down in disputes over the budget, but that has not been the case this year. Congress and the White House were bound by budget rules set last year that basically prevented any tax and spending initiatives.
The only pending budget issue was a supplemental money bill containing $4 billion for the left-over costs of the war against Iraq, and money for crop-loss payments for farmers and ranchers, and special assistance for a few communities that had been hit by a natural disaster.

A helicopter crash last week has heightened a long-running and deadly feud between the Soviet republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan over a disputed territory. A8
