HEADLINE: Why Aren't We Thankful?

BYLINE: By James Reston; James Reston is former chief Washington correspondent and executive editor of The New York Times.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
With the cold war over and with fears of another Pearl Harbor at rest, it's hard to remember a Thanksgiving Day when there were more reasons for the U.S. to give thanks than in this second year of the last decade of the century. But somehow there is little rejoicing. We seem to be at peace with everybody but ourselves.
How could this be? For 50 years since the invention of atomic weapons, we have lived in fear of a third world war. In the first two world wars, 70 million people were killed. 
 In the cold war against Communism, when the two political parties finally agreed on a nonpartisan foreign policy, the U.S. avoided a third world war with comparatively few casualties. Surely this was a cause for rejoicing, but that's not the way it is. Instead, we are engaged here in a series of mean and nasty arguments over abortion, racial politics, the cost of credit cards, who's to be blamed for the economic recession and unemployment, and what's the matter with George Bush and Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York.
You might have thought that at least for this one holiday week the President would have brought a sense of historical perspective to the national debate. But in this year, when the "the evil empire" collapsed, he proposed a five-year military budget that, in constant dollars, would be 25 percent higher than 20 years ago, at the height of the cold war.
No opposition party can really compete with the President in changing the thought of the nation during such a revolution in world affairs. As Woodrow Wilson said, the President's "is the only national voice in affairs. Let him once win the admiration and confidence of the country and no other single force can withstand him. His is the vital place of action in the system."
President Bush seemed to sense the truth of this for a time, and talked of "a new world order," which he started with a war that took the lives of more than 150,000 Iraqis and Kurds, which he barely mentioned.
There was a kind of jingoistic rejoicing after the painful liberation of Kuwait, but since then the object of his policies seems to have been his own re-election, and the Democrats have responded with their own brand of bush league politics.
Accordingly, it's easy to understand why the American people are not rejoicing this Thanksgiving Day, for they are also suffering from the consequences of these wars, hot and cold.
While paying for the threats to their security from abroad -- necessary as those payments were -- their children have been shortchanged in the schools; the problems of crime, drug abuse, health insurance and compassion for the homeless have been under-financed, if not neglected; and the nation's industries, once the envy of the world, have been losing their lead to our former enemies, Germany and Japan, whose budgets concentrate, not on military defense, but on research and development for products that are competing with ours and often beating us in world trade.
In short, we have changed the world, but haven't changed our minds, and this is not surprising.
For if the people are told for more than 12 years by their leaders that they should think about themselves and their own special interests, that they can spend their way to prosperity and happiness with borrowed money and that government is not the answer but the cause of all their problems, you shouldn't be surprised if they are disappointed in the pursuit of greediness, and ask, after their sacrifices in the cold war and Operation Desert Storm, "Where's the rainbow?"

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
To Cuomo or Not to Cuomo

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
There are three schools of thought on whether Gov. Mario Cuomo should run for President:
* Yes, not because he'd be a good President but because he'd raise the right issues and mop up George Bush in debates. 
 * Yes, not because he'd be a good President but because he'd be better than George Bush.
* No, because he might get elected and probably wouldn't be as good as Mr. Bush.
I have a foot in all three schools -- which leads me to break ground for a fourth. The Governor should wait until 1996 and run for the White House only after he's lived up to his promises to New York and actually demonstrated his unique promise as a leader. If he would do that, he'd have a much better chance of winning, and he'd deserve to win.
Here's the case:
1. Mr. Cuomo cannot beat Mr. Bush.
President Bush won't be weak next fall. He will take away a lot of the Democrats' thunder with his own proposals for health care and economic growth. Living standards will continue on a downward slope, but Mr. Bush will give the economy a little boost before election time.
New York will be pure dead weight around the Governor's neck, no matter what Mr. Cuomo says. He'll show that things are just as bad in California, run by a Republican Governor, and argue that this proves the problem lies in Washington. But that argument is too complicated to sell. He'll recite his ten-page list of accomplishments. But New Yorkers will be the first to tell the country of their Governor's spotty record.
Besides, there are already several strong Democratic candidates who can give Mr. Bush a race.
2. Governor Cuomo can beat Dan Quayle or almost anyone else in 1996, if he delivers leadership for New York in the meantime.
Non-incumbents are easier opponents. More important, the economy will be down the tubes in another five years. By that time, it will be landslide city for the Democrats.
Whether Mr. Cuomo will be chosen to lead the Democratic charge will still depend on his performance in Albany in the next three years. He has a reputation for making second-rate appointments. Let him show that he can attract the best and brightest to government and listen to them. He has just advanced a plan to fix New York City's infrastructure. Let him refine that and get it under way. He has a disappointing record on race relations. Let him use his magic to bring blacks and whites together. He says the country needs a comprehensive approach to economic growth -- tax fairness, investments, slashing government bureaucracy, better public education and the like. Let New York be the model.
3. Mr. Cuomo won't be able to accomplish these things, and be a good Governor or President, unless he first conquers his own demons.
His mind is awesome, somewhere between that of a philosopher-king and a lexicographer, between Descartes and Daniel Webster. On a TV talk show Sunday, he gave a strong critique of Bushonomics. Asked about his pledge not to raise taxes on the middle class, he answered, "it depends on how you define middle class . . . how many kids, what circumstances, do they have two children that need special equipment?"
His lofty and powerful mind often works its way deep into the black hole of immobility and indecision. Unlike leaders who concentrate on the rule and their goals, he is forever stymied by exceptions.
He transforms everything into an argument, and often seems more interested in winning arguments than governing. He turns the slightest slight into mortal combat.
His temperament wavers between street fighter and attack dog, between Jimmy Cagney and Cujo, killer pet. It's hard to feel sorry for Sam Donaldson. But when the ABC newsman asked the Governor about calling Vice President Quayle "Danny the cabin boy," Mr. Cuomo denied it and went for Sam's throat. Mr. Donaldson, not a meek man and dead right besides, had to say, "If you never used the name Danny, then I stand corrected." After the show, the Governor's staff recanted his denial.
Mr. Cuomo, brilliant and charismatic, has yet to master his temperament and mind, and has yet to make his record in office -- and cannot be a worthy Presidential candidate or President until he does.

HEADLINE: Don't Make the David Dukes News Media Stars;
Rights for All

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Little Comfort in Mr. Duke's Loss" (editorial, Nov. 18), you again miss the significance of David Duke. Mr. Duke lost because of his background as Nazi and Ku Klux Klan geek. If a known child molester with an innovative day-care program had got 40 percent of the way toward certification, we would heave a sigh of relief at his defeat. Would we also reject the innovations he proposed? 
 Many people in Louisiana supported David Duke, despite his background, because of his ideas. Indeed, several of his ideas are half baked. But he is, unfortunately, one of a very few politicians who -- for whatever reason -- advocate equal opportunity and civil rights for white males.
Most other politicians, including the President, seem to believe that rights are something you have only if you don't have power. If you are a rich black man, you belong to a group that has rights that must be enforced to the extent that they infringe on those of a poor white man whose group has power instead.
A prime example is the so-called Civil Rights Act of 1991. Without this law, if a black man did not meet the qualifications for a job, a white man could be hired because of his qualifications. With this law (barring certain exceptions), the white man's superior qualifications will be irrelevant, and the black man will get the job because of his race. If you are a white person who can envision imminent unemployment as a result of the economy, the prospect of facing de jure racial discrimination for your next job is a real issue.
David Duke got almost 40 percent of the vote because of the opposition's liabilities and because he fastened onto the burgeoning issue of equal rights for whites. If, by some miracle, he had been elected, any attempt on his part to legislate inequality against blacks would have engendered twice the backlash we saw Nov. 16. The antidote to David Duke is equal rights for every individual, regardless of group.
 
JOHN G. SIMS
Burke, Va., Nov. 18, 1991

HEADLINE: The Dream of Land Dies Hard in Mexico

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TELPANCINGO, Mexico

 BODY:
For 74 years, the Mexican Constitution has promised land to any citizen who would work it. But there were a few catches: the land could not be rented, mortgaged or sold.
So when a Government functionary began telling local farmers here the other day how President Carlos Salinas de Gortari was going to change all that, the men might have been expected to applaud. They did not. 
 "What?" an older man bellowed over the din that rose in the ruins of a once-vast estate here, not far from where the peasant revolutionary Emiliano Zapata was killed in 1919. "Was the revolution worth nothing? What did all of those people die for? There is nobody, not even the President of the republic, who can take away our land!"
There were a few shouts of "Viva Zapata!" as the official tried to point out that the proposed law would merely allow peasants to rent or sell their plots or join with outside investors; it would not compel them to do so. But the confusion and mistrust was by no means unusual. Officials in Mexico City said they expected such explaining to continue around the country for months.
The tumult underscored how Mr. Salinas's plan to transform Mexican agriculture has quickly become the stiffest challenge of his quest to modernize the economy.
"This is touching the very heart of Mexican history of the last 70 years," said Luis Tellez, the Under Secretary of Agriculture who was a principal architect of the proposed laws. "It is the point of no return."
The "agrarian reform" that most Mexicans knew had been a seemingly endless process, the basic tool by which the Government redistributed wealth in the countryside and asserted political control over it. But early in November, with 2.5 million peasants still waiting for their plots, Mr. Salinas told the country what its leaders had realized for years: that there was no more land to hand out.
 
A Role for Foreigners
 In addition to legalizing the sale of redistributed land, he also moved to permit large-scale agribusiness ventures, with foreigners free to participate.
While there is little doubt that the Congress, dominated by Mr. Salinas's Institutional Revolutionary Party, will approve his plan, the debate reinvigorated the country's floundering political left to the point that the President took the unusual step of inviting opposition parties to propose amendments to the new laws.
"The only thing that will happen is that those who can buy will reconstitute the big estates," said Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, the leftist leader whose father, President Lazaro Cardenas, gave land to nearly a million peasants in the late 1930's. "Now, instead of the haciendas, it is going to be the great transnational corporations."
Mexican officials say the capitalization and modernization of agriculture are essential if Mexico is to compete successfully with the United States and Canada under the free trade agreement now being negotiated. But they do not doubt that the adjustment will be a wrenching one.
 
Meager Farm Investments
 While farmers and their families now make up nearly a third of the country's 82 million people, they produce less than one-tenth of the gross national product and have collected less than 1 percent of the billions of dollars in foreign investment flowing into Mexico. The great majority of the 17 million Mexicans who, by World Bank standards, live in extreme poverty live in the countryside. And within a decade or two, Mr. Tellez said in an interview, about half of the rural population will most likely be forced to move.
Many of the migrants, officials say, will settle in towns in the interior. Others will swell the already overcrowded and underserviced cities. But despite the new jobs that a booming economy should create, critics wonder whether a third destination is not most likely.
"Where is the support system for those people?" asked Adolfo Aguilar Zinser, a political scientist. "It is on the northern border and in the United States."
Even the most passionate of advocates for the Mexican family farmer does not dispute the need for change in the country's system of community farms.
The ejidos, as both the communities and their lands are called, hark back to the land tenure of the Maya. Reconceived under the revolutionary Constitution of 1917, they have been carved from expropriated holdings until, under Mr. Salinas, they came to cover about half of the country's arable land. They may be worked communally or, far more often, as individual parcels, but can be transferred only from one generation to the next.
Divided among heirs, farms that were mandated to be at least 25 acres have typically shrunk to half that. Most lack irrigation, and with outside investment barred by law, their mechanization is usually a day's tractor rental at best. Under the weight of Mexico's huge foreign debt, credits to the ejidos nearly evaporated during the 1980's, while many private landowners stopped investing out of fear that land-starved peasants might invade their parcels in order to force the Government's hand.
Almost as a rule, ejido farmers must take on additional work to sustain their families. Some sell knickknacks or cut wood from outlying forests, and some pick vegetables in California or pack fish in Alaska. Thousands return to harvest their crops; others simply sell or rent their land illegally.
The system would have collapsed of its own inefficency long ago, economists say, had the Government not heavily subsidized farm loans and grain prices. And despite paying about double world market prices for its peasants' corn, for example, only in the last two years has Mexico not had to import corn and beans.
 
Higher Subsidies Asked
 In selling the new plan, the Government has essentially argued that "land and liberty" -- the slogan of Zapata's revolt and the chorus of Government oratory for half a century -- do not necessarily go together anymore.
By granting farmers the power to vote themselves titles to their land, officials contend, the Government will end its paternalistic control over the ejidos, undercut the power of the corrupt bosses who dominate many farms and free the farmers from the demands of Government banks that often condition loans on the planting of certain crops.
But critics of the plan are demanding that the Government raise rather than cut its subsidies. "The Government is backing away from its responsibility," said Ramon Danzos Palomino, the 79-year-old former Communist leader who is a sort of grand old man of the peasant left.
Far as such arguments might diverge from the mainstream of contemporary economic logic, some officials acknowledged that they might still be persuasive to millions of poor Mexicans.
"The worry," said a senior official who spoke on condition he not be identified, "is that you could have political unrest in the countryside at this stage, when we are negotiating a free-trade agreement with the United States."
After an initial flurry of leftist opposition to his bill, Mr. Salinas promised to soften the repayment terms on outstanding ejido loans and spend about $3 billion next year on new credits, technology and infrastructure to strengthen the farm system.
 
Different Reactions
 Like Mexican agriculture itself, the longer-term reception given the new law will almost certainly vary by region. In the north, where landholdings are larger and production agriculture is more established, farmers are expected to turn more quickly to the many potential investors whom Government officials say have shown interest. In the south, where plots are smaller, poorer and still disputed by thousands of peasants, the evolution will likely be much slower.
In visits to ejidos in the state of Morelos, just south of the capital, it was difficult to find a farmer even thinking about cashing in under the proposed laws. "As long as I have faith in God, I think I would not sell my land," said Clemente Torres, 40, who stood on one of the rutted dirt streets of San Jose de Pala. "It has always given me something to eat."
But the appearance of new crops in the fields belie the outward resistance to change.
On the ejido of Miacatlan, Valente Mastache, 61 years old, was still smarting from the loss of $670 he suffered when a Canadian company backed out of the pilot project under which he had abandoned his corn to grow Chinese vegetables. But keeping to his diversification, Mr. Mastache had sown peanuts and watermelons this year. And he did not rule out the possibility of another effort to grow oriental squash.
"We just have to make the contract a little bit better next time," he said.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 28, 1991, Thursday

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 662 words

HEADLINE: Where Shall We Find the Leaders We Need?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is chilling to hear Dick Thornburgh, former Attorney General, conclude on the occasion of his defeat in the Pennsylvania senatorial race that the economy and the cost of health care "obviously commanded much greater attention in the campaign than we anticipated" (news article, Nov. 6). 
 If public concern for the economy and health care comes as a surprise to the former chairman of President Bush's Domestic Policy Council, only months from that office and after almost two years of nagging headlines, what does this say about awareness and leadership in Washington? And what does it say about President Bush, himself so taken off balance by the news of voter discontent in Pennsylvania that he abruptly canceled an important visit to Japan to focus on the economy and to reinforce chances for re-election in 1992?
The Thornburgh incident, though it happened in one state (Pennsylvania), and though tied to just two issues (health care and the economy), speaks volumes about the larger question: the condition of leadership in the United States, and to the supreme question about our readiness to compete and to lead with Europe and Japan in the new global economy.
A majority of today's major domestic problems and a number of our global ones were foreseen, publicly discussed by think tanks and issues groups, with preliminary policy positions advanced for consideration by decision makers as early as the late 1960's and throughout the 70's. These were the big issues: energy policy, research and development objectives and financing, quality and productivity improvements, renewal of the country's physical infrastructure, water supply and purity, waste management, education and housing, the need to understand cross-cultural management, the pressing need in senior management in the business community for strategic information input to balance operational information input to capture the newer global and domestic realities.
Is 20 years of procrastination really leadership in today's fluid, fast-paced and competitive world, given the stunning cost of unaddressed problems? Can we credibly admonish
other countries to adjust their traditions, change their practices, restructure their economies, be more like us, when we ourselves are so conspicuously unwilling to give up practices no longer relevant on the global market frontier? Are we most credible when Europe and Japan have to tell the United States to turn in short-term goals and expectations for longer-range goals? Does it inspire confidence at home or abroad to hear on television a respected Republican Party pollster concede that "the White House is adrift."
If politics grows out of economics, one must look at business leadership. American business leaders, through cumulative decisions over more than 50 years, deserve credit for doing the most to create and usher in the global economy. Yet could it be that the devotion of many American senior executives to the perceptions and assumptions that helped them to positions of power and respect fetter their ability to grasp the new realities and retool for success?
In addition, we need to address the presence and spread of dishonesty, denial and "forgiveness" in leadership ranks in government and business, and even on campus, exceeding almost anything anyone can remember. It has become so commonplace that perpetrators feel quite at ease lecturing their examiners, putting their selfish interests above the public interest and brazenly pleading with authorities and the press to turn their attentions elsewhere so "I can put all this behind me and get on with my life and my career." Memory is becoming a scarce resource.
There is a growing recognition across this land that the best thing for America is to be a competitive equal with Europe and Japan in the global marketplace. This begins with strong leadership at home. Where are these leaders?
 
CHARLES M. DARLING 3D
New York, Nov. 17, 1991

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Rallies Amid Worries On U.S. Inflation and Soviets

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold futures prices rallied yesterday, ending a two-day decline, amid worries about unrest in the Soviet Union and the possibility of higher inflation at home.
Gold for delivery in December rose $1.60, to $367.90, on New York's Commodity Exchange. December silver slipped 1.5 cents, to $4.06 a troy ounce. 
 About 55,000 gold contracts changed hands in relatively busy trading, partly in reaction to a report by the Kyodo News Agency of Japan that quoted Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze as saying another Soviet coup was possible.
 
Comments Clarified

A Foreign Ministry spokesman, Vitaly Churkin, said later that Mr. Shevardnadze was referring to the threat of social instability because of the collapsing Soviet economy, not to a particular coup threat.
Nevertheless, analysts said the report caused buying of gold, which has traditionally held its value in times of political and economic chaos.
Gold is also a traditional investment hedge against inflation, which some analysts see as an increasing danger if the Bush Administration tries to stimulate the economy.
Yesterday's mixed bag of economic reports -- shrinking consumer spending, higher factory orders and fewer unemployment claims -- offered no clear signals on inflation, said Bette Raptopoulos, metals analyst with Prudential Securities Inc. in New York.
 
Could Be Inflationary

Nevertheless, she said, there is a prevailing perception "that the President will have to come up with an economic package that will wind up being inflationary."
Most energy futures advanced after a weekly American Petroleum Institute report showed a drop last week in United States crude supplies.
Gains were limited by an OPEC agreement to extend the organization's current production contract into the first quarter of 1992.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
False Rumor of Soviet Coup A Factor in Dollar's Rise

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar's value rose against most key currencies today, strengthened at first by a false rumor of a second Soviet coup and later by better-than-expected news about the American economy.
Foreign exchange dealers said trading volume was thin because many participants quit early for the Thanksgiving holiday. But they said the market was predisposed toward the dollar. 
 Part of the reason stemmed from surprise remarks Tuesday by Germany's Economics Minister, Jurgen Molleman, who said the dollar was undervalued.
Mr. Molleman's statement was a key reason for the dollar's surge late Tuesday, and some traders said it might have undermined a belief in the foreign exchange market that the dollar's value would inevitably worsen in coming weeks.
"The dollar probably has taken a turn for the better," said Hillel Waxman, a foreign exchange dealer for the New York office of the Bank Leumi Trust Company. "The market is ready to shift its psychology."
Dealers started the day with an unsubstantiated rumor that the Kremlin plotters who overthrew the Soviet Government in August had done it again. That type of rumor usually tends to help the dollar, a safe-haven currency during times of political crisis.
"We got the initial pop on the dollar from that," said Peter Stern, a corporate dealer at Refco Inc., a commodity futures trading concern in New York.
The rumor evidently stemmed from misinterpretations of a report by Japan's Kyodo news agency, which quoted the newly reappointed Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze as predicting another coup. The Soviet Foreign Ministry sought to play down the significance of the Kyodo report, saying Mr. Shevardnadze was referring only to the general threat of social instability.
The dollar was helped later by economic reports that showed durable goods orders surged 3 percent in October, much better than expected, and that weekly unemployment-insurance claims tumbled in mid-November.
Mr. Stern said those numbers suggested the anemic American economy might be stronger than many market strategists had thought, which would tend to bolster the dollar. Still, he said: "I don't think anyone's buying that. We're still in a bearish mode toward the dollar here."
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.95 yen, to a closing of 129.25 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 129.55 yen. By the time trading concluded in New York the dollar fetched 130.05 yen, down from its 130.15 rate late Tuesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7665, from $1.7975 Tuesday. In late New York trading the pound fetched $1.7675, cheaper than its $1.7730 rate late Tuesday.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Market Fund Yields Fell Slightly in Latest Week

 BODY:
Yields on tax-exempt and taxable money market funds fell slightly in the week that ended yesterday, according to IBC/Donoghue's, the Holliston, Mass., publisher of The Money Fund Report.
Walter S. Frank, chief economist at IBC/Donoghue's, said the small change in yields showed that the demand for tax-exempt funds was keeping pace with the high level of money that is currently on the market. 
 "There was a large supply that came on the market this week, but the yields did not rise, as you might expect," he said.
 
Gains for Tax-Exempt Funds
 Total assets of the tax-exempt funds showed a moderate rise to $91.8 billion, up $524 million from the previous week. Mr. Frank said the average days to maturity on holdings in tax-exempt portfolios remained unchanged at 58 days.
The seven-day compound average yield for tax-exempt funds fell to 3.74 percent, down one basis point from 3.75 percent the week before. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The seven-day simple yield for the tax-exempts dropped two basis points, to 3.67 percent, from 3.69 percent the previous week.
The 30-day compound yield for the same period dropped to 3.83 percent, down four basis points from 3.87 percent, while the 30-day simple yield was at 3.76 percent, down four basis points from 3.80 percent.
The highest-yielding tax-exempt fund among those with assets greater than $100 million was Strong Municipal Money Market Fund, based in Milwaukee, with a seven-day compound yield of 4.79 percent, down one basis point from 4.80 percent the previous week. Strong has been the top-yielding tax-exempt fund for the last several weeks.
 
State-Specific Funds
 Among the tax-exempt funds that invest in individual state securities, the top-yielding New York fund continued to be Salomon Brothers New York Municipal Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compound yield of 4.46 percent, down three basis points from 4.49 percent a week earlier.
In New Jersey, the leading fund was Fidelity Spartan New Jersey Municipal, reporting a seven-day compound yield of 4.30 percent, up from the 4.28 percent offered by the previous week's top performer, Prudential N.J. Municipal Money Market Fund.
Two funds were the leaders in Connecticut, with seven-day compound yields of 4.10 percent: Prudential Connecticut Municipal Money Market Series, and the previous week's top performer, Fidelity Spartan Connecticut Municipal Money Market Performer, which had a yield of 4.11 percent a week earlier.
The assets of taxable funds rose by $2.5 billion in the last week, to a total of $474.2 billion. Of that $2.5 billion increase, $2.2 billion came from institutional investors.
 
Competitive Yields
 "The institutional flow appears to be a combination of money which is coming out of the stock and bond markets," Mr. Frank said. "Money fund yields are still competitive for cash holders."
The average days to maturity on taxable holdings was a relatively long 63 days, unchanged from the previous week.
The seven-day compound yield on the taxable funds dropped nine basis points, to 4.81 percent, from 4.92 percent, while the seven-day simple yield for the taxable funds fell eight basis points, to 4.70 percent, from the previous week's 4.78 percent.
The average compound 30-day yield for the same period was at 4.94 percent, an decline of six basis points from the previous week's 5.00 percent. The 30-day simple yield was down to 4.82 percent, down six basis points from 4.88 percent.
The highest-yielding taxable fund for the week continued to be Riverside Capital in Columbus, Ohio, with a seven-day compound yield of 6.00 percent, up from 5.95 percent last week.
By comparison, bank money market accounts, a primary competitor of the money funds, fell to a yield of 4.70 percent, compared with 4.74 percent a week earlier, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.

HEADLINE: Experts Dismiss Big Drop in Jobless Claims

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
Initial claims for unemployment benefits tumbled by 80,000 in mid-November, the Labor Department reported today. Although it was the biggest improvement in nearly a decade, the decline was largely dismissed as a holiday fluke.
"One should not conclude that the economy suddenly did a U-turn," said Robert Dederick, chief economist of the Northern Trust Company. He noted that on average, nearly 450,000 Americans had filed new unemployment claims each week for a month. 
 The Labor Department said 413,000 Americans filed first-time claims in the week that ended on Nov. 16, down from 493,000 in the previous week.
Fewer Days to File
It was the largest one-week decline since January 1982, in the middle of the last recession. At that time, claims fell 90,000 in a week, mostly reversing the previous week's surge of 105,000, the agency said.
The decline this month was largely dismissed because it came during the week of the Veterans Day holiday, meaning that people had fewer days to file claims. In addition, the mid-November decline followed three consecutive weekly increases. During that period, claims rose to nearly 500,000, from 406,000.
But Irwin Kellner of Manufacturers Hanover Trust was more upbeat about the decrease, noting that blizzard-related layoffs were partly responsible for a 39,000 jump in claims in the previous week. "In the latest week, construction activity resumed and some of these people were back on payrolls," Mr. Kellner said.
The claims numbers can vary greatly from week to week, and economists are wary of attaching much significance to a one-week movement. They consider a four-week average a better barometer.
The latest four-week average is 445,000, up from the previous average of 443,000 and far more than the 400,000 reached in the summer, when the number was improving.
The Labor Department usually releases the claims numbers on Thursday, but moved up the release because of the Thanksgiving holiday. Robert Brusca, of Nikko Securities, said the numbers might have been skewed in the rush to release them.

HEADLINE: Income Rose A Scant 0.2% In October

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
Americans' personal incomes barely grew in October, the Commerce Department reported today. The gain, of only two-tenths of a percent, followed larger increases of four-tenths of a percent in September and five-tenths in August.
Some analysts asserted that the economy needed help to avoid sliding back into recession. 
 "It is time to dial 911 for the recovery," said John M. Albertine, a Washington economist.
The Commerce Department noted that incomes were bolstered by several special factors in October, including a large increase in farm subsidies, bonus payments to auto workers and restitution payments to Japanese-Americans who were interned during World War II.
In contrast, uninsured losses caused by a devastating fire in Oakland, Calif., reduced rental incomes.
Excluding these special factors, "personal income decreased $7 billion, or one-tenth of a percent, in October," the department said.
The White House has given its support to a Republican tax-cut proposal that is given little chance of passage. Hearings will be held during the Congressional recess on policies to try to stimulate the economy, but Mr. Albertine said those discussions would not make consumers more optimistic.
"It is foolish for Congress to adjourn in the middle of deteriorating economic conditions," he said, "especially when it is obvious that the American people are so worried about the economy."
Personal savings did rise during October, to $183 billion, or 4.4 percent of disposable income, from 4 percent in September.

HEADLINE: Chinese Goods Listed for Higher Tariffs in Trade Dispute

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, proposed steep tariffs on about $1.5 billion worth of Chinese imports today, while Chinese negotiators and American importers criticized the decision to seek the trade sanctions after patent and copyright negotiations failed.
Mrs. Hills said that the list of imports affected would be trimmed at the end of a 30-day public-comment period beginning Tuesday. A final figure of $750 million would be "in the ballpark," she said at a news conference this morning, and a decision on whether the tariffs are imposed will be made at the end of the comment period. 
 Chinese trade negotiators, who engaged in six days of talks here that ended on Tuesday, criticized the American decision to announce plans for retaliation. "This is not fair and not in the interest of either side, nor does it conform with normal international practices," the delegation said in a statement.
 
Inadequate Concessions

Mrs. Hills said that Chinese negotiators had not made adequate concessions on the protection of American inventions, particularly pharmaceutical patents. The United States is also concerned about the protection of trade secrets, trademarks and the copyrights of American works published outside of China.
Announcement of the planned tariffs will immediately disrupt trade of the affected products with China as importers seek to block the delivery of goods that could cost twice as much as anticipated, said trade groups representing importers. They said the announcement would also prompt political efforts to reduce the scale of the tariff measures.
"There's no question that there'll be lobbying, but it'll not be a China lobby; it'll be a lobby of industries that will be affected," said Eugene J. Milosh, the president of the New York-based American Association of Exporters and Importers.
"This is just one more problem placed on importers by the Administration," he added.
Mrs. Hills's office this afternoon released a list of imports that would be subject to the tariffs, including luggage, overcoats, pajamas, T-shirts, track suits, imitation jewelry and wristwatches.
Private experts have predicted that the planned tariffs would be 100 percent, but Mrs. Hills told the news conference this morning only that the tariffs would be "prohibitive."
 
First Use of Law

The list represented the first time that the United States has made specific preparations for trade sanctions under Special 301, a section of American trade law dealing with foreign violations of American patents and copyrights.
For importers of products on the list, the new tariffs will be more harmful than a loss by China of its most-favored-nation trade status, which allows Chinese goods to enter the American market at the lowest tariffs available.
The list's release today followed a vote on China's trade status in the House of Representatives on Tuesday night. The House approved, by a 409-to-21 margin, a compromise House and Senate bill attaching conditions to any renewal next year of the most-favored-nation status.
The conditions include an improvement in Chinese human rights policy and an end to Chinese missile and nuclear technology shipments to the Middle East.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Issues Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed yesterday, as credit market participants sifted through seemingly conflicting economic reports and worried that policy makers in Washington might return after Thanksgiving to consider quick passage of a package to stimulate the economy.
Reports that upset traders early in the session included news from the Labor Department that initial unemployment claims fell by a larger than expected 80,000 during the week ended Nov. 16, and that new orders for durable goods rose by 3 percent during October, the first increase in three months. 
 While traders focused on those numbers as signs of some strength in the economy that might discourage lower interest rates, economists were more interested in, and concerned about, a report from the Commerce Department showing that personal consumption spending fell by three-tenths of a percent during October. It was the second decline in three months and the biggest dip since April.
"The consumption data was on the weak side, even though it may rise in the months to come," said Kenneth Kim, an economist at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and credit markets.
Even if consumption expenditures pick up, Mr. Kim said the figures released yesterday do not improve the outlook for growth during the current quarter.
"Personal consumption spending will probably be down by 1 percent or so in the fourth quarter," he said. "That implies that overall G.N.P. growth will be pretty weak."
The price movement that followed the reports came on extremely thin trading. Activity in the Government securities market ended at 1 P.M. yesterday to prolong the Thanksgiving holiday weekend. The market will operate under a similar abbreviated schedule tomorrow.
Concern that Congress might not adjourn for the year and would return instead after Thanksgiving to consider a tax cut package intended to stimulate the economy was the major influence on bond prices, traders said.
Credit market participants are concerned that any package that Congress agrees upon will further swell the already-bloated Federal budget deficit.
At the close of trading, the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 100 13/32, down 9/32, to yield 7.96 percent, compared with 7.93 percent late Tuesday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were unchanged, at 100 21/32, to yield 7.40 percent. And the 6 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 19/32, up 1/ 32, to yield 5.77 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates inched lower.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.37 percent late yesterday, down one basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by two basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.42 percent. And one-year bill rates fell by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 4.48 percent.
Activity in the corporate bond market was highlighted by a $240 million offering of high-yield bonds issued by the Stone Container Corporation.
The 11 7/8 percent senior notes, which mature Dec. 1, 1998, were priced at $99.415, to yield 12 percent.
The securities, which are noncallable for seven years, are rated B-1 by Moody's Investors Service and BB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Merrill Lynch & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting.
Activity in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate and tax-exempt municipal bonds was very slow, traders said.
Prices of most corporate issues were unchanged. Meanwhile, participants in the municipal bond market said that prices of widely quoted issues dipped by about 1/8 point to 1/4 point.

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 16.10 on Blue-Chip Losses

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks closed mixed yesterday, with blue chips bearing the brunt of the weakness. Sharp declines in I.B.M. and Philip Morris pushed the Dow Jones industrial average down 16.10 points, to 2,900.04.
For the most part, blue-chip issues traded in a tight range just below Tuesday's closing level, but the declines in I.B.M. and Philip Morris rattled the rest of the market. I.B.M. fell 3 5/8, to 94 1/4, and Philip Morris dropped 1 5/8, to 68 1/8. 
 According to Birinyi Associates, a stock market research company, the decline in I.B.M. accounted for 6.5 points in the Dow's fall, while Philip Morris represented 3.1 points, together accounting for 60 percent of the Dow's move.
 
Volume Down 21.5%

Volume on the Big Board totaled 167.7 million, down from a heavy 213.8 million shares on Tuesday. Losing issues outpaced gaining ones by a narrow margin of 879 to 739, showing the closeness in yesterday's trading.
The Big Board composite index slipped 0.55 points, to 208.22, while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 1.41 points, to 376.55. On the American Stock Exchange, trading took the composite index down 0.66, to 370.00.
On the upside of yesterday's trading, the Nasdaq composite index rose 0.55, to 522.78, with the Russell 2,000 index of small-company stocks just 0.06 points below its close on Tuesday.
 
Announcement Takes Effect
 Traders said I.B.M.'s shares were down as a few analysts adjusted their ratings after the company said on Tuesday that it was taking a fourth-quarter charge of $3 billion and cutting 20,000 jobs. The traders cited a lower rating given by Daniel Mandresh of Merrill Lynch.
"You just don't take the saved earnings per share and add it to the bottom line in a difficult economy, and to a company in transition," Mr. Mandresh said. "In a still-very-tough industry, revenues are the critical issue."
And Clifford Friedman, of Bear, Stearns, reduced his rating on I.B.M. to a "buy" from a "strong buy," noting that the restructuring was a radical decision, but still an evolutionary process.
Philip Morris said it was taking $275 million charge in the fourth quarter to cover the restructuring of its Kraft General Foods unit, and said it planned to buy back up to $2 billion common shares over two years.
Despite the recent weakness in stocks, Gene J. Seagle, the director of research for Gruntal & Company, said the market did have some things going for it. One was that November, December and January are historically the strongest months of the year in terms of advances. Another is lower interest rates.
Finally, Mr. Seagle said, there is the coming Presidential market cycle, where the President and the Federal Reserve will do everything to turn the economy up and keep interest rates moving down.
 
BankAmerica Down to $31.50

In other stock action yesterday, the shares of BankAmerica were off 1/2, to 31 1/2, as Thomas Brown, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, lowered his 1991 and 1992 earnings estimates but repeated a "buy" on the stock. He said the near-term reductions did not take away from the long-term growth.

HEADLINE: OPEC Leader Looks Ahead, And Sees Possible Turmoil

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VIENNA, Nov. 27

 BODY:
The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, ending a two-day meeting here, decided today to keep its oil production at the current level. But its Secretary General issued a strong warning that next year would be filled with unpredictable developments for the world's oil markets.
The Secretary General, Subroto, said that among other uncertainties OPEC did not know when Iraq, once a leading oil producer, would be able to export again. 
 Other OPEC officials warned that if Iraq resumed large-scale exports, which are currently prohibited by the United Nations, the volume of oil it sold might well force the group to revise its decisions.
Baghdad is known to have discreetly exported a few thousand barrels of refined oil products over the last year, but those supplies have had a negligable impact on the world market. Before the United Nations embargo was imposed, Iraq exported three million barrels a day.
 
Uncertainty About the Soviets

Dr. Subroto, formerly the oil minister of Indonesia, also said that another big question was whether the Soviet Union's oil production, which he estimated at less than 9 million barrels a day, might fall further next year, creating a need for more OPEC oil on world markets.
OPEC officials also noted that the demand for their oil would depend on the degree to which the United States and several other industrial countries recovered from recession.
Dr. Subroto said that Iraq's failure to accept Security Council Resolution 706, which permits the country to export enough oil to generate $1.6 billion in revenues, was "a political decision," and that any decision to resume exports must be made by Baghdad. But he noted that Iraqi acceptance of the resolution could have a significant effect on OPEC's prices and production levels.
The United Nations barred Iraq from exporting oil after it invaded Kuwait in August 1990. Permission to export was granted only on a temporary and limited basis, a stipulation that Iraq has rejected.
In the view of oil experts, these uncertainties make OPEC's decision to keep production stable a tentative one.
 
'Living in a Dream World'

"In a way, OPEC is living in a dream world," said John H. Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York, who was an observer at the meeting. Mr. Lichtblau said the near-total absence of Iraq and Kuwait from the world oil market, and the changing Soviet production profile, meant the organization would probably have to re-examine its policies soon.
The steady fall in Soviet oil exports, down to about a million barrels a day, from 1.6 million barrels two years ago, could also alter the market's supply-and-demand balance.
Similarly, OPEC officials said, Kuwait's ability to make a comeback as an oil producer is another factor that the group must watch and weigh. Kuwait has essentially been out of the oil-exporting business since the Iraqi invasion. But it has been slowly repairing oil operations destroyed by Iraq and has begun to pump more oil in recent months.
Kuwaiti officials say they will reach a production level of 600,000 barrels a day by the end of the year and 800,000 barrels a day in July 1992.
 
February Meeting Is Set
 OPEC said it would meet again on Feb. 12 in Geneva to consider these elements of uncertainty and "decide on a production ceiling" for the second quarter of 1992.
For the moment, the OPEC ceiling will remain where it has been in the last few months, at about 24 million barrels a day.
OPEC reiterated its desire to bring prices closer to its "minimum reference price" of $21 barrel, but the group refrained from specifying what measures it would adopt to lift prices to that level. The average price of OPEC-produced oil is now a little less than $19 a barrel.
Saudi Arabia has opposed any talk of trimming production to raise prices.

HEADLINE: Economic Watch;
Soviet Debt Deal May Add To Problems of the Republics

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Can anyone spare a dime? The leaders of the Soviet republics, who were hoping for a coin or three in return for assuming the Soviet Union's debts, were left empty-handed last week. While the West agreed to a delay in repayment of the principal through 1992, the deal offered no money to slow the republics' perilous financial decline.
Indeed, the negotiation with the United States and its major economic allies in Moscow may have added to the republics' economic woes by highlighting both the division of interests between the Russian Federation and the Ukraine and Washington's indecision on aid. 
 Russian leaders, eager to put the best possible spin on the agreement, point out that it gives the West explicit leverage over plans for creating a market economy in the republics. And that arrangement improves the prospects for a "grand bargain" on the financing of reforms. "It was a willing surrender by Russia," said Robert Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International.
By conventional yardsticks, the Soviet foreign debt is quite modest. Official Russian estimates put hard-currency debts to governments, banks and private businesses in the range of $80 billion. Planecon, a Washington consulting firm specializing in Eastern European economies, pegs the net debt -- Soviet obligations less sums owed to Moscow -- at about half that. But even the higher official number "would be the envy of most developing countries," said Darryl McLeod, an economist at Fordham University.
The $80 billion represents one and a half times current annual Soviet export earnings -- and just 7 percent of the Soviet G.N.P. Mexico, by contrast, owes 2.5 times as much as it earned from exports in 1990. Even South Korea owes foreigners the equivalent of 17 percent of its G.N.P.
The catch, of course, is that the Mexican and South Korean economies are stable and growing, while lenders doubt both the capacity and the will of the former Soviet republics to service a foreign debt. While Soviet hard currency earnings will actually be higher this year than last because former East bloc trading partners are now required to pay their bills in dollars, signs of the rapid deterioration in Soviet creditworthiness are still plain to those who care to look.
Soviet gold reserves, the former union's rainy day fund, now stand at 240 tons -- hardly enough to cover a month's worth of imports. The production of oil, along with natural gas and weapons, the Soviets' most reliable source of hard-currency revenues, has fallen by a sixth since the peak in 1987. And while David Johnson, an economist at Planecon, notes that the decline largely reflects poor physical management of the oil reserves, production problems are rapidly being compounded by organizational chaos. For example, critical oilfield machinery is desperately scarce because the factory in Azerbaijan has been plagued by the conflict between Muslims and Armenian Christians.
 
Spending on Imports

What is more, the pressure to spend foreign exchange earnings on imports rather than interest payments grows as domestic deliveries of consumer goods falter. Morgan Guaranty estimates that Soviet factories idled for want of parts and supplies will make 15 percent less this year than last. The 1991 harvest was also smaller than expected because farms were short of everything from tractor fuel to fertilizer. And farmers are shipping less of what they produce because they are less than eager to trade food and fiber for rubles that buy nothing.
It is thus no surprise that private foreign lenders are scrambling to trim their exposure, canceling short-term credits that had previously been renewed routinely. Even before the August coup attempt, Susanne Gehler of Morgan Guaranty in London predicted that Soviet short-term debts to Western banks and suppliers would be reduced by $5 billion this year. And with the cupboard otherwise bare -- hard currency reserves are reportedly down to a few billion dollars -- it was obvious the republics would be forced to default on billions in longer-term debts scheduled to be repaid next year.
What was not obvious, is that the response to the impending debt crisis from the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada would be so limited, said Jeffrey Sachs, an economist at Harvard and consultant to the Russian government.
The deal proposed by the Western finance ministers and signed last week by their counterparts from eight republics requires the republics to assume joint responsibility for Soviet debts and to keep current on all interest payments. In return, the Western governments agreed to look the other way when $3.6 billion in principal payments due this year and next fail to arrive. The finance ministers also implied that they would lean on Western (mostly European) banks that hold billions in Soviet i.o.u.'s to make parallel concessions.
 
Pawnshop Operation

But the only cash the West put on the table was a $1 billion line of credit, to be secured by $1 billion of Soviet gold. This pawnshop operation does spare the republics the embarrassment of selling the last of their gold, but as Mr. Hormats of Goldman Sachs said, the Western governments "certainly got a lot for their money."
One unintended result of the hard-nosed bargaining is a further fraying of the inter-republic fabric. While the Ukraine was reportedly willing to guarantee a share of Soviet debt, it balked at Western demands that each republic be responsible for the whole. That can only add to the temptation for the Russian Federation to go its own economic way, Ms. Gehler of Morgan Guaranty suggested.
Western economists are virtually of one voice in urging the opening of borders to inter-republic trade. But the path of least domestic political resistance for Russia, which sells more within the union than it buys, is to require all trade with other republics be settled in dollars at world prices. This would give Russia the ability to divert substantial amounts of oil for sale in the West much the way the demise of the East bloc market created a surge in hard-currency sales for the Soviet Union.
This might damage Russia's economic prospects almost as much as it damaged the oil-importing republics. After all, a substantial portion of Russian exports to other republics consists of manufactured goods that no one would buy if they had to pay hard currency.
But Ms. Gehler of Morgan Guaranty pointed out that it took a year for the former East bloc economies to have second thoughts and begin to reconstruct internal barter arrangements -- a year in which trade between the Soviet Union and its former satellites fell by half, stranding hundreds of thousands of workers in enterprises with nothing worth selling.
The best hope, said Graham Allison at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, is that the debt deal will suck Western governments into the elusive "grand bargain," rewarding a rapid Soviet transition to democratic capitalism with dollars, yen and Deutsche marks. While the agreement offers no money beyond the modest gold swap, it does say that the debt deferral would be renewed beyond 1992 if the republics follow the International Monetary Fund's advice on economic reforms.
Such leverage, Mr. Allison said, "is a step down a slippery slope," toward taking broader responsibility for the economic fate of the shattered Soviet empire.

HEADLINE: Congress Restricts Robot Phone Dialers

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
Riding a wave of popular annoyance over telephone sales calls, Congress today approved and sent to President Bush a bill that would ban the use of automated dialing devices that deliver recorded messages to the home. The measure would also allow consumers to try to block calls from human salespeople by placing their names on a "do not call" list.
The bill, which passed on voice votes in the House on Monday and in the Senate today, was supported by both Democrats and Republicans, some of whom have recounted their own annoying experiences with unsolicited sales calls. Although the White House has expressed concerns about what it views as unnecessary regulation, the President has not threatened to veto the bill. 
 The measure, which combines provisions from several separate measures passed previously by both chambers of Congress, bans the use of autodialers for calling most homes. The few exceptions would be cases in which a person has explicitly agreed to receive such calls or in which autodialers are used to notify people of an emergency. Autodialers that are used to call businesses would be prohibited from reaching more than two numbers at a single business.
Many states have already passed laws that restrict autodialers, including about a dozen states that ban them altogether and about two dozen others that restrict their use in various ways. The state laws, however, do not stop a company from using an autodialer in an unregulated state to call homes in a state with regulations.
In an attempt to curb telemarketing by human sales representatives, the measure would instruct the Federal Communications Commission to either oversee the creation of a nationwide "do not call" list or issue rules ordering companies to maintain their own lists. The bill would allow people who placed their names on such a list to file suits in small claims courts against companies that persisted in calling. The suits could seek up to $500 for each unwanted call, up to a maximum of three calls from a single company.
Finally, the bill would ban unsolicited "junk fax" messages, which are advertisements transmitted to facsimile machines.
"This is a victory for beleaguered consumers, who in this piece of legislation have their declaration of independence from junk faxes and junk calls," said Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, the measure's principal sponsor in the House.
 
Autodialer Companies Respond
 Companies that make or use autodialers glumly predicted today that the measure would put them out of business and would hurt small advertisers the most.
"I think it will put us out of business," said Mark Anderson, owner of the Telleshoppe Corporation, a New Orleans concern that uses about 160 machines for clients who sell everything from tanning products to health insurance. "What people don't understand is that a lot of mom-and-pop operations use electronic marketing and use it successfully."
Ray Kolker, president of Kolker Systems, the largest maker of autodialers, echoed those views. "Passage of this bill demonstrates that Congress just isn't as concerned about the economy as they think they are," he said. "This will destroy a multibillion-dollar business."
Quieting a Booming Business
Telemarketing has surged in recent years, as the cost of long-distance service has plunged and as consumers have become deluged by catalogues they do not read and envelopes they do not open. According to Congressional estimates, the volume of goods and services sold through all forms of telephone marketing has increased from about $72 billion in 1982 to $435 billion in 1990. Over all, an estimated 300,000 people are employed in some facet of telephone marketing.
Autodialers, which can each make about 1,500 calls a day, have become one of the most efficient but disliked forms of telemarketing. By one estimate, 20,000 autodialers are in operation at one time, with the capacity of making more than 20 million calls in a single day.
During hearings on the issue earlier this year, Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, noted irritably that he had been summoned to the telephone only to hear a recorded sales message about winning a trip to Hawaii.
Support From Some Telemarketers
Today's legislation was not opposed by all companies involved in telephone sales. Many marketing experts have long deplored the use of autodialers as a sales tool, arguing that they are counterproductive because they generate more irritation than sales interest. The Direct Marketing Association, a trade group, has expressed cautious support for the legislation and already maintains its own, voluntary "do not call" list.
Beyond simply annoying people at home, the autodialers have been known to tie up telephone paging networks and the switchboards of hospitals and universities.
 
Questions About F.C.C. Options
 But it remains unclear how effective the "do not call" lists would be in practice, because the two options available to the F.C.C. differ greatly.
A national list maintained by the Government would effectively protect consumers from all unwanted sales calls. But a requirement that each company maintain its own list would be much more limited, because people might have to call each company to be placed on its individual list.
Congressional aides noted that the measure passed today strongly implied that the F.C.C. should set up its own list, because it provides two pages of detail on just how such a list should be created.

HEADLINE: Consumer Spending Drops 0.3%

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

 BODY:
The Commerce Department said yesterday that spending by American consumers, which accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity, fell a sharp three-tenths of a percent in October, the biggest decline since April, when spending fell five-tenths of a percent.
Coming after two bleak assessments of consumer confidence released on Monday, the decline suggested a mood of extreme caution among shoppers at the start of the crucial holiday season. 
If that caution persists through November and December, several economists said, it could tip the economy back into decline in the fourth quarter. Growth of 2.4 percent in the third quarter was widely interpreted as a sign that the recession was ending.
 
Weak Christmas Could Linger

Moreover, said David Wyss, the research director for DRI/McGraw-Hill, an economic consulting firm, "a weak Christmas will mean it would be hard to get much action in the first quarter of 1992, because retailers will be overstocked and orders anemic."
Other reports released yesterday by the Commerce Department suggested that consumers were not buying because their income was not increasing, and that much of what they were purchasing was coming from abroad.
Personal income grew a meager two-tenths of a percent in October, the worst showing since July. And the country's trade deficit rose 33 percent in the July-September quarter, to $20.49 billion, the highest level this year.
"Buying imports may be wonderful for Chinese manufacturers, but it's more bad news for U.S. manufacturers," said Walter K. Joelson, the chief economist for the General Electric Company.
 
Jobless Claims Drop

Not all of the news was bad. The Labor Department reported that the number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits fell by 80,000 in mid-November, the biggest one-week improvement in almost a decade. There were 413,000 people filing first-time claims during the week that ended on Nov. 16, down from 493,000 in the previous week.
Because of the Veterans Day holiday, there was less time to file claims in the mid-November week, and some economists dismissed the decline as a fluke. But others said the sharp drop indicated that the labor market was not as weak as the widespread reports of layoffs had suggested.
"The labor market is not unwinding as dramatically as many had feared, and that is really good news for an economy that is trying to stay out of double-dip recession," said Stephen Roach, the chief economist at Morgan Stanley, the Wall Street investment firm.
Orders to American factories for durable goods rose 3 percent in October after two consecutive declines, reaching $123.79 billion, seasonally adjusted. The upturn followed a 4.2 percent drop in September and a 4.1 percent fall in August.
But many economists discounted the slight rise, since it stemmed principally from a 53 percent surge in orders for military equipment. These orders had fallen 49.2 percent in the previous month.
"I just ignore defense business because it can swing so wildly," said Mr. Joelson of General Electric. "The relevant fact is that the numbers are very bad compared to a year ago, when they were not particularly good."
He noted that new orders in October for capital goods other than military items were down 16 percent from October 1990. In the third quarter, the orders were off 3.5 percent from a year earlier.
"My personal sense is that what we have here is a continuation of stagnation," Mr. Joelson added.
 
Consumers Are 'Tapped Out'

This view was shared by several other economists, who used expressions like "a sideways economy" and "an economy that is squeaking by" to characterize the overall situation suggested by the figures released yesterday. None expressed hope of a decisive upturn before spring, and several underlined the danger of a double-dip recession if consumers do not respond soon.
"The economy is basically doing nothing because the consumer is doing nothing," said Mr. Wyss of DRI/McGraw-Hill. "He's tapped out and he's seeing no income gain.
"Moreover, it seems that what demand there is is being sucked off by imports."
Irwin Kellner, the chief economist for Manufacturers Hanover Trust, added: "The economic pulse is beating, but it's very weak. I'm not prepared to throw in the towel on a recovery yet, but it's a recovery that seems to be just barely alive."

HEADLINE: Congress Votes $100 Billion Bank and S.& L. Aid

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
In a final burst of legislation before adjourning until January, Congress today approved two broad bailout measures that total more than $100 billion, one for the nation's banking industry and one to continue the Government's rescue of hundreds of savings and loans.
Along with the adoption of a $151 billion, six-year transportation program, the actions on financial bailouts were the most significant accomplishments of the final day of a Congressional session that began on the sober note of war with Iraq and concluded with a quarrelsome sitting that lasted 33 hours and 2 minutes. 
 Even though President Bush threatened to veto a similar banking bill several weeks ago, he is expected to sign both the banking measure and the savings and loan measure. Regulators say the insurance funds that protect almost $3 trillion in deposits at banks and savings associations are virtually empty, and the Government has already slowed its pace in seizing weak institutions. Together, the two bills are the largest spending effort by the Government for any financial crisis in American history.
There was considerable fear on Capitol Hill today that the bills -- while essential to the health of the nation's financial system -- would still not provide enough money and could come back to haunt the lawmakers politically. Facing a choice between being irresponsible or unpopular, House members took the unusual step of deciding not to record any significant votes but to approve the legislation and all key amendments by voice vote.
"This is an unpleasant task," said the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri. "But I hope everyone will remember that we're not bailing out anyone but our constituents, who have their deposits in institutions."
The Senate was headed on a similar course until Paul Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota, insisted that votes be recorded.
 
Direct Cost to Taxpayers
 The savings and loan bill would directly cost taxpayers at least $25 billion and increase the amount that could be borrowed for working capital by $35 billion, and Administration officials and lawmakers expressed new concerns this week that the mounting problems of the banking industry could raise those costs substantially if the economy and real estate markets around the nation remain anemic.
Because the money would come from long-term borrowing, it would have no immediate effect on the Federal budget. The proceeds would give regulators the wherewithal to mount a wave of seizures of banks and savings associations beginning in January.
The bank bill, which would provide more than $70 billion in taxpayer loans that are supposed to be repaid by the industry, was completed by House and Senate negotiators after a marathon drafting session that ended at 4:57 this morning.
It was stripped of all the recommendations the Bush Administration made in February to eliminate more than 60 years of Federal laws restricting banks from entering the securities and insurance businesses and from being owned by industrial enterprises, like General Motors and I.B.M. The Administration argued that banks could be strengthened by repeal of those laws.
Congress also rejected the Administration's recommendations to impose modest limits on the deposits that insurance can cover, and to combine four regulatory agencies into two.
After a subdued debate, the House approved the banking measure by voice vote with fewer than three dozen lawmakers on the floor.
The savings and loan measure was approved 44 to 33 in the Senate, with the support of 23 Democrats and 21 Republicans and over the opposition of 23 Democrats and 10 Republicans. While no recorded vote was taken in the House, 112 members were counted in favor of the bailout measure and 63 rose in objection.
The banking bill was approved by the Senate on a 68-to-15 vote. Voting for the measure were 36 Democrats and 32 Republicans. Voting against it were 13 Democrats and 2 Republicans.
The White House proposals fell victim to a combination of intense lobbying by some of Washington's most powerful financial interest groups, from Wall Street, the insurance industry and the nation's smallest banks. Critics asserted that the proposals, by deregulating the industry, would lead to greater bank losses that would ultimately have to be borne by taxpayers.
For his part, President Bush did little during the months leading to today's vote to promote the legislation, leaving most of the work to Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady.
In a statement after the vote, Mr. Brady repeated his view that taxpayers might ultimately be forced to pay for the bank bailout because the House and Senate had rejected his proposals on broad changes to the banking system.
 
Brady's Criticism
 "Congress failed to take the opportunity to strengthen the American financial system and enable banks to attract sufficient private capital to help insure that the possibility of taxpayers' paying for industry losses could be avoided," Mr. Brady said. But many lawmakers said imbedded losses in the nation's largest banks made a taxpayer bailout of them inevitable, and on Monday one of the nation's senior regulators, William Taylor of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said the Administration's proposals would probably have only helped to reduce losses "at the margins."
Administration officials, who had defended their recommendations on the ground that they would permit the banks to become more profitable and diversify their businesses, said today that there was virtually no chance that Congress would address these issues again next year.
"The only way to do it is with bipartisan support, and in the run-up to an election, it very difficult to imagine such support," said a senior Administration official who insisted on not being identified.
Earlier this month, the House rejected two other banking bills before it approved the measure that formed the basis for today's legislation.
The following provisions are also included in the bill passed today:
*Regulators would be given more authority to seize weak banks and monitor foreign banks. They would also be instructed to conduct more examinations of banks.
*Banks would be required to provide more accurate information about the interest rates they pay depositors.
*No banks would be able use new affiliates in Delaware to underwrite insurance, but banks that already have such affiliates, notably Citicorp and Bankers Trust, would be permitted to remain in that business.
*The Supreme Court's recent ruling in Lampf v. Gilbertson would be partly overturned so that it would not apply to cases filed before the decision. The case had sharply limited the statute of limitations for securities fraud lawsuits filed by shareholders.
 
Victory for Small Banks
 *Charitable organizations that had accounts of more than $100,000 at Freedom National Bank in Harlem and Community National Bank and Trust on Staten Island would receive complete deposit insurance coverage.
*The Federal Government would provide loan guarantees to assist depositors at Rhode Island credit unions and banks that collapsed and were not federally insured.
The clear winners in today's legislation were the nation's smallest banks, which had fought hard to defeat the Administration's proposal because they said it would give their larger rivals the ability to take them over and to compete more directly against them. Wall Street and the insurance industry, which had also opposed the Administration's proposals for fear that the banks would be able to enter their industries, also fared well.
The savings and loan measure would provide an additional $25 billion, enough to continue that bailout through March. It would also include an increase to $160 billion, from $125 billion, in the amount regulators can borrow for working capital for the bailout. Those loans are supposed to be repaid through the sale of assets from seized institutions, but they could add substantially to the taxpayers' ultimate bill if the Government is unable to recover all of the money lent on the underlying assets. The Administration had sought $80 billion, which it said would be enough to complete the bailout.
Congress has already provided $80 billion since the bailout began more than two years ago. Government auditors have forecast that the bailout could cost $500 billion over 40 years.
The legislation would also change the structure of the savings and loan bailout by merging the two boards that now supervise the rescue effort into one. The new seven-member board is to be led by the Treasury Secretary and includes the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, the chief executive of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the head of the Office of Thrift Supervision, and two members from private industry.

HEADLINE: Congress Moves to Force Icahn to Insure T.W.A. Pensions

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
Congress served notice today on Carl C, Icahn, chairman of Trans World Airlines, that he would be personally liable for the pensions of T.W.A.'s employees even if he proceeded with plans to restructure the ailing carrier.
Unions representing workers for the carrier, which has its hub in St. Louis, persuaded members of the Missouri delegation to sponsor a measure that would force Mr. Icahn to retain liability for the unfunded portions of T.W.A.'s pensions, even if his stake in the company dips below 80 percent, the legal limit at which shareholders assume that liability. 
 The measure was an amendment to a $6.9 billion emergency appropriation, which was approved by the House early in the morning in a 303-to-114 vote and by a voice vote in the Senate later in the day. The sponsors included Senator John C. Danforth, a Republican, and Representative Richard A. Gephardt, a Democrat, who is the majority leader.
 
May Be a First
 Financial analysts and pension law experts said they knew of no previous instance when a company owner was required to retain his liability for pensions when his equity stake fell below 80 percent.
The unions feared that if Mr. Icahn was relieved of pension liability, he would sell the carrier's assets, shut the airline down and walk away.
"This gives Icahn, for the first time, a compelling economic interest in keeping T.W.A. in operation," a Republican Senate aide said.
Mr. Icahn has been negotiating for several months with the carrier's creditors to retructure T.W.A.'s debt, which the company says is $190 million. As part of that restructuring, Mr. Icahn is reportedly attempting to reduce his equity stake in the carrier from more than 80 percent to less than 50 percent, though he would retain control.
 
15.2% Not Funded

Company records indicated that 15.2 percent of the carrier's pension plan was not funded as of Sept. 30. At that time, the company estimated its pension liability at $193 million, but some independent estimates placed the figure as high as $900 million.
The Congressional action also means that even if T.W.A. went out of business, Mr. Icahn would be remain liable for the unfunded portion of the pension for up to six years. Under Federal law, former employees could attach up to 30 percent of his assets to make up the shortage in the carrier's pension plan.
Some legal experts said Mr. Icahn's other holdings -- in ACF Industries, for example -- could be at risk of being attached to pay for the unfunded portion of the T.W.A. pension plan if the carrier ceased operating and its former employees sought immediate payment of their pensions -- their right under pension laws.
"Depending on the size of the unfunded pension liability claim, he might have to sell his interest in his other business to make good those claims," said Julius Maldutis, director of research at Salomon Brothers.
The measure could make it more difficult for Mr. Icahn to borrow money since any assets he used as collateral could be attached because of the unfunded pension liability.
