U.S. MOVES TO RECOGNIZE UKRAINE
President Bush has decided to recognize an independent Ukraine "expeditiously" if the second-largest Soviet republic breaks with Moscow in a referendum on Sunday. The decision represents a major shift in American policy away from the central Soviet Government. Page A1
 
KHMER ROUGE CHIEF ASSAULTED
Screaming "murderer" and vowing to "kill the monster," a mob of revenge-seeking Cambodians beat and bloodied Khieu Samphan, a senior Khmer Rouge leader, and forced him to flee to Thailand only hours after he returned to the Cambodian capital under the auspices of a United Nations peace treaty. A1
 
U.N. BACKS YUGOSLAV PEACE FORCE
The Security Council pledged to send a peacekeeping force of up to 10,000 soldiers to reinforce the fragile cease-fire in Yugoslavia if the warring Serbs and Croats show they really want peace. The council had to overcome the reservations of many countries worried about creating a precedent by intervening in what is essentially a civil war. A1
 
ISRAEL REBUFFS U.S. ON TALKS
In a blunt challenge to the United States, Israel rejected an American call for a new round of peace negotiations in Washington next week. It proposed instead that the talks be delayed for five days and then moved quickly to a new site in or near the Middle East. A1

U.S. AND IRAN REACH SETTLEMENT

HEADLINE: U.S., TURNING FROM MOSCOW, WOULD GRANT RECOGNITION TO AN INDEPENDENT UKRAINE

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
President Bush has authorized a major shift in American policy away from the central Soviet Government and toward the republics, deciding to recognize an independent Ukraine "expeditiously" if the second-largest Soviet republic breaks with Moscow in a referendum on Sunday, officials said today.
Independence fever in the Ukraine is running high, and Administration officials say they expect the Ukrainians will vote to separate from the Soviet Union. In that case, Washington will start trying to strengthen its ties with the Ukraine immediately, but will delay formal diplomatic recognition for some time, perhaps weeks, the officials said.
 
U.S. Would Set Demands
 Instead, in hopes of setting a pattern for demands from other republics for similar treatment, United States recognition of the Ukraine will be timed according to the speed with which the Ukrainians move to ease American concerns on human rights, ethnic tensions, disarmament and control over nuclear weapons, officials said. 
 On Aug. 1, less than three weeks before the abortive hard-line coup in Moscow, President Bush delivered a peech in Kiev, the Ukrainian capital, warning against what he called "suicidal nationalism" and saying that the United States would not choose sides between Moscow and the restive republics.
Today, Administration officials said that the President was prepared eventually to open an embassy in Kiev and establish diplomatic relations with an independent country that has its own foreign, military and economic policies. It is unclear, however, how far the Ukrainians will go in severing all of their ties to the central Government.
 
Challenge to Moscow
 Still, Mr. Bush's willingness to recognize full independence if the Ukrainians choose it represents the first real challenge from Washington to the central Soviet Government's ability to hold together its ragged union, which would be seriously undermined by the independence of the second-largest of the 12 remaining republics, one that supplies much of the country's industrial and agricultural output. If the Ukraine becomes independent, it would be the fourth-most-populous nation situated wholly in Europe.
American support for Ukrainian independence also threatens one of President's Mikhail S. Gorbachev's remaining threads of power: Mr. Bush's explicit, and hitherto often-proffered, endorsement of Mr. Gorbachev as the sole legitimate repository of sovereignty in the Soviet Union.
There was no formal announcement of Mr. Bush's decision, which officials said was made on Tuesday at an Oval Office meeting with his top foreign policy advisers and conveyed to a group of Ukrainian-Americans at a White House meeting today. Instead, details were provided by Administration officials who spoke on condition of anonymity.
They said that President Gorbachev "is aware" of Mr. Bush's plans but that his reaction was not known. "We've spoken to the Ukrainians and the Russians about this and they're the ones that count," one official said.
White House officials said Mr. Yeltsin's reaction was also unknown.
After the vote Sunday, one official said, Mr. Bush will initially issue "a strong statement supporting Ukrainian aspirations." That will be followed by a strengthening of Ukrainian-American relations and "sooner rather than later" by full diplomatic recognition.
Administration officials said Mr. Bush was deliberately not setting any timetable for full recognition of the Ukraine to avoid the appearance of hesitation that marked his recognition of the Baltic nations and to see how Ukrainian policy develops in the areas outlined by the United States in recent contacts with Ukrainian officials.
 
Support for the Kremlin
 For months since the aborted Kremlin coup in August, Mr. Bush clung to a policy of supporting the central Government in Moscow, and in particular Mr. Gorbachev, despite growing evidence that Mr. Gorbachev's Government was losing its powers.
Officials were careful today to stress that Mr. Bush still supports Mr. Gorbachev. But they said American policy had been slowly shifting toward greater ties with the republics and a recognition that independence for some of them is inevitable.
In recent months, there has been a division within the Administration's top foreign policy councils over policy toward the Soviet Union, officials said. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney had been pushing for some time for stronger ties to the republics, while Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security adviser, argued in favor of supporting the center, they said.
Mr. Bush's inclination was to stick to the established authority as long as possible, officials said.
On Tuesday, Mr. Bush met with Mr. Baker, Mr. Scowcroft and Mr. Cheney in the Oval Office and Mr. Scowcroft threw his support to Mr. Cheney's position, officials said. "That tipped the scales," an official said.
The White House said it was prepared to take this action despite lingering disputes over Ukrainian-Russian borders, and said the United States would leave it to the Ukrainians and the Russians to resolve those differences. Shortly after the coup, a statement was issued in the name of President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian federated republic in which the Russian republic said it would not let other Soviet republics secede form the union taking areas with heavily Russian populations with them. A Yeltsin spokesman said at the time that the statement referred to areas of northern Kazakhstan and to the Donets Basin region and the Crimea, both in the Ukraine.
Although White House officials said tensions over this issue seem to have subsided, one of the effects of the Yeltsin declaration was to galvanize the Ukrainians' separatist drive, by stirring old Ukrainian fears that Russia seeks to dominate its neighbor. About 20 percent of the Ukraine's 52 million people are Russian, with areas of Russian population concentrated in the eastern part of the republic.
In his meeting today with the Ukrainian-Americans, officials said Mr. Bush promised that Washington "will be prepared to salute Ukrainian independence" on Sunday and "that we will move forward on the issue."
In another sign of change in American policy, an official said today that this week, after the Senate ratified the treaty reducing conventional armed forces in Europe, known as the C.F.E. Treaty, that Washington contacted "both Moscow -- the Russians -- and Kiev -- the Ukrainians -- to urge them to ratify it as well."
The United States has been warning the Ukraine for some time against trying to gain control of the nuclear weapons on its soil for any purpose other than to destroy them.
The White House also has signaled that it would be reluctant to give aid to the Ukraine if it carried through on an announcement that it planned to develop its own, large-scale military.
President Leonid M. Kravchuk of the Ukraine sent Mr. Bush a letter recently reassuring him that the Ukraine did not seek to develop an offensive army, an official said. Mr. Kravchuk, the official said, asserted that the Ukraine's plans for a 400,000-man army represented a "demobilization" from the current 1.5-million-strong Soviet military force on Ukrainian soil.

HEADLINE: U.S. Base Is an Oasis To Haitians

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GUANTANAMO BAY, Cuba, Nov. 27

 BODY:
In a dusty clearing ringed by double rows of concertina wire and patrolled by armed American guards, scores of Haitian refugees stood in long lines for lunch today at an emergency camp being built here to guard their welfare.
"We don't know how long we'll be here, but we know we can't go back" to Haiti, said Celius Pierre Williams, a 39-year-old math teacher, voicing a sentiment loudly seconded by several young men clustered around him. "The army would kill us." 
 The tent city springing up in a corner of an American naval base here aims to ease the burden on the overcrowded Coast Guard and Navy vessels that have plucked thousands of Haitians from the rickety vessels on which they left their country. The refugees were fleeing from the turmoil that followed the ouster of Haiti's first democratically elected leader, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, on Sept. 30.
 
135 Tents Going Up
 Today about 240 refugees were being transferred from a Coast Guard cutter to an emergency center of cinderblock buildings and World War II-era Quonset huts at Camp Bulkeley, a former Marine training center at the Guantanamo Bay naval base.
By Friday, about 135 large green canvas tents will accommodate about 20 people each, or a total of roughly 2,500 people. Just over 1,000 refugees are living at the camp now.
More than 2,000 Haitians remained on 14 other Coast Guard vessels, and others were in custody in Navy ships offshore. Many of the refugees survived their perilous voyages with only the clothes they were wearing.
On a tour organized by the Pentagon, reporters were guided today through the emergency camp and to some of the cutters. "We're going to see a continued flow of Haitians," acknowledged the commander of the military task force responsible for building the refugee center, Brig. Gen. George H. Walls Jr. of the Marines.
General Walls said he expected to receive orders soon to maximize the shelter capacity on the base. American military officials said that such an order could mean beds for several thousand more refugees.
 
A Political Limbo
 The military and Coast Guard emphasize that theirs is a humanitarian mission. For the Haitians, though, the emergency camp at the American military base on Cuba's eastern tip is a political limbo, and a short-term solution to a difficult diplomatic issue.
United States officials argue that the Haitians are economic refugees and should not be granted political asylum. But the Bush Administration is facing criticism that this stance conflicts with its policy of opposing the forced repatriation of Vietnamese boat people from Hong Kong.
Officials from the Immigration and Naturalization Service who were here to interview the Haitians told reporters that the refugees had fled to escape the indiscriminate violence that spread through their country after President Aristide's ouster.
"Some of my family was killed by stray bullets," said Ari Milot, a 26-year-old fisherman. "The army would come and knock down entire villages."
Aboard the Coast Guard cutter Legare, 285 Haitians were crammed today onto a helicopter flight deck, , huddled together under a patchwork quilt of canvas tarps lashed together by Air Force crews. .
Most of the refugees on the ship were young men and teen-agers. "Traveling is too difficult for the children," said Erick Chery, a 25-year-old day laborer.
In interviews conducted in French and English and in Creole through an interpreter, the refugees on the Legare said they received two sizable meals of rice, pinto beans and fresh fruit each day. Dressed in short-sleeved shirts, trousers and shower togs provided by the Coast Guard, most of the men and boys said they had no other belongings with them.
On another Coast Guard cutter, the Steadfast, the otherwise quiet refugees lined the top deck and sang a spiritual hymn, swaying and clapping to some of the refrains: "Glory to the Lord! Hallelujah!" and "The time has come."
 
Straining Guard's Resources
 General Walls said that the crowded conditions aboard the ships were taxing the Coast Guard's resources and made it imperative that the refugees be unloaded.
The refugees will receive more hospitable if still spartan accommodations on the site at Camp Bulkeley, which juts out into the Caribbean at the naval base's northern boundary. The transfer will also free up Coast Guard vessels to resume patrols.
At the windswept campsite, 18 to 20 cots are squeezed under each canvas tent, per United Nations specifications. Men and women live in separate quarters, and children stay with oneparent.
The food is better here too, the refugees said. The base commander, Capt. William C. McCamy of the Navy, said the military serves a hot breakfast, including scrambled eggs, oatmeal, fruit and juice.
About 2,400 personnel are stationed at the Guantanamo Bay base, which was first leased to Washington by Cuba in 1903. The base became a symbol of cold-war tensions after Fidel Castro rose to power in 1959. The United States pays an annual rent of about $4,000, but Cuba has never cashed the checks.

The camps were built to ease the burden on the overcrowded Coast Guard and Navy vessels that have plucked thousands of refugees from unseaworthy vessels. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: In Medicaid Vote, Congress Limits How States Can Pay

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
Congress today passed legislation that sets new ground rules for the financing of Medicaid, severely restricting the states' use of certain taxes and other devices to pay for the health care of 27 million poor people.
The bill follows the contours of an agreement negotiated last week by the Bush Administration and the National Governors' Association, which lobbied for the bill in the hope that it would slow the explosive growth of Medicaid. 
 President Bush is expected to sign the measure, which will curtail the states' ability to shift Medicaid costs from state governments to the Federal Government.
 
Effect in Region
 Officials in New York and New Jersey said the bill could adversely affect their states because it sets limits on Federal payments to hospitals serving large numbers of poor people, at a time when the need for such care appears to be growing. Connecticut expects no adverse effect.
Thomas A. Scully, associate director of the Office of Management and Budget, who represented the White House in negotiations with Congress on Medicaid, said: "I'm happy. It's a reasonable compromise."
Raymond C. Scheppach, executive director of the National Governors Association, said, "We are very pleased."
But Representative Henry A. Waxman, a California Democrat who is chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health, said that as a result of the deal struck today "it's going to be much more difficult for low-income patients to get the care they need," in part because there will be "artificial limits on reimbursement" of certain hospitals serving large numbers of poor people.
The bill limits the states' ability to pay their share of Medicaid through money collected from hospitals, as taxes or voluntary donations. States count these taxes and donations as part of their share of Medicaid and can get back in Federal matching funds as much as four dollars for every one collected. The Administration had called some of these fund-raising arrangements scams, because hospitals got back more than they contributed, and Washington bore most of the cost.
Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, said: "These financing arrangements are, in effect, an open spigot in the Federal Treasury. There is virtually no limit to the amount of money that the Federal Government may end up pouring into these programs."
Thirty-eight states, including New York, New Jersey, Florida, Texas and California, have adopted such fund-raising arrangements to finance health care for poor people, especially children and pregnant women. Under the bill, states may continue using such techniques until at least Sept. 30, 1992, and some states could continue as late as June 30, 1993.
The Federal Government and the states share the cost of Medicaid. The state share rises with a state's per capita income, to a maximum of 50 percent in higher-income states like New York and California.
 
Types of Restrictions
 The bill approved today would eventually impose three types of restrictions on the states' ability to pay for Medicaid:
*States would no longer receive Federal matching money for revenue obtained from donations by hospitals or nursing homes.
*If states impose taxes on hospitals or nursing homes, such taxes may not account for more than 25 percent of the state share of Medicaid.
*Special payments to hospitals serving "a disproportionate number of low-income patients" must not exceed 12 percent of total national spending on Medicaid. Eighteen states are now above that level and the Administration says that some states have abused this provision of the Medicaid law by designating too may hospitals as eligible for these extra payments.
In September, the Administration issued rules that would have imposed much more severe restrictions on state fund-raising techniques. The bill approved today blocks those rules, which were to take effect on Jan. 1, 1992.
Until now, there have been virtually no Federal restrictions on how states pay their share of Medicaid costs. The bill adopted today, therefore, represents a fundamental change in the program, which was created in 1965.
Mr. Scheppach of the governors' association said the bill was good because it provided the "permanence and stability" that state officials need in planning Medicaid programs and budgets.
But Mr. Waxman, a longtime defender of the Medicaid program, said, "The governors made a mistake entering into this agreement with the Administration, and I think they are going to regret very soon allowing the Federal Government to interfere so heavily with their ability to run Medicaid and finance the program."
Mr. Waxman said that governors had "a gun to their head" as they negotiated with the Administration. The gun, he said, was the set of regulations scheduled to take effect Jan. 1.
Members of Congress wrote special provisions into the bill to soften its effect on a handful of states, including Connecticut, Texas and Georgia.
The bill was passed by voice vote in both houses after a conference committee worked out a compromise.
Senator Wyche Fowler Jr., Democrat of Georgia, initially warned that the bill would have a "potentially disastrous effect." But after talking with the Federal Health Care Financing Administration, he said that he would support the bill because he had obtained "critical changes that should prove beneficial to the State of Georgia."
Bruce Lesley, a Washington representative for the State of Texas, said tonight: "The Administration bought off states one by one, making concessions to address their specific concerns. We have been working on this issue for six months, but does the bill improve the health of anyone? The answer is no. It just sets limits on the Medicaid program."
The bill passed today does not effect a section of the Medicaid law that says payments to hospitals and nursing homes must be "reasonable and adequate." Many hospitals and nursing homes have sucessfully sued states to force them to raise their Medicaid payments, and such suits are likely to increase if states do not find new sources of revenue to replace those banned by the bill passed today.
Medicaid has grown rapidly in the last year because of the recession and because Congress expanded eligibility to new groups of people.
The Administration estimates that state fund-raising schemes will cost the Federal Government $5.5 billion in extra payments this year. Without the new restrictions, it said, the cost would rise to $10 billion next year.

HEADLINE: Strategy of a Tax Cut

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
After months of hesitation and often aimless economic debate, the White House and Congress have suddenly decided that now is the right time to talk about a tax cut, even if it is not the right time to enact one.
It remains unlikely that Congress will actually act on tax reduction until next year, even after completion of hearings on the issue that House and Senate chairmen today scheduled for December. There are strong pressures against a cut now, including economic arguments that it might not be the best way to speed the economy's recovery. 
 But there is no doubt that Washington has just gone through one of those peculiar moments in which all parties seem to have been stampeded at least into the appearance of action by a sudden political epiphany.
 
Critical Issue Unaddressed
 In this case, it seemed, both Congress and the White House came to the realization that lawmakers were about to go home for two months without addressing the one issue foremost in voters' minds -- the sagging economy -- and that it would get increasingly hard for them to keep blaming each other for the lapse.
Over a chaotic 24 hours, a last-minute economic proposal that a group of House Republicans floated as a short-term tactical measure suddenly galvanized the capital, even though it was not supported even by a majority of their own party.
After initially chastising the sponsors, President Bush reversed himself and reluctantly endorsed their plan, only to find himself assailed once again for flip-flopping in a way that Republican strategists found uncomfortably like his vacillation over taxes in the 1990 budget debate.
The Democrats, for their part, gleefully scheduled hearings next month on the Republican plan by the Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee. The Democrats are expected to bring up their own proposals for tax cuts, while attacking the Republicans over tax cuts that Democrats say favor the wealthiest Americans. The Democrats also left open the possibility of returning to a session in December, rather than sitting at home and waiting for the broadside from the White House that Mr. Bush had warned would be forthcoming in the winter recess.
 
'Politician's' Holy Grail'
 The result will inevitably be a lot of punchy political lines, but perhaps not much sound economic policy.
"They're all searching for the tax cut that raises revenue -- the politician's Holy Grail," said Herbert Stein, an economist with the American Enterprise Institute, adding that it did not seem likely to him that the quest would bear fruit.
It all began with Republicans in the House of Representatives who, frustrated by the President's inaction, threw together a last-minute economic growth package, including a cut in the tax rate on profits from investments, to show they were concerned about the economy even if the White House did not appear to be.
Leading the charge was Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip, who is one of the most vocal proponents of a tax cut and, by extension, one of the leading critics of White House inaction.
The Republicans dared their Democratic opponents to bring it to the floor before the Thanksgiving recess, knowing it had no prayer of passage but counting on attacking the Democrats later if they failed to take action.
 
Letter Inflames Bush
 At first, Mr. Bush was annoyed by the Republican move, Administration officials said, and a letter over the weekend from 81 of the 166 House Republicans urging Mr. Bush to appoint Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp as his domestic policy czar only served to inflame Mr. Bush further.
Mr. Bush is reported to have said he saw the letter and the growth package as the kind of challenge that would not have been made to President Richard M. Nixon or to President Ronald Reagan, and on Monday he told a group of House Republicans that he would not back their bill.
But Administration officials said Mr. Bush had been coming under increasing pressure from his own aides, from within the party and from supporters around the country, to take some action on the economy, if only to demonstrate that he is concerned about domestic issues and stem the decline in his public approval ratings.
The noise finally penetrated the White House on Tuesday morning, officials said, when Vice President Dan Quayle, who had returned from a trip to Massachusetts on Monday evening, told the President in the Oval Office that everyone in New England was talking about how bad the economy was and waiting for him to do something.
After an intensive discussion among Mr. Bush, Mr. Quayle, John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, and Richard G. Darman, the budget director, Mr. Bush decided to lend his support to Mr. Gingrich's Republican growth package.
In doing so, he strayed from the advice of top White House advisers, including Mr. Sununu, Mr. Darman and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who had been telling Mr. Bush for weeks not to take action to spur economic growth and that, in particular, engaging in a bidding war with the Democrats over a tax cut would be politically suicidal.
"There had been an argument for weeks in the Administration about whether it was better to get Congress out of town or take the lead on our economic agenda even if that meant keeping them around a while," one official said.
"It happens that Brady and Sununu wanted to believe that a lot of our trouble had to do with Congress being around," the official said. "There was a certain amount of self-deception and self-justification there."
In the end, he said, "The President was convinced he could not fail to show support for a united effort by House Republicans, which embodies our own principles, on the ground that life is easier if Congress is not around. That's not a policy, it's an excuse."
 
Gambit Falls Flat
 While Mr. Sununu telephoned Mr. Gingrich to tell him the President had changed his mind, Mr. Bush told reporters at a photo opportunity that he was "enthusiastic" about Mr. Gingrich's plan and demanded that Congress vote on it that very day.
The tactic fell flat. For one thing, Mr. Gingrich's proposal was not even in legislative form at the time, and many Republican lawmakers and party strategists said Mr. Bush's endorsement was too tepid and too late.
Mr. Bush's endorsement also turned around the Democrats on Capitol Hill, focusing the normally confused closing days of a Congressional session on a single issue, emboldening their attack on the White House over the economy and leaving the White House open for another fight over the capital gains tax cut.
The Democrats have had success in portraying that proposal as a tax break for the rich, while the Republicans have struggled to make their argument that it would also benefit the middle class.
Meanwhile, nobody at either end of Capitol Hill missed the point that Mr. Bush seemed to be putting his economic agenda in the hands of Mr. Gingrich, who last year showed no compunction about breaking with the White House openly and dramatically when Mr. Bush broke his "no new taxes" campaign pledge from 1988.
And, even worse in the eyes of many Republicans, the President appeared to be flip-flopping on taxes again. One Republican commented that if a radio program were to be made about this White House, it would have to be called "Flipper McGee and Millie."

HEADLINE: Democrats Set Hearings On Taxes and Economy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
Preparing the ground for a showdown with President Bush next year, Congressional Democrats announced today a series of public hearings next month on tax policy and the state of the economy.
Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said the first witnesses he would call, in hearings that he scheduled for next week, would be the President's top economic policy advisers. Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas said he would try to get those Administration officials to appear before his Finance Committee as well. 
 No legislation would be drafted until next year. But the Democrats intend to use the hearings during what is usually a slow time in Washington to spotlight their proposals for tax cuts for middle-income families and to paint the President as the patron of fat cats.
 
Goal for Tax Legislation
 The Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, said he hoped a tax measure would be enacted early next year.
Mr. Rostenkowski scheduled hearings for Dec. 5 and 6, Mr. Bentsen set his for Dec. 12 and 13, and Mr. Rostenkowski scheduled two more days on Dec. 17 and 18.
In an interview, Mr. Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, accused the Democrats of trying "to get attention," but he said Administration officials would be pleased to testify next week.
The Democratic strategy is to control the political stage each week between now and Christmas.
The mood among Congressional Democrats today was one of utter relief. They had feared that Mr. Bush would have the political arena to himself for two months while Congress was out of session and would use that time to campaign against the Democratic Congress for leaving town without a plan for dealing with the economy.
On Tuesday, Mr. Bush endorsed a tax-cut plan hastily drafted late last week by Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia and other conservative House Republicans. Until then, the White House position had been that the President would present a full-scale plan to deal with weakness in the economy in his State of the Union Message, probably in February.
The Democrats were having a hard time mounting an attack against patience, but once Mr. Bush sided with Mr. Gingrich, against the advice of some of his more moderate advisers, the Democrats seized the opportunity.
They believe they can win politically by demonstrating that Mr. Bush is behind a giveaway to the rich, while they favor middle-class tax relief.
"He got us off the hook," said Representative Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota.
The Democrats circulated a study by the theoretically nonpartisan expert staff of the Congressional Joint Tax Committee showing that under the Republican plan, taxpayers with incomes between $20,000 and $50,000 a year would get tax cuts ranging from $45 to $84, while those with incomes above $200,000 a year could count on a tax reduction of more than $11,500.
Mr. Gingrich challenged those figures, saying they did not take account of hundreds of thousands of new jobs that he said would be created by an economy stimulated by the Republican tax cuts.
But statistics like the Joint Tax Committee's proved to be a boon to Democrats in last year's budget negotiations.
A Congressional staff assistant said Mr. Rostenkowski called Administration officials today and invited them to testify on "the Bush-Gingrich tax plan."
Mr. Rostenkowski's staff said the first two days of his hearings would involve Administration officials and other politicians with tax plans. Prominent economists will testify at the hearings later in the month.
Senator Bentsen said in an interview that he had not prepared a witness list but that he hoped Mr. Bush's top advisers would testify. He has expressed frustration all year about the refusal of Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, to appear before his panel to testify on tax policy.
House Democrats discussed their strategy at a caucus late Tuesday night. "Nothing unites the Democrats like Newt Gingrich," said a staff assistant who attended the closed session.
According to some lawmakers, Democratic leaders, including Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the party whip, argued that Congress should go back into session after Thanksgiving and pass a Democratic tax bill that Mr. Bush would have to sign or veto.
But cooler heads prevailed. Representative Leon E. Panetta of California, chairman of the House Budget Committee, said the economy was so "fragile" that to pass a bill in haste would be irresponsible.
At the end of a news conference this evening, Mr. Foley said, "It's important we have the opportunity to examine a number of proposals fully and responsibly."
On the House floor today, Republicans continued to insist that their tax plan would give the economy a quick jolt and should be approved at once. "Our economy is hurting a great deal," said Representative Vin Weber of Minnesota. "Despite the fact that this is the 11th hour, we should act now."
Democrats have proposed a variety of tax measures, but all of them would have the effect of giving tax cuts worth hundreds of dollars a year to families with incomes in the range of $20,000 to $50,000 a year.
 
Taxing the Rich
 Mr. Rostenkowski favors paying for those cuts by raising taxes on the wealthy. Other Democrats have other ways, like cutting military spending to keep the Treasury from losing money.
Among the main elements of the Republican plan are a lower capital gains tax rate, new tax breaks for small businesses and real estate investments, a new form of individual retirement account, tax incentives for savings by families with incomes below $50,000 and an increase in the amount older people can earn from working without reduction in their Social Security benefits.
Democrats say the Republican plan would cost the Treasury more than $20 billion over five years. The Republicans say the revenue generated by the capital gains cut and the new I.R.A. rules would offset that cost.
 
 
A SAMPLING OF TAX CUT PROPOSALS

 
BENTSEN AND ROTH
 
Proposal: Am income tax credit of $300 for each child 18 or younger and, regardless of income or pension coverage, full deductibility of up to $2,000 in contributions to individual retirement accounts.
 
Plan for financing: A 5 percent reduction in military spending.
 
Sponsors: Senator Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, and Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware.
 
 
ROSTENKOWSKI
 
Proposal: An income tax credit equal to 20 percent of the Social Security and Medicare taxes the worker pays, with a maximum of $200 for a single taxpayer and $400 for a working couple. The credits would last two years.
 
Plan for financing: A 10 percent tax surcharge on that part of income above $1 million and a rise in the top tax bracket from the current 31 percent to 35 percent, which would apply to incomes above $85,000 for individuals and $145,000 for couples.
 
Sponsors: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois.
 
 
HOUSE REPUBLICAN<spade>
 
Proposal: A cut in the capital gains tax, to about 20 percent from the current cap of 28 percent, phased in over three years; adjustment in the value of capital gains to take account of inflation; withdrawal of I.R.A. funds without penalty for the purchase of a first home; a new form of I.R.A. in which earnings on accounts held at least five years would not be taxed; a deduction of up to $450 a year for savings by taxpayers with incomes below $50,000; an increase in the amount of income a person could earn and still receive Social Security benefits; tax breaks for investments by small businesses; tax break for real estate investments.
 
Plan for financing: According to the sponsors' reckoning, challenged by Democrats, the cost of the tax cuts, more than $20 billion over five years, would be offset by revenue generated by the reduction in the capital gains tax and the new form of I.R.A.'s.
 
Sponsors: House Repbulican Polciy Committee.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
3 A.M. in the Capitol, and Not Pretty

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
About 3 this morning, Representative Charles Wilson, the lanky Texas Democrat, could be found sprawled out on a bench just outside the House chamber, snoring away. Passers-by hardly noticed him.
Several other members were sitting nearby, eyes shut, in wingback leather chairs and in an anteroom off the House floor, and the couches in the cloakrooms were fully occupied. 
 Not so in the Senate, which had tired of waiting for the House to pass some bill or other and recessed for a short night's sleep.
Though some managed to fit in naps, they were not enough to restore good humor in the House.
As the morning wore on, members grew increasingly irritable. From time to time, they lost patience with their colleagues' speeches on things like the supplemental spending bill and broke into chants of "Vote! Vote! Vote!"
Nor were the substantive speeches calm, measured discussions, especially when the Republicans confronted the suddenly resurrected crime bill. Representative Lawrence Coughlin, Republican of Pennsylvania, said, "It is the most pro-criminal bill possible."
But despite his anger at the bill itself, Representative Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois, could have been speaking for the Congress and the whole issue when he declared, "We come here today in a spasm of spurious macho -- to prove to our constituents that we are not soft on crime."
 
An Ironclad Delay
 Congress never seems to lack reasons for delay, but it may have found a new one this morning.
The House wanted to take up the transportation conference report, but it needed the original copies of the House and Senate bills.
About 4 A.M., lawmakers and members of their staffs were panicking outside the House chamber, trying to figure out what they could do. "Do we know where they are?" one in the group asked.
They were locked in a safe on the Senate side. No one had the key.
It was close to 4:30 when the House agreed by unanimous consent to waive the rules and begin preliminary debate on the bill even though they did not have the original documents. Perhaps they were recalling the tradition that maintains that during the legislative blizzard of the first days of the New Deal, the House once passed a rolled-up newspaper instead of a bill.
It was close to 5 A.M. when Charles W. Johnson, the House deputy parliamentarian, said officials rousted from bed a clerk on the Senate Public Works Committee who rushed to the Capitol to retrieve the bills, saving the day -- and the transportation bill.
"The House and Senate never act," Mr. Johnson said, "unless the documented papers are before them."
 
Recess From Art
 Some orators spurned invective for verse.
But in the relentlessly competitive world of politics, even would-be poets try to outdo one another.
First came Representative Jim Bunning, a Kentucky Republican who doubtless will remain better known for pitching a perfect game for the Philadelphia Phillies against the New York Mets in 1964 than for his verse.
On Monday he recited his poem, "The Eve Before Recess," to the Ways and Means Committee:
 
 Twas the eve before recess
 And throughout the House
 All the members were restless,
 They all wanted out.
 The conferences all hung
 In the member's cold stare
 In hopes that sine die
 Soon would be there.
Not to be outdone, Senator William V. Roth Jr., a Delaware Republican, weighed in Tuesday on the Senate floor with his own version, " 'Twas the Night Before Recess":
 
 'Twas the night before recess and all through the land
 The economy was stagnant, employees were canned.
 The Congress was wrapped up all tight in its words;
 At home angry voices of voters were heard.
 While lobbyists with smiles and special interests with grins
 Went off to vacation to boast of their wins.
Joseph Brodsky, the poet laureate of the United States, has nothing to worry about. Though they get credit for trying, the consensus on Capitol Hill was that the works of Mr. Roth and Mr. Bunning did not scan or rhyme well.
 
Punctuating the Session
 Always vying to get the last word, Republicans and Democrats staged their end-of-session news conferences today to snare attention for themselves and to sell the Congressional line of how "productive" they were this year.
Today, Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington pronounced the last year as "a signally important and significant session of the Congress."
Representative Vin Weber, a Minnesota Republican, spun it another way: "This is not a Congress that many people should feel proud of," he said. "The Congress has sort of fallen into a pattern of working very hard and taking credit for the speed with which we spin our wheels."
 
Borough Will Tell
 Early this morning, in the marathon, 15-hour negotiations to put together a banking bill, Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat, popped into the room and began dining on Chinese takeout from boxes.
He disappeared and came back a few minutes later with a slice of pizza loaded with all sorts of toppings. His hearty appetite provoked more than a few snickers from many famished lawmakers, staff members and lobbyists.
But Mr. Schumer had a ready retort: "Hey, I'm from Brooklyn," he said between mouthfuls. "It's in my genes."
 
A Round of Planning?
 Not all lawmakers and their aides were concentrating on turgid legislative text before the sun rose over the Capitol this morning.
In the wood-trimmed offices of Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House Republican leader, and his staff could be found thumbing through catalogues, searching for holiday gift ideas during a break.
Mr. Michel was particularly interested in the gardening catalogues.
"He sat down and paged through one and said his usual, 'Hmm,' " an aide, Kerri Sattler, recalled. "He was interested in the kitchen compost, where you recycle your vegetable peels and egg shells."
His male aides went for the racier catalogues. The top choice: Victoria's Secret, a women's lingerie and sleepwear catalogue.

HEADLINE: After Senate Backs Bush and Blocks Anti-Crime Bill, Congress Goes Home

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
Congress went home today fighting over crime after House Democrats suddenly brought up and passed an anti-crime bill, and Senate Republicans just as promptly killed the politically charged measure with a filibuster threat.
The Senate action represented a victory for President Bush, who had faced an emboldened Democratic challenge on his handling of the economy and other social issues. Mr. Bush had asked that the anti-crime legislation include tougher restrictions on criminal appeals in Federal courts and looser restrictions against police searches and seizures of evidence, but his differences with Democrats on the issue had taken on broader political meaning. 
 The House worked past dawn as Democrats considered how to deal with Mr. Bush's dare that it stay in session to pass an economic growth package sponsored by Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip.
Democratic leaders had dropped the crime bill from the end-of-session agenda, at first sure that a coalition of liberals who disliked the death penalty and conservatives who agreed with Mr. Bush would kill it.
 
Action at 6 A.M.
 As late as midnight, Democratic leaders were privately saying they did not want to risk losing political capital by bringing up the bill for a vote that they figured would lose by from 6 to 25 votes.
But the delay over the economic package gave them time for an all-night lobbying effort that relied on appeals to party loyalty and arguments that the bill was, on balance, a strong measure.
About 6 A.M., they brought the bill up, still uncertain of victory but increasingly confident. With Speaker Thomas S. Foley watching carefully over any last-second switches, the Democrats passed the bill, 205 to 203.
Mr. Gingrich underlined the political link between the conflicts on taxes and crime during the pre-dawn debate on the floor when he attacked the Democratic position on the anti-crime bill. "The liberals in the House and Senate side," he said, "gathered together to perpetrate a hoax. The death penalty was written in such a way that it could never be used."
But Senate Democrats failed to follow up on the new aggressiveness displayed by their House colleagues, losing a vote to end debate on the bill and bring it to the floor for a vote. A 60-vote majority would have been required to avert a threatened filibuster, but Democrats could muster only a 49-to-38 vote. Three Democrats joined 35 Republicans in sinking the measure.
Representative Charles E. Schumer, the Brooklyn Democrat who was the main sponsor of the anti-crime package, said he and his fellow Democratic leaders had given up hope on the legislation because of the threat of a Presidential veto. Then late Tuesday night they noted an extreme exasperation among members at a party caucus. "The tax thing really got people upset," he said. "There was a feeling in the caucus that Bush is manipulating us."
Speaker Foley suddenly called swing members into his office, and even twisted arms on the floor during votes on less disputed measures to expand unemployment benefits, put conditions on the renewal of normal trade relations with China and set aside 8.2 million acres of desert as a nature preserve in Southern California.
In a spirit of party loyalty, about a dozen liberals suppressed their dismay over the anti-crime bill's expansion of the death penalty to more than 50 Federal crimes. Meanwhile, leaders persuaded a handful of conservative Democrats, who like the President had argued that the bill too easily granted habeas corpus appeals to death-row inmates, that the bill was tougher on criminals than current law. Some voted with the leaders; others simply cast no vote all.
 
Imparting a Positive Spin
 One hundred and ninety-nine Democrats and 6 Republicans voted for the bill, 53 Democrats, 149 Republicans and 1 independent voted against it. Those voting in favor of President's position included 149 Republicans and 53 Democrats.
The Congressional Democratic leadership, at a joint news conference this afternoon, tried to portray the ultimate death of the crime bill, along with various ethics scandals and the embarrassing hearings on the accusations of sexual harassment against Clarence Thomas, as irritating exceptions to an otherwise successful session.
Citing a sweeping transportation bill, protection of bank deposits, extension of unemployment benefits and passage of civil rights legislation, and the still incomplete campaign financing bills, Mr. Foley said, "We have a solid record of achievement."
He and Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader, promised that the Congress would work to pass an economic plan that includes provisions for a tax cut as well as health care legislation when members returned to work next year. Mr. Mitchell took a swipe at Mr. Bush's embrace of Mr. Gingrich's proposal, calling it more of the same "trickle down policy." He added, "By contrast, we Democrats think the American people have been trickled down long enough."
Senator Robert Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, attempted to end the session on a bipartisan note. Turning to his Democratic colleagues on the floor, he said, "I think we had a pretty good year." He concluded his remarks with the hope that "by December both parties can work together to work out the right economic growth package. We want to make certain that what we do in Congress will make a difference in the lives of Americans."
But in what appeared to be a pointed insult, the Democratic leaders decided not to make the traditional telephone call to the President saying they were completing their work and going home for recess.
Mr. Bush had angered Democrats by pledging to veto the anti-crime bill Monday, explaining in a letter to Representative Robert H. Michel, the House minority leader, that "for too long, the scales of justice have been tipped in favor of criminals instead of law-abiding Americans."
Democratic leaders said Mr. Foley thought about making a full-court press to defeat the President. But his vote counts Tuesday afternoon convinced him he did not have the votes to pass the bill. Then at the Tuesday night caucus, the anger over the threatened veto merged with anger over the President's challenge to the Democrats to quickly pass a tax cut.
"There was a real fighting spirit in the caucus," recalled Representative Bill Richardson, Democrat of New Mexico, "that charged up a lot of members to take on the President."
 
The Habeas Corpus Debate
 Another factor in passing the bill was the vigorous lobbying of Representative Jack Brooks, the influential chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, who persuaded a number of members in his Texas delegation to follow his lead.
Mr. Bush's supporters said he was upset that Democrats had detached a provision from the bill that would have given the police wider ability to obtain evidence without holding a court-granted search warrant.
The President's main objection to the bill was on its habeas corpus provisions. He contended the legislation would create loopholes for criminal defendants to needlessly appeal their cases in Federal courts, even when they had clearly received fair trials in lower courts. Mr. Bush preferred a Senate measure, abandoned in a Democratic-dominated conference committee over the weekend, that would have allowed Federal courts to dismiss appeals by ruling that defendants already received a fair hearing at the state level.
Democratic leaders said their version would have achieved the White House goal of averting endless delays in capital punishment cases by setting a one-year deadline on habeas corpus petitions and barring successive appeals. They accused Mr. Bush of opposing the bill to support the gun lobby, which strongly opposed a five-day waiting period on the purchase of handguns set forth in a provision called the Brady bill, named for James S. Brady, the press secretary to President Ronald Reagan who was wounded in the 1981 assassination attempt against Mr. Reagan.
 
Issues for '92
 President Bush had said he would support the Brady bill if it was included in a comprehensive anti-crime package that limited the rights of criminal defendants and expanded the latitude of law enforcement officers to search for evidence and arrest criminals.
House Democrats said they would consider introducing the Brady bill outside the crime package next year, and make crime and handgun control issues in the 1992 Presidential election.
Among the most controversial measures in the bill is the expansion of the death penalty to 52 Federal crimes, a provision that conservatives said did not go far enough but one that liberals said represented a deterioration of society's humanity.
More than 20 liberal and conservative Democrats decided to back the bill in the wee hours of the morning. "In the final analysis," said Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, "liberals realized that defeating the bill would destroy the chances for meaningful gun control. And more moderate members realized there was no substance to Bush's charges that this was not a strong crime bill."

HEADLINE: President's Proclamation

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Following is the text of President Bush's Thanksgiving Day proclamation.

The White House
 
By the President of the United States of America
 
A Proclamation 
 From the moment it was "conceived in liberty, and dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal," our nation has enjoyed the mercy and protection of Almighty God. Thus, when we join with family and friends on Thanksgiving, we celebrate not only the many blessings that we have received as individuals -- including the gift of life itself -- but also our great fortune as one nation under God. On this occasion, Americans of every race, creed and walk of life are united by a profound sense of gratitude and duty.
As we continue the Thanksgiving tradition, a tradition cherished by every generation of Americans, we reflect in a special way on the blessings of the past year. When this nation and its coalition partners took up arms in a last-resort effort to repel aggression in the Persian Gulf, we were spared the terrible consequences of a long and protracted struggle. Indeed, the millions of people who prayed for a quick end to the fighting saw those prayers answered with a swiftness and certainty that exceeded all expectations. During the past year, we have also witnessed the demise of communism and welcomed millions of courageous people into the community of free nations.
Of course, as we give thanks for these and other developments, we also remember the less fortunate -- those who do not yet share in the promise of freedom; those who do not know the comfort of peace and security; and those whose tables do not reflect the prosperity and plenty.
Time and again, Scripture describes our Creator's special love for the poor. As the Psalmist wrote, "He pours contempt upon princes. . .yet sets the poor on high from affliction." In this great nation, we have a special obligation to care for the ill and the destitute. Therefore, recalling that much will be asked of those to whom much has been given, let us resolve to make food drives and other forms of charity an increasingly important part of our Thanksgiving tradition.
On this occasion, as we count our blessings and reach out to help the less fortunate, we also do well to remember that, in many ways, the poorest nations are those who neither recognize nor revere what our founders called "the laws of nature and of nature's God." Indeed, we have seen totalitarian regimes impoverish entire peoples, not just economically, but spiritually, by denigrating religion and by denying the inherent dignity and worth of individuals. The moral bankruptcy of communism should remind every free nation of the dangers of cynicism and materialism.
Similarly, can any individual be truly rich or truly satisfied if he or she has not discovered the rewards of service to one's fellow man? Since most of us first experience the love of God through the goodness and generosity of others, what better gift could we give our children than a positive example?
Finally, as we gather with family and friends on Thanksgiving, we know that our greatest blessings are not necessarily material ones. Indeed, perhaps the best thing about this occasion is that it reminds us that God loves each and every one of us. Like a faithful and loving parent, He always stands ready to comfort, guide and forgive. That is our real cause for Thanksgiving, today and every day of our lives.
NOW THEREFORE, I, GEORGE BUSH, President of the United States of America, do hereby proclaim Thursday, Nov. 28, 1991, as a National Day of Thanksgiving. I urge all Americans to gather together in their homes and in places of worship on that day to offer thanks to Almighty God for the many blessings that He has bestowed upon us as individuals and as a nation.
IN WITNESS WHEREOF, I have here unto set my hand this 25th day of November, in the year of our Lord 1991, and of the Independence of the United States of America the 216th.
GEORGE BUSH

HEADLINE: A Lesson on AIDS Fight From Developing Nations

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
The nation's fight against AIDS could benefit from lessons learned in developing countries where condoms are vigorously promoted, with American help, on television and in drug stores, a Federal official says.
The official, Dr. Jeff Harris, director of the AIDS program for the United States Agency for International Development, said Monday that modern marketing techniques based on research had increased condom use substantially in countries where the heterosexual spread of AIDS posed a serious threat. 
 The lesson for the United States, he said at a news conference at the State Department, is "that we can increase condom use" with programs based on a thorough understanding of what would motivate sexually active adults to use condoms and practice other sexual acts considered safe.
 
'Portray Condoms Positively'
 The human immunodeficiency virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome is spread principally through sexual activity or the sharing of contaminated needles for the injection of drugs. Latex condoms have proved effective in decreasing the spread of AIDS through sexual intercourse.
Dr. Harris said efforts should be made in the United States to "portray condoms positively" and to work at a community or neighborhood level to promote their use.
While he said that research on sexual practices and attitudes was essential to accomplish these goals, Dr. Harris declined to comment about the Bush Administration's opposition to such research within the United States.
The National Institutes of Health has recommended that the Federal Government sponsor research among sexually active adults to learn how best to promote changes in sexual behavior to decrease the chances of contracting AIDS. But such research proposals have been turned down in the face of opposition from the White House and from some members of Congress.
Dr. Harris said programs of the Agency for International Development had promoted both sexual abstinence and safe sex practices. But abstinence, he admitted, has not been a widely accepted message and leaders of some countries recognize this.
 
Aiming at Specific Groups
 "In Uganda, the President and first lady say they would like a return to traditional values" of no sexual promiscuity, Dr. Harris said, "but they also recognize that condoms have a role." Condoms are widely promoted now in Uganda with advertising and distribution programs.
Television advertising, based on market research into how best to reach specific populations, has successfully promoted the use of condoms in such areas as Turkey, Ecuador, the Caribbean and south-central Africa. Dr. Harris said that in each area the program has to be based on a concept that make condoms acceptable.
For instance, he said, in Mexico, prostitutes were not insisting that their clients use condoms until a survey found that most of the prostitutes were also mothers. The campaign shifted to encourage condom use to protect the children.
A condom program in the Dominican Republic faltered until research showed that people did not know how to use the devices. Condoms became more accepted after a comic strip brochure was printed and counselors, in person-to-person interviews, began explaining how to use condoms.
Successful programs have borrowed sales techniques from consumer products, Dr. Harris said. "We market condoms like we would Coca-Cola," he said. This has included songs by major entertainers.

HIGH WIRE OVER THE DELAWARE
Since 1987, the Delaware River Water Commission and its member states -- New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware -- have thrashed their way toward tough new water-quality regulations, writing and rewriting terms and proposed policies and, in effect, trying to walk a high wire: maintaining first-rate water quality without choking development. HEADLINE: More Changes Are in Store At City Hall

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Two top-level city officials have informed Mayor David N. Dinkins that they plan to leave their posts early next year as the administration approaches the midpoint of Mr. Dinkins's term, senior administration officials say.
The two are the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, Sally Hernandez-Pinero, and the Sanitation Commissioner, Steven M. Polan. 
 Mr. Polan, conceding that he was frustrated by budget cuts, announced yesterday that he plans to resign in January when the city's financial plan is completed. He said he will become general counsel to the Fischbach Corporation, an electrical engineering and construction company, which holds contracts with city agencies.
Mr. Polan said that he knew of no contracts that Fischbach had signed with the Sanitation Department and that, in accordance with city ethics rules, he would not represent the company in its business with the city.
 
Series of Departures
 Deputy Mayor Hernandez-Pinero, a 38-year-old lawyer, has told the Mayor that she would like to shift to a less taxing post in city government because she needs to spend more time with her young children, according to senior administration officials who asked to remain anonymous.
Ms. Hernandez-Pinero would be the first Deputy Mayor to leave and would join a series of other Dinkins appointees who have departed this year. They include the city's Corporation Counsel, Victor A. Kovner; the press secretary, Albert Scardino; the labor relations commissioner, Eric J. Schmertz; the director of the Office on Homelessness and Single Room Occupancy, Nancy G. Wackstein; the Health Commissioner, Woodrew A. Myers, and J. Emilio Carrillo, the president of the Health and Hospitals Corporation.
Associates of the First Deputy Mayor, Norman Steisel, have said for some time that he is looking for work in the private sector, assertions that Mr. Steisel has shrugged off, saying that he has no plans to leave anytime soon.
 
Looking for Replacement
 If she departs, Ms. Hernandez-Pinero would leave as the administration's chief promoter of economic development even as the city struggles through one of the worst development crises in its history. After an initial period in which she was perceived by many in the business community to be weak and inexperienced, she gradually earned respect from many of those same critics.
Asked if Ms. Hernandez-Pinero had requested a different job, Mayor Dinkins said at a meeting with reporters yesterday: "When I am ready to make a personnel announcement involving Sally Hernandez-Pinero or any other official, I will let you know." She, too, said she had no plans to move.
Reports of her leaving the post first appeared in Newsday yesterday.
But Mr. Dinkins's aides said privately yesterday that the administration is looking for a replacement for the Deputy Mayor and is having serious discussions with New York business leaders.
 
A Sympathetic Ear
 Ms. Hernandez-Pinero's departure could raise an image problem for Mayor Dinkins because she is the only Hispanic member of the cabinet. Thus, some Dinkins aides said that she probably will not leave until Cesar Perales, New York State's Social Services Commissioner, assumes his role as the city's Deputy Mayor for Health and Human Services early next year.
While many business leaders have expressed frustration with the administration's response to the city's economic problems, Ronald K. Shelp, president and chief executive of the New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce, said that Ms. Hernandez-Pinero was viewed as a sympathetic ear in the administration and was credited with convincing Mayor Dinkins to limit tax increases in his latest financial plan.
Aides to Sanitation Commissioner Polan said yesterday that his resignation comes as little surprise given severe budget cutting at the Sanitation Department. Sanitation's budget dropped to $514 million in fiscal 1992 from $600 million in fiscal 1991, reducing recycling, street cleaning and dumping enforcement programs.
 
Frustrated by Budget Cuts
 Asked if budget cuts were a factor in his departure, Mr. Polan said yesterday: "I'm not going to pretend that budget cuts were not a source of frustration for this Administration and all the commissioners involved."
Environmental groups and the sanitation workers union praised Mr. Polan's work. John Ruston, an economic analyst for the Environmental Defense Fund, an advocacy group, said: "Recycling was a priority for him, but it became clear that he received either overt hostility or indifference from City Hall on the key issues he needed to make it work."
Perhaps the most controversial issue that Mr. Polan has faced in office is whether the city should build huge garbage-burning incinerators to dispose of trash as its remaining landfills reach capacity. In a speech in September on how to resolve New York City's refuse problem, Mr. Polan said that he favored expanding recycling and building incinerators.
 
Joining Former Boss
 That position brought the wrath of some environmentalist groups like the New York Public Interest Research Group, which issued a statement yesterday saying that it welcomed Mr. Polan's resignation and that it hoped Mayor Dinkins would impose a moratorium on incinerator development.
At Fischbach, Mr. Polan, former general counsel of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, will join his former boss, Robert R. Kiley, who resigned as M.T.A. chairman last November to become Fischbach's president and chief executive.
Mr. Polan declined to say how much he would be paid at Fischbach, but he said that it is expected to be considerably more than his current salary of $110,000 a year. "Let's just say they made me an offer I could not refuse," Mr. Polan said in a meeting with reporters.
Dinkins administration officials said yesterday that a successor has yet to be found.

HEADLINE: U. of Bridgeport Dismisses Law Dean

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 27

 BODY:
The dean of the University of Bridgeport School of Law was dismissed today, as the struggling university, nearly out of money, began fighting to block the law school's plans to affiliate with another institution.
But the dean, Terence H. Benbow, refused to accept the letter of termination held out to him by President Edwin G. Eigel, who had come to Mr. Benbow's office to dismiss him. And he refused to obey Mr. Eigel's order to leave. 
 The university summoned Bridgeport police officers. A crowd of law students gathered outside Mr. Benbow's office window. And once again, as has happened so many times this fall, television news trucks began pulling up next to the hot dog stands at the center of campus.
 
Waiting for Lawyers
 Then everyone waited for lawyers for the university and Mr. Benbow to arrive.
The tumult came only a day after Mr. Eigel announced to hundreds of undergraduate and graduate students that the university would no longer offer degrees in their academic subjects after spring semester, ending their careers at Bridgeport.
The cutback eliminated liberal arts degrees at the university, leaving it with business, engineering, fashion, industrial design and law. But on Monday the faculty of the law school voted to take its 700 students to Quinnipiac College in Hamden, in a deal negotiated by Dean Benbow.
Today the chairman of the university's trustees, Colin Gunn, said the trustees had voted to dismiss Mr. Benbow, saying he had breached his fiduciary responsibility to the university by trying to sell its law school without its permission. The trustees, Mr. Gunn said, were furious.
That, however, confused the students and professors who gathered outside Mr. Benbow's office today to cheer him on, crowding around the overgrown yews under his window and packing the hallway leading into the dean's suite.
 
Seek a New Partner
 The trustees had passed resolutions authorizing the dean to seek a new partner for the law school, if that was necessary to insure its survival as the university thrashed about for a solution to its own deepening financial crisis.
"They told him to do something, he went and did it," said Craig McLean, a first-year law student from Washington, D.C. "They told him don't let the law school die, so he acted to save it.
"The guy's got commitment," Mr. McLean continued, "but his commitment is to the law school, not to the transient leadership this place has had."
Mr. Eigel, the university's provost, has served as interim president since the Nov. 11 resignation of Janet Greenwood, who had been president since 1987. He would not comment on his action today, except to say he had discharged the dean with the full support of the trustees.
Mr. Benbow has publicly been at odds with the administration since September, when he and the law school faculty loudly opposed a proposal by the Professors World Peace Academy, an institute financed by the Unification Church, to affiliate with the University of Bridgeport.
 
'Public Relations Disaster'
 Mr. Benbow said he had warned trustees that even entertaining the proposal would be a "public relations disaster," because the Unification Church's reputation was that of a "brainwasher of students." He subsequently called for Dr. Greenwood's resignation.
Mr. Benbow said Mr. Eigel, in his letter, accused him of insubordination and failure to follow his directives.
At the end of the day, lawyers for Mr. Benbow and the university had worked out a temporary arrangement: As a tenured member of the law faculty, he would have access to his office and law books, and on Monday the trustees would meet with him and the law faculty.
The law school is a relatively recent addition to the University of Bridgeport, existing as the independent Wethersfield School of Law until 1977. On Tuesday, the trustees of Quinnipiac College voted to accept the law school's proposal to affiliate, if the law school first regained its independence.

HEADLINE: Hard Times Hit the Suburbs, Touching Affluent Addresses

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 27

 BODY:
This is a town of old money and new, bound together by country clubs, riding stables and costly water views in one of the wealthiest counties in the nation. But here in Greenwich, and in dozens of other towns across the metropolitan region, there are people who are having a hard time putting food on their tables.
They conceal it as best they can, as life in the suburbs often dictates. But left jobless by the recession, caught in the vise of their mortgages and with no more unemployment benefits available, thousands of men and women in the region who never sought assistance of any kind before are beginning to accept free turkeys, jars of peanut butter and boxes of spaghetti in an effort to make ends meet. 
 They are people like the woman from this town's tony back-country section, who showed up in tears earlier this week at the only food pantry in Greenwich. "She was obviously formerly affluent," said Betty Sheridan, a co-chairwoman of the program, called Neighbor to Neighbor, "and she hated to ask for help. But her husband had lost his job six months ago, and they were really in bad shape."
 
A Choice of Food or Clothing
 Directors of social-service agencies who oversee food programs in the New York area say they have experienced an increase in demand of at least 25 percent over last year. They are still feeding poor people who have long depended on them, but what is most remarkable, they say, is the appearance this year of large numbers of middle-class clients, who are finding themselves forced to choose between paying for housing or paying for food, and are further pressured by not wanting to admit that they are in financial trouble. These new clients range from clerical workers to company vice presidents and have have one thing in common: They have lost their jobs.
"We used to be able to just sweep it under the rug and say, it's those ne'er-do-wells on that end of town," said Audrey Triolo, director of the Food Bank of Lower Fairfield County, which collects and distributes food to various programs in Greenwich, Stamford, Norwalk, Darien and New Canaan. "But it's much more widespread now, and it's covering more people who used to be our donors.
"These are people who have paid their way all their lives and are now in difficult circumstances," she said. "They are not eligible for food stamps because they have a house or a car, and they're trying to hang on so they can hunt for work. They are at the end of their rope when they ask for free food."
 
'Helping Our Own'
 It is a shift that has devastating implications for the rest of society: People are being forced to redefine themselves as receivers rather than givers as their hope runs out. Instead of taking canned goods to church on Sundays for the anonymous lessfortunate, they are lining up for programs housed in churches in the middle of the week to collect bags of groceries to feed their own families.
"In this recession, we're really turning and helping our own congregants," said Rabbi Robert B. Lennick of the Greenwich Reform Synagogue. "In a community like Greenwich, people are less likely to admit that they are in trouble. It's in part a matter of appearances, and it's also a matter of pride."
As the demand mounts, corporations that once poured thousands of dollars into local programs are cutting back, if not leaving the area altogether to try to control their own costs. One Thanksgiving program in East Orange, N.J., had long counted on getting 150 turkeys from one corporation, the American International Adjustment Company. But the company moved away this year, "and now we have to scavenge for turkeys," said Connie Crawford, executive director of the East Orange Community Development Corporation.
In Manhattan, the Food and Hunger Hotline, founded in 1980, announced this week that it would be closing down because financing had dried up. Because of government cuts "we're all competing for the same private money," said Ellyn Rosenthal, the program's exective director. "We can't do it anymore," she said.
Cutbacks amid the recession have affected large donors and small ones. Many grocery chains that once gave their dented cans of food to charity now send them to reclamation centers, to recoup the cost of the can, Mrs. Triolo said.
"We're getting less donated to us, from half a million pounds of food last year to only 365,000 this year," she said. "When you've got hard economic times, that's also when the need in the community increases, so it's a serious mismatch."
Long Island Cares, a food bank based in West Brentwood, has already distributed twice as much food this year as last year. Its executive director, Catherine Bern, said: "Hunger's not supposed to happen in suburbia. But it certainly does."
Ms. Bern told of a mother who did not send her child to school one day recently, because she had nothing to give him for lunch, and of others who could not buy formula for their babies because their husbands had been laid off months ago.
Looking past the holiday season, several experts said they expected the situation to get worse. A recent study found that 67 percent of the people who use food pantries or soup kitchens in the Stamford area suffer from chronic hunger, with another 19 percent at potential risk for the same problem.
"It's just not working out for people," said Sheila Y. Oliver, director of the Essex County Division of Community Action in New Jersey. Utility companies, she said, "are already experiencing nonpayment of utility bills by customers who have good payment records. We're seeing people turn to us for that kind of help, middle-class and professional people in many instances, people we never saw here before. Many of the people who seek emergency assistance from us tell us they are one paycheck away from poverty."
This new clientele grew up thinking they were supposed to take care of the people below them, said social service administrators. Now many of them seem to feel that they need taking care of just as much.
"These are people who are not used to being on the receiving end, whose whole sense of who they are is that they are the people who make decisions, who do the giving, who help run the world," said Janet Evans, director of Person to Person, a community-service organization based at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien. "It's an enormous leap, psychologically."
