HEADLINE: D'Amato Wins in Effort For Charities

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
As lawmakers struggled against exhaustion just before dawn this morning to piece together a bank bailout bill, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato asked colleagues for a small favor.
The New York Republican said he needed $6 million to help charitable groups that lost hundreds of thousands of dollars when two small New York City banks collapsed. It wasn't much, he said. And the recipients were worthy. A nursing home. The United Negro College Fund. 
 When the lawmakers had finally fashioned a compromise, Mr. D'Amato got his money. And while $6 million is a minuscule sum in a $95 billion piece of legislation, the decision to provide the money is fraught with symbolism. For most of that money would go to depositors of the Freedom National Bank of Harlem, a black-owned emblem of the economic struggles of America's pre-eminent black neighborhood.
The money writes what may well be the final chapter in a neighborhood dream of economic independence and the forces that combined to crush those aspirations. But the legislative maneuvering that won the $6 million, which includes $1 million for depositors at the Community National Bank of Staten Island, provides an unusual glimpse into the favor-trading and curious alliances forged by politicians running scared in the face of tough re-election campaigns and tough economic times.
 
Political Odd Couples
 The decision created such political odd couples as Senator D'Amato, a conservative Republican from Long Island, and Representative Charles B. Rangel, a liberal Democrat from Harlem. On most issues, one is the opposite of the other.
Other unlikely allies in the cause were Representative John J. LaFalce, an upstate New York Democrat who represents the district around Niagara Falls that sent Barry Goldwater's Presidential running mate, William Miller, to Washington; Representative Edolphus Towns, a Brooklyn Democrat and former teacher, social worker and hospital administrator, and Representative Charles E. Schumer, also a Brooklyn Democrat, and a Congressional powerhouse who could face a difficult election challenge because of redistricting.
But the $6 million amendment also shows Senator D'Amato's dedication to what supporters call constituent services and critics see as parochial pandering. Five years after he sought to win national recognition as a spokesman for conservative causes, and still bruised by a Senate ethics investigation that ended with no charges being filed, he is preparing for what certainly will be his toughest election campaign in a decade by returning to his roots as a local politician fighting before a national audience.
The strategy reaps headlines for the Senator. This week, for instance, his work in securing millions of dollars in increased Federal aid for mass transit, with New York as a prime beneficiary, was trumpeted around the state. At times it seemed to overshadow the accomplishments of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the Democrat widely seen as the mastermind of the transportation bill, which reverses 35 years of Federal transit priorities.
But as Mr. D'Amato prepares to declare his candidacy for a third term, his strength has also become his Achilles heel. The ethics investigation, in which he was accused of misusing his poffice on behalf of constituents, raised questions about whether constituent service sometimes crossed a line into cronyism or worse. And the New York fiscal crisis has led to fresh evaluations about his success in bringing home the Federal bacon. Critics say he must shoulder some of the blame for the fiasco since he was a key supporter of the Reagan Administration budget cuts, which cost the city billions and helped aggravate its problems.
The failure last year of the Freedom National Bank is in part an outgrowth of the policies the Senator supported, a cautionary tale of an incautious era. Most of the loans that bankrupted the bank were made between 1985 and 1987.
After years of growing loan defaults, Federal agents last fall strode into the bank, plastered the automatic teller machine with masking tape and padlocked Freedom's doors. It was an ignominious end for the bank that had been opened by Jackie Robinson and civil rights leaders who had been unable to obtain financing at white-run institutions.
 
Yearlong Political Battle
 The closing was also the opening of a yearlong political battle. When regulators marched into the 125th Street headquarters, charitable institutions lost all deposits in excess of $100,000.
The organizations pleaded with regulators and earlier this year were told they would be refunded 50 cents on each $1 in deposits over $100,000.
Senator D'Amato and Representative Rangel introduced legislation in the Senate and House to refund the money. The House bill stalled, while the Senate approved Mr. D'Amato's amendment as an addendum to a bill to provide $70 million for a nearly bankrupt Federal insurance fund.
The horse trading started at 5 P.M. Monday as legislators met in a conference committee. In the rush to adjourn for the year, House conferees offered their bill to their Senate counterparts. "The House came with a narrow bill," one staff member recalled. "We countered. They offered again. We countered again."
Progress was slow. Frustrated House Democrats began to consider adjourning and coming back to finish the banking bill and other items after Thanksgiving. But that unappetizing prospect paved the way for compromises. At 3:30 this morning, with conferees exhausted and their staffs collapsing, Senator D'Amato offered his amendment to the House.
"It was pretty touching," said Laura Unger, an aide to the Senator. "He made a really moving speech. It was compelling. These were charitable organizations. He said we have to protect people who have fallen through the safety net."
Representative Schumer supported the Senator, she said. So did Representative LaFalce. But Representative Doug Bereuter of Nebraska was opposed. He said some depositors in his district had lost money in a similar situation and had not been refunded. It was, he said, pork.
The debate lasted 10 minutes, or $600,000 a minute. The amendment was accepted by voice vote. By then conferees were so exhausted few can recall if the decision was unanimous.
This morning Senator D'Amato's office issued a press release trumpeting his success on behalf of the banks. But a clerical error almost cost him his victory. The staff forgot to include the amendment in the bill when it was retyped and brought to the floor.
The Senator had little trouble correcting the mistake in the Senate. But in the House, the process stalled, apparently because of rivalry among members seeking credit. But in its final decision before adjournment, the House also corrected the mistake.
"This was an emotional roller coaster, from ecstasy to agony to defeat and then, finally, gratefulness," an exhausted Senator D'Amato said.

HEADLINE: 4-State Commission Moves to Preserve the High Water Quality of the Upper Delaware River

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 26

 BODY:
The upper 121 miles of the Delaware River, the playground of hundreds of thousands of canoeists, hikers, swimmers and anglers, runs clean and clear. Some call it pristine.
Not quite, the experts say, because man has intruded. Still, they quickly add, the upper Delaware's water quality ranks among the highest in the East. And that's the way they want to keep it. 
 The chore of maintaining the water quality has fallen to the Delaware River Basin Commission, a four-state agency created by Congress in 1961 to regulate water use and quality and flood control in a sprawling 13,000-square-mile region surrounding the river and Delaware Bay. Since 1987, the commission's staff and its member states -- New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware -- have thrashed their way toward tough new water-quality regulations, writing and rewriting terms and proposed policies and, in effect, trying to walk a high wire: maintaining first-rate water quality without choking off development in the basin.
 
Maintaining Quality
 The undertaking is rare for two reasons, the commission says. Few states have worked together to maintain the high quality of a common body of water. And, officials say, the effort is one of the first in the country to create a new anti-degradation policy pegged to existing high quality levels.
Usually, the officials said, if socioeconomic need is shown, high-quality rivers and lakes are allowed to degrade slowly until they reach the standards written to protect swimming and fishing. But the quality of the upper Delaware is 30 to 70 percent higher than the fishing and swimming standards, and the new regulations would prohibit any backsliding.
For instance, in the summer the upper Delaware's dissolved oxygen levels, vital to the health of fish and other aquatic life, average between 8 and 9 milligrams per liter of water. Officials want to retain that quality, though a level of 4 to 5 would be allowable under the Federal Clean Water Act.
A similar situation prevails for such other common pollutants as fecal coliform bacteria and phosphorous and nitrogen, two nutrients that come from treated effluent from sewage plants and storm runoff from farmland, streets, parking lots and building sites.
The new regulations would mean tighter restrictions on sewage treatment plants, possibly including more disposal of effluent on land, and finding ways to control "nonpoint" pollution, or storm runoff, which generally accounts for 65 percent of river pollution, officials said.
 
War of Words
 After four years of preliminary work, the commission hopes to conduct public hearings on the proposed regulations in January. Then the scholarly technical discussion in the commission's Water Quality Advisory Committee, which is helping draft the plan, will no doubt give way to a public war of words, with environmentalists demanding something tougher and developers seeking something weaker.
Each member state is represented on the advisory committee, along with the commission's technical experts and officials from the Federal Environmental Agency and the National Park Service, which has two parks in the area and owns much of the river bank and nearby land.
To the uninitiated, the committee's monthly debates at times seem arcane, filled with the jargon of science and engineering.
"There's a lot of semantical dancing on the head of a pin here," said Mary Ellen Noble, head of the Watershed Association of the Delaware River, an environmental group.
The association has been a major factor in the regulatory process. At first, the idea was to preserve water quality in the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area, which surrounds the southern third of the 121-mile stretch. Two years ago, the association asked that the commission add the river's northernmost 80 miles, ban new or increased discharges in the 121-mile area and create stricter controls on nonpoint pollution.
"That created pandemonium," Ms. Noble said. "None of the states could grapple with that."
The request for no new discharges led to a discussion on whether the new policy would require "nondegradation" -- no additional discharges -- or "anti-degradation" -- some new discharges from developments that are considered socially and economically justified.
The committee opted for an anti-degradation definition and an expanded monitoring system that it said would assure "no measurable change" in water quality. It also decided to extend quality rules to the mouths of tributaries. The one major unresolved issue -- curbing nonpoint pollution -- became a hot potato at today's meeting. Pennsylvania's delegate, Ed Brezina, called for tougher regulations for nonpoint pollution.
"That's a wrinkle that has to be smoothed out," said New York's representative, Al Bromberg.
The head of the commission's planning branch, David Pollison, suggested that the states take the lead on a policy to curb pollution from runoff. "We don't have one," Mr. Pollison said. "You go ahead. We'll define one and delegate it to you."
In the end, the issue was put over until December's meeting.
Curbing nonpoint pollution is a problem, officials said after the meeting. "Everybody's grappling for a solution," said Richard Albert, the commission's supervising engineer. "Nonpoint sources are tricky because the state of the art is not as advanced as waste-water treatment. And you get to some extent into land-use control, and land use is seriously guarded by local government."

HEADLINE: PARKCHESTER JOURNAL;
Risk Lures Teen-Agers To 'Surf' on the Subways

 BODY:
WEARING a purple baseball cap and a cocky smile, Elliott Ortiz stood between two cars on the No. 6 train as it rumbled over tracks 30 feet above the Parkchester section of the Bronx. He paused for a second, waiting for the wiggling 400-ton train to pick up speed. Then he hoisted himself to the roof and disappeared.
In less than a minute -- enough time, he said, for a windblown handstand -- he dropped down again, this time, one car closer to the train's front. Three passengers jolted to their feet in surprise, but he looked as nonchalant as if he had done nothing more unusual than offer up his seat. 
 At 22 years old, Mr. Ortiz is an old-timer at the dangerous stunt that he and other young people perform on the roofs of trains across the city, particularly along the elevated tracks in the Bronx.
It is called "surfing," or "hang on," and the transit authorities say it is the most perilous of the many games that threaten and occasionally kill young people, mostly teen-agers, on New York City's subways.
The risk is the lure. Mr. Ortiz, who is unemployed , said the danger was a test of himself and his place in his tough neighborhood, Clason's Point in the Bronx.
"I've got to learn not to be afraid of nothing; rats, cockroaches, a gang from one block to the other," he said. "It's like those people that do movies, they do it. It's like you are escaping from hell."
The stunt, like its cousin elevator surfing, is nothing new, but transit officials say it recently appears to be more popular. There are no numbers to back that up, though.
"Like anything else, things get trendy, unfortunately," said Bob Previdi, a Transit Authority spokesman. "This is certainly a dangerous thing to be trying."
Especially on a elevated line, said Al O'Leary, a spokesman for the transit police. "It's so incredibly dangerous it boggles the mind," he said.
Over the last decade, two deaths have been attributed to subway surfing. In 1980, a young man riding atop a J train was killed after he hit a girder on the Williamsburg Bridge. And in 1989, a 14-year-old riding on a train in the South Bronx was struck in the head by a beam.
Subway conductors, drivers, police officers and rescue workers say that just the sight of a teen-ager lying atop a speeding train -- in some cases standing, as if riding a surf board -- is horrifying.
"It's the kids, they pick dangerous ways to have fun," said one frustrated conductor.
More than a dozen teen-agers in northern Manhattan and the Bronx said in recent interviews that they had either seen someone ride on the top of subway cars or knew friends who did. They said people did it, occasionally even in tunnels, for thrills or to show their bravery.
"They get bored on the regular cars so they climb on top," said Julio Diaz, a 15-year-old student at Walton High School in the Bronx. "They do it just to show off. It don't make no sense. What if you fall?"
Joseph Araujo, a 17-year-old senior at Harry S. Truman High School in the Bronx, said that he and a few friends used to surf nearly every day two years ago, either on the No. 2 or No. 5 lines in the Bronx, or on the No. 1 train between Dyckman Street in Manhattan and 225th Street in the Bronx.
"It's mostly like a dare to see who is who, what you can do," he said. "Some people just do it to see how far they can go -- how close they can get to death without really dying."
He compared surfing to proving yourself on the street, where being tough and fearless is often more important than safety.
"Sometimes it's scary but after a while it just seems funny," he said. "That's what the street is all about."
Mr. Ortiz, who was surfing at the St. Lawrence stop in the Bronx, said he did it about four times a week, often with a group of four other youths, none older than 14, who call themselves "The Train Brothers." Aside from handstands, he said, he jumps from car to car and has even done forward flips.
The question of why he does it brings a tangle of answers. Raised in Minneapolis, he said that he always wanted to be a professional speed skater but that his family could not afford the training.
So he now wants to be a professional stunt man, he said, and he surfs from the Bronx to Rockaway with the hope he will become famous like his hero Chuck Norris.
Mr. Ortiz, who said he usually sneaks into the subway, has no plans to stop surfing unless he gets hurt or meets a woman who wants to marry him and begs him "to cut it out."
But Mr. Araujo stopped, and for a reason he does not like to talk about: The 14-year-old killed surfing in the Bronx two years ago was his friend.
"It was scary," he said. "If you've never done it, I'd advise you not to because you are going to get hurt."

HEADLINE: Remembering the Neediest in a Difficult Time

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
Last year at this time Alberto R.'s biggest worry was Christmas presents. Then he lost his job. Then came a winter without new coats for his wife and three children, macaroni in place of meat, months of a futile search for work and then -- inevitably, it seemed -- an eviction notice.
At his lowest moment he silently pleaded, "All I want is a hand to bring me up." He was desperate enough to try anything, the 44-year-old Manhattan resident recalled last week. "Anything to keep my home, anything to stay off welfare." 
 As the recession in the New York region drags on and deepens, tens of thousands of working-class families have found themselves on the brink of poverty.
For Alberto R. and many others, economic security vanished as suddenly as a pink slip. Others had been waging a paycheck-to-paycheck battle for survival that ended in an unexpected illness or the limit of a landlord's patience.
For officials at the charities they are turning to in record numbers, this flood of what one official calls "the new poor" comes on top of the vast problems of the chronically needy, and at a time when, they say, many New Yorkers have either become inured to the suffering around them or are too pinched themselves to give.
"People feel more vulnerable, more apprehensive, -- let's face it, more frightened -- than at any time I can remember," said Philip Coltolf, executive director of the Children's Aid Society. "It's as bad as it's been and the bottom isn't in sight yet.
"If it's a recession when someone you know loses a job and a depression when you lose your job," he said, "then for many New Yorkers, this is a depression."
 
Signs of the Times
 These are among the new signs of hard times reported by the seven charities affiliated with The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which begins its 80th appeal on Sunday:
*Requests to the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York for emergency rent relief are 10 times last year's, up to 1,000 a week this year.
*Requests for food packages at Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service's main office are running at triple the level of last year.
*The demand for clothing, especially jackets and ties for job interviews, has risen so greatly much at the Harlem Men's Shelter that volunteers from the Community Service Society of New York have called on manufacturers to supplement individual donations.
*Counseling provided by Catholic Charities in the Brooklyn Archdiocese is up by 50 percent from last year, primarily for problems related to the loss of jobs. The problems range from substance abuse to depression.
 
'Staring at Homelessness'
 Rescue for Alberto R. began with a call by his wife to the Community Service Society of New York. The society helped him obtain a one-shot rent relief check from a city bureaucracy that had previously turned him away and gave him $508 for food and clothing from its own funds.
"Me and my family were staring at homelessness," said Alberto R. last week on a break from his new job as an electronics-store salesman. "But their help pulled me through, let me keep my dignity until I found a job. Christmas is going to be happy again in my home."
Until August, Pegeen Nieves had a full-time job -- but a razor-thin margin of safety. "After I paid my rent and utilities and fed my three kids, I had $67 left over every month," she recalled.
Then the 26-year-old single mother had to take a leave of absence because of a difficult pregnancy. With no savings and no family to lean on, she wondered how she would support her family as she lay on the pull-out bed in her two-room Brooklyn apartment.
She miscarried in September.
"The doctor let me go back to work part time," she said, "but I was only taking home $800 a month, but the rent was $550 and the baby sitter was $720."
October brought an eviction notice from her landlord and a shut-off notice from Brooklyn Union Gas. It also brought assistance from Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn. "The day I called they gave me food and two weeks later $150 to pay my gas and electric," she said. "They gave me some breathing room so I could get money to pay my rent when I started working full-time again in November. If it hadn't been for them I don't know where I'd be."
 
'The New Poor'
 Stephen D. Solender, executive vice president of the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, calls people like Ms. Nieves and Alberto R. "the new poor." They are, he said, "casualties of the recession who need assistance for the first time in their life."
The struggle to avoid the abyss of poverty involves stark choices for families. "Adequate clothing is the first thing they do without, not getting the children the winter coat they need or wearing the shoes with thin soles another winter," said David Jones, executive director of the Community Service Society of New York.
For the charities serving them, the added pressures of the recession are forcing another kind of triage. The agencies were already pressed as city and state funds for foster care, job training, work with AIDS, drug abuse and teen-age pregnancy were shrinking.
Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese, for instance, has been dipping into its reserves for the last five years to subsidize its programs. But faced with a $2.9 million deficit, the organization has been forced to close three of its centers and to stop its homemaker programs, which had helped young mothers and newly housed homeless people learn how to take care of their homes and their families.
 
'A Vital Lifeline'
 Msgr. Timothy McDonnell, the chief operating officer of Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese, said the many strains that his agency is under place a greater emphasis on the need for individual donations like those made to the Neediest Cases.
"At a time when more people are falling into need and less public resources are available, revenue sources like The New York Times Neediest Cases becomes even more of a vital lifeline," he said.
Last year the fund raised a record total of $4,439,093.47. Although the average size of the donations was smaller than in the previous year, more people gave -- at least 15,580 individuals and organizations. The New York Times pays for the campaign's overhead, giving the contributions directly to the seven not-for-profit agencies, which use the money for direct services.
Mr. Solender of the Jewish Federation said the charities recognize that many potential contributors may be feeling vulnerable themselves this year. Others may feel that no help can revive a city that seems sicker each day, but he said that is not the case.
"We are rescuing people each day!" he said. "It's crucial now that we provide the resources to people on the front lines who are helping them become self-sufficient while we still have that chance."
 
Persian Gulf Veteran
 And there is Louis Garcia, 33, a veteran of the Persian Gulf war who entered the Catholic Charities' Bronx office earlier this month. He lost his family, job and home while defending his country.
He returned from Army Reserve service in the gulf region on Sept. 20 and was discharged from active duty, but the security company where he had worked was out of business. His wife, who abuses drugs and alcohol, had been evicted from their apartment for nonpayment of rent and handed over care of their 4-year-old daughter to his mother. He had no savings and was told that he would to have to wait 30 days before he could apply for unemployment benefits.
He began sleeping on the floor of his mother's one-room apartment, but the landlord told him he would evict the family if he did not leave. He slept two nights on the streets before, wheezing and coughing, he turned to the Catholic Charities.
Corrine Malavase, a social service assistant in the Belmont Avenue office, helped him find an apartment and on Nov. 21 provided him with $500 for the first month's rent and $60 more for food.
"He now has pneumonia," she said. "We expect he will need more help and when he does, we'll be there for him."

HEADLINE: Fearful Consumers Cut Back Plans for Gifts

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
To save money, Rocky Nelson of Lincoln, Neb., plans to make most of her Christmas presents by hand this year, and she is giving each of her two married children a certificate redeemable for a night of free baby-sitting.
"It used to be 1,001 presents under the tree," she said. "This year, Christmas is going to be a little skimpy present-wise." 
 The sputtering economy has forced Mrs. Nelson, like many Americans, to curtail her Christmas spending plans this year. "I'm a big Christmas person, but I really have to learn to hold it down because I can't afford to spend what I have in the past," she said.
Although Mrs. Nelson and her husband both have jobs, they lost their home last year, after a real estate investment went bad and they filed for bankruptcy. "We're starting over," she said. "It's kind of scary."
Mrs. Nelson was first interviewed for a New York Times/CBS News poll, and she answered additional questions in a second interview.
With the vitally important Christmas shopping season starting today, frightened consumers are creating anxiety among retailers.
A number of recent consumer surveys have shown that consumers plan to spend less for presents this year than they did last year. A recent New York Times/CBS News poll found that 46 percent of the people surveyed planned to spend less on gifts this holiday season than in recent years. Only 12 percent of the people surveyed said they planned to spend more this year. The poll found a strong preference for buying clothing and educational gifts for children instead of toys and video games.
The nationwide telephone poll of 1,106 adults was conducted from Nov. 18 to Nov. 22, and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
The Conference Board, a business research group, is releasing its own survey results today that found that the average American household is expected to spend about $375 for gifts this year. The Conference Board said Christmas sales were likely to be down by as much as 3 percent this year.
In contrast, many retailers and retailing industry analysts are predicting that Christmas sales will increase about 4 percent this year. But Fabian Linden, executive director of the Conference Board's Consumer Research Center, called such projections "a fantasy."
Mr. Linden estimated that holiday spending would total $36 billion this year.
Other surveys had a similar grim message for retailers. Leo J. Shapiro & Associates, a Chicago market research firm, said 53 percent of consumers recently polled planned to spend less this Christmas than last.
 
Damage of Unemployment
 Analysts say concerns over job security are putting a damper on consumer spending. Mr. Linden said nearly 20 percent of the nation's households had at least one family member who was unemployed in the last 12 months. "When you are out of work, you are damaged financially and psychologically for quite a while," he said.
For instance, Toni Nobles, a 34-year-old single mother of two in Bakersfield, Calif., has been unemployed for a year. "I'm not as optimistic as I once was," she said. Unable to find a job as a telephone operator, she is now on welfare. She said she would buy a few Christmas presents for her children this year. "They want specific things," she said, including Ninja Turtles figures and toy guns and trucks. She was first reached for The Times/CBS poll and answered additional questions in a second interview.
Many consumers simply have less money or higher expenses. "It's not just that people have a preference for spending less on Christmas," said Philip Johnson, president of Leo J. Shapiro. "They have to spend less because they are feeling really pinched."
"People are feeling economic pressure," he added. "That's why this thing won't go away."
Another damper, in addition to the bad economy, is that the Christmas selling season has six fewer days this year than last. Between Thanksgiving and Christmas, there are 26 shopping days, this year, down from 32 last year.
Still, not all consumers are saving string. Colette Knowles, a 25-year-old engineer in Racine, Wis., said she and her husband recently bought a new house and were busy furnishing it. "We are in a spending mood," she said.
She recently got a raise and said the couple planned to replace one of their two cars next year. They recently bought a stereo system, a dining room set and draperies. Like the others, Mrs. Knowles was first interviewed for the poll and answered additional questions in a second interview.
But all is not rosy for the couple. She said her husband could not find a job matching his qualifications, and has been working the night shift at a factory repairing machinery. It took him six months to find the job.
Even people like the seemingly free-spending Knowles will not provide that much solace to retailers. Mrs. Knowles said she and her husband were going out of their way to look for bargains. "We're buying a lot of stuff, but we are looking for a deal," she said. "We don't buy anything that's not on sale."
